question_text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of progressive weakness of his lower extremities and urinary incontinence for the past 3 weeks. Over the past 2 months, he has also had increasing back pain. Physical examination shows an unsteady gait. Muscle strength is decreased in both lower extremities. Sensation to pain, temperature, and position sense is absent in the buttocks, perineum, and lower extremities. Ankle clonus is present. An x-ray of the spine shows multiple sclerotic lesions in the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of progressive weakness of his lower extremities and urinary incontinence for the past 3 weeks. Over the past 2 months, he has also had increasing back pain. Physical examination shows an unsteady gait. Muscle strength is decreased in both lower extremities. Sensation to pain, temperature, and position sense is absent in the buttocks, perineum, and lower extremities. Ankle clonus is present. An x-ray of the spine shows multiple sclerotic lesions in the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The presence of back pain, urinary incontinence, muscle weakness, and decreased sensation in the lower extremities is consistent with spinal cord compression. Multiple sclerotic lesions on x-ray suggest osteoblastic metastases.
learning_objective: Recognize osteoblastic vertebral metastases, and recall the diagnostic finding of the most likely underlying primary cancer.

answers.content: Elevated prostate-specific antigen in the serum
answers.explanation_why: Elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels are typically found in patients with prostate cancer but can also be seen in benign prostatic hyperplasia and prostatitis. This patient's age, as well as his clinical and radiological findings, which strongly suggest spinal cord compression due to metastatic lesions of the vertebrae, indicate metastatic prostate cancer. Prostate cancer is one of the most common cancers and also the most common cause of bone metastases in men. It mostly affects older men (average age of onset is 66 years of age).

answers.content: Palpable thyroid nodule on neck examination
answers.explanation_why: A palpable thyroid nodule would be concerning for thyroid cancer. Although thyroid cancer can also metastasize to the bone, it typically manifests with osteolytic lesions rather than the osteoblastic ones seen in this patient.

answers.content: Bence Jones protein in the urine
answers.explanation_why: Bence Jones protein in the urine would be suggestive of multiple myeloma, which can also cause spinal cord compression, as seen in this patient. However, multiple myeloma typically causes osteolytic lesions rather than osteoblastic ones. Additionally, a patient with multiple myeloma would most likely present with other clinical features such as anemia, increased susceptibility to infections, and/or hypercalcemia.

answers.content: Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen in the serum
answers.explanation_why: An elevated carcinoembryonic antigen can be seen in several different cancers but is especially associated with pancreatic cancer and colon cancer. Although colon cancer can metastasize to the bones and present with osteoblastic metastases, this is not a frequent finding (seen in only 5–10% of cases of advanced colorectal cancer). Instead, the liver and lungs are the most common sites of metastases for both pancreatic and colorectal carcinoma. The absence of typical symptoms associated with colorectal cancer, such as a change in bowel habits, melena or hematochezia, signs of anemia, and/or weight loss, also makes colon cancer less likely.

answers.content: Irregular, asymmetric mole on skin examination
answers.explanation_why: An irregular, asymmetric mole would be concerning for malignant melanoma. Although malignant melanoma may also rarely manifest with bone metastases, this disease typically causes osteolytic lesions rather than the osteoblastic ones seen in this patient.

question_text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting for 30 minutes. Forty-five minutes ago, he fell and struck his head, resulting in loss of consciousness for 1 minute. After regaining consciousness, he felt well for 15 minutes before the headache began. On arrival, the patient becomes rigid and his eyes deviate to the right; he is incontinent of urine. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and the rigidity resolves. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting for 30 minutes. Forty-five minutes ago, he fell and struck his head, resulting in loss of consciousness for 1 minute. After regaining consciousness, he felt well for 15 minutes before the headache began. On arrival, the patient becomes rigid and his eyes deviate to the right; he is incontinent of urine. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and the rigidity resolves. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?
hint: After sustaining a head injury and briefly losing consciousness, the patient experienced a brief asymptomatic period (a lucid interval), followed by signs and symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure (headache, nausea, vomiting, and seizure).
learning_objective: Recognize an epidural hematoma.

answers.explanation_why: Intracerebral hemorrhage typically results from a spontaneous (i.e., nontraumatic) rupture of vessels secondary to structural changes of the vessel walls, e.g., in chronic hypertension or cerebral amyloid angiopathy. Patients present with headache and focal neurologic deficits such as hemiparesis. Rarely, it is caused by a head trauma with direct damage of the vessel. Signs of increased ICP and a lucid interval are more suggestive of another diagnosis.

images.title: Intracerebral hematoma
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)A large hyperdense hematoma (green overlay) in the posterior aspect of the left cerebral hemisphere is accompanied by hypodense edema (red overlay), effacement of the occipital horn of the left lateral ventricle, and midline shift (dashed line and arrowheads).ROH: right occipital horn

answers.explanation_why: A mismatch between production and absorption of CSF is the cause of idiopathic intracranial hypertension, which usually presents with chronic headaches and visual symptoms (e.g., transient loss of vision) that worsen over months to years. It is not associated with head trauma.

images.title: Optic disc edema
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeLeft image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

answers.explanation_why: Rupture of bridging veins causes subdural hematoma (SDH). The onset of symptoms in patients with subdural hematoma depends on the size, location, and rate of growth of the SDH. In acute-onset SDH, the patient can also present with headache and signs of increased ICP immediately following head trauma. In rare cases, patients may also experience a lucid interval. However, the temporary recovery of consciousness is more commonly associated with a different diagnosis.

images.title: Subdural hematoma and cerebral edema
images.description: CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window) of a patient with a history of traumaA large acute subdural hematoma is visible as a hyperdense crescent-shaped lesion along the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere (red overlay). It is accompanied by an extracranial soft tissue hematoma (hatched red overlay). There is extensive hypodense left cerebral edema (gray overlay), with sulcal effacement and shift of midline structures (green line) to the right. The anterior horns of the lateral ventricles (hatched green overlay) are compressed and the posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle (red circle) is dilated.

answers.content: Acute insufficiency of cerebral blood flow
answers.explanation_why: Acute insufficiency of cerebral blood flow causes an ischemic stroke, the symptoms of which depend on the affected area of the brain. Patients typically have risk factors such as diabetes or hypercholesterolemia and present with focal neurological deficits like hemiparesis, none of which applies to this patient. In addition, seizures, elevated ICP, and traumatic etiology are all unusual findings for ischemic stroke.
answers.explanation_but: In malignant middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction, the most devastating form of acute stroke, complete occlusion leads to acute brain edema and elevated ICP, which may cause herniation of the brain, usually over a course of 1–5 days. Although this condition cannot be entirely ruled out in this patient, the absence of risk factors for ischemic stroke, the acute deterioration of symptoms, and the presence of a lucid interval make this scenario unlikely.

images.title: Acute ischemic stroke with hyperdense middle cerebral artery sign
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

answers.content: Bleeding between dura mater and skull
answers.explanation_why:
Bleeding between the dura mater and the skull causes epidural hematoma. This diagnosis should be suspected in any patient with head trauma causing loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval and subsequently renewed deterioration and signs of elevated ICP. The lucid interval represents the time required for the blood to accumulate in the epidural space to proportions great enough to compress the brain.

The diagnosis is confirmed by noncontrast cranial CT which shows a biconvex, hyperdense, sharply demarcated lesion located between the brain and the calvarium, limited by suture lines. Emergency treatment is necessary and involves surgical opening of the skull and evacuation of the hematoma.

images.title: Epidural and subdural hematomas
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (brain window: axial and coronal planes; bone window: axial plane)A biconvex epidural hematoma (green overlay) with mass effect is seen in the left frontal region, adjacent to which is a small frontotemporal subdural hematoma (red overlay). A calvarial fracture (arrowheads) involves the left temporal and parietal bones.

answers.explanation_why: Rupture of a cerebral aneurysm is a potential cause of a subarachnoid hemorrhage that can also occur after head trauma. Patients typically present with sudden, excruciating headaches (thunderclap headache), meningism, and loss of consciousness. While this patient experienced headache and a loss of consciousness, the signs of elevated ICP and his momentary recovery of consciousness suggest another diagnosis.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Multiple areas of high attenuation in the basal cisterns, Sylvian fissures, and sulci (examples indicated by green overlay) are characteristic of extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage.

question_text: One hour after undergoing a surgical repair of a thoracic aortic aneurysm, a 70-year-old man experiences severe pain at the thoracolumbar junction and weakness and numbness in both legs. He appears pale and anxious. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 95/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to pain and temperature below the level of the umbilicus. Muscle strength is 1/5 in the lower extremities. Proprioception and vibration sense are normal in both lower extremities. Sensation and motor function in the upper extremities, chest, and back are intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: One hour after undergoing a surgical repair of a thoracic aortic aneurysm, a 70-year-old man experiences severe pain at the thoracolumbar junction and weakness and numbness in both legs. He appears pale and anxious. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 95/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to pain and temperature below the level of the umbilicus. Muscle strength is 1/5 in the lower extremities. Proprioception and vibration sense are normal in both lower extremities. Sensation and motor function in the upper extremities, chest, and back are intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient may also experience bowel and bladder dysfunction due to bilateral damage to the lateral horns of the spinal cord.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior cord syndrome.

answers.explanation_why:
Anterior cord syndrome (ACS) which is caused by damage to the anterior ⅔ of the spinal cord, manifests bilaterally, with lower motor neuron deficit at the level of the lesion (anterior horn damage), and decreased pain and temperature sensation (spinothalamic tract damage) and upper motor neuron deficit (lateral corticospinal tract damage) below the level of the lesion. In ACS, proprioception and vibration sense are preserved because the posterior spinal arteries provide blood supply to the dorsal columns. The thoracolumbar segment of the spinal cord is a watershed area and is, therefore, the most common site of infarction, as seen here.

ACS may occur as a complication of an aortic aneurysm itself or iatrogenically during the repair of the aneurysm (due to damage to the anterior spinal artery and/or artery of Adamkiewicz). Other causes of ACS include trauma (e.g., penetrating injury), hypotension (e.g., from severe hemorrhage), and compression (e.g., tumors, cervical spondylosis).

Spinal epidural hematoma (SEH) can cause acute spinal cord compression and manifest as back pain and lower extremity weakness and numbness, as seen in this patient. However, SEH typically occurs following puncture of the dura mater that causes damage to the vertebral venous plexus (e.g., following lumbar puncture, after pulling a dural catheter) rather than following an aortic aneurysm repair.

Leriche syndrome (i.e., aortoiliac occlusive disease) is caused by peripheral artery disease at the level of the aortic bifurcation or bilateral occlusion of the iliac arteries. This condition manifests as the triad of thigh/hip claudication, erectile dysfunction, and absent/diminished femoral pulses, which this patient does not have. Moreover, this patient presents with severe thoracolumbar pain, lower extremity numbness, and lower extremity muscle weakness, which would not be expected in Leriche syndrome.

Brown-Séquard syndrome occurs as a result of hemisection of the spinal cord and manifests as an ipsilateral loss of proprioception, fine touch, and vibration sense (dorsal column damage), contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (spinothalamic tract damage), ipsilateral lower motor neuron deficit at the level of the lesion (anterior horn damage), and ipsilateral upper motor neuron deficit below the level of the lesion (corticospinal tract damage). This is not consistent with the bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and bilateral weakness in lower extremities seen here. Moreover, this patient's proprioception and fine touch are intact bilaterally.

Posterior cord syndrome affects the dorsal columns. It would manifest as a loss of proprioception, fine touch, and vibration sense below the level of the lesion, with preserved muscle strength and pain and temperature sensation, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation.

Central cord syndrome (CCS) can manifest as bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (damage to the decussating fibers of the spinothalamic tract at the anterior white commissure) and bilateral paresis of the extremities (damage to lateral corticospinal tracts), as seen here. However, the paresis is usually worse in the upper extremities (especially the hands) when compared to the lower extremities (upper extremity tracts are more medial than lower extremity tracts). Moreover, CCS is commonly associated with pain and temperature loss in a “cape-like” distribution across the upper back and down the posterior upper extremities, which is not seen here.

question_text: A 74-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after he fell from the top of the staircase at home. He reports pain in the neck as well as weakness of the upper extremities. He has hypertension well-controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. He is alert and immobilized in a cervical collar. His pulse is 90/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. Examination shows bruising and midline cervical tenderness. Neurologic examination shows diminished strength and sensation to pain and temperature in the upper extremities, particularly in the hands. Upper extremity deep tendon reflexes are absent. Strength, sensation, and reflexes in the lower extremities are intact. Anal sensation and tone are present. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the cause of this patient's neurologic examination findings?
content_preview: A 74-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after he fell from the top of the staircase at home. He reports pain in the neck as well as weakness of the upper extremities. He has hypertension well-controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. He is alert and immobilized in a cervical collar. His pulse is 90/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. Examination shows bruising and midline cervical tenderness. Neurologic examination shows diminished strength and sensation to pain and temperature in the upper extremities, particularly in the hands. Upper extremity deep tendon reflexes are absent. Strength, sensation, and reflexes in the lower extremities are intact. Anal sensation and tone are present. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the cause of this patient's neurologic examination findings?
hint: Bilateral upper extremity weakness with diminished pain and temperature sensation (particularly in the hands) is characteristic of a central cord syndrome at the level of the cervical spine. Strength and reflexes are intact in the lower extremities because the motor fibers supplying the legs run more laterally in the corticospinal tract than the motor fibers supplying the arms. The acute onset of symptoms following trauma indicates that traumatic myelopathy is the underlying etiology.
learning_objective: Recognize central cord syndrome, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: In a patient who has sustained trauma, MR angiography of the neck is an appropriate imaging modality when clinical or radiological findings suggest an injury to blood vessels in the neck (e.g., carotid artery dissection, pseudoaneurysm). This patient is at lower risk for vascular injury, as he did not suffer any penetrating trauma. He also lacks clinical features that would suggest injury to the vertebral or carotid arteries (e.g., neurological deficits caused by a cortical or brainstem infarct). A different imaging modality is indicated for this patient with clinical features of a central cord syndrome, which is not known to be caused by a vascular etiology.

In a patient who has sustained trauma, CT angiography of the neck is an appropriate imaging modality when clinical or radiological findings suggest an injury to blood vessels in the neck (e.g., carotid artery dissection, pseudoaneurysm). This patient is at a lower risk for vascular injury as he did not suffer any penetrating trauma. He also lacks clinical features that would suggest injury to the vertebral or carotid arteries (e.g., neurological deficits caused by a cortical or brainstem infarct). A different imaging modality is indicated for this patient with clinical features of a central cord syndrome, which is not known to be caused by a vascular etiology.

answers.content: CT of the cervical spine with contrast
answers.explanation_why: CT with contrast may be appropriate for patients with myelopathy of suspected vascular origin (e.g., anterior spinal artery syndrome), as contrast can help define vascular structures. However, this patient likely has central cord syndrome from cervical hyperextension, not vascular infarction. In traumatic cervical myelopathy, CT of the cervical spine without contrast is indicated to identify fractures or dislocations of the cervical vertebrae; a contrast-enhanced CT scan is not recommended, since contrast and blood have similar Hounsfield units, and a contrast medium can obscure a possible cord hematoma.

Myelography may be considered in patients in whom the first-line diagnostic test is inconclusive or cannot be performed. However, it is not commonly performed as it has been largely replaced by less invasive and faster imaging modalities.

An x-ray of the cervical spine may be indicated in a patient with traumatic myelopathy if the first-line diagnostic test cannot be performed or is unavailable. A different imaging modality is indicated in this patient.

answers.content: MRI of the cervical spine without contrast
answers.explanation_why:
Central cord syndrome most commonly occurs in older individuals with cervical spondylosis after acute hyperextension following a trauma, as seen in this patient. MRI of the cervical spine without contrast is the first-line diagnostic test in patients with traumatic cervical myelopathy since it provides the best visualization of the soft tissue structures and can thus accurately delineate the extent of contusion or edema within the spinal cord. Documentation of the severity of spinal cord injury is important for follow-up and prognostication.

In addition to a non-contrast MRI, a non-contrast CT of the cervical spine may also be performed since a CT, which is more sensitive than MRI for bone pathology, can provide complementary information to the soft tissue findings obtained on MRI.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She reports dull aching pain and paresthesia over her left hand for the last few weeks. The pain radiates to her shoulder and is worse at night. Her hand feels numb upon waking up in the morning. She has a sister who has multiple sclerosis. Her current medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the wrist is passively held in full flexion, aggravation of paresthesia is perceived immediately. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She reports dull aching pain and paresthesia over her left hand for the last few weeks. The pain radiates to her shoulder and is worse at night. Her hand feels numb upon waking up in the morning. She has a sister who has multiple sclerosis. Her current medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the wrist is passively held in full flexion, aggravation of paresthesia is perceived immediately. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
hint: Beside pregnancy, hypothyroidism and rheumatoid arthritis are also risk factors for this patient's condition.
learning_objective: Recognize median nerve compression as carpal tunnel syndrome.

answers.content: Lower trunk palsy of the brachial plexus
answers.explanation_why: Paralysis of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Klumpke palsy) causes deficits along the C8 and T1 myotomes and dermatomes. Although Klumpke palsy may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand and would also be present on the ulnar aspect of the forearm. Hand and finger weakness is also typically prominent. In addition, this patient lacks a history that would suggest Klumpke paralysis (e.g., upward traction on the arm, thoracic outlet syndrome, Pancoast tumor).

Compression of the ulnar nerve in the ulnar groove between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon (cubital tunnel syndrome) may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand as seen in this patient. However, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand, and/or the ring and little finger and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with ulnar nerve compression. Also, this patient has no history that would suggest a cubital tunnel syndrome (e.g., osteoarthritis or trauma to the elbow).

images.title: Ulnar nerve neuropathy
images.description:
Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4^th and 5^th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1^st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3^rd and 4^th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingersProximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

answers.explanation_why: Radiculopathy of C6, C7, and/or C8 nerve roots may manifest with pain and paresthesia in the hand and shoulder. However, radiculopathy is typically accompanied by restriction of neck, arm, or hand movements. Also, nocturnal paresthesia is usually not present. Exacerbation of paresthesia by passive flexion of the wrist (Phalen sign) suggests a specific mononeuropathy and not radiculopathy.

Immune-mediated demyelinating neuropathies such as Guillain-Barre syndrome can manifest with pain and paresthesias affecting the distal extremities. However, these sensory abnormalities are generally symmetric and associated with concurrent ascending flaccid muscle paralysis that begins in the lower limbs. The presence of an asymmetric sensory disorder that is localized to the hand and the absence of motor deficits suggest a different diagnosis.

Compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel (carpal tunnel syndrome, CTS) results in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the areas innervated by the median nerve (i.e., palmar surface of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, and radial half of the ring finger). Pregnancy is an important risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome because of physiological fluid retention, which leads to edema of soft tissue in and around the carpal tunnel. The sensory disturbances in CTS are classically worse at night and pain on flexion of the wrist (a positive Phalen test) may be present. Occasionally, the pain may radiate to the shoulder, as seen in this patient. Most cases of carpal tunnel syndrome with an onset during pregnancy can be managed by splinting of the wrist. Surgery and corticosteroid injections are usually not required because symptoms usually resolve after delivery.

images.title: Phalen maneuver supported by the examiner
images.description: The Phalen maneuver is considered specific for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The examiner holds the patient's wrist in flexion (1) or extension (2). If paresthesia in the fingers innervated by the median nerve (marked in white) occurs or is aggravated within one minute, this finding is highly specific for CTS.

answers.explanation_why: Radial nerve compression usually results from trauma or prolonged pressure on the mid-arm (e.g., Saturday night palsy). Radial nerve palsy typically manifests with sensory changes over the posterior forearm/hand and weakness on wrist extension (i.e., wrist drop). This patient has no significant risk factors for radial nerve compression (e.g., trauma or intoxication) and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with radial nerve compression.

images.title: Radial nerve neuropathy
images.description:
Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP jointsSensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2^nd and 3^rd fingers. The 1^st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumbProximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

answers.explanation_why: Demyelinating diseases of the CNS such as multiple sclerosis (MS) may manifest with a variety of neurologic symptoms, including arm paresthesias. While this patient is at increased risk for MS (woman of childbearing age with a positive family history), the association of her symptoms with sleep, its presence during pregnancy, and exacerbation with wrist flexion are inconsistent with MS. MS should be suspected if there are recurrent neurologic symptoms in different parts of the body (e.g., wrist paresthesia that resolves, followed by diplopia months later). MS exacerbations tend to cause symptoms that are persistent for days to weeks, until the flare resolves. Finally, MS symptoms tend to improve during pregnancy (possibly due to immunosuppression).

question_text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of white discharge from her nipples for 4 months. During this period, menses have occurred at irregular 30- to 45-day intervals and have lasted 3 to 10 days; menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals with moderate flow. She has also had recurrent headaches that partially subside with ibuprofen. She has a healthy 5-year-old son. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m^2. Breast examination shows bilateral milklike discharge from the nipples; no masses are felt. Pelvic examination shows mild vaginal atrophy. An MRI of the head with contrast followed by hormone assays confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of white discharge from her nipples for 4 months. During this period, menses have occurred at irregular 30- to 45-day intervals and have lasted 3 to 10 days; menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals with moderate flow. She has also had recurrent headaches that partially subside with ibuprofen. She has a healthy 5-year-old son. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Breast examination shows bilateral milklike discharge from the nipples; no masses are felt. Pelvic examination shows mild vaginal atrophy. An MRI of the head with contrast followed by hormone assays confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's galactorrhea, irregular menses, vaginal atrophy, and confirmatory hormone assays indicate hyperprolactinemia. Her headaches and positive findings on MRI (likely an intrasellar mass) suggest a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma (i.e., prolactinoma).
learning_objective: Recognize hyperprolactinemia, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: High levels of prolactin suppress the release of GnRH from the hypothalamus resulting in low levels of LH and FSH, and subsequently, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This patient likely has low estrogen levels, and estrogen replacement therapy (ERT) would improve her vaginal atrophy. However, ERT does not help to treat the underlying cause of her hyperprolactinemia.

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated in asymptomatic patients with nonsecretory pituitary microadenomas. However, this patient has headaches, galactorrhea, irregular menses, and vaginal atrophy and should receive treatment. Without proper treatment, she is at risk of developing osteoporosis and infertility due to long-term suppression of sex hormone production. Also, further tumor growth may lead to bitemporal hemianopia or the destruction of normal pituitary gland tissue and deficiency of other pituitary hormones.

Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is the first-line treatment for most pituitary macroadenomas. Prolactinomas of any size, however, usually respond well to a less aggressive treatment modality; surgical resection is only considered as a second-line treatment.

Dopamine receptor agonists such as cabergoline or bromocriptine are first-line treatments for all prolactinomas. By decreasing prolactin secretion they improve symptoms due to hyperprolactinemia such as galactorrhea, irregular menses, or vaginal atrophy, all of which are seen in this patient. Dopamine agonists usually also induce regression of tumor size, thereby improving symptoms due to mass effects such as headaches or bitemporal hemianopsia.

images.title: Pituitary mass 2/2
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactinA large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: External beam radiotherapy can be used to treat prolactinomas or other pituitary adenomas that do not respond to medical therapy or cannot be resected surgically. In this patient with likely prolactinoma, other treatment options should be tried first.

question_text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had her menses for 6 months. She has also had milky-white discharge from her nipples, frequent headaches, and blurry vision during the past 4 months. Menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals and lasted for 4–5 days with moderate flow. She takes no medications. She has two children who are healthy and attend middle school. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (145 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows vaginal atrophy and a normal uterus. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference range. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Serum studies are most likely to show which of the following sets of findings in this patient?

Prolactin
Follicle-stimulating hormone
Luteinizing hormone

A
Normal
decreased
decreased

B
Decreased
increased
increased

C
Increased
increased
increased

D
Decreased
decreased
decreased

E
Normal
increased
increased

F
Increased
decreased
decreased
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had her menses for 6 months. She has also had milky-white discharge from her nipples, frequent headaches, and blurry vision during the past 4 months. Menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals and lasted for 4–5 days with moderate flow. She takes no medications. She has two children who are healthy and attend middle school. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (145 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows vaginal atrophy and a normal uterus. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference range. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Serum studies are most likely to show which of the following sets of findings in this patient? Prolactin Follicle-stimulating hormone Luteinizing hormone A Normal decreased decreased B Decreased increased increased C Increased increased increased D Decreased decreased decreased E Normal increased increased F Increased decreased decreased
hint: The presence of amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and vaginal atrophy in a woman with new-onset headaches and blurry vision should raise suspicion of a prolactinoma.
learning_objective: Recognize a prolactinoma, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why: The constellation of normal prolactin level, decreased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and decreased luteinizing hormone (LH) could be seen in a nonfunctioning pituitary adenoma because gonadotropic cells often respond to mass effect earlier than other cell types, e.g., those producing prolactin. A pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms (e.g., headache, visual changes), and this patient's amenorrhea and vaginal atrophy do suggest decreased FSH, resulting in low estrogen levels. However, her galactorrhea would suggest another hormonal abnormality.

Decreased prolactin, elevated follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and increased luteinizing hormone (LH) could be explained by a functioning gonadotroph adenoma, which may induce hypopituitarism via mass effect. A pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms, which would explain this patient's sudden headaches and blurry vision. However, her estrogen level would be normal-to-high in the case of increased FSH secretion by the adenoma, which would not explain her vaginal atrophy — a sign of low estrogen levels. Also, her galactorrhea would indicate a different hormonal abnormality.

The combination of elevated prolactin, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH) might be seen if a functioning gonadotropic adenoma grew large enough to cause impingement of the infundibular stalk, leading to mild hyperprolactinemia secondary to the interruption of the tonic inhibitory effect of hypothalamic dopamine on the secretion of prolactin (disconnection hyperprolactinemia). Hyperprolactinemia can cause galactorrhea. However, elevated FSH leads to a normal/high estrogen and would not be consistent with vaginal atrophy, which is a sign of decreased estrogen.

The constellation of decreased prolactin, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH) is seen in some forms of hypopituitarism, e.g., in a patient with a slow-growing, nonsecretory adenoma that compresses the regular hormone-secreting cells of the pituitary gland. A pituitary tumor could explain this patient's headaches and vision problems and decreased FSH could cause decreased estrogen levels, which would explain the vaginal atrophy and oligomenorrhea. However, her galactorrhea is highly suggestive of a different hormonal abnormality.

Normal prolactin, elevated follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and elevated luteinizing hormone (LH) could be caused by a hormone-secreting gonadotropic adenoma. Although a pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms (e.g., headache, blurry vision), and increased FSH can cause amenorrhea (via ovarian hyperstimulation), the described constellation of hormones would not explain this patient's galactorrhea nor the vaginal atrophy.

Prolactinomas are the most common cause of hyperprolactinemia. Hyperprolactinemia has an inhibitory effect on GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone), which leads to a decrease in LH and FSH (luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone) and subsequently a decline in estrogen and testosterone, resulting in amenorrhea/oligomenorrhea, vaginal atrophy, and endometrial atrophy. Hyperprolactinemia has a direct tropic effect on breast tissue and triggers lactation, explaining this patient's galactorrhea — a finding that is seen in 80% of premenopausal women with hyperprolactinemia. A pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms, leading to bitemporal hemianopsia and/or palsy of the adjacent cranial nerves III, IV, or VI. The best next step in the diagnosis of suspected pituitary adenoma is a brain MRI with contrast. First-line treatment for prolactinomas is dopamine agonists (e.g., cabergoline), which inhibit prolactin secretion and induce shrinkage of the tumor.

question_text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of episodic headaches for 5 months. The headaches involve both temples and are 4/10 in intensity. The patient has been taking acetaminophen, but the headaches did not subside. He has also had visual disturbances, including double vision. He has no nausea, temperature intolerance, or weight changes. The patient does not smoke. He drinks 2–3 beers on weekends. He appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure 125/80 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows impaired peripheral vision bilaterally. An MRI scan of the head with contrast shows a 16 × 11 × 9 mm intrasellar mass. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of episodic headaches for 5 months. The headaches involve both temples and are 4/10 in intensity. The patient has been taking acetaminophen, but the headaches did not subside. He has also had visual disturbances, including double vision. He has no nausea, temperature intolerance, or weight changes. The patient does not smoke. He drinks 2–3 beers on weekends. He appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure 125/80 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows impaired peripheral vision bilaterally. An MRI scan of the head with contrast shows a 16 × 11 × 9 mm intrasellar mass. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: The intrasellar mass seen on this patient's MRI scan is likely a pituitary adenoma that is causing his headaches and bitemporal hemianopia. The most common form of pituitary adenomas is a prolactinoma. What are the potential consequences of this tumor in men?
learning_objective: Recognize a pituitary adenoma, and recall the hormonal sequelae.

answers.explanation_why: Galactorrhea is a very rare manifestation of hyperprolactinemia in men but is commonly found in premenopausal women with hyperprolactinemia. Instead, gynecomastia is a common manifestation of hyperprolactinemia in men.

This patient has a pituitary adenoma, a rare variant of which is a somatotroph adenoma that can produce growth hormone. In adults, excess growth hormone can result in acromegaly, which typically manifests with coarse facial features. However, this patient does not have typical manifestations of acromegaly, such as macrognathia, large hands and feet, and hypertension. He has another type of pituitary adenoma that is much more common and produces other distinct symptoms.

This patient has a pituitary adenoma, a rare variant of which is a thyrotroph adenoma that can produce thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). A TSH-producing pituitary adenoma can result in the development of a diffuse goiter and hyperthyroidism. However, this patient does not have typical manifestations of hyperthyroidism, such as tachycardia, palpitations, tremor, and heat intolerance. He has another type of pituitary adenoma that is much more common and produces other distinct symptoms.

This patient has a pituitary adenoma, the most common form of which is a prolactinoma that can cause hyperprolactinemia. Hyperprolactinemia results in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism because prolactin inhibits the synthesis and release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which results in decreased secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). In men, decreased concentrations of LH result in decreased production of testosterone in testicular Leydig cells. The resulting manifestations include erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, reduced testicular volume, infertility, gynecomastia, and loss of axillary hair. The visual deficits caused by a growing pituitary adenoma develop very gradually as the mass grows and compresses the optic chiasm (causing bitemporal hemianopia) and the oculomotor nerve (causing diplopia).

See “Clinical features of hyperprolactinemia” table.

images.title: Pituitary mass 2/2
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactinA large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: This patient has a pituitary adenoma, a variant of which can produce adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and cause Cushing disease, which results in the development of abdominal striae. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of Cushing disease, such as facial plethora, proximal muscle weakness, abnormal fat distribution, and easy bruising. He has another type of pituitary adenoma that is much more common and produces other distinct symptoms.

question_text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a fall that occurred while he was taking a shower earlier that morning. His wife heard him fall and entered the bathroom to find his arms and legs twitching. The episode lasted approximately 30 seconds. He was unsure of what had happened and was unable to answer simple questions on awakening. He has regained orientation since that time. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include metoprolol and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Cranial nerve examination shows no abnormalities. He has 5/5 strength in all extremities. Examination shows full muscle strength. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is normal and symmetrical. A noncontrast head CT is performed and shows a slightly hyperdense mass. Follow-up MRI shows a homogeneous, well-circumscribed 4-cm mass with compression of the adjacent white matter, and a hyperintense border around the mass on T2-weighted imaging. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a fall that occurred while he was taking a shower earlier that morning. His wife heard him fall and entered the bathroom to find his arms and legs twitching. The episode lasted approximately 30 seconds. He was unsure of what had happened and was unable to answer simple questions on awakening. He has regained orientation since that time. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include metoprolol and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Cranial nerve examination shows no abnormalities. He has 5/5 strength in all extremities. Examination shows full muscle strength. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is normal and symmetrical. A noncontrast head CT is performed and shows a slightly hyperdense mass. Follow-up MRI shows a homogeneous, well-circumscribed 4-cm mass with compression of the adjacent white matter, and a hyperintense border around the mass on T2-weighted imaging. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Brain tumors that manifest with seizures are most often supratentorial. The compression of adjacent white matter and/or a rim of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) around the tumor (hyperintense appearance of CSF on T2-weighted imaging) indicate that the tumor is most likely extraaxial (external to the brain parenchyma).
learning_objective: Recognize a meningioma.

answers.explanation_why: Glioblastoma multiforme almost always occurs in patients over the age of 40 and can manifest with seizures. On CT scan, however, glioblastoma multiforme appears as a poorly demarcated, hypodense, intraaxial lesion that tends to infiltrate along condensed white matter tracts such as the corticospinal tract and the corpus callosum. On T2-weighted MRI, glioblastoma multiforme typically appears as an expansive hyperintense signal, which represents vasogenic edema involving both the cortex and underlying white matter. The presence of a well-circumscribed, extraaxial mass makes this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Mass effect from glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV astrocytoma)
images.description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a 69-year old man with a history of personality changes and left-sided hemiparesis from glioblastomaThe right cerebral hemisphere is diffusely abnormal, with intermixed hypodense (green overlay), isodense, and hyperdense (red overlay) areas. There is mass effect with sulcal effacement and midline shift to the left (dashed line). The frontal and occipital horns (arrowheads) of the right lateral ventricle are effaced.Yellow overlay: choroid plexus calcification
Blue overlay: falx cerebri calcification

answers.explanation_why: Oligodendrogliomas are most common among individuals 40–60 years of age and commonly manifest with seizures. However, oligodendrogliomas usually appear on CT as hypodense, intraaxial tumors with focal hyperdense regions within the tumor, which are caused by calcification and/or hemorrhage.

images.title: High signal intensity lesion on brain MRI (FLAIR)
images.description: MRI head (FLAIR sequence; axial plane)A hyperintense area (green overlay) in the right medial temporooccipital region was hypointense on a contrast-enhanced T1-weighted sequence (not shown). The lesion proved to be an oligodendroglioma. The differential diagnosis on MRI also included ischemic and inflammatory processes.C: cerebellum; M: mesencephalon (midbrain)

answers.explanation_why: Acoustic neuroma, the most common type of schwannoma, is especially common in patients 40–60 years of age. However, seizure would be an uncommon symptom of an infratentorial tumor such as an acoustic neuroma. Instead, patients typically present with sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and facial nerve palsy. Additionally, acoustic neuromas, while generally best visualized on gadolinium-enhanced MRI, appear on noncontrast T2-weighted imaging as heterogeneously hyperintense extraaxial lesions that are localized to the cerebellopontine angle, the internal auditory meatus, and/or the internal auditory canal.

images.title: Vestibularis schwannoma (acoustic neuroma)
images.description:
Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

answers.explanation_why: Cranial hemangioblastomas are almost always infratentorial tumors. As a result, they manifest with features of elevated intracranial pressure, cerebellar dysfunction, and/or palsies of cranial nerves that arise from the pons and medulla oblongata. On CT scan, they appear as sharply demarcated, hypodense, intraaxial cystic lesions. The presence of seizures and a hyperdense, extraaxial mass in this patient makes the diagnosis of hemangioblastoma unlikely.

images.title: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
images.description: MRI head (with contrast; axial view)A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Medulloblastomas are intraaxial tumors that most commonly occur near the cerebellar midline. Since medulloblastomas are infratentorial tumors, seizures are uncommon. Instead, features of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, vomiting, papilledema) and cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., ataxia, nystagmus) are typically present. On CT, medulloblastomas appear as hyperdense tumors in the cerebellum, with possible diffuse infiltration of the fourth ventricle and brainstem. This patient's presentation with seizures and the extraaxial location of the lesion make a medulloblastoma highly unlikely.

images.title: Medulloblastoma in a child
images.description: Head MRI (T2 weighted image)Medulloblastoma within the posterior cranial fossa (green border in overlay). The lesion contains cystic areas, particularly on the left side (green overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Meningiomas are tumors derived from the meninges and occur supratentorially (e.g., near the falx cerebri, convex cerebral surface, or olfactory groove) in about half of all cases. Meningiomas may be asymptomatic or cause general symptoms of brain tumors such as seizures and/or specific patterns of symptoms depending on their location. On CT, meningiomas appear as a round, well-circumscribed, extraaxial mass that is usually hyperdense. On plain MRIs, meningiomas may appear isointense to gray matter on T1 and hyperintense to gray matter on T2.

images.title: Dural based mass
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

question_text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a severe headache for 1 hour. Every day of the past week, he has experienced 3–4 episodes of severe pain over his left forehead. Each episode lasts around 30–45 minutes, and he reports pacing around restlessly during these episodes. He has been using acetaminophen for these episodes, but it has provided only minimal relief. He works as a financial analyst and says his job is very stressful. He had experienced similar symptoms 4 months ago but did not seek treatment at that time. He has no history of serious illness and takes no other medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years. He appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is conjunctival injection and tearing of the left eye. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is most likely to provide acute relief of this patient's headaches?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a severe headache for 1 hour. Every day of the past week, he has experienced 3–4 episodes of severe pain over his left forehead. Each episode lasts around 30–45 minutes, and he reports pacing around restlessly during these episodes. He has been using acetaminophen for these episodes, but it has provided only minimal relief. He works as a financial analyst and says his job is very stressful. He had experienced similar symptoms 4 months ago but did not seek treatment at that time. He has no history of serious illness and takes no other medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years. He appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is conjunctival injection and tearing of the left eye. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is most likely to provide acute relief of this patient's headaches?
hint: This young man has recurrent attacks of severe unilateral headache that are associated with ipsilateral cranial autonomic symptoms (conjunctival injection, lacrimation), which is indicative of cluster headache.
learning_objective: Recognize cluster headaches, and choose the most appropriate acute treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Indomethacin is not effective in the treatment of cluster headaches. Instead, indomethacin is highly effective in preventing attacks of paroxysmal hemicrania, a rare form of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia, although it is not very effective as an abortive therapy in acute cases. In fact, most treatment options for paroxysmal hemicrania have limited efficacy as abortive therapy. While paroxysmal hemicrania may present very similarly, the attacks are usually more frequent (≥ 5 per day) and often shorter.

High-dose steroid therapy is the treatment of choice for giant cell arteritis (GCA). Patients with GCA can present with severe unilateral headache, as seen in this patient. However, autonomic symptoms do not occur, and symptoms such as jaw claudication and scalp tenderness, which are not seen in this patient, are usually present. More importantly, GCA usually occurs in elderly individuals (peak incidence: 70–79 years) and is rare in patients younger than 50.

images.title: Pain localization in secondary headache
images.description:
Certain pain characteristics and associated symptoms can help in the diagnosis of a secondary headache:– Temporal arteritis: unilateral headache, jaw claudication, tenderness of scalp or temporal artery, constitutional symptoms, visual changes
– Hypertensive crisis: diffuse, often bifrontal, headache (Headache in the setting of hypertensive crisis can be an isolated finding but may also be a manifestation of hypertensive encephalopathy, which constitutes a hypertensive emergency)
– Sinusitis: Facial pain or pressure in the sinus cavity region, purulent rhinorrhea, flu-like symptoms
– Medication overuse headache: diffuse headache that can change in type and location within an episode and has developed or worsened with pain medication overuse

answers.explanation_why: Amitriptyline is used to prevent chronic tension-type headaches and migraine attacks. Amitriptyline is not used, however, to acutely treat any type of headache.

Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia. While trigeminal neuralgia can present with unilateral facial pain that occurs in repetitive attacks, unlike in this patient, these attacks usually only last a few seconds and are characterized by shooting or stabbing pain (like an electric shock) from mouth to the angle of the jaw on the affected side. Frontal headache, conjunctival injection, and lacrimation are not features of trigeminal neuralgia.

images.title: Trigeminal neuralgia
images.description: Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

answers.explanation_why: Oxycodone is an orally administered opiate analgesic that is used to treat chronic and/or severe pain that cannot be managed with NSAIDs. Opiate analgesics should not, however, be used in the management of primary headache disorders because of the risk of opiate dependence.

Naproxen can be used for pain relief in, e.g., migraine and acute tension-type headaches (TTH). While TTH are the most common type of primary headache, the pain associated with TTH is usually holocephalic or bifrontal rather than unilateral. Cranial autonomic symptoms, as seen in this patient, do not occur. Migraine is another common type of primary headache disorder that is characterized by episodes of (typically unilateral) headache lasting 4–72 hours accompanied or preceded by nausea, vomiting, hyperacusis, photophobia, and/or aura, which are absent in this patient. Furthermore, while patients with migraine headache tend to rest motionlessly in a quiet, dark room, this patient prefers to pace around during the episodes of pain.

Administration of 100% oxygen is effective in terminating acute episodes of cluster headache in up to 80% of individuals. The exact mechanism is unknown, but it is thought to involve the vasoconstriction of cranial blood vessels in response to high oxygen concentration and hypocapnea.

Sumatriptan and ergotamine are also used to treat cluster headaches, but these drugs should be used with caution because they can cause vasoconstriction; most patients with cluster headaches (approx. 80%) smoke cigarettes and may therefore have other smoking-associated diseases, such as hypertension, peripheral artery disease, and/or coronary artery disease.

question_text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent episodes of stabbing facial pain for 4 months. The pain occurs over her left cheek, is 9 out of 10 in intensity, radiates towards her mouth, and lasts around half a minute before subsiding. These episodes commonly occur when she washes her face, brushes her teeth, or eats a meal. She does not have visual disturbances, weakness of her facial muscles, or hearing loss. She had a tooth extracted about 2 months ago, but the facial pain has persisted. She has hypothyroidism and vitiligo. Her mother has major depressive disorder. Current medications include levothyroxine and herbal cream. She appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent episodes of stabbing facial pain for 4 months. The pain occurs over her left cheek, is 9 out of 10 in intensity, radiates towards her mouth, and lasts around half a minute before subsiding. These episodes commonly occur when she washes her face, brushes her teeth, or eats a meal. She does not have visual disturbances, weakness of her facial muscles, or hearing loss. She had a tooth extracted about 2 months ago, but the facial pain has persisted. She has hypothyroidism and vitiligo. Her mother has major depressive disorder. Current medications include levothyroxine and herbal cream. She appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The history of intermittent episodes of severe, stabbing, unilateral facial pain lasting several seconds is consistent with trigeminal neuralgia.
learning_objective: Recognize trigeminal neuralgia, and choose the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Amitriptyline can be used for the management of neuropathic pain, such as diabetic neuropathy and postherpetic neuralgia, and may also be considered in patients with trigeminal neuralgia who do not respond to first-line therapy. This patient has not received treatment for trigeminal neuralgia and therefore requires different management at this time.

While microvascular decompression is used to provide relief in cases of refractory trigeminal neuralgia, it is an invasive procedure. As such, it entails a risk of nerve damage, which may lead to hearing loss, facial numbness, or diplopia (double vision) and should not be used as first-line therapy.

Botulinum toxin injection into a facial muscle is indicated for blepharospasm, and some studies also support the use of this therapy for refractory trigeminal neuralgia. However, there is not enough evidence supporting the use of botulinum toxin in the management of trigeminal neuralgia for it to be considered a first-line treatment.

Radiofrequency rhizotomy refers to the application of heat to the trigeminal ganglion or root using a cannula that is passed through the foramen ovale. This is an ablative procedure that may help in cases of cluster headaches and refractory trigeminal neuralgia, but this patient does not have a history of pain refractory to a recommended first-line therapy.

Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic agent that is used as first-line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia. The efficacy of carbamazepine has been proven in several randomized controlled trials. However, it is not well tolerated by all patients because of its common side effects (e.g., hepatotoxicity, hematologic abnormalities, sedation, diplopia) and potential for drug interactions. Oxcarbazepine, which has similar efficacy and overall better tolerability, is another first-line agent for patients with trigeminal neuralgia. Surgical management (e.g., microvascular decompression) is usually reserved for patients who show no symptomatic improvement with medication therapy or who develop significant side effects.

images.title: Trigeminal neuralgia
images.description: Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

question_text: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fatigue and a cough productive of a blood-tinged phlegm. Over the past month, he has had a 5.0-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Eight months ago, he underwent a kidney transplantation. The patient does not smoke. His current medications include lisinopril, insulin, prednisone, and mycophenolate mofetil. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 152/92 mm Hg. Rhonchi are heard at the right lower lobe of the lung on auscultation. There is a small ulceration on the left foot. An x-ray of the chest shows a right lung mass with lobar consolidation. Antibiotic therapy with levofloxacin is started. Three days later, the patient has a seizure and difficulty coordinating movements with his left hand. An MRI of the brain shows an intraparenchymal lesion with peripheral ring enhancement. Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage yields weakly acid-fast, gram-positive bacteria with branching, filamentous shapes. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fatigue and a cough productive of a blood-tinged phlegm. Over the past month, he has had a 5.0-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Eight months ago, he underwent a kidney transplantation. The patient does not smoke. His current medications include lisinopril, insulin, prednisone, and mycophenolate mofetil. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 152/92 mm Hg. Rhonchi are heard at the right lower lobe of the lung on auscultation. There is a small ulceration on the left foot. An x-ray of the chest shows a right lung mass with lobar consolidation. Antibiotic therapy with levofloxacin is started. Three days later, the patient has a seizure and difficulty coordinating movements with his left hand. An MRI of the brain shows an intraparenchymal lesion with peripheral ring enhancement. Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage yields weakly acid-fast, gram-positive bacteria with branching, filamentous shapes. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
hint: This immunocompromised patient presents with signs and symptoms of infection in multiple locations: lungs (hemoptysis, consolidated lung mass on x-ray), skin (ulceration), and CNS (seizure, brain abscess on MRI). The presence of weakly acid-fast, branching bacteria confirms the diagnosis of disseminated nocardiosis.
learning_objective: Recognize disseminated nocardiosis in an immunocompromised patient, and choose the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol are antibiotics indicated in the treatment of tuberculosis. Posttransplant patients receiving immunosuppressive therapy are at increased risk of tuberculosis, which can manifest with similar pulmonary (lung mass with consolidation), extrapulmonary (cerebral abscess), and constitutional symptoms. Mycobacterium tuberculosis is, however, strongly acid-fast and not usually filamentous or branching.

Vancomycin is commonly used to treat infections with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Infection with MRSA can cause a variety of pulmonary, skin, and CNS findings. However, the bacterium is not acid-fast and presents as a gram-positive coccus on Gram stain.

Piperacillin/tazobactam is used in the treatment of pneumonia caused by gram-negative bacilli such as Pseudomonas species. Pseudomonas pneumonia can occur in immunosuppressed patients but does not usually manifest with CNS and skin findings. Pseudomonas aeruginosa would appear as a gram-negative rather than a gram-positive aerobic rod on Gram stain.

Long-term therapy (≥ 6 months) with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is the treatment of choice for nocardiosis. In patients with CNS involvement, combination therapy with imipenem is indicated. Additionally, a neurosurgical consultation should be initiated for stereotactic aspiration or surgical excision of the brain abscess.

The lungs are the primary site of infection in most cases of nocardiosis. While pulmonary nocardiosis may occasionally occur in immunocompetent patients, disseminated disease is almost always associated with underlying immunosuppression, e.g., due to HIV infection, organ transplant, glucocorticoid therapy, recent chemotherapy, or diabetes mellitus.

images.title: Nocardia in blood culture
images.description: Photomicrograph of bacteria in blood culture (Kinyoun stain)Clusters of branching, filamentous rods are concentrated in the center.

answers.explanation_why: Erythromycin can be used to treat atypical pneumonia (e.g., due to infection with Chlamydia pneumoniae or Mycoplasma pneumoniae). Atypical pneumonia usually manifests with a low-grade fever and a non-productive cough; CNS and cutaneous involvement are uncommon. In addition, Mycoplasma pneumoniae is usually not seen on Gram stain because it lacks a bacterial cell wall; the microscopy findings characteristic of Chlamydia pneumoniae infection are intracellular inclusions.

question_text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe lower back pain for the past 3 weeks. The pain was initially exacerbated by activity but now presents also at rest. The patient has not had a headache or a cough. He reports no changes in bowel movements or urination. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His current medications include metformin and lisinopril. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 134/92 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the spinous processes of the second and third lumbar vertebrae with significant paraspinal spasm. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
14 g/dL

Leukocyte count
10,800/mm^3

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
75 mm/h

Serum

Ca^2+

9.6 mg/dL

Urea nitrogen
22 mg/dL

Glucose
216 mg/dL

Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL

Albumin
3.7 g/dL

Alkaline phosphatase
55 U/L

C-reactive protein

82 mg/L (N = 0.08–3.1)

An x-ray of the lumbar spine shows bone destruction, sequestrum formation, and periosteal reactions along the second and third lumbar vertebrae. An MRI of the lumbar spine shows increased T2 signals within the second and third lumbar vertebrae without signs of epidural abscess. He is started on appropriate analgesia. Blood cultures grow no organisms after 48 hours. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe lower back pain for the past 3 weeks. The pain was initially exacerbated by activity but now presents also at rest. The patient has not had a headache or a cough. He reports no changes in bowel movements or urination. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His current medications include metformin and lisinopril. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 134/92 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the spinous processes of the second and third lumbar vertebrae with significant paraspinal spasm. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 14 g/dL Leukocyte count 10,800/mm3 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 75 mm/h Serum Ca2+ 9.6 mg/dL Urea nitrogen 22 mg/dL Glucose 216 mg/dL Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL Albumin 3.7 g/dL Alkaline phosphatase 55 U/L C-reactive protein 82 mg/L (N = 0.08–3.1) An x-ray of the lumbar spine shows bone destruction, sequestrum formation, and periosteal reactions along the second and third lumbar vertebrae. An MRI of the lumbar spine shows increased T2 signals within the second and third lumbar vertebrae without signs of epidural abscess. He is started on appropriate analgesia. Blood cultures grow no organisms after 48 hours. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient with diabetes mellitus presents with lower back pain, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and elevated C-reactive protein (CRP). These features, together with the x-ray and MRI findings, indicate vertebral osteomyelitis.
learning_objective: Recognize vertebral osteomyelitis, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic procedure after negative blood cultures.

answers.explanation_why: Skeletal scintigraphy can be useful for diagnosing osteomyelitis when a patient cannot undergo other imaging modalities, such as MRI (e.g., due to the presence of cardiac or cochlear implants). However, this patient's imaging already suggests osteomyelitis, so further imaging studies would be redundant and an inefficient use of healthcare resources.

In a patient with suspected vertebral osteomyelitis supported by x-ray and MRI findings, the next most appropriate step after negative blood cultures is a CT-guided bone biopsy with Gram staining, culture, and histology to identify the causal organism. This not only confirms the diagnosis but also enables appropriate antibiotic selection based on the culture results. 

In hemodynamically stable patients with no signs of neurologic compromise, antibiotic treatment should be withheld until the underlying pathogen has been identified. Spinal epidural abscesses are common complications in patients with vertebral osteomyelitis.

images.title: Spondylodiscitis (discitis-osteomyelitis)
images.description: X-ray lumbar spine (lateral view)The inferior endplate of L2 and superior endplate of L3 are osteopenic and the cortices appear fragmented (green ellipse). The intervening L2–3 disc space is narrowed.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical debridement is a second-line treatment for osteomyelitis after conservative management with bed rest and antibiotics has failed. This is also useful for patients who have spinal instability or demonstrate neurological deficits on physical exam. However, this patient is both hemodynamically and neurologically stable.

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) assay is used to screen for prostate cancer or to monitor for prostate cancer metastasis or recurrence following treatment. The most common site of distant metastasis for prostate cancer is bone, including the vertebral bodies. These metastases are usually osteoblastic and appear as blastic or sclerotic lesions on x-ray. Although CRP and ESR can be elevated in patients with prostate cancer, this patient does not have any other signs of advanced or metastatic prostate cancer such as fatigue, weight loss, or neurologic deficits due to spinal cord compression from spinal metastases.

The combination of vancomycin and ceftazidime has excellent coverage of gram-negative rods and gram-positive cocci, including methicillin-resistant S. aureus, making it a good empirical treatment for patients with osteomyelitis due to an unknown pathogen. Empiric antibiotic treatment should be initialized as soon as possible in patients with osteomyelitis who are hemodynamically unstable or have neurological deficits. However, in hemodynamically stable patients without neurological deficits, such as this one, antibiotic therapy should be postponed until after another step is conducted.

answers.content: Isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol therapy
answers.explanation_why: The combination of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, often referred to as quadruple therapy, is the first-line treatment for tuberculous spondylitis (Pott disease), a common late extrapulmonary manifestation of tuberculosis infection. Patients can present with signs of osteomyelitis. However, patients also usually have a history of tuberculosis symptoms including cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, and B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss). This patient has none of those symptoms, making this diagnosis less likely. In addition, given the significant morbidity associated with antituberculosis drugs, these should not be started unless clinical suspicion is high or the diagnosis is confirmed.
