question_text:
A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of headaches, vertigo, and changes to his personality over the past few weeks.  He was diagnosed with HIV 14 years ago and was started on antiretroviral therapy at that time. Medical records from one month ago indicate that he followed his medication schedule inconsistently. Since then, he has been regularly taking his antiretroviral medications and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination shows ataxia and apathy. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 15/30. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL

Leukocyte count
8400/mm^3

 Segmented neutrophils
80%

 Eosinophils
1%

 Lymphocytes
17%

 Monocytes
2%

CD4^+ T-lymphocytes
90/mm^3

Platelet count
328,000/mm^3

An MRI of the brain with contrast shows a solitary ring-enhancing lesion involving the corpus callosum and measuring 4.5 cm in diameter. A lumbar puncture with subsequent cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows slight pleocytosis, and PCR is positive for Epstein-Barr virus DNA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of headaches, vertigo, and changes to his personality over the past few weeks. He was diagnosed with HIV 14 years ago and was started on antiretroviral therapy at that time. Medical records from one month ago indicate that he followed his medication schedule inconsistently. Since then, he has been regularly taking his antiretroviral medications and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination shows ataxia and apathy. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 15/30. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL Leukocyte count 8400/mm3 Segmented neutrophils 80% Eosinophils 1% Lymphocytes 17% Monocytes 2% CD4+ T-lymphocytes 90/mm3 Platelet count 328,000/mm3 An MRI of the brain with contrast shows a solitary ring-enhancing lesion involving the corpus callosum and measuring 4.5 cm in diameter. A lumbar puncture with subsequent cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows slight pleocytosis, and PCR is positive for Epstein-Barr virus DNA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient has HIV and presents with neurological impairment (ataxia, apathy). Diagnosis should be based on the combination of a solitary ring-enhancing lesion on MRI and the evidence of EBV in the CSF.
learning_objective: Recognize primary CNS lymphoma in an HIV patient.

answers.explanation_why: AIDS dementia refers to the clinical syndrome of cognitive deficits, ranging from minor memory impairment to severe neurologic deficits, that frequently affects patients with AIDS. Although this patient's symptoms could potentially correspond to AIDS dementia, his MRI does not show the cerebral atrophy that would confirm such a diagnosis, but rather a ring-enhancing lesion consistent with another condition encountered in patients with HIV/AIDS.

images.title: HIV-associated dementia
images.description: MRI brain (a: T2-weighted; b: FLAIR; axial plane) of a 56-year-old patient with a history of HIV infection and longstanding weakness, confusion, and memory lossThe sulci and ventricles are prominent, which is consistent with generalized cerebral atrophy. The white matter is diffusely hyperintense (green overlay). There is no mass effect.In a patient with HIV or AIDS and no other identifiable cause of neurocognitive decline, these features suggest HIV-associated dementia.

answers.explanation_why: Primary CNS lymphoma is a non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is most commonly associated with immunosuppression (e.g., due to HIV infection) and EBV infection. Its incidence is much higher in patients with HIV/AIDS compared to the general population, and it typically occurs in patients with a CD4 count < 100/mm^3. Primary CNS lymphoma usually manifests with focal neurological deficits, neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g., personality changes), and headaches. Seizures may also occur but are less common. MRI of the brain with contrast typically shows a large (> 4 cm), solitary, ring-enhancing lesion. The diagnosis is confirmed with brain biopsy (when feasible).

images.title: Ring-enhancing lesions in the brain
images.description: MRI head (A and B: T1-weighted, with contrast; C: FLAIR; axial plane) of a patient with HIV-associated primary CNS lymphomaRing-enhancing lesions in the right thalamus (A) and left frontal lobe (B) have central, low-signal intensity (hatched green overlay), suggesting necrosis. Hyperintense edema (green overlay) surrounds both lesions on the FLAIR sequence. Prominent sulci and ventricles reflect mild, generalized cerebral volume loss.Toxoplasmosis and primary CNS lymphoma in patients with HIV/AIDS can have similar appearances, and further workup is needed if MRI cannot distinguish between them.

answers.explanation_why: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a demyelinating disease of the CNS. It is an AIDS-defining condition and is caused by reactivation of the JC virus. It does not cause ring-enhancing cerebral lesions on imaging but rather non-enhancing disseminated lesions. Furthermore, CSF analysis in PML shows JC virus DNA on PCR, not EBV DNA.

images.title: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
images.description: MRI head (left: T2-weighted; right: diffusion-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with common variable immunodeficiency syndromeA confluent, hyperintense area (green overlay) without mass effect is seen in the right frontoparietal subcortical white matter. High signal intensity on the diffusion-weighted image (red overlay) indicates diffusion restriction.The MRI features and immunocompromised state suggest progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), even though PML lesions are typically multifocal, bilateral, and asymmetric. PML lesions generally show little or no mass effect or contrast enhancement.

answers.explanation_why: A bacterial brain abscess, or pus-filled cavity caused by a bacterial infection within the brain, is an important potential cause of ring-enhancing cerebral lesions in patients with HIV/AIDS. Causative organisms include Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, Salmonella, Nocardia, Rhodococcus, and Listeria. Although bacterial abscesses can cause ring-enhancing lesions in this patient population, they are not the most common cause and have no special association with EBV in the CSF.

images.title: Ring-enhancing lesion left temporal lobe
images.description: MRI head (T1 weighted; with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with a history of left advanced otitis mediaIn the left temporal lobe, there is an oval lesion with ring-like contrast enhancement (green outline), central low signal intensity necrosis (green hatching), and perifocal edema (white area). The walls of the left ear canal and middle ear are thickened and show contrast enhancement consistent with otitis media and otitis externa.The appearance of the temporal lobe lesion is compatible with an abscess. Examples of other brain lesions that may show ring enhancement include cerebral toxoplasmosis, primary CNS lymphoma, glioblastoma, and metastasis.

answers.explanation_why: Cerebral toxoplasmosis is the most common neurological AIDS-defining illness and is the most important differential diagnosis in this patient. Reactivation of Toxoplasma gondii usually manifests in the CNS, leading to neurological features (fever, headache, impaired vigilance, seizures, and focal neurological deficits) and ring-enhancing cerebral lesions on imaging. For this reason, patients with HIV with a CD4 count < 100/mm^3 are typically started on toxoplasmosis prophylaxis with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, as this patient was, making toxoplasmosis a less likely diagnosis.

images.title: Internal capsule lesion in neurotoxoplasmosis
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with cerebral toxoplasmosisA small nodule (hatched overlay) in the right internal capsule is accompanied by hyperintense perilesional edema (solid overlay).Neurotoxoplasmosis more commonly manifests with multiple lesions and it has a propensity for the corticomedullary junction, thalami, and basal ganglia. It is a leading cerebral opportunistic infection in patients with AIDS.

answers.explanation_why: Glioblastoma multiforme is the most common primary malignant brain tumor in adults. It presents with headaches, personality changes, seizures, and/or other neurological deficits. It may appear as a ring-enhancing lesion on imaging, but in patients with HIV/AIDS, there are several other more common causes of ring-enhancing lesions.

images.title: Mass effect from glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV astrocytoma)
images.description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a 69-year old man with a history of personality changes and left-sided hemiparesis from glioblastomaThe right cerebral hemisphere is diffusely abnormal, with intermixed hypodense (green overlay), isodense, and hyperdense (red overlay) areas. There is mass effect with sulcal effacement and midline shift to the left (dashed line). The frontal and occipital horns (arrowheads) of the right lateral ventricle are effaced.Yellow overlay: choroid plexus calcification
Blue overlay: falx cerebri calcification

question_text: The patient is admitted to the hospital. A stereotactic brain biopsy of the suspicious lesion is performed and shows many large lymphocytes with irregular nuclei. Ophthalmological examination including fundoscopy and slit lamp examination discloses no evidence of intraocular lesions. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis and a bone marrow biopsy show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: The patient is admitted to the hospital. A stereotactic brain biopsy of the suspicious lesion is performed and shows many large lymphocytes with irregular nuclei. Ophthalmological examination including fundoscopy and slit lamp examination discloses no evidence of intraocular lesions. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis and a bone marrow biopsy show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has primary CNS lymphoma (PCNSL).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate treatment for primary CNS lymphoma.

answers.explanation_why: Ganciclovir is used to treat cytomegalovirus (CMV) encephalitis, which can cause neurological deficits and cognitive dysfunction and most commonly affects immunocompromised patients. However, CMV encephalitis is usually seen in patients with a CD4^+  cell count < 50/mm^3, and causes periventricular white matter lesions that are diffusely contrast-enhancing rather than a solitary ring-enhancing lesion. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) rather than CMV is implicated in the pathogenesis of PCNSL and there are no approved antivirals that specifically target EBV.

Interferon-alpha is used to treat AIDS-related Kaposi sarcoma, hairy cell leukemia, cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, and certain aggressive cases of follicular non-Hodgkin lymphoma but is not used to treat PCNSL.
A combination of pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine is the treatment of choice in patients with cerebral toxoplasmosis, not PCNSL.

Combination chemotherapy using a regimen with high-dose methotrexate is the treatment of choice in patients with confirmed PCNSL. Systemic glucocorticoids rapidly decrease the size of a PCNSL and can alleviate tumor-related symptoms but should only be started after a brain biopsy has been obtained. Radiotherapy is indicated if the patient has a poor functional status (i.e., not a candidate for chemotherapy) and for patients with intraorbital or spinal cord lesions. Surgical resection is not typically a part of the management of the PCNSL. In patients with HIV-related PCNSL, administering antiretroviral therapy concurrently with definitive cancer treatment is essential for facilitating immune reconstitution.

Most PCNSLs are multifocal, deep-seated tumors that do not have a distinct capsule. Surgical resection carries the risk of causing neurological deficits and tumor seeding in other parts of the brain for most PCNSLs. In addition, most studies show no survival benefit in patients who undergo surgical resection of PCNSL as sole therapy.

question_text: One day after undergoing left carotid endarterectomy, a 63-year-old man has a severe headache. He describes it as 9 out of 10 in intensity. He has nausea. He had 80% stenosis in the left carotid artery and received heparin prior to the surgery. He has a history of two transient ischemic attacks, which occurred two and four months ago, respectively. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He drinks 1–2 beers on weekends. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Examination shows pupils that react sluggishly to light. There is a right facial droop. Muscle strength is decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the right. There is a left cervical surgical incision that shows no erythema or discharge. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, electrolytes, and glucose are within the reference range. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
content_preview: One day after undergoing left carotid endarterectomy, a 63-year-old man has a severe headache. He describes it as 9 out of 10 in intensity. He has nausea. He had 80% stenosis in the left carotid artery and received heparin prior to the surgery. He has a history of two transient ischemic attacks, which occurred two and four months ago, respectively. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He drinks 1–2 beers on weekends. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Examination shows pupils that react sluggishly to light. There is a right facial droop. Muscle strength is decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the right. There is a left cervical surgical incision that shows no erythema or discharge. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, electrolytes, and glucose are within the reference range. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient has clinical features of a stroke (e.g., facial droop, right-sided hemiparesis, hyperreflexia, headache) and a CT scan of the head that shows intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH; hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema) in the left hemisphere.
learning_objective: Recognize intracerebral hemorrhage, and recall its strongest predisposing factor.

answers.explanation_why: Carotid artery stenosis is a risk factor for embolic (through carotid plaque emboli) and thrombotic (through carotid plaque thrombosis) ischemic stroke. Carotid stroke and intracerebral hemorrhage also share multiple risk factors. However, patients with early signs of ischemic stroke on noncontrast CT typically have hypodense parenchyma and loss of grey-white matter differentiation; this patient has a hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema, which indicates ICH.

images.title: Subacute posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)A hypodense occipital infarct (green) in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery is accompanied by a loss of normal gray-white matter differentiation. The density of the lesion is greater than that of CSF. There is no mass effect or hemorrhage. Choroid plexus calcifications in the lateral ventricles are physiologic.

answers.explanation_why: Aspirin inhibits platelet aggregation, theoretically predisposing patients to bleeding such as intracerebral hemorrhage. However, aspirin therapy only minimally increases the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage, if at all.

The risk of intracerebral hemorrhage is directly correlated with the degree of anticoagulation (e.g., by heparin). However, anticoagulation is not the strongest risk factor for intracerebral hemorrhage.

Arterial hypertension is the single most important predisposing factor for atraumatic intracerebral hemorrhage. Chronic hypertension results in lipohyalinosis of the arterial walls, leading to microaneurysm formation and elevated risk of rupture. Acute hypertension then leads to rupture of the weakened vessels, which likely was the mechanism of rupture in this patient.

Management of intracerebral hemorrhage depends on the intracranial pressure (ICP) of the patient. If ICP is normal, blood pressure should be decreased to < 160 mm Hg through labetalol or nicardipine administration. If intracranial hypertension is suspected (as is likely in this patient, given his altered mental status and sluggishly reactive pupils), blood pressure should be lowered more cautiously, as cerebral perfusion must be maintained. Finally, if herniation is suspected (e.g., uncal herniation), emergency craniotomy is required.

images.title: Basal ganglia hemorrhage
images.description: Hemorrhage in the region of the left basal ganglia causing a midline shift to the rightThe basal ganglia are supplied by the lenticulostriate arteries, which arise from the middle cerebral artery. Hemorrhage from a lenticulostriate artery (e.g., due to poorly controlled hypertension or rupture of a Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm) leads to a basal ganglia hemorrhage.

answers.explanation_why: Smoking does increase the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage in a dose-response relationship. The mechanism is likely multifactorial and includes both increased blood pressure and arterial wall damage associated with smoking. However, it is not the strongest risk factor for intracerebral hemorrhage.

images.title: Basal ganglia hemorrhage
images.description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of chronic hypertensionHyperdense hemorrhage in the left basal ganglia is surrounded by hypodense perifocal edema (red overlay).The location is typical for hemorrhage from the lenticulostriate arteries as a result of long-standing hypertension.1: head of caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3 and green overlay: internal capsule; 4: thalamus
Arrowheads: calcified pineal gland; white circles: calcified choroid plexus

question_text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but reports occasional episodes of slurred speech and weakness during the past 6 months. He has a history of peripheral arterial disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gout. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He drinks 3 cans of beer daily. His current medications include aspirin, metformin, enalapril, simvastatin, and febuxostat. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Auscultation of the right side of the neck shows a bruit. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference ranges. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and no acute abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but reports occasional episodes of slurred speech and weakness during the past 6 months. He has a history of peripheral arterial disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gout. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He drinks 3 cans of beer daily. His current medications include aspirin, metformin, enalapril, simvastatin, and febuxostat. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Auscultation of the right side of the neck shows a bruit. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference ranges. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and no acute abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's occasional episodes of weakness and slurred speech are consistent with transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). This history, in combination with his peripheral vascular disease, multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia), and carotid bruit indicate symptomatic carotid artery stenosis (CAS) due to atherosclerosis.
learning_objective: Recognize symptomatic carotid artery stenosis, and choose the initial diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why:
Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is typically the first-line imaging modality for patients with symptomatic CAS (e.g., TIA, amaurosis fugax, ischemic stroke). Some guidelines also recommend ultrasonography of the neck to screen for CAS in asymptomatic patients with a carotid bruit and multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease. In patients with CAS, ultrasonography shows a focally-increased velocity of blood flow. Duplex ultrasonography is an inexpensive, noninvasive test with high specificity and sensitivity for the detection of CAS. It can also quantify the degree of stenosis.

Antiplatelet therapy, statin therapy, blood pressure control, and lifestyle changes (e.g., smoking cessation, weight control, regular exercise) are the mainstays of treatment in CAS. Carotid revascularization (typically with carotid endarterectomy) is indicated for patients with symptomatic disease and severe stenosis (≥ 70%).

Echocardiography is used to identify cardiogenic sources of emboli in patients with symptomatic ischemic neurological disease (e.g., TIA) without a clear intracranial or extracranial vascular etiology. However, this patient's physical exam revealed a carotid bruit that is likely secondary to CAS. Echocardiography would not be the next best step for evaluating CAS.

In patients with CAS, anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin) are not used for stroke prevention. Instead, antiplatelet drugs (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel) are used. Warfarin is used for stroke prevention only in patients with certain risk factors (e.g., atrial fibrillation, prosthetic heart valves).

CT angiography and MR angiography are not first-line imaging modalities in the workup of CAS, but they can be used to confirm the diagnosis if the first-line modality shows findings consistent with the condition or yields inconclusive results (e.g., due to significant carotid artery calcification). Angiography also plays a role in preoperative risk stratification and intervention planning.

answers.content: Digital subtraction angiography of the neck
answers.explanation_why: Digital subtraction angiography of the neck, which requires arterial catheterization, used to be the preferred test for evaluating CAS but it has been replaced by other modalities because it is an invasive and costly procedure that carries a ∼ 4% risk of iatrogenic neurological complications (e.g., stroke). Although it may have some utility in select patient groups (e.g., if the initial imaging modalities reveal discordant results or additional anatomic detail is needed), it would not be used as a first-line diagnostic test.

question_text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to his back during an altercation. He reports weakness and numbness of the lower extremities. He has no history of serious illness. On arrival, he is alert and cooperative. His pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm laceration on his back next to the vertebral column at the level of the T10 vertebra. Neurologic examination shows right-sided flaccid paralysis with a diminished vibratory sense ipsilaterally, decreased sensation to light touch at the level of his laceration and below, and left-sided loss of temperature and pin-prick sensation at the level of the umbilicus and below. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in his right lower extremity and 2+ in his left lower extremity. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to his back during an altercation. He reports weakness and numbness of the lower extremities. He has no history of serious illness. On arrival, he is alert and cooperative. His pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm laceration on his back next to the vertebral column at the level of the T10 vertebra. Neurologic examination shows right-sided flaccid paralysis with a diminished vibratory sense ipsilaterally, decreased sensation to light touch at the level of his laceration and below, and left-sided loss of temperature and pin-prick sensation at the level of the umbilicus and below. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in his right lower extremity and 2+ in his left lower extremity. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The dorsal columns, which are located posteromedially within the spinal cord, transmit ipsilateral proprioceptive, vibratory, and some light-touch sensations, while the anterolateral spinothalamic tracts transmit contralateral pain and temperature sensations. The posterolateral corticospinal tracts transmit ipsilateral motor impulses.
learning_objective: Recognize Brown-Séquard syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Anterior cord syndrome can occur following a stab wound as a result of damage to the aorta. It presents with complete motor paralysis (damaged corticospinal tracts), loss of pain and temperature (damaged spinothalamic tracts), and autonomic dysfunction (hypotension, bowel, or bladder dysfunction) below the level of the lesion. Unlike this patient, the deficits in a patient with an anterior cord syndrome would typically occur bilaterally, while proprioception and vibratory sensation would be preserved (intact dorsal columns).

images.title: Anterior spinal artery syndrome at T8 level
images.description: Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

answers.explanation_why: Cauda equina syndrome can occur after trauma to the lumbar spine. The syndrome may present with sensory and motor deficits in both limbs as in this patient. However, the distribution of neurological deficits is variable, and does not follow a specific lateralization pattern, as seen here. Other clinical features associated with cauda equina syndrome, such as lower back pain radiating to the leg(s), weakness of plantar flexion (S1 and S2 lesions), and bladder or rectal sphincter paralysis (S2–S4 involvement), are also not present in this patient. Moreover, the knife wound is located above the level of the cauda equina, making cauda equina syndrome an unlikely diagnosis.

images.title: Conus medullaris and cauda equina syndromes
images.description: 1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equinaWhile disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

answers.explanation_why: Brown-Séquard syndrome can occur after trauma to the spinal cord. In this patient, a right-sided hemisection of the spinal cord has resulted in right-sided flaccid paralysis (damaged right lateral corticospinal tract), as well as a right-sided loss of proprioception, tactile discrimination, and vibratory sense (damaged right dorsal column). Additionally, damage to the right spinothalamic tract has resulted in a left-sided loss of pain and temperature sensation. These symptoms are consistent with acute manifestations of Brown-Séquard syndrome. Within 1–2 weeks after the initial injury, patients typically develop an ipsilateral Babinski reflex and ipsilateral spastic paralysis. Bladder symptoms (e.g., incontinence) are generally not present, as there is only unilateral involvement of the descending autonomic fibers.

Posterior cord syndrome can occur following penetrating injury to the dorsal columns, or damage to the posterior spinal arteries. Patients would present with isolated loss of proprioception, vibratory sensation, and tactile discrimination. The posterior arteries are paired so interruption of a posterior spinal artery may only affect one side of the cord. Although this patient presents with asymmetric loss of light touch and vibratory sensation, the loss of both temperature and pinprick sensation are inconsistent with posterior cord syndrome.

Central cord syndrome is the most common injury of the cervical spinal cord. The syndrome classically presents in the setting of a hyperextension injury in individuals with chronic cervical spondylosis, resulting in a disproportionately greater loss of motor function and sensation in the upper extremities when compared to the lower extremities. This patient, however, presents with loss of proprioception and vibration sense, which suggests damage to the dorsal column. The dorsal column is usually spared in a central cord lesion. Furthermore, a knife wound is unlikely to cause isolated damage to the central spinal cord.

question_text:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling 16 feet from a ladder. He has severe pain in both his legs and his right arm. He appears pale and diaphoretic. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min and weak, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He opens his eyes and withdraws in response to painful stimuli and makes incomprehensible sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. All extremities are cold, with 1+ pulses distally. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.29

PCO_2

33 mm Hg

PO_2

65 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

15 mEq/L

A CT scan shows displaced fractures of the pelvic ring, as well as fractures of both tibiae, the right distal radius, and right proximal humerus. The patient undergoes emergent open reduction and is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following best indicates inadequate fluid resuscitation?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling 16 feet from a ladder. He has severe pain in both his legs and his right arm. He appears pale and diaphoretic. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min and weak, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He opens his eyes and withdraws in response to painful stimuli and makes incomprehensible sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. All extremities are cold, with 1+ pulses distally. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.29 PCO2 33 mm Hg PO2 65 mm Hg HCO3- 15 mEq/L A CT scan shows displaced fractures of the pelvic ring, as well as fractures of both tibiae, the right distal radius, and right proximal humerus. The patient undergoes emergent open reduction and is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following best indicates inadequate fluid resuscitation?
hint: There are many ways that physicians monitor volume status, but some are more reliable than others in the absence of confounding medications or illnesses.
learning_objective: Recognize indicators of inadequate fluid resuscitation, and recall the expected urine output for adequate end-organ perfusion.

answers.explanation_why: High pulse pressure is usually caused by an increase in stroke volume (e.g., normal exercise, aortic regurgitation) or a decrease in arterial compliance (e.g., atherosclerosis) and would likely increase following fluid resuscitation. However, pulse pressure is an indicator of stroke volume and not a direct indicator of end-organ perfusion. Fluid resuscitation aims to achieve adequate end-organ perfusion, so a change in pulse pressure is not the best indicator to evaluate fluid resuscitation.

answers.content: Urine output of 25 mL in 3 hours
answers.explanation_why:
The goal of fluid resuscitation is to maintain adequate end-organ perfusion and to restore intravascular volume. Since renal blood flow (and therefore GFR) is highly sensitive to changes in blood pressure and intravascular volume, urine output can serve as a surrogate measure to determine if fluid resuscitation is adequate. Ideally, urine output in adults should be greater than 0.5 mL/kg/hr. Therefore, a 70-kg man should have a urine output of 35–70 mL/hr. A urine output of 25mL in 3 hours suggests that his kidneys are not receiving adequate blood flow and therefore that he has not received adequate fluid resuscitation.

With adequate fluid resuscitation, an increase in some of the other indices, such as pulse pressure and Glasgow coma scale, might occur before a change in urine output is apparent. However, these parameters are not specific indicators of end-organ perfusion. Other parameters, such as lactate and a base deficit, are more useful for determining the prognosis than for guiding fluid therapy.

Confusion, lethargy, and even coma can be seen in patients with severe shock. However, a low Glasgow coma score (GCS) following trauma may be caused by a number of factors, including hypotension, hypoxia, and intracranial hemorrhage. Therefore, the GCS should not be used as a guide for fluid therapy.

An increase in serum lactate (> 4 mEq/L) may indicate tissue hypoxia due to inadequate tissue perfusion. However, serum lactate levels are not used to determine whether fluid resuscitation is inadequate because, even after adequate fluid resuscitation and correction of tissue hypoperfusion, lactate levels may not reach normal levels (< 2 mEq/L) for a few hours. Lactate clearance may take even longer in critically ill patients as a result of a prolonged lactate half-life (due to hepatic and/or renal dysfunction) and/or increased glycolysis. In trauma patients, elevated lactate levels are associated with increased mortality and are used to evaluate the prognosis.

A prolonged capillary refill time (≥ 3 seconds) is seen as a result of peripheral vasoconstriction in patients with hypotension. However, capillary refill is not the most direct measure of organ perfusion and adequate volume resuscitation, as it can be affected by confounding factors (e.g., ambient temperature, lighting, physical exam techniques, peripheral artery disease, blood viscosity).

This patient has an increased base deficit (> 2 mEq/L), which indicates metabolic acidosis (most likely due to lactic acidosis from inadequate perfusion and fluid resuscitation). Normalization of the base deficit (< 2 mmol/L) following fluid resuscitation would suggest an improvement in tissue perfusion and a more favorable prognosis, not inadequate fluid resuscitation.

question_text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He has acute myeloid leukemia and is currently receiving chemotherapy. On arrival, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and sluggish. There are multiple bruises over the face, trunk, and right upper and lower extremities. There is a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over his right cheek. He does not respond to any commands but does groan. Painful stimuli cause him to open his eyes and withdraw all extremities. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. There is tenderness to palpation over the left chest wall. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. There is swelling of the right elbow and wrist. The right lower extremity is shorter than the left lower extremity. There are 2 lacerations around 2 cm (0.8 in) each on the right leg. The right knee is swollen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He has acute myeloid leukemia and is currently receiving chemotherapy. On arrival, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and sluggish. There are multiple bruises over the face, trunk, and right upper and lower extremities. There is a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over his right cheek. He does not respond to any commands but does groan. Painful stimuli cause him to open his eyes and withdraw all extremities. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. There is tenderness to palpation over the left chest wall. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. There is swelling of the right elbow and wrist. The right lower extremity is shorter than the left lower extremity. There are 2 lacerations around 2 cm (0.8 in) each on the right leg. The right knee is swollen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 8 (groans = 2; opens eyes to pain = 2; withdraws extremities to pain = 4).
learning_objective: Recognize the need for airway protection in a patient with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 8, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: The patient does have abdominal tenderness and will require some form of assessment for intraabdominal bleeding such as a FAST scan, but only after implementing a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

A pelvic binder would address critical blood loss and help stabilize potential pelvic fractures, but it would not address the primary concern as dictated by the ABCDE approach to treating trauma patients.

An intercostal chest tube is indicated for treating tension pneumothorax (TP). The patient has decreased breath sounds at the right lung base, a finding associated with TP, but does not show other signs like tachypnea, tracheal deviation away from the affected lung, or jugular venous distention, making TP an unlikely diagnosis. The first priority for this patient with a GCS score of 8 is another very critical measure of the ATLS-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

answers.content: CT scan of the head and neck
answers.explanation_why: The patient will require imaging of the head to assess intracranial bleeding and other damage to the head and neck area. Imaging of the neck is especially important for assessment of cervical spine integrity. However, head and neck imaging can take place only after implementing a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

This patient will need evaluation of his extremities for bone and soft tissue damage, but only after implementation of a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

As a general rule, patients with a GCS score of 8 or below as a result of traumatic brain injury require intubation and mechanical ventilation to protect the airway and ensure adequate ventilation. Such patients are at risk of airway obstruction via aspiration because they lack a gag reflex. They are also at risk of hypoxia from poor ventilation because brainstem damage can decrease the respiratory drive.

question_text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after his head was hit with a bat during a baseball game. His teammates state that he was unresponsive after the incident but regained consciousness after 15 minutes. The patient initially refused to go to the hospital and sat on the bench for the remainder of the game. He initially appeared fine but became increasingly confused. He appears lethargic but opens his eyes to loud verbal commands. He is oriented to person and place. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 148/87 mm Hg. Examination shows an area of soft-tissue swelling over the left temporal region. A CT scan of the head shows a biconvex lens-shaped hyperdensity in the left frontotemporal region. After returning from the CT scan, the patient only opens his eyes to painful stimuli and responds to questions with incomprehensible sounds. He withdraws from painful stimuli. On repeat examination, the left pupil is 6 mm in diameter and reacts minimally to light. The right pupil is 3 mm in diameter and reacts normally to light. His respiratory rate is 10/min and he is intubated in the emergency department. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after his head was hit with a bat during a baseball game. His teammates state that he was unresponsive after the incident but regained consciousness after 15 minutes. The patient initially refused to go to the hospital and sat on the bench for the remainder of the game. He initially appeared fine but became increasingly confused. He appears lethargic but opens his eyes to loud verbal commands. He is oriented to person and place. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 148/87 mm Hg. Examination shows an area of soft-tissue swelling over the left temporal region. A CT scan of the head shows a biconvex lens-shaped hyperdensity in the left frontotemporal region. After returning from the CT scan, the patient only opens his eyes to painful stimuli and responds to questions with incomprehensible sounds. He withdraws from painful stimuli. On repeat examination, the left pupil is 6 mm in diameter and reacts minimally to light. The right pupil is 3 mm in diameter and reacts normally to light. His respiratory rate is 10/min and he is intubated in the emergency department. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: In a patient with head trauma, a lucid interval followed by a neurological decline together with a biconvex lens-shaped hyperdensity on CT scan is consistent with an expanding epidural hematoma.
learning_objective: Recognize an expanding epidural hematoma, and choose the most appropriate surgical intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Nonsurgical management, which includes serial head CT scans and neurological observation, may be considered in experienced neurosurgical centers for patients with small acute epidural hematomas (hematoma volume < 30 mL) with a GCS > 9, if focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiplegia, cranial nerve palsy) are absent. This patient displays signs and symptoms of severely elevated intracranial pressure (anisocoria, decrease in respiratory rate) with imminent brain herniation. Urgent treatment is indicated to prevent further neurological deterioration, permanent brain damage, and death.

Administration of hypertonic (not hypotonic) saline can help to acutely lower elevated intracranial pressure and may be used as an adjuvant treatment in this patient. It establishes an osmolarity gradient, which draws water from the interstitium across the blood-brain barrier into the vessels and thereby decreases the intracranial pressure. Hypotonic saline would do just the opposite, further increasing intracranial pressure by drawing water into the brain, and is, therefore, contraindicated in this patient.

Dexamethasone is the primary corticosteroid used to treat brain edema and elevated intracranial pressure, e.g., in a patient with a brain tumor or bacterial meningitis. However, glucocorticoids (including dexamethasone) should not be used in patients with severe traumatic head injuries because they are associated with a significant increase in acute mortality. This patient has an expanding epidural hematoma with imminent brain herniation, which warrants a more aggressive treatment approach.

Lumbar puncture (LP) is indicated in numerous neurological conditions, e.g., in patients suspected of subarachnoid hemorrhage with a negative CT. However, LP is contraindicated in any patient with suspected intracranial pressure, because the sudden loss of spinal fluid may trigger brainstem herniation. In this patient, who has obvious signs of elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., anisocoria, Cushing reflex), an LP is contraindicated.

Emergency hematoma evacuation through a burr hole may be used to treat acute epidural hematoma. However, it is only the second-line treatment because it does not always allow complete evacuation of the hematoma and/or ligation of the bleeding meningeal vessel. In centers with limited neurosurgical expertise, burr hole evacuation is an acceptable alternative, because it can be performed by general surgeons, but generally it is not the preferred surgical approach.

First-line treatment for patients with an epidural hematoma is urgent craniotomy and hematoma evacuation to prevent brain herniation resulting from the progressive increase in intracranial pressure (ICP). This procedure also helps identify and ligate the injured vessel. A delay in surgical treatment is associated with a worsening prognosis. This patient's rapid decline in consciousness (GCS is 8 following the CT scan), decrease in respiratory rate, and anisocoria suggest ongoing compression of the brain that should prompt immediate decompressive craniotomy. Further management includes countering the elevated ICP using head elevation, hyperventilation, and/or osmotic diuresis with mannitol or hyperosmotic saline solution.

images.title: Epidural hematoma
images.description: CT head (axial section; noncontrast)An epidural hematoma is visible as a solitary biconvex hyperdense lesion in the left frontotemporal region (green overlay), causing a midline shift to the contralateral side (indicated by lines and arrows). The soft tissue of the scalp overlying the lesion also appears hyperdense, indicating a scalp hematoma (red overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Although MRI has a higher sensitivity than CT, it is not the imaging test of choice for patients with epidural hematoma. It takes much longer than a CT scan, making it unsuitable for unstable patients, such as this one. This patient's CT confirms acute epidural hematoma, and further diagnostics would unnecessarily delay treatment. Urgent treatment is indicated to prevent further neurological deterioration, permanent brain damage, and death.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after falling from her bicycle 1 hour ago. The patient was on her way to work as she lost her balance, hitting her head on the sidewalk. She had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. She currently has nausea and a headache. She has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. She has no history of a serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While the remainder of the physical examination is being performed, the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and she is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after falling from her bicycle 1 hour ago. The patient was on her way to work as she lost her balance, hitting her head on the sidewalk. She had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. She currently has nausea and a headache. She has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. She has no history of a serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While the remainder of the physical examination is being performed, the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and she is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
hint: This patient had a brief recovery of consciousness (lucid interval) after experiencing head trauma, but now has signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), including nausea, headache, vomiting, seizure, and Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, and bradypnea). All of these features suggest intracranial hemorrhage most likely due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery.
learning_objective: Recognize an epidural hematoma.

answers.explanation_why: Symptoms of ischemic stroke depend on the affected area of the brain. Patients typically present with focal neurological deficits like hemiparesis and have risk factors such as diabetes or hypercholesterolemia. Additionally, seizures, elevated ICP, and a traumatic origin are all unusual findings for ischemic stroke.

Onset of symptoms in patients with subdural hematoma (SDH) depends on the size, location, and rate of growth of the SDH. In acute onset, the patient may also present with headache and signs of increased ICP immediately following head trauma. In rare cases, patients may also experience a lucid interval. However, the temporary recovery of consciousness is more commonly associated with a different diagnosis.

Intracerebral hemorrhage typically results from a spontaneous (i.e., nontraumatic) rupture of vessels secondary to structural changes of the vessel walls, e.g., in chronic hypertension or cerebral amyloid angiopathy. Patients present with headache and focal neurologic deficits, such as hemiparesis. Rarely, it is caused by a head trauma with direct damage of the vessel. Signs of increased ICP and a lucid interval are more suggestive of another diagnosis.

Subarachnoidal hemorrhages may occur spontaneously or after head trauma. Patients typically present with sudden, excruciating headaches (thunderclap headache), meningism, and loss of consciousness. While this patient also experienced headache and a loss of consciousness, signs of elevated ICP and the momentary recovery of consciousness point to another diagnosis.

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) usually presents with chronic headaches and visual symptoms (e.g., transient loss of vision) that gradually worsens over months to years. It is not associated with head trauma. While this patient is in the peak age group of IIH (15–45 years of age), she developed her symptoms rapidly following a traumatic event and does not have any visual symptoms.

An epidural hematoma should be suspected in any patient with severe head trauma and initial loss of consciousness that is followed by a lucid interval and then soon after by a new decline in mental status with signs of elevated ICP. The lucid interval represents the time it takes for blood to accumulate in the epidural space before compressing the brain and resulting in clinical deterioration. The length of the lucid interval depends on the severity of the trauma and the intensity of the bleeding and is typically shorter in patients with bleeding from the meningeal arteries compared to patients who bleed from a torn bridging vein (as seen with subdural hematomas).

images.title: Pathophysiology of an epidural hematoma
images.description: Most epidural hematomas (EDH) are caused by a rupture/tear of the middle meningeal artery secondary to a traumatic head injury, typically associated with a skull fracture. The resulting hemorrhage separates the dura mater from the inner aspect of the calvarium and accumulates within the epidural space. As the dura mater is tightly adherent at the skull suture lines, an EDH does not extend beyond the sutures. An EDH would be seen on neuroimaging as a biconvex hyperdense lesion that does not cross the suture lines.

question_text: A 77-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of headache, nausea, and vomiting for 24 hours. His wife says that over the past 2 weeks, he has been more irritable and has had trouble remembering to do routine errands. Two weeks ago, he fell during a skiing accident but did not lose consciousness. He has coronary artery disease and hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. He has had 2 glasses of wine daily since his retirement 10 years ago. Current medications include atenolol, enalapril, furosemide, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He appears acutely ill. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. During the examination, he is uncooperative and unable to answer questions. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the left and 2+ on the right. Babinski sign is present on the left. There is mild weakness of the left iliopsoas and hamstring muscles. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a high-density, 15-mm crescentic collection across the right hemispheric convexity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 77-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of headache, nausea, and vomiting for 24 hours. His wife says that over the past 2 weeks, he has been more irritable and has had trouble remembering to do routine errands. Two weeks ago, he fell during a skiing accident but did not lose consciousness. He has coronary artery disease and hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. He has had 2 glasses of wine daily since his retirement 10 years ago. Current medications include atenolol, enalapril, furosemide, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He appears acutely ill. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. During the examination, he is uncooperative and unable to answer questions. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the left and 2+ on the right. Babinski sign is present on the left. There is mild weakness of the left iliopsoas and hamstring muscles. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a high-density, 15-mm crescentic collection across the right hemispheric convexity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: An older patient with a recent history of a fall and presenting with signs of increased intracranial pressure (headache, nausea, vomiting), altered mental status, and focal neurological signs raises concern for subacute subdural hematoma (SDH). The CT findings of a crescentic bleed confirm the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize subacute subdural hematoma, and choose the most appropriate management for increased intracranial pressure and neurological deterioration.

answers.content: Obtain an MRI of the head
answers.explanation_why: An MRI of the head is more sensitive than a CT scan for the detection of intracranial hemorrhage. However, CT scan of the head is the most widely used imaging study for acute head trauma because of its speed, simplicity, relative affordability, and widespread availability. Since a CT scan has already confirmed this patient's diagnosis, further confirmation with an MRI is not needed at this time.

Recombinant tissue-type plasminogen activator is used in the treatment of ischemic stroke. This patient has a subdural hemorrhage confirmed by CT, which is an absolute contraindication for thrombolytic therapy because it increases the risk of further hemorrhage.

A lumbar puncture (LP) is used in the diagnosis of suspected subarachnoid hemorrhage after a negative CT. This patient's CT scan showed a crescentic hemorrhage, so LP would not be indicated. LP would also place the patient at risk for transtentorial herniation because of increased intracranial pressure, as indicated by his cognitive impairment and worsening neurologic status.

The patient has symptoms of cognitive impairment and neurological decompensation with a hematoma > 10 mm on noncontrast CT scan of the head. Observation would not be the most appropriate next step in management in this case. Observation would be appropriate if the patient were clinical stable with no signs of brain herniation or neurologic impairment.

In closed head injuries, rapid deceleration can cause shearing of the bridging veins that drain from the surface of the brain to the dural sinuses, leading to SDH. In cases of mild trauma, SDH can develop slowly and only provoke noticeable symptoms after days to weeks. Both this patient's age and alcohol consumption contribute to brain atrophy and stretching of the bridging veins, making him particularly susceptible to SDH. Management involves CT scan of the head without contrast and urgent surgical evacuation if there is evidence of neurological deterioration, the SDH is ≥ 10 mm, or there is midline shift ≥ 5 mm on brain scan.

images.title: Left subdural hematoma
images.description: CT head (axial view)A hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion (green hatched overlay) is visible over the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere. There is also a diffuse, hypodense area in the left hemisphere (green overlay) due to white matter edema and midline shift to the right (green line).These findings are characteristic of a left subdural hematoma.

answers.explanation_why: Electroencephalography is not indicated for the diagnosis or management of subdural hematoma. Electroencephalogram (EEG) is the diagnostic study of choice for the evaluation of epileptic seizures. EEG would be indicated if the patient had presented with a seizure and the CT failed to identify a cause.

question_text: A 76-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an episode of seeing jagged edges followed by loss of central vision in his right eye. The episode occurred 6 hours ago and lasted approximately 5 minutes. The patient has no pain. He has a 3-month history of intermittent blurriness out of his right eye and reports a 10-minute episode of slurred speech and left-sided facial droop that occurred 2 months ago. He has hypercholesterolemia, stable angina pectoris, hypertension, and a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include glyburide, atorvastatin, labetalol, isosorbide, lisinopril, and aspirin. He feels well. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 154/78 mm Hg. The extremities are well perfused with strong peripheral pulses. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/30 in the left eye and 20/40 in the right eye. Visual fields are normal. Fundoscopic examination shows two grayish-white spots along the supratemporal and inferotemporal arcade. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Cardiopulmonary examination shows systolic rumbling at the right carotid artery. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no evidence of ischemia. In addition to obtaining a CT scan of the head, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 76-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an episode of seeing jagged edges followed by loss of central vision in his right eye. The episode occurred 6 hours ago and lasted approximately 5 minutes. The patient has no pain. He has a 3-month history of intermittent blurriness out of his right eye and reports a 10-minute episode of slurred speech and left-sided facial droop that occurred 2 months ago. He has hypercholesterolemia, stable angina pectoris, hypertension, and a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include glyburide, atorvastatin, labetalol, isosorbide, lisinopril, and aspirin. He feels well. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 154/78 mm Hg. The extremities are well perfused with strong peripheral pulses. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/30 in the left eye and 20/40 in the right eye. Visual fields are normal. Fundoscopic examination shows two grayish-white spots along the supratemporal and inferotemporal arcade. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Cardiopulmonary examination shows systolic rumbling at the right carotid artery. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no evidence of ischemia. In addition to obtaining a CT scan of the head, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Sudden, painless, transient monocular loss of vision with cloudy discoloration along the retinal arterial supply on fundoscopy is highly suggestive of retinal artery occlusion. The most common cause in older adults is atherosclerotic emboli, which is consistent with this patient's age, extensive atherosclerotic risk factors (hypercholesterolemia, stable angina pectoris, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus), history of possible transient ischemic attack, and finding of an ipsilateral carotid bruit on examination.
learning_objective: Recognize retinal artery occlusion secondary to atherosclerotic emboli, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Echocardiography is used to evaluate for cardiac causes of retinal vessel occlusion and TIA, such as emboli due to atrial fibrillation. Cardiogenic emboli are the most common cause of retinal artery occlusion in younger patients (< 40 years of age) and should be suspected based on a patient history that includes, e.g., atrial fibrillation (AF), endocarditis, or valvular disease. However, while this patient does have a history and exam findings that both suggest retinal vessel occlusion and a TIA, he has no AF and there are signs of carotid artery stenosis. Echocardiography would be an appropriate step in management only after atherosclerotic causes of this patient's symptoms have been ruled out.

Fluorescein angiography allows for visualization of flow through the retinal vessels and may be used to diagnose a variety of retinal disorders, such as macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathy, and retinal vascular occlusions. While fluorescein angiography might show slow or absent filling of retinal arteries in retinal artery occlusion, it is usually indicated when the diagnosis is not otherwise clear, e.g., when ischemic retinal whitening is not clearly present on fundoscopy. In this case, such findings are apparent, as is the diagnosis of retinal artery occlusion. Fluorescein angiography would not contribute significantly to this patient's care.

Reassurance and follow-up might be appropriate in a patient with transient vision loss secondary to a benign etiology. For example, migraine is the most common cause of transient binocular vision loss in young adults. This patient's vision loss was transient and he has a history of intermittent blurriness that could be consistent with migrainous aura, but the lack of other migraine symptoms, along with the monocular presentation, make the diagnosis of migrainous aura unlikely.

Temporal artery biopsy could conclusively evaluate for the presence of giant cell arteritis (GCA), which can result in permanent vision loss if untreated. Suspicion of GCA should be especially high in patients above the age of 50 with fundoscopy findings of pallid optic disc swelling without apparent emboli. While our patient's monocular vision loss and history of intermittent monocular blurriness could be consistent with GCA, he lacks additional symptoms such as temporal headache or jaw claudication, and his fundus examination reveals clearly demarcated areas of vascular involvement, which is not consistent with GCA. A temporal artery biopsy is therefore not indicated.

images.title: Polymyalgia rheumatica and giant cell arteritis fact sheet

answers.explanation_why:
Carotid duplex ultrasonography is the best next step in the management of a patient with transient retinal artery occlusion secondary to atherosclerotic emboli. This procedure allows for the assessment of the carotid arteries for atherosclerotic plaques and vessel stenosis, and thus the patient's candidacy for treatment options (e.g., antiplatelet therapy, carotid endarterectomy).

Retinal vessel occlusion is primarily a clinical diagnosis, so confirmatory testing is generally not indicated, except in unusual cases. This patient presented with classic history and exam findings, making testing unnecessary in his case. Instead, the diagnostic focus is on the cause of occlusion, which might be cardiovascular or inflammatory disease.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has back pain and numbness in her lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy 3856 g (8 lb 8 oz) newborn male. She had a placental abruption and lost approximately 2000 mL of blood. During the procedure, she received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below her waist. She feels the vibrations of a tuning fork placed on both of her great toes. Muscle strength is 0/5 in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has back pain and numbness in her lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy 3856 g (8 lb 8 oz) newborn male. She had a placental abruption and lost approximately 2000 mL of blood. During the procedure, she received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below her waist. She feels the vibrations of a tuning fork placed on both of her great toes. Muscle strength is 0/5 in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The dorsal columns, which are located posteromedially within the spinal cord, transmit ipsilateral proprioceptive, vibratory, and some light-touch sensation, while the anterolateral spinothalamic tracts transmit contralateral pain and temperature sensations. The anterior corticospinal tracts transmit ipsilateral motor impulses.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior spinal artery syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Tabes dorsalis, which is the result of tertiary syphilis, affects the dorsal columns and manifests with an isolated loss of proprioception. Flaccid paralysis with pain and temperature deficits is typically not seen in tabes dorsalis. Furthermore, tabes dorsalis typically occurs after many years of infection with syphilis and proprioceptive deficits evolve slowly. The acute onset of this patient's symptoms makes tabes dorsalis unlikely.

Anterior spinal artery syndrome (ASA syndrome) is a loss of function of the part of the spinal cord supplied by the anterior spinal artery, which includes the descending corticospinal tract fibers (resulting in bilateral flaccid paralysis and loss of deep tendon reflexes in the acute phase), the ascending spinothalamic tracts (causing bilateral pain/temperature sensation loss), and autonomic fibers (resulting in hypotension). The anterior spinal cord is at increased risk for infarction because it is supplied by the single anterior spinal artery, which has few collaterals. Therefore, significant blood loss, as seen in this patient, can lead to ischemic infarction of the anterior spinal cord.

In patients with ASA syndrome vibration and proprioception are typically preserved because the dorsal column, which is supplied by posterior spinal arteries, remains intact.

images.title: Anterior spinal artery syndrome at T8 level
images.description: Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

answers.explanation_why: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) usually manifests with ascending flaccid paralysis that develops over the course of hours to weeks. Patients may have a prodrome of painful sensations and typically have an antecedent viral or gastrointestinal illness such as Campylobacter enterocolitis. Although this patient has flaccid paralysis, her paralysis began without an ascending course or prodromal symptoms. Furthermore, in GBS, the patient is areflexic in all joints, and pain and temperature sensation are relatively preserved. This patient has 2+ reflexes in her upper extremities and has lost significant pain and temperature sensation, making GBS unlikely.

Brown-Séquard syndrome occurs when either the right or the left half of the spinal cord is damaged. Unlike this patient's bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and preserved proprioception, Brown-Séquard syndrome manifests with ipsilateral weakness and loss of proprioception, as well as pain and temperature deficits contralaterally.

Posterior spinal artery syndrome results in loss of proprioception, vibratory sensation, and diminished two-point discrimination at and below the level of the injury. This patient has preserved vibratory sensation as demonstrated by the tuning fork. In addition, the condition is not very common because the posterior cord is supplied by two posterior spinal arteries with collateral blood supply from reticulospinal arteries.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 1 hour after falling off his bike and landing head-first on the pavement. His mother says that he did not lose consciousness but has been agitated and complaining about a headache since the event. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. There is a large bruise on the anterior scalp and several superficial abrasions on both hands and knees. Examination, including neurologic examination, shows no other abnormalities. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows a nondepressed linear skull fracture with a 2-mm separation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 1 hour after falling off his bike and landing head-first on the pavement. His mother says that he did not lose consciousness but has been agitated and complaining about a headache since the event. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. There is a large bruise on the anterior scalp and several superficial abrasions on both hands and knees. Examination, including neurologic examination, shows no other abnormalities. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows a nondepressed linear skull fracture with a 2-mm separation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with agitation and headache, both of which can be signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for a child with a skull fracture and signs of potentially elevated intracranial pressure.

answers.explanation_why: Although asymptomatic patients with relatively small (< 3 mm) linear, nondepressed skull fractures may be sent home without further management, those with signs of potentially elevated ICP require further inpatient observation. Other indications for inpatient observation include evidence of traumatic brain injury on imaging (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage), signs of physical abuse, or caregivers who are unreliable or unable to return if neurological deficits develop within 24 hours after release.

Asymptomatic patients with relatively small, linear skull fractures (< 3 mm) without depression may be sent home if a caregiver is able to properly monitor the patient for signs of altered consciousness or other new neurological symptoms for 24 hours. This patient exhibits signs of potential elevated ICP (e.g., headache, agitated state), which requires another action at this time.

Contacting child protective services is not necessary because this patient does not have identifiable signs of physical abuse (e.g., subdural hemorrhages, buckle fractures, fractures showing different states of healing on x-ray) and thus his injury was most likely accidental.

A brain MRI is a costly imaging modality that would not provide additional useful information for the management of this patient based on his current presentation. It may be indicated for patients in which the clinical picture is inconsistent with the CT scan findings (e.g., a patient with a worsening condition despite a normal CT scan), or if diffuse axonal injury may be suspected (acceleration/deceleration injuries or rotational injuries). The primary clinical manifestation of diffuse axonal injury is loss of consciousness; an MRI may be indicated in this child if he develops any deficits in consciousness.
CT angiography would be indicated for the evaluation of patients with cerebral aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations but does not play a role in the management of patients with acute head trauma.
