question_text: A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of sudden-onset headache associated with nausea and vomiting. The patient reports that she was sitting at her desk when the headache began. The headache is global and radiates to her neck. The patient has hypertension. Her father had a stroke at the age of 58 years. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 10 years. She drinks alcohol occasionally. She appears to be in severe distress. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Cranial nerves II–XII are intact. She has no focal motor or sensory deficits. She flexes her hips and knees when her neck is flexed while lying in a supine position. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
content_preview: A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of sudden-onset headache associated with nausea and vomiting. The patient reports that she was sitting at her desk when the headache began. The headache is global and radiates to her neck. The patient has hypertension. Her father had a stroke at the age of 58 years. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 10 years. She drinks alcohol occasionally. She appears to be in severe distress. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Cranial nerves II–XII are intact. She has no focal motor or sensory deficits. She flexes her hips and knees when her neck is flexed while lying in a supine position. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
hint: Sudden-onset severe headache with meningeal signs (Brudzinski sign, nausea, vomiting, fever) and the CT scan findings of hyperdensity in the basal cistern suggest subarachnoid hemorrhage.
learning_objective: Recognize subarachnoid hemorrhage, and choose the most appropriate intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Vancomycin and ceftriaxone are drugs recommended for the treatment of bacterial meningitis. Although this patient has some features consistent with bacterial meningitis, such as headache, nausea, vomiting, fever, and signs of meningism, symptoms tend to progress over the course of a few hours or days, unlike the abrupt onset seen here. A nonenhanced CT scan might show cerebral edema or mild hydrocephalus, but intracranial hemorrhage would not be present.

Alteplase, a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, is indicated for acute ischemic stroke. This patient has risk factors for ischemic stroke, such as smoking and hypertension. Although ischemic stroke sometimes manifests with headache, nausea, and vomiting, these are not characteristic features. Furthermore, this patient does not have focal neurological deficits, which are expected in ischemic stroke. Additionally, acute ischemic stroke does not manifest with features of meningism, and this patient's CT findings are not characteristic of ischemic stroke. In patients with findings that suggest intracranial hemorrhage, thrombolytic agents such as alteplase are contraindicated.

Aspirin and atorvastatin are administered to patients with ischemic stroke to reduce the risk of a subsequent stroke. This patient has risk factors for ischemic stroke, such as smoking and hypertension. Although ischemic stroke sometimes manifests with headache, nausea, and vomiting, these are not characteristic features. Furthermore, this patient does not have focal neurological deficits, which are expected in ischemic stroke. Additionally, acute ischemic stroke does not manifest with features of meningism, and this patient's CT findings are not characteristic of ischemic stroke.

Burr hole surgery may be indicated for the treatment of subdural hematoma, which may manifest with headache, nausea, and vomiting. However, the condition does not usually cause meningeal signs and most cases occur following trauma. Lastly, a CT scan in acute subdural hematoma would show a crescent-shaped, extra-axial hyperdense collection.

images.title: Subdural hematoma and cerebral edema
images.description: CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window) of a patient with a history of traumaA large acute subdural hematoma is visible as a hyperdense crescent-shaped lesion along the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere (red overlay). It is accompanied by an extracranial soft tissue hematoma (hatched red overlay). There is extensive hypodense left cerebral edema (gray overlay), with sulcal effacement and shift of midline structures (green line) to the right. The anterior horns of the lateral ventricles (hatched green overlay) are compressed and the posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle (red circle) is dilated.

answers.explanation_why: A decompressive craniectomy may be used to decrease intracranial pressure in patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage if they are at increased risk of cerebral herniation. This patient is hemodynamically stable and does not have cranial nerve palsies or evidence of a midline shift on CT scan to suggest that she is at increased risk of herniation.

Ruptured aneurysms are the most common cause of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). Surgical clipping or endovascular coiling are used in the treatment of aneurysms to prevent rebleeding; the choice of option is based on a variety of factors, such as the location and size of the aneurysm, severity of neurological deficits, and the patient's age. CT angiography is used to identify the location of the aneurysm before either clipping or coiling is performed. Other measures that should be undertaken immediately include blood pressure control (e.g., with labetalol or calcium channel blockers), vasospasm prevention (e.g., with nimodipine), and control of elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., head-of-bed elevation, administration of mannitol, intubation, and controlled hyperventilation).

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage in the basal cisterns
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Hyperdensity (green overlay) in the basal cisterns indicates the presence of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

question_text: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of facial drooping on the left side since awakening that morning. He had difficulty chewing his food at breakfast. He was treated the previous day at the hospital after sustaining a head injury from falling off of a ladder. A CT scan of the head showed no abnormalities. He is in no apparent distress. His vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is drooping on the left corner of the mouth. The left nasolabial fold is flattened. When he is asked to close both eyes, his left eye remains partially open. When he is asked to raise his eyebrows, there are no wrinkles on the left side of his forehead. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of facial drooping on the left side since awakening that morning. He had difficulty chewing his food at breakfast. He was treated the previous day at the hospital after sustaining a head injury from falling off of a ladder. A CT scan of the head showed no abnormalities. He is in no apparent distress. His vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is drooping on the left corner of the mouth. The left nasolabial fold is flattened. When he is asked to close both eyes, his left eye remains partially open. When he is asked to raise his eyebrows, there are no wrinkles on the left side of his forehead. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Facial muscle paralysis (lagophthalmos of the left eye, drooping of the left corner of the mouth) that does not spare the ipsilateral forehead is consistent with peripheral facial nerve palsy.
learning_objective: Recognize peripheral facial nerve palsy, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why:
Peripheral facial nerve palsy following facial trauma is caused by temporal bone fracture or trauma. Management typically depends on symptom onset. Acute onset of symptoms following facial trauma is usually caused by nerve injury (e.g., transection); therefore, surgery (e.g., nerve repair) may be indicated. A delayed presentation (e.g., one day after trauma) is most likely secondary to edema within the facial nerve canal. In this patient, corticosteroid therapy is indicated to control swelling within the facial nerve canal. If this patient's facial nerve palsy does not improve or worsens, surgical decompression of the facial nerve canal is indicated.

Proper eye care with artificial tears and moisturizing ointments is an important part of managing lagophthalmos.
The patient presents with delayed facial nerve palsy following trauma. Given the underlying traumatic etiology and the fact that he is symptomatic, reassurance alone is not indicated.

In a patient with delayed facial nerve palsy following traumatic injury, surgical decompression is only indicated if the presenting symptoms do not improve or continue to worsen with first-line therapy (short course of high-dose steroids). Surgical decompression of the facial nerve puts the patient at risk for further injury to an already injured nerve, may prolong or prevent nerve recovery, and carries the risk of additional complications such as hearing loss, vestibular function loss, cerebrospinal fluid leaks, and meningitis.

Acyclovir therapy is appropriate for Bell palsy or facial palsy from a viral infection (e.g., herpes zoster). Although the patient presents with clinical features associated with Bell palsy (e.g. lagophthalmos, flattened nasolabial fold, drooping of a corner of the mouth), his facial palsy is likely the result of his recent trauma. In addition, the patient does not report dermatomal pain or vesicles near the external meatus, which would be expected in herpes zoster.

Primary nerve repair with good nerve approximation may reduce the degree of facial paralysis, and would be the appropriate step in management if there was direct transection of the facial nerve. However, the patient presented with delayed facial nerve palsy (one day after the traumatic event), which indicates that nerve transection is not the underlying pathology in this patient. Moreover, the CT scan does not show evidence of a transverse fracture of the temporal bone nor is there a penetrating injury near the cheek to suggest facial nerve transection.

question_text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of persistent headaches for the last 2 months. The symptoms started insidiously. Menses had previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 12 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband but reports decreased interest in sexual intercourse over the past few months. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A pelvic ultrasound shows atrophic endometrium. A cranial MRI with contrast shows a 2-cm intrasellar mass. A hormone assay confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of persistent headaches for the last 2 months. The symptoms started insidiously. Menses had previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 12 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband but reports decreased interest in sexual intercourse over the past few months. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A pelvic ultrasound shows atrophic endometrium. A cranial MRI with contrast shows a 2-cm intrasellar mass. A hormone assay confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
hint: This patient presents with persistent headaches, decreased libido, atrophic endometrium, and secondary amenorrhea, all of which suggest a pituitary adenoma. The intrasellar mass seen on the cranial MRI and a positive hormone assay confirm the suspected diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize a prolactinoma, and choose the most appropriate initial treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is a second-line treatment for prolactinoma that is only indicated if conservative treatment fails.

Cabergoline, a dopamine agonist, is the first-line treatment for symptomatic prolactinoma regardless of tumor size. Dopamine agonists inhibit the release of prolactin from the anterior pituitary gland, leading to decreased symptoms of hyperprolactinemia and a reduction in tumor size. Treatment for prolactinoma is indicated in all symptomatic patients (e.g., those with galactorrhea, hypogonadism) or in patients with existing or impending signs of mass effect (e.g., visual impairments, headaches).

Because bromocriptine is more likely to cause side effects (e.g., nausea) and is less effective than cabergoline, it is the second-line treatment for prolactinoma. Surgery may only be considered in patients for whom pharmacological treatment has been unsuccessful or cannot be tolerated.

images.title: Pituitary mass 2/2
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactinA large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: Radiotherapy is sometimes used as adjuvant therapy for prolactinoma after surgical treatment, but would not be used as a first-line treatment for prolactinoma.

Observation and monitoring are indicated for asymptomatic, nonsecretory pituitary adenomas and can also be considered in small, asymptomatic prolactinomas (microadenomas). However, since this patient is symptomatic (headache, amenorrhea, decreased libido), treatment is indicated.

Domperidone therapy exacerbates the symptoms of prolactinoma because this dopamine antagonist decreases the inhibiting role of dopamine on prolactin release, thereby further worsening hyperprolactinemia.

Biopsy is an invasive procedure that is rarely used to assess intrasellar masses because most masses can be diagnosed with hormonal and clinical assessment. If a biopsy is indicated, a resection of the entire mass is likely to be necessary. Because this patient's diagnosis is confirmed, a biopsy is not required.

question_text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-hour history of severe, sudden-onset generalized headache. The pain began while he was at home watching television and worsened within minutes. He has since developed nausea and has had one episode of vomiting. Six days ago, he experienced a severe headache and vague neck discomfort that resolved without treatment. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His current medications include lisinopril/hydrochlorothiazide and simvastatin. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 162/98 mm Hg. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Fundoscopic examination shows no swelling of the optic discs. Cranial nerves II–XII are intact. He has no focal motor or sensory deficits. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-hour history of severe, sudden-onset generalized headache. The pain began while he was at home watching television and worsened within minutes. He has since developed nausea and has had one episode of vomiting. Six days ago, he experienced a severe headache and vague neck discomfort that resolved without treatment. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His current medications include lisinopril/hydrochlorothiazide and simvastatin. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 162/98 mm Hg. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Fundoscopic examination shows no swelling of the optic discs. Cranial nerves II–XII are intact. He has no focal motor or sensory deficits. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Severe, sudden-onset, instantly peaking generalized headache with associated nausea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and a history of a possible sentinel bleed (severe headache 6 days prior) strongly suggests subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
learning_objective: Recognize subarachnoid hemorrhage, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test when CT is inconclusive.

answers.content: Repeat CT scan of the head in 24 hours
answers.explanation_why: While a repeat CT scan may show an evolving pathology, waiting 24 hours is not appropriate when the likely diagnosis could lead to permanent neurologic deficits and death within this time period.

If CT scan of the head is inconclusive but clinical suspicion remains high, lumbar puncture (LP) should be performed to rule out SAH. CT scan of the head has a high sensitivity for SAH (> 90%) especially if performed within 6 hours of symptom onset, but small bleeds may not be detected. Even though this patient has negative head imaging, his sudden-onset headache with nausea and vomiting is highly concerning for SAH and warrants further diagnostic work-up. Expected LP findings in SAH include elevated RBCs, high protein, xanthochromia (after 6–12 hours), and possibly elevated opening pressure. CT angiography is an alternative second-line test to diagnose SAH.

It is important to distinguish SAH from a traumatic spinal tap. In SAH, the amount of RBCs remains the same in a series of collection tubes, whereas in a traumatic LP the RBC count decreases (until reaching zero) over successive collection tubes.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: A nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage is most commonly caused by the rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

answers.explanation_why: Oxygen and intranasal sumatriptan are the preferred treatment for cluster headache. Cluster headache typically manifests as a severe, strictly unilateral pain associated with ipsilateral physical findings such as lacrimation and rhinorrhea, which are absent in this patient. While cluster headache may remain on the differential, this patient's sudden-onset severe headache with nausea and vomiting should raise concern for a more dangerous diagnosis such as subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Management of SAH should include careful blood pressure control to reach a systolic pressure below 160 mm Hg. However, the initial drugs of choice are beta-blockers (e.g., labetalol) and calcium-channel blockers (e.g., nimodipine, which also has neuroprotective effects). Nitrates such as sodium nitroprusside are indicated for hypertensive crises, but they are a poor choice in SAH because they can elevate intracranial pressure.

Watchful waiting is not appropriate if there is high suspicion of subarachnoid hemorrhage. If left untreated, it may lead to severe elevated intracranial pressure, permanent neurologic deficits, and death.

answers.content: Obtain an MRI scan of the head
answers.explanation_why: Once a subarachnoid hemorrhage is confirmed, MRI may be used for further surgical planning (e.g., aneurysm clipping vs. endovascular coiling). It is not, however, more sensitive than CT scan for the diagnosis of SAH, and is therefore not the most appropriate test following a negative CT scan. MRI is particularly useful for evaluating mass lesions, ischemic areas, and other interstitial brain pathologies, but involves more time and expense than CT scan in the acute setting.

question_text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician for the evaluation of a 1-month history of episodes of irritability and occasional vomiting. The parents report that she has been drowsy during much of the day and has not engaged in her usual activities during this period. She was born at term and has been healthy. She is at the 60^th percentile for height, 40^th percentile for weight, and 90^th percentile for head circumference. The patient is irritable and listless. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A cranial CT scan with contrast shows enlargement of the ventricular spaces as well as a 4-cm enhancing solid mass with scattered calcifications within the 4^th ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician for the evaluation of a 1-month history of episodes of irritability and occasional vomiting. The parents report that she has been drowsy during much of the day and has not engaged in her usual activities during this period. She was born at term and has been healthy. She is at the 60th percentile for height, 40th percentile for weight, and 90th percentile for head circumference. The patient is irritable and listless. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A cranial CT scan with contrast shows enlargement of the ventricular spaces as well as a 4-cm enhancing solid mass with scattered calcifications within the 4th ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient's symptoms?
hint: Dilation of the ventricles and signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), such as vomiting, papilledema, and irritability, indicate hydrocephalus. Hydrocephalus in a 3-year-old child with a mass in the 4^th ventricle suggests an ependymoma.
learning_objective: Recognize obstructive hydrocephalus, and recall its causes.

answers.explanation_why:
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) overproduction is a rare cause of hydrocephalus and only occurs due to choroid plexus tumors. A choroid plexus papilloma may manifest with communicating hydrocephalus and a solid mass that may be calcified. However, pediatric choroid plexus papillomas are typically seen in the lateral ventricles and are relatively rare, accounting for < 6% of intracranial tumors in this age group.

Unlike in the pediatric population, the most common site of a choroid plexus papilloma among adults is the fourth ventricle.

Cerebral edema is a complication of a variety of central nervous system diseases (e.g., stroke, infection, trauma), and often results in raised ICP, which manifests with headache, vomiting, and papilledema. Brain tumors may have surrounding parenchymal edema that can exacerbate raised ICP symptoms. However, cerebral edema does not result in enlarged ventricles. While some of this patient's symptoms can be attributed to edema, the majority are likely due to hydrocephalus.

A congenital failure of the foramen of Magendie to open is the underlying cause of Dandy-Walker malformation (DWM). DWM is characterized by cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, and hydrocephalus. This patient has no symptoms of cerebellar disease (e.g., ataxia), and there is no evidence of cerebellar hypoplasia on her CT scan. Moreover, symptoms of DWM usually appear within the first year of life, unlike this patient who presents at 3 years of age.

images.title: Dandy-Walker syndrome
images.description: Cranial MRI of a young child (T2 weighted, sagittal view)The posterior fossa and the pons appear cystic and hyperintense. The cerebellum also appears hypoplastic and the posterior fossa is enlarged.This radiographic appearance suggests Dandy-Walker syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Impaired CSF reabsorption by the arachnoid granulations is seen in conditions associated with increased pressure in the dural venous sinuses (e.g., dural venous thrombosis). Dural venous sinus thrombosis in children may produce symptoms that are similar to this patient's, such as irritability, vomiting, and communicating hydrocephalus (dilation of all ventricles). However, dural venous thrombosis usually occurs in patients with pericranial infections (e.g., sinusitis, mastoiditis), hypercoagulable states, or following trauma. Moreover, patients have a cord-like hyperdensity within the dural sinus on CT scan.

Ependymomas usually develop from the lining of the ventricular system and, if they grow large enough, will cause obstruction of CSF flow and consequent dilation of the ventricles proximal to the obstruction (obstructive hydrocephalus). This patient's tumor is in the fourth ventricle, which is the most common location for ependymoma in children and the last ventricle along the CSF pathway; as such, all ventricles become dilated with trapped CSF. Ependymomas typically appear as homogeneous enhancing masses on CT neuroimaging, often with cysts and calcifications. Ependymomas have a poor prognosis, especially when located in the posterior fossa. The next step in management for this patient would be a brain MRI to provide better images of the tumor. Treatment would likely involve surgical resection and possibly radiation therapy.

question_text: A 49-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for a severe, sudden-onset generalized headache that began while she was riding an exercise bike at home that morning. After quickly getting off the bike and lying down, she lost consciousness. She was unconscious for a period of one minute. When she regained consciousness, she had neck stiffness, nausea, and two episodes of vomiting. She has hypertension. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her current medications include chlorthalidone and a multivitamin. She is in severe distress. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 169/102 mm Hg. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows hyperdense material between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater. The patient is taken to the operating room for surgical clipping and transferred to the intensive care unit. Five days later, she has new-onset focal weakness of her left lower extremity. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 148/90 mm Hg. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the left lower extremity and 5/5 in the right lower extremity. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient’s current condition?
content_preview: A 49-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for a severe, sudden-onset generalized headache that began while she was riding an exercise bike at home that morning. After quickly getting off the bike and lying down, she lost consciousness. She was unconscious for a period of one minute. When she regained consciousness, she had neck stiffness, nausea, and two episodes of vomiting. She has hypertension. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her current medications include chlorthalidone and a multivitamin. She is in severe distress. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 169/102 mm Hg. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows hyperdense material between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater. The patient is taken to the operating room for surgical clipping and transferred to the intensive care unit. Five days later, she has new-onset focal weakness of her left lower extremity. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 148/90 mm Hg. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the left lower extremity and 5/5 in the right lower extremity. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient’s current condition?
hint: This patient presents with signs of cerebral ischemia (new-onset focal weakness of an extremity) 5 days after a subarachnoidal hemorrhage (SAH). The most likely explanation for this finding is vasospasm of cerebral arteries, which is a common complication of SAH.
learning_objective: Recognize vasospasm as a complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage, and choose the appropriate medication to prevent this complication.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous labetalol is useful for the initial management of hypertension in subarachnoid hemorrhage because of its rapid onset of action. Labetalol may also be indicated in cases of rebleeding with associated SBP > 160 mm Hg, but it is not used for prophylaxis of vasospasm.

Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is used for the treatment of severe coagulopathy (e.g., caused by warfarin overdose complicated by intracranial hemorrhage). This patient has no underlying conditions that would cause coagulopathy (such as liver failure) and does not take warfarin. Moreover, FFP is not used for prophylaxis of vasospasm after SAH.

Blood pressure control is an important component of the initial therapy for subarachnoid hemorrhage and rebleeding. However, nitrates such as sodium nitroprusside should be avoided because of their potential to raise intracranial pressure.

Oral nimodipine should be given after SAH to reduce the risk of ischemia associated with vasospasm. This patient's sudden-onset neurologic deficit five days after SAH is a common manifestation of vasospasm, which occurs as a complication of ∼ 30% of SAH cases and is more common with aneurysms. This patient should be evaluated with CT scan and angiography to distinguish potential vasospasm from rebleeding and receive prompt treatment to prevent ischemic stroke.

Despite its vasodilatatory effects, nimodipine does not significantly reverse angiographic vasospasm. The mechanism of ischemic risk reduction for patients with SAH is not fully understood, but it may include neuroprotection via blockade of calcium influx to the damaged neurons, impairment of platelet aggregation, and/or vasodilation of arteries too small to be appreciated on angiography.

Dual antiplatelet therapy may be used for secondary prevention of ischemic stroke in patients that are at risk for atherosclerosis and in those with known symptomatic cerebrovascular disease. Given the timing of this patient's current condition (five days after SAH), the ischemic symptoms are more likely due to vasospasm than to a recurrent ischemic event caused by thrombosis. Dual antiplatelet therapy would also be indicated for patients who received arterial stents to prevent stent thrombosis. However, this patient underwent surgical clipping, which does not require postprocedural antiplatelet therapy.

question_text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained driver. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 3-cm laceration over the forehead and multiple bruises over the trunk. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The right knee is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun and intravenous acetaminophen is administered. Two hours later, blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drains from both nostrils and is made worse by leaning forward. On a piece of gauze, it shows up as a rapidly expanding clear ring of fluid surrounding blood. Further evaluation of this patient over the next 24 hours is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained driver. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 3-cm laceration over the forehead and multiple bruises over the trunk. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The right knee is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun and intravenous acetaminophen is administered. Two hours later, blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drains from both nostrils and is made worse by leaning forward. On a piece of gauze, it shows up as a rapidly expanding clear ring of fluid surrounding blood. Further evaluation of this patient over the next 24 hours is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This man has blood-tinged fluid draining from his nose after trauma that shows a halo sign (rapidly expanding clear ring of fluid surrounding blood), indicating cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea. The most likely explanation is a basilar skull fracture of the anterior cranial fossa.
learning_objective: Recognize cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea after trauma, and recall the diagnostic finding of a basilar skull fracture.

answers.explanation_why: Basilar skull fracture can be associated with cranial nerve palsies. Anterior basilar skull fracture can cause cranial nerve (CN) I palsies, as well as palsies in CN V, VI, VII, or VIII. However, CN XII exits the skull at the hypoglossal canal of the occipital bone (in the posterior fossa) and thus is associated with posterior basilar skull fractures, not anterior basilar skull fractures. Additionally, most cranial nerve palsies associated with basilar skull fracture are not present until 1–3 days after injury, because the palsy is the result of compression or contusion of the nerve, which does not occur acutely. If a nerve is transected by trauma (which is uncommon), then the palsy would be present immediately.

This patient presents with CSF rhinorrhea, which is a classic sign of anterior basilar skull fracture. The positive halo sign confirms that the leakage contains CSF. Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis (“raccoon eyes”) is another typical sign of basilar skull fracture involving the anterior cranial fossa. "Raccoon eyes" is not seen immediately after an injury but rather develops after 1–3 days.

If basilar skull fracture is suspected, the next best steps in management are noncontrast CT scan of the head to confirm the diagnosis and neurosurgical consultation.

images.title: Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis
images.description: Face of a 54-year-old man after a fall on the back of his head 2 days earlierBilateral, symmetrical, dark purplish discoloration around the eye sockets is visible.This appearance, also referred to as "raccoon eyes," is a typical sign of basilar skull fractures involving the anterior fossa and typically develops 1–3 days after injury. Nontraumatic causes include neuroblastoma, plasma cell proliferative disorders (e.g., amyloidosis), and hematological malignancies. Periorbital ecchymosis may occur unilaterally or bilaterally.

answers.explanation_why: Upper cheek numbness is caused by damage to the infraorbital nerve, which is a complication of orbital fracture. Basilar skull fracture can in rare cases cause facial numbness by damaging cranial nerve V, but this would be seen in middle cranial fossa fracture. This patient's CSF rhinorrhea is indicative of anterior fossa fracture.

Trismus is most commonly associated with tetanus but may also be caused by zygomatic arch or mandibular fracture. Other signs of zygomatic arch or mandibular fracture include facial paresthesias, intraoral lacerations, and orbital edema. However, this patient has signs of anterior basilar skull fracture, not zygomatic or mandibular fracture, making trismus unlikely.

Carotid artery dissection is a rare complication of basilar skull fracture, specifically fractures involving injury to the carotid canal. Another finding would be much more likely. Additionally, this patient's CSF rhinorrhea suggests damage to the anterior fossa, while the carotid canal is in the middle fossa.

Retroauricular ecchymosis (“Battle sign”) involves the petrous part of the temporal bone specifically and is a classic sign of basilar skull fracture. However, petrous temporal fracture would cause CSF otorrhea, not rhinorrhea.

question_text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of paresthesias and weakness in her left leg for one year. Her symptoms have become progressively worse during this period and have led to some difficulty walking for the past month. She has had frequent headaches for the past 4 months. She has a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. Current medications include amlodipine and levothyroxine. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows decreased muscle strength in the left lower extremity. Deep tendon reflexes of the lower extremity are 4+ on the left and 2+ on the right side. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, glucose, creatinine, and calcium are within the reference ranges. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of paresthesias and weakness in her left leg for one year. Her symptoms have become progressively worse during this period and have led to some difficulty walking for the past month. She has had frequent headaches for the past 4 months. She has a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. Current medications include amlodipine and levothyroxine. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows decreased muscle strength in the left lower extremity. Deep tendon reflexes of the lower extremity are 4+ on the left and 2+ on the right side. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, glucose, creatinine, and calcium are within the reference ranges. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Focal weakness and paresthesia of the left lower extremity with hyperreflexia on the same side are consistent with an upper motor neuron lesion. The MRI confirms the location of the tumor and shows a round, well-demarcated, extraaxial tumor with a dural tail in the parasagittal cortical region, which is highly suggestive of a meningioma.
learning_objective: Recognize a meningioma, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why:
Surgical resection is the first-line treatment for most meningiomas. This patient's large meningioma is located on the convex surface of the cerebrum and is easily accessible via parietal craniotomy. Complete surgical resection of the meningioma ensures the lowest chance of recurrence. Focused radiotherapy (stereotactic radiotherapy) is indicated in inoperable tumors (e.g., meningiomas near the optic sheath or critical structures at the base of the skull) or if the tumor is incompletely resected.

Symptoms are determined by the location of the tumor. However, most meningiomas are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally.

Whole brain radiotherapy is indicated for patients with multiple brain metastases. Brain metastasis can manifest with a headache and neurological deficits (such as motor and sensory deficits), but they typically occur intraaxially in the grey-white matter junction (and are not attached to the dura, as seen here), making it an unlikely diagnosis.

A biopsy is required for definitive diagnosis as well as for histological grading of meningiomas. Histological grading is important for guiding further management. Stereotactic brain biopsy is indicated as the next best step if the tumor is inoperable (e.g., tumors at the base of the skull) and/or if stereotactic radiosurgery is being considered as the first-line treatment. In this patient, however, a biopsy can be performed in the pathological specimen that is obtained via first-line management, and a stereotactic brain biopsy is not required.

Stereotactic radiosurgery is the first-line treatment for small meningiomas (usually < 3 cm) in patients who are poor candidates for surgical resection (e.g., meningiomas near the optic sheath or critical structures at the base of the skull). Stereotactic surgery is not the treatment of choice for large, easily accessible meningiomas, as is the case here.
Active surveillance via serial imaging is indicated for small, asymptomatic meningiomas that are discovered incidentally on imaging. It is not appropriate in a patient with neurological deficits.

Intrathecal chemotherapy with methotrexate is typically used for the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia with CNS invasion or primary CNS lymphomas. These tumors may manifest with focal neurological deficits, headaches, and a space-occupying lesion. However, acute lymphoblastic leukemia typically occurs during childhood and would manifest with an abnormal complete blood count. This patient also does not have risk factors for a primary CNS lymphoma (e.g., immunosuppression). Moreover, both of these tumors are usually intra-axial lesions. Intrathecal chemotherapy with methotrexate is not useful for the treatment of meningiomas because they respond poorly to chemotherapy.

Temozolomide is typically used in the treatment of glioblastoma multiforme. However, glioblastoma multiforme appears as a poorly demarcated, intra-axial lesion that tends to infiltrate along condensed white matter tracts such as the corticospinal tract and the corpus callosum, unlike the well-demarcated, extraaxial lesion seen here.

images.title: Parasagittal meningioma
images.description: MRI Head (T1 weighted; with contrast; coronal plane)There is a well-circumscribed, homogeneously enhancing rounded mass (green overlay) continuous with the falx cerebri and dura of the right parietal bone. It does not invade the surrounding brain tissue or bone.This is a case of meningioma. This is the most common diagnosis for a dural-based mass with smooth margins and homogeneous contrast enhancement. Other important differentials include lymphoma and metastasis, both of which would more likely (but not always) be less uniform in shape and enhanceheterogeneously.

question_text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of right foot pain for 3 months. She has a burning sensation in the plantar area between the third and fourth metatarsals that radiates to the third and fourth digits. She is an account executive and wears high heels to work every day. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right lower extremity shows intact skin. The posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses are palpable. When pressure is applied to the sole of the foot between the metatarsal heads the patient feels pain and there is an audible click. Tapping on the affected area causes pain that shoots into the third and fourth digits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of right foot pain for 3 months. She has a burning sensation in the plantar area between the third and fourth metatarsals that radiates to the third and fourth digits. She is an account executive and wears high heels to work every day. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right lower extremity shows intact skin. The posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses are palpable. When pressure is applied to the sole of the foot between the metatarsal heads the patient feels pain and there is an audible click. Tapping on the affected area causes pain that shoots into the third and fourth digits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The medial plantar nerve is likely involved in the disease process affecting this patient.
learning_objective: Recognize intermetatarsal neuroma.

answers.explanation_why: A first metatarsophalangeal joint sprain, also called turf toe, manifests with swelling, tenderness, and an inability to move the first toe. This patient has none of these features and instead has pain on palpation of the third intermetatarsal space.

Third metatarsal stress fractures commonly occur in individuals who regularly run or have a high-intensity exercise program like military personnel. Even though this patient has pain on palpation of the third intermetatarsal space, she does not have a classical history associated with a stress fracture. Additionally, stress fractures do not manifest with neuropathic pain (i.e., radiating burning pain) and a positive Tinel sign.

Metatarsal osteochondrosis, also called Freiberg disease, affects the second metatarsal and is typically seen in adolescent girls. However, this patient's symptoms are limited to the third metatarsal space and the adjoining toes. Additionally, metatarsal osteochondrosis manifests with pain and swelling over the metatarsal and is not associated with the neuropathic pain seen in this patient.

Intermetatarsal neuroma (also called Morton neuroma) is caused by entrapment or enlargement of one of the plantar digital nerves, in this patient likely the medial plantar nerve, and typically manifests with neuropathic pain in the plantar aspect of the foot that is exacerbated by palpation. The condition is commonly seen in individuals who wear narrow or high-heeled footwear and is characterized by the presence of Mulder sign and Tinel sign.

Morton neuroma is a clinical diagnosis based on history and provocation testing. If there is clinical uncertainty, imaging is appropriate to confirm the diagnosis or exclude alternative causes of chronic foot pain. Initial treatment includes reducing pressure on the metatarsal heads through wide footwear and orthotics. Other treatment options include ultrasound-guided corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections. Surgical resection of the neuroma may be necessary for symptomatic individuals who do not respond to other therapy modalities.

A ganglion cyst may cause pain in the foot, but would most likely occur with movement and not be associated with burning sensation, an audible click, or a positive Tinel sign. Additionally, most ganglion cysts are palpable as small bumps and are typically located in the posterior wrist.

Although osteomyelitis can also cause foot tenderness, this patient does not have fever, fatigue, or any localized signs of osteomyelitis like a draining sinus tract. There is also no history of any risk factors for osteomyelitis like an open wound or immunosuppression. Additionally, osteomyelitis does not manifest with neuropathic pain and a positive Tinel and Mulder sign.

question_text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of burning pain in his neck and arms for a year. He has also had paresthesias in his hands during this period. He has had increasing weakness in both hands during the past 3 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. He was involved in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He has had 7 sexual partners in his lifetime; he uses condoms inconsistently. He is oriented to time, place, and person. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination of the upper extremities shows decreased muscle strength, absent reflexes, and decreased hand grip with fasciculations bilaterally. Sensation to temperature and pain is absent over the chest and bilateral upper arms. Vibration and joint position sensations are present in the upper limbs. Cranial nerve examination shows no focal findings. Examination of the lower extremities show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of burning pain in his neck and arms for a year. He has also had paresthesias in his hands during this period. He has had increasing weakness in both hands during the past 3 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. He was involved in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He has had 7 sexual partners in his lifetime; he uses condoms inconsistently. He is oriented to time, place, and person. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination of the upper extremities shows decreased muscle strength, absent reflexes, and decreased hand grip with fasciculations bilaterally. Sensation to temperature and pain is absent over the chest and bilateral upper arms. Vibration and joint position sensations are present in the upper limbs. Cranial nerve examination shows no focal findings. Examination of the lower extremities show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The presence of pain along with sensory deficits to pain and temperature in a cape-like distribution over the neck and upper extremities while sparing more distal sensory levels suggests injury to decussating fibers in the cervical and upper thoracic spinal cord. A history of motor vehicle collision and progressive symptoms point to a traumatic etiology.
learning_objective: Recognize syringomyelia.

answers.explanation_why: Tabes dorsalis, a manifestation of tertiary syphilis, manifests with progressive loss of vibration and proprioception in the lower extremity by affecting the dorsal column of the spinal cord. While this patient may have a sexually transmitted disease such as syphilis as a result of inconsistent condom use, his lower extremities are unaffected, making tabes dorsalis unlikely.

Cervical disc prolapse can lead to nerve root compression (radiculopathy), which may manifest with paresthesias as well as sensory and/or motor deficits. However, neurological symptoms produced by disc prolapse are usually unilateral and localized to the distribution of the compressed nerve root. It is very unlikely that nerve root compression is the cause of this patient's symmetrical distribution of deficits; many nerve roots would have to be compressed simultaneously on both sides. In addition, all sensations are usually affected by nerve root compression, and the preservation of vibration and positional sense suggests a different diagnosis.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) may manifest with a combination of upper and lower motor neuron weakness that progresses over time. However, ALS is more typically asymmetric and does not present with sensory deficits.

images.title: Clinical features and pathophysiology of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
images.description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

answers.explanation_why: Brown-Séquard syndrome, which results from a hemisection of the spinal cord, presents with dissociated sensory loss and unilateral motor deficits below the level of the injury. This patient has deficits affecting only his arms and chest, without involvement of the remaining trunk and lower extremities. In addition, Brown-Séquard syndrome typically occurs immediately following spinal cord injury and is not likely to develop three years later.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) manifests with multiple demyelinating lesions affecting the brain and spinal cord. Although this patient's sensory deficit and arm weakness may be explained by demyelinating lesions in the spinal cord and the medulla, MS is unlikely given this patient's lower motor neuron findings (e.g., fasciculations, loss of reflexes). In addition, unlike this patient's gradual progression, MS more typically manifests with a relapsing-remitting course (though in rare cases, may also be rapidly progressive).

Subacute combined degeneration (SCD) of the spinal cord affects the posterior and posterolateral columns of the spinal cord, presenting with upper motor neuron pattern weakness of the extremities and impaired fine touch and proprioception. This patient has preserved fine touch and proprioception along with fasciculations and areflexia of the upper extremities, which are more characteristic of lower motor neuron pattern weakness.

Posttraumatic syringomyelia can occur months to years after whiplash injury to the neck and manifests with the classical findings of a central cord syndrome. Patients experience a symmetric cape-like distribution of pain and temperature sensory loss around the upper trunk, shoulders, and upper limbs. Vibration and position sense are selectively spared because fibers of the posterior columns decussate higher up in the medulla. As syringomyelia progresses, lower motor neuron weakness develops symmetrically in the upper limbs (evident by hand weakness, areflexia, and fasciculations in this patient) because the fluid-filled cavity begins to compress the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord at the level of the lesion. As the lesion expands, patients develop an upper motor neuron palsy of the lower extremities and lower half of the trunk (due to involvement of the corticospinal tracts), as well as complete sensory loss below the level of the lesion (including loss of vibration and position sense). However, sensations around the sacral region are usually spared.

question_text: A 53-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife for the evaluation of a progressively generalized headache that started suddenly 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as 10 out of 10 in intensity. The pain radiates to the neck and is aggravated by lying down. The patient has vomited once on his way to the hospital. He had a similar headache 1 week ago that resolved after a few hours without treatment. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 165/89 mm Hg. Pupils are equal and reactive to light and extraocular eye movements are normal. There is no weakness or sensory loss. Reflexes are 2+ throughout. Neck flexion causes worsening of the pain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 53-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife for the evaluation of a progressively generalized headache that started suddenly 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as 10 out of 10 in intensity. The pain radiates to the neck and is aggravated by lying down. The patient has vomited once on his way to the hospital. He had a similar headache 1 week ago that resolved after a few hours without treatment. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 165/89 mm Hg. Pupils are equal and reactive to light and extraocular eye movements are normal. There is no weakness or sensory loss. Reflexes are 2+ throughout. Neck flexion causes worsening of the pain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: Thunderclap headache, meningism, hypertension, mild fever, and signs of increased intracranial pressure (pain worse when lying down, lethargy, and vomiting) suggest a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) from a ruptured aneurysm. The recent similar episode that spontaneously resolved was likely from a sentinel bleed.
learning_objective: Recognize subarachnoid hemorrhage, and choose the initial diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Although EEG is indicated in working up seizures, a potential complication of SAH, it is a time-consuming test that is unable to directly confirm SAH. Regardless, this patient has no evidence of seizure at this time.

Although lumbar puncture (LP) is commonly indicated for headache and/or meningism, it is not the best first test to assess for SAH. LP would be indicated if the initial screening test was negative for SAH, but clinical suspicion remained high. Regardless, because this patient has signs of intracranial hypertension, brain imaging would be advised prior to LP because of the risk of brainstem herniation.

MRI is the test of choice to diagnose subacute SAH presentation (> 4 days from symptom onset) because it is more sensitive to the changing density of the resolving bleed compared to other imaging modalities. However, MRI is not as readily available and therefore only a second-line test to diagnose acute SAH.

Intracranial pressure (ICP) monitoring is most frequently used in closed traumatic head injury. While this patient does have signs of increased ICP, most likely as a complication of SAH, ICP monitoring would not confirm the actual diagnosis of SAH. Additionally, ICP monitoring is highly invasive as it involves placing a transducer through the skull. It is rarely indicated because similar data can usually be inferred by less invasive means (physical exam and imaging).

CT angiography (CTA) of the head is commonly performed in patients with SAH after the diagnosis is confirmed. The procedure is typically used for presurgical planning, specifically to visualize the vascular anomalies that are bleeding (e.g., aneurysm). It would be difficult to definitively diagnose acute bleeding in the presence of IV contrast, which is required for CTA.

answers.content: CT scan of the head without contrast
answers.explanation_why:
A noncontrast CT scan of the head is the best initial test to assess for subarachnoid hemorrhage, as it is readily available in most hospitals, highly sensitive, and may be performed rapidly. SAH requires rapid diagnosis and treatment because it can quickly cause death if bleeding persists. Any patient who presents with a sudden, severe headache must have SAH ruled out with a head CT scan.

If the head CT scan is negative for SAH, but clinical suspicion remains high, a lumbar puncture is indicated. A negative head CT scan and negative lumbar puncture rule out acute SAH. Analgesia, IV fluids, and seizure prophylaxis are initiated if SAH is diagnosed. Further treatment depends on the suspected cause of the hemorrhage. In this patient's case (suspected ruptured aneurysm), surgical clipping would likely be attempted.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Multiple areas of high attenuation in the basal cisterns, Sylvian fissures, and sulci (examples indicated by green overlay) are characteristic of extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of tinnitus and progressive hearing loss in the left ear. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and Raynaud syndrome. Her current medications include metformin, nifedipine, and a multivitamin. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Immediately after the patient does not hear a tone, the tuning fork is held over the left ear and she reports hearing the tuning fork again. The same test is repeated on the right side and shows a similar pattern. The vibration tuning fork is then placed on the middle of the forehead and the patient hears the sound louder in the right ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of tinnitus and progressive hearing loss in the left ear. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and Raynaud syndrome. Her current medications include metformin, nifedipine, and a multivitamin. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Immediately after the patient does not hear a tone, the tuning fork is held over the left ear and she reports hearing the tuning fork again. The same test is repeated on the right side and shows a similar pattern. The vibration tuning fork is then placed on the middle of the forehead and the patient hears the sound louder in the right ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A positive Rinne test (normal conductive hearing) in combination with a Weber test showing right-sided lateralization suggests unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (of the left ear).
learning_objective: Recognize an acoustic neuroma.

answers.explanation_why: Although meningiomas are usually asymptomatic, a tumor in the cerebellopontine angle could explain the patient's sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. However, meningiomas most frequently arise from the falx cerebri and other supratentorial regions, whereas only 10% occur in the cerebellopontine angle.
Progressive sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus in an older patient are the characteristic findings of presbycusis. However, both tinnitus and hearing loss are usually bilateral.

This patient has characteristic features of a left cerebellopontine tumor, including unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. The most common brain tumors in this location are acoustic neuromas (vestibular schwannomas), which usually arise from Schwann cells in the internal auditory meatus and may expand into the cerebellopontine angle. Later symptoms include unilateral facial weakness (due to pressure on CN VII) and unilateral facial pain and/or paresthesia (due to pressure on CN V) as well as gait instability due to vestibular deficits. Further management includes audiometry and cranial MRI with contrast to confirm the tumor. For patients with large tumors or significant hearing loss, the treatment of choice is surgical removal or radiation therapy. For patients with smaller tumors and minimal hearing loss, observation with follow-up may be appropriate.

The presence of bilateral acoustic neuromas should raise suspicion for neurofibromatosis type II.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Improper ear care (e.g., use of cotton swabs) may precipitate the formation of cerumen plugs that block the auditory canal. Cerumen impaction typically manifests as sudden (e.g., triggered by showering or bathing) rather than progressive hearing loss. Unlike in this woman, the Rinne test would be abnormal (negative) in the affected ear and the Weber test would show a lateralization to the same ear, suggesting conductive rather than sensorineural hearing loss.

The typical triad of Meniere disease includes sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo, which usually last from minutes to hours and lead to a stepwise decline in hearing, rather than the constantly progressive hearing loss described in this vignette. Also, this patient does not have vertigo.

question_text: A 67-year old woman is brought to the emergency department after she lost consciousness at home. Her daughter was with her at the time and recalls that her mother was complaining of a diffuse headache and nausea about 2 hours before the incident. The daughter says that her mother has not had any recent falls and was sitting in a chair when she lost consciousness. She has hypertension. Current medications include amlodipine, a daily multivitamin, and acetaminophen. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 158/100 mm Hg. She is disoriented and unable to follow commands. Examination shows nuchal rigidity. She has flexor posturing to painful stimuli. Fundoscopic examination is notable for bilateral vitreous hemorrhages. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. An emergency noncontrast CT scan of the head is obtained and shows a diffuse hemorrhage at the base of the brain that is largest over the left hemisphere. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 67-year old woman is brought to the emergency department after she lost consciousness at home. Her daughter was with her at the time and recalls that her mother was complaining of a diffuse headache and nausea about 2 hours before the incident. The daughter says that her mother has not had any recent falls and was sitting in a chair when she lost consciousness. She has hypertension. Current medications include amlodipine, a daily multivitamin, and acetaminophen. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 158/100 mm Hg. She is disoriented and unable to follow commands. Examination shows nuchal rigidity. She has flexor posturing to painful stimuli. Fundoscopic examination is notable for bilateral vitreous hemorrhages. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. An emergency noncontrast CT scan of the head is obtained and shows a diffuse hemorrhage at the base of the brain that is largest over the left hemisphere. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Sudden-onset headache, nuchal rigidity, and diffuse hemorrhage at the base of the brain on a CT scan are suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage.
learning_objective: Recognize a ruptured saccular aneurysm.

answers.explanation_why: A ruptured mycotic aneurysm is a rare cause of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhages. Mycotic intracranial aneurysms result from infected emboli, most often secondary to infective endocarditis. This patient does not have any signs or symptoms such as fever, cardiac murmurs, bacteremia, or cutaneous lesions (Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, or Roth spots) that would suggest infection or endocarditis.

Ruptured saccular aneurysms are the cause of 80% of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhages. This patient has several risk factors for the development of a saccular aneurysm, including age > 40 years, female gender, hypertension, and cigarette smoking. Other risk factors for a saccular aneurysm include heavy alcohol use, connective tissue disorders, polycystic kidney disease, and family history.

Intracranial arteriovenous malformations cause 10% of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhages. Arteriovenous malformations would have shown up on the CT as foci of calcification and hyperattenuating vascular channels.

Intracranial artery dissection is a rare cause of subarachnoid hemorrhage. The majority of cases occur in people between the ages of 35–50 years. Intracranial artery dissection is usually preceded by a history of trauma, exertional activity, or cerebral artery stretching, which can occur with migraines or sudden elevations of blood pressure. Even though this patient does have increased blood pressure, it is not dramatically high. There is also no history of trauma.

Spinal arteriovenous malformations are a rare cause of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage. These malformations are often located in the cervical cord or craniocervical junction, and rupture presents with prominent back or neck pain, which is absent in this patient.

question_text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the unrestrained passenger. His wife confirms that he has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and chronic lower back pain. Current medications include metoprolol, warfarin, hydrochlorothiazide, and oxycodone. On arrival, he is lethargic and confused. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 172/78 mm Hg. The eyes open spontaneously. The pupils are equal and sluggish. He moves his extremities in response to commands. There is a 3-cm scalp laceration. There are multiple bruises over the right upper extremity. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Two large-bore peripheral intravenous catheters are inserted. A 0.9% saline infusion is begun. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma is negative. Plain CT of the brain shows a 5-mm right subdural hematoma with no mass effect. Fresh frozen plasma is administered. Which of the following is most likely to reduce this patient's cerebral blood flow?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the unrestrained passenger. His wife confirms that he has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and chronic lower back pain. Current medications include metoprolol, warfarin, hydrochlorothiazide, and oxycodone. On arrival, he is lethargic and confused. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 172/78 mm Hg. The eyes open spontaneously. The pupils are equal and sluggish. He moves his extremities in response to commands. There is a 3-cm scalp laceration. There are multiple bruises over the right upper extremity. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Two large-bore peripheral intravenous catheters are inserted. A 0.9% saline infusion is begun. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma is negative. Plain CT of the brain shows a 5-mm right subdural hematoma with no mass effect. Fresh frozen plasma is administered. Which of the following is most likely to reduce this patient's cerebral blood flow?
hint: Reducing this patient's cerebral blood flow can lower intracranial pressure (ICP) but also lead to ischemia. Cerebral autoregulation is controlled by the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO_2).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate intervention to reduce cerebral blood flow in the context of intracranial pressure management.

answers.explanation_why:
Hyperventilation blows off CO_2, which lowers PaCO_2 levels and results in arterial smooth muscle constriction. Based on Poiseuille's law, small decreases in the arterial radius from vasoconstriction can profoundly decrease cerebral blood flow. Since the cranial vault has a finite amount of space, decreasing cerebral blood flow allows more room for brain tissue and reductions in ICP.

Although hyperventilation was commonly used to reduce ICP, studies have failed to show long-term outcome advantages. Prophylactic hyperventilation is no longer recommended and should only be used as a temporary measure for elevated ICP refractory to medical therapy.

Decompressive craniectomy can increase blood flow by creating more space for brain swelling and thus reducing intracranial pressure. This reduction in intracranial pressure can improve cerebral perfusion pressure and blood flow. However, this technique is controversial, as the efficacy of decompressive craniectomy in traumatic brain injury is unclear and would not be the most appropriate first step in management for this patient.

Lumbar puncture can increase cerebral blood flow by removing CSF, thus creating more space for brain tissue and vessels. This technique is most commonly used to lower ICP in patients with hydrocephalus (e.g., normal pressure hydrocephalus). However, lumbar puncture is contraindicated in any patient with increased intracranial pressure due to brain swelling, as CSF removal can release pressure in the lower spinal cord causing downward brain herniation and death.

Hypertonic saline increases blood osmolality, which draws water from brain tissue into the intravascular space and thereby reduces ICP. Decreases in ICP can increase cerebral perfusion pressure and cerebral blood flow by creating more space for vessels. Unless there is evidence of brain herniation, hypertonic saline is reserved for patients with confirmed increases in ICP.

Mannitol acts by rapidly expanding circulating blood volume and decreasing blood viscosity. This causes an increase in cerebral blood flow and the subsequent compensatory cerebral vasoconstriction results in an initial fall in ICP. After about 15–30 minutes, it further increases cerebral blood flow by increasing cerebral perfusion pressure. Because prolonged mannitol therapy can increase ICP, it should only be used in the acute phase in patients with signs of significant increases in ICP (e.g., mass effect, impending brain herniation).
