question_text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. She was riding a bike when she lost control and hit a car on the opposite side of the road. On arrival, she is unconscious. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. Her pulse is 56/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 196/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm laceration over the left cheek and a 3-cm laceration over the left chest. There are multiple abrasions over her face and chest. She opens her eyes and flexes her extremities to painful stimuli. The pupils are dilated and react sluggishly to light. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung. The trachea is central. There is no jugular venous distention. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The left knee and right ankle are swollen; range of motion is limited. Two large-bore peripheral intravenous catheters are inserted. The patient is intubated and mechanical ventilation is initiated. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma is negative. An occlusive dressing is applied over the left chest wound. She is scheduled for a noncontrast CT scan of the brain. Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's hypertension?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. She was riding a bike when she lost control and hit a car on the opposite side of the road. On arrival, she is unconscious. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. Her pulse is 56/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 196/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm laceration over the left cheek and a 3-cm laceration over the left chest. There are multiple abrasions over her face and chest. She opens her eyes and flexes her extremities to painful stimuli. The pupils are dilated and react sluggishly to light. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung. The trachea is central. There is no jugular venous distention. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The left knee and right ankle are swollen; range of motion is limited. Two large-bore peripheral intravenous catheters are inserted. The patient is intubated and mechanical ventilation is initiated. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma is negative. An occlusive dressing is applied over the left chest wound. She is scheduled for a noncontrast CT scan of the brain. Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's hypertension?
hint: This patient presents with Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration) as a result of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) due to traumatic brain injury (TBI).
learning_objective: Recognize Cushing's triad, and recall its association with elevated intracranial pressure.

answers.explanation_why:
Elevated ICP in this patient has led to a decrease in cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP). The sympathetic nervous system is activated in order to maintain CPP by increasing systolic blood pressure, which explains this patient's hypertension and widening pulse pressure. The increased arterial pressure stimulates aortic arch baroreceptors that activate the parasympathetic nervous system, resulting in bradycardia. A further increase in ICP leads to brain stem compression, which further promotes bradycardia and causes dysfunction of the respiratory center (bradypnea and irregular breathing).

Clinical features of elevated ICP warrant urgent neuroimaging (CT or MRI) to evaluate for intracerebral pathologies and guide further treatment, and potentially invasive ICP monitoring to confirm the diagnosis.

Elevated ICP results in decreased cerebral perfusion pressure, to which the body responds with an increased, not decreased, parasympathetic response. Autoregulatory mechanisms in the CNS result in increased systolic blood pressure to maintain cerebral blood flow. The stimulation of aortic arch baroreceptors then leads to activation of the parasympathetic nervous system and consequent bradycardia.

Patients involved in motor vehicle collisions are at risk for traumatic tension pneumothorax, which causes a rise in intrathoracic pressure. However, tension pneumothorax results in decreased cardiac output leading to hypotension, not hypertension. While this patient does have decreased unilateral breath sounds, which can be a sign of tension pneumothorax, other important findings, such as distended neck veins (due to reduced venous return), tracheal deviation, or tachycardia are absent.

Brainstem compression and the consequent disruption of centers responsible for autonomic function (circulation, respiration) plays an important role in the pathophysiology of Cushing reflex and is likely responsible for this patient's bradycardia, bradypnea, and irregular breathing. Hypertension in ICP does not, however, result from brainstem compression; instead, it is the result of an autoregulatory mechanism that maintains adequate cerebral perfusion pressure.

Vasospasm is a common complication of subarachnoid hemorrhages, that typically appears 3 to 10 days after SAH. Symptoms include new-onset neurological deficits such as speech difficulties, unilateral weakness, or focal seizures, none of which this patient has. Posttraumatic vasospasm is not a cause of systemic hypertension.

question_text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after his wife found him unresponsive 1 hour ago. He had fallen from a flight of stairs the previous evening. Four years ago, he underwent a mitral valve replacement. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. On arrival, he is unconscious. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 200/102 mm Hg. The right pupil is 5 mm and fixed. The left pupil is 4 mm and reactive to light. There is extension of the extremities to painful stimuli. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a systolic click. The abdomen is soft and nontender. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A mannitol infusion is begun. A noncontrast CT scan of the brain shows a 6-cm subdural hematoma on the right side with an 18-mm midline shift and compression of the right medial temporal lobe. If left untreated, which of the following findings is most likely to develop first as his current condition progresses?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after his wife found him unresponsive 1 hour ago. He had fallen from a flight of stairs the previous evening. Four years ago, he underwent a mitral valve replacement. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. On arrival, he is unconscious. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 200/102 mm Hg. The right pupil is 5 mm and fixed. The left pupil is 4 mm and reactive to light. There is extension of the extremities to painful stimuli. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a systolic click. The abdomen is soft and nontender. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A mannitol infusion is begun. A noncontrast CT scan of the brain shows a 6-cm subdural hematoma on the right side with an 18-mm midline shift and compression of the right medial temporal lobe. If left untreated, which of the following findings is most likely to develop first as his current condition progresses?
hint: Cushing triad (bradycardia, irregular respiration, and hypertension) and ipsilateral oculomotor palsy in a patient who recently sustained a head injury indicate transtentorial (uncal) herniation.
learning_objective: Recognize uncal herniation, and recall its early neurological sequelae.

answers.content: Right eye medial deviation and elevation
answers.explanation_why: Right eye medial deviation and elevation would be caused by unopposed CN III activity due to concomitant CN IV and VI palsies. When CN III is unopposed, the associated extraocular muscles (medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles) together produce adduction and elevation or depression of the eye. Instead, uncal herniation causes CN III palsy, resulting in pupillary dilation and absent light reflex (as seen in this patient), abduction, and slight depression of the eye (“down and out” gaze). Although severe advanced uncal herniation can eventually cause CN IV and VI palsies due to brainstem displacement and secondary hemorrhagic brainstem infarctions, CN III would also likely be impaired. In concomitant CN III, CN IV, and CN VI palsies, the eye position would be closer to a neutral gaze.

Spasticity indicates upper motor neuron (UMN) damage. Severe, advanced uncal herniation causes brainstem displacement leading to secondary hemorrhages, which, in turn, cause brainstem strokes and, potentially, concomitant bilateral corticospinal tract damage. However, spasticity is typically a late sequela of UMN injury, appearing days to weeks later. Other exam findings would be more typical and be found earlier in the progression of this patient's uncal herniation.

Acute left-sided facial nerve palsy is commonly caused by stroke affecting the facial nerve nucleus or its tract in the pons, or inflammation of the nerve peripherally (e.g., Bell palsy). This patient has suffered a severe head injury, resulting in a large subdural hematoma, elevated ICP, and associated uncal herniation. Severe, advanced uncal herniation can cause brainstem displacement leading to secondary hemorrhages and subsequent brainstem strokes and, potentially, facial nerve palsy. However, other exam findings would be found earlier and are more typical of uncal herniation.

Multifocal myoclonus is associated with a variety of neurologic disorders, including seizures, which can be a complication of intracranial hypertension. However, multifocal myoclonus is not a common symptom of uncal herniation. Instead, multifocal myoclonus more frequently occurs in severe cerebral hypoxia, progressive myoclonic epilepsy, neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer disease), or metabolic coma (e.g., secondary to glycemic disturbances, hyperthyroidism, or hepatic dysfunction).

This patient has a large right-sided subdural hematoma which results in elevated ICP and cerebral edema, presenting as midline shift and herniation of the medial temporal lobe (the uncus). Initially, uncal herniation manifests with ipsilateral compression of CN III and the corticospinal tract (resulting in contralateral hemiparesis). As herniation of the ipsilateral (right) uncus progresses, displacing the midbrain and compressing the contralateral (left) cerebral peduncle (which contains the left corticospinal tract) across the tentorium, it causes ipsilateral (right-sided) hemiparesis and upper motor neuron (UMN) signs (e.g., Babinski sign) as most corticospinal fibers cross over, a process called Kernohan phenomenon. This can be confusing in a clinical setting because the patient's lesion is on the right side, but right-sided hemiplegia typically localizes a left-sided lesion (this is why Kernohan syndrome is also called false localizing syndrome). This patient's extensor posturing is a sign that midbrain compression has already begun.

After emergency resuscitative measures (e.g., intubation, mannitol, oxygen supplementation, and head of bed elevation), emergency surgical decompression is required. As the herniation progresses, the brainstem can become compressed and displaced caudally, shearing the vessels, leading to midbrain and pontine hemorrhages, and subsequently resulting in coma, apnea, impaired circulation, and death.

question_text: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of slurred speech and left facial droop for the past 30 minutes. During this period, she has also had numbness on the left side of her face. She has never had such an episode before. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her father died of lung cancer 1 week ago. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. She drinks one glass of wine daily. Her current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. She is oriented to person, place, and time but speaks slowly with slurred speech. Her temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the left side of the face. Examination shows full muscle strength. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. A finger-nose test and her gait are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a right-sided carotid bruit. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, glucose, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. An ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. A noncontrast CT scan of the brain shows no abnormalities. On the way back from the CT scan, her presenting symptoms resolve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of slurred speech and left facial droop for the past 30 minutes. During this period, she has also had numbness on the left side of her face. She has never had such an episode before. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her father died of lung cancer 1 week ago. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. She drinks one glass of wine daily. Her current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. She is oriented to person, place, and time but speaks slowly with slurred speech. Her temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the left side of the face. Examination shows full muscle strength. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. A finger-nose test and her gait are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a right-sided carotid bruit. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, glucose, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. An ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. A noncontrast CT scan of the brain shows no abnormalities. On the way back from the CT scan, her presenting symptoms resolve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient with risk factors for cardiovascular disease (obesity, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, smoking history) has sudden-onset focal neurologic deficits (facial palsy) that resolve without treatment.
learning_objective: Recognize a transient ischemic attack (TIA).

answers.explanation_why: Functional neurological symptom disorder is characterized by significant distress and/or psychosocial impairment caused by neurologic symptoms (e.g., paralysis, weakness, visual disturbances) that cannot be fully attributed to another condition. Stressful events (e.g., loss of a close relative) are a risk factor for this condition. Although functional neurological symptom disorder cannot be excluded entirely, this condition is a diagnosis of exclusion and another diagnosis is more likely in this patient.

A partial seizure is a surge of electrical activity that starts in one hemisphere of the brain (and is therefore focal). It may manifest with a variety of symptoms depending on which area of the cortex is affected. In this patient with cardiovascular risk factors and no history of focal epilepsy, a different diagnosis is more likely.

Stroke workup is indicated in all patients presenting with new focal neurologic deficits (e.g., facial palsy). In addition, this patient has substantial risk factors for cardiovascular disease and therefore stroke. However, symptoms in this patient resolve spontaneously and there is no evidence of ischemia on CT imaging, which is diagnostic of a different condition.
Although Bell palsy is the most common cause of unilateral facial paralysis and may cause slurred speech, facial sensation would be unaffected and recovery would typically take a few weeks.

Sudden onset of focal neurologic deficits (facial droop, numbness, and slurred speech) in a patient with multiple cardiovascular risk factors as well as a carotid bruit is highly suggestive of cerebral ischemia (stroke). Because this patient's focal symptoms resolve spontaneously without intervention and there is no evidence of ischemia on neuroimaging, it is by definition a transient ischemic attack (TIA) rather than a stroke.

In patients with ongoing symptoms of stroke, an emergency noncontrast CT scan of the head is used to exclude intracranial hemorrhage. If there is no evidence of stroke on the emergency CT scan or in patients with resolving symptoms, a diffusion-weighted MRI can be used to detect signs of reversible ischemia and diagnose TIA. Besides neuroimaging, antiplatelet therapy should be initiated urgently because TIA is associated with a high risk of subsequent stroke.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a demyelinating condition of the CNS that can be diagnosed according to McDonald's criteria. This diagnosis requires clinical symptoms and CNS lesions to be distributed over space and time, meaning there is a history of otherwise unexplained neurologic symptoms in the past and CNS lesions are seen on MRI in different locations and at differing stages (new and old). A suspected first episode of neurologic deficits in the context of MS (e.g., opticus neuritis) is called a clinically isolated syndrome (CIS), which may partially or fully resolve (like relapsing-remitting MS). However, a sudden onset of symptoms within minutes and resolution of symptoms within one hour are neither consistent with an episode of CIS nor MS.

question_text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a dull persistent headache that began this morning. He has nausea and has vomited twice. Over the past four days, the patient has had left-sided ear pain and fever, but his parents did not seek medical attention. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at the 45^th percentile for height and 40^th percentile for weight. He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 69/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Lateral gaze of the left eye is limited. Otoscopy of the left ear shows an erythematous bulging tympanic membrane. There is no nuchal rigidity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a dull persistent headache that began this morning. He has nausea and has vomited twice. Over the past four days, the patient has had left-sided ear pain and fever, but his parents did not seek medical attention. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at the 45th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 69/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Lateral gaze of the left eye is limited. Otoscopy of the left ear shows an erythematous bulging tympanic membrane. There is no nuchal rigidity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Headache, vomiting, and a focal neurological deficit (abducens nerve palsy) are consistent with increased intracranial pressure (ICP) secondary to an intracranial abscess, most likely as a complication of acute otitis media (AOM).
learning_objective: Recognize intracranial abscess secondary to acute otitis media, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Clindamycin and cefazolin are not appropriate antibiotics for treating suspected intracranial infection because they have relatively poor CNS penetration. Metronidazole and ceftriaxone are typically used instead. Moreover, antibiotic therapy without prior surgical intervention is insufficient for the treatment of most brain abscesses because antibiotics cannot effectively penetrate the abscess cavity.

Myringotomy is not routinely indicated for AOM and is only considered if the patient has recurrent or treatment-refractory AOM or chronic otitis media. Moreover, this procedure is not the most important initial step in the management of a patient with features that suggest an intracranial abscess.

images.title: Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion
images.description:
The procedure can be performed under local or general anesthesia; general anesthesia is usually required for children. An operating microscope is preferred, although the procedure can be performed using a handheld operating otoscope.1. A radial incision is made in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa using a myringotomy blade.
2. Alligator forceps are used to insert the tympanostomy tube. Short-term tubes (I) are designed to self-extrude after approximately one year, whereas long-term tubes (II) have a longer flange that prevents extrusion.
3. A curved or angled pick can be used to facilitate correct placement.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with suspected intracranial abscess should promptly undergo cranial imaging with a contrast-enhanced CT scan or MRI to identify the size, location, and number of abscesses to guide further management. Treatment of an intracranial abscess consists of urgent abscess evacuation to decompress the cranial cavity and identify causative pathogens. Patients should also be given early empiric antibiotic therapy with metronidazole and ceftriaxone, and vancomycin should be added if a staphylococcal infection is suspected. Antibiotic therapy alone may be attempted in rare instances when the brain abscess is small (< 2.5 cm), uncomplicated, and has a known pathogen.

images.title: Brain lesion
images.description: Cranial MRI (with contrast, axial view)An oval lesion can be seen in the left temporal lobe, with ring-like contrast enhancement (green ring) and central necrosis (green overlay). The perifocal edema (white overlay) that is visible corresponds to the lesion. Differential diagnoses include an abscess, glioblastoma, and metastasis.Diagnosis: abscess following advanced otitis media

answers.explanation_why:
Aspiration of the abscess through a burr hole is often the definitive treatment for an intracranial abscess but before performing this procedure, more information should be obtained on the size, location, and number of the intracranial abscesses to guide management and trajectory planning for the burr hole procedure.

A secondary decompressive craniectomy, which involves creating burr holes without trajectory planning, is only performed if the patient has increased ICP that is refractory to treatment of the underlying cause as well as subsequent medical therapy (e.g., controlled hyperventilation, hyperosmolar solutions).

Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in patients with features of elevated ICP because of the risk of brain herniation. Moreover, cerebrospinal fluid analysis is often normal in patients with an intracranial abscess and only shows abnormal findings if the abscess ruptures into the ventricular system or if the patient has concomitant meningitis or encephalitis. A different diagnostic step is much more important for this patient.

question_text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent severe left neck, shoulder, and arm pain and paresthesias of the left hand. The pain radiates to the radial aspect of her left forearm, thumb, and index finger. She first noticed her symptoms after helping a friend set up a canopy tent. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the patient extends and rotates her head to the left and downward pressure is applied, she reports paresthesias along the radial aspect of her left forearm and thumb. There is weakness when extending the left wrist against resistance. The brachioradialis reflex is 1+ on the left and 2+ on the right. The radial pulse is palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent severe left neck, shoulder, and arm pain and paresthesias of the left hand. The pain radiates to the radial aspect of her left forearm, thumb, and index finger. She first noticed her symptoms after helping a friend set up a canopy tent. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the patient extends and rotates her head to the left and downward pressure is applied, she reports paresthesias along the radial aspect of her left forearm and thumb. There is weakness when extending the left wrist against resistance. The brachioradialis reflex is 1+ on the left and 2+ on the right. The radial pulse is palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The pattern of symptoms and exam findings indicate that a nerve root has been damaged.
learning_objective: Recognize C5-C6 disk herniation.

answers.explanation_why: Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) typically manifests with radiating pain, paresthesias, and weakness. However, these symptoms are generally confined to the hand, specifically the palmar radial aspect, the first three digits, and the radial half of the fourth digit. Symptoms are often worse at night or after repetitive movements of the hand. The patient here does not have this pattern of symptoms. Additionally, a patient with CTS would not have pain in the neck or arm, weakness when extending the wrist (a sign of damage to the radial nerve or its corresponding cervical nerve roots), nor pain with Spurling's test.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, ventral view)

answers.explanation_why: A patient with degeneration of the spine between vertebral bodies C3 and C4 may experience damage to the C4 nerve root. If the C4 nerve root were damaged, a patient might describe pain and paresthesia in the lateral aspect of the neck or the interscapular region, difficulty elevating the shoulder, and/or dyspnea or shortness of breath, as C4 also innervates the diaphragm muscle.

A patient with syringomyelia would also likely present with radiating radicular pain, paresthesias, diminished reflexes, and weakness of the upper extremities. However, symptoms would be bilateral and usually include decreased sensation in a “cape-like” distribution secondary to the progressive compression and damage to crossing neural fibers of the lateral spinothalamic tract. It would also manifest as flaccid paralysis and muscle atrophy due to damage to the medial part of the corticospinal tract.

A patient with thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) may present with pain, paresthesias, and weakness of the upper extremity, often following overhead activity. However, rather than causing symptoms to one specific nerve root, TOS usually compresses the lower trunk (C8–T1 nerve roots) of the brachial plexus. In a patient with TOS, Spurling's test would not recreate the patient's symptoms because the test is relatively specific for damage/irritation of the cervical nerve roots rather than the brachial plexus. Furthermore, TOS often affects vascular structures as well; patients present with arm pallor, coldness, decreased pulses, and/or cyanosis of the affected extremity, none of which is present in this patient.

This patient has some characteristic symptoms of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). She is in the typical age range for symptom onset (50–70 years) and presents with unilateral paresthesias and weakness. Classically, ALS manifests with symptoms of both upper motor neuron (e.g., increased muscle tone, spasticity, increased reflexes) and lower motor neuron dysfunction (e.g., flaccid paralysis, decreased reflexes, atrophy). Although possible, the majority of the patients do not report sensory dysfunction. This patient has pain and paresthesia that radiates from the neck distally to the arm and hand, indicating selective nerve root compression.

images.title: Clinical features and pathophysiology of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
images.description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient has cervical radiculopathy, most likely from a C5–C6 spinal disk herniation. Her radiating pain and paresthesias are caused by damage and/or irritation of the C6 nerve root, which innervates the radial aspect of the forearm and the thumb. These symptoms are reproduced with Spurling's maneuver, which has a high specificity for cervical radiculopathy. This patient's weakness results from damage to the same nerve root, as C6 provides motor function to the wrist extensors. C6 nerve root damage is also causing the decreased brachioradialis reflex in this patient, as C6 supplies motor function to that muscle.

Other possible causes of the patient's radiculopathy include cervical spondylosis or a tumor causing nerve root compression. Her neurologic symptoms may also be caused by infections that affect the peripheral nervous system such as herpes zoster and Lyme disease. The diagnostic workup includes MRI, which would show a laterally prolapsed disk with surrounding edema in the case of disk herniation.

images.title: Cervical disk herniation
images.description: MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane) of a patient with symptoms of cervical myelopathyA herniated disk at C5–6 (red overlay) effaces the dural sac and compresses the spinal cord. Hyperintense compression-induced edema (green overlay) is seen within the cord.

question_text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after a bicycle accident. He was cycling downhill at approximately 30 miles per hour when he lost control at a curve in the road. He was wearing a helmet and did not lose consciousness. There is no personal history of serious illness and he takes no medications. On arrival, the patient is alert and oriented. He is placed on a backboard with a cervical collar around his neck. Pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple bruises over the forehead and right cheek. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 2-cm laceration below the right ear. Both ear canals show no abnormalities. The right wrist is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is mild midline cervical spine tenderness as well as tenderness along the 2^nd and 3^rd ribs on the right side. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) shows no free intraperitoneal fluid. Bedside chest x-ray shows a fracture of the 3^rd rib on the right side and no other abnormalities. ECG is normal. Two peripheral venous catheters are placed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after a bicycle accident. He was cycling downhill at approximately 30 miles per hour when he lost control at a curve in the road. He was wearing a helmet and did not lose consciousness. There is no personal history of serious illness and he takes no medications. On arrival, the patient is alert and oriented. He is placed on a backboard with a cervical collar around his neck. Pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple bruises over the forehead and right cheek. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 2-cm laceration below the right ear. Both ear canals show no abnormalities. The right wrist is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is mild midline cervical spine tenderness as well as tenderness along the 2nd and 3rd ribs on the right side. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) shows no free intraperitoneal fluid. Bedside chest x-ray shows a fracture of the 3rd rib on the right side and no other abnormalities. ECG is normal. Two peripheral venous catheters are placed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's midline cervical tenderness raises concern for a possible cervical spine injury.
learning_objective: Recognize the potential for cervical spine injury in a trauma patient, and choose the appropriate imaging modality to rule out injury.

answers.explanation_why: Abdominal CT scan is an important diagnostic tool for patients with blunt abdominal trauma. This patient presents with abdominal tenderness but does not require CT scan at this time because he has no signs of abdominal injury, is hemodynamically stable, and has a negative FAST scan.
X-ray of the neck may be used to initially assess for cervical spine injury, which must be ruled out in this patient, but another test has a higher sensitivity and is preferred whenever available.

Brain imaging may be indicated for patients with blunt head injury to assess for traumatic intracranial lesions (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage). This patient did not lose consciousness, has a normal mental status, no focal neurological deficits, and no risk factors for intracranial hemorrhage (e.g., bleeding disorder, anticoagulation), making a traumatic intracranial lesion unlikely. Additionally, if this patient did require brain imaging, a CT scan of the head without contrast would be the initial test of choice because it is more readily available and results can be rapidly obtained.

answers.content: CT scan of the cervical spine
answers.explanation_why:
In patients with blunt neck trauma, cervical spine imaging is required to rule out injury if at least one of the NEXUS cervical spine criteria is met: focal neurological deficit, posterior midline cervical spinal tenderness, altered consciousness, intoxication, and/or distracting injury. A CT scan of the cervical spine is the preferred imaging modality to rule out cervical spine injury in adult trauma patients.

If none of the NEXUS criteria are present, the risk of cervical spine injury is low, meaning that imaging is not indicated and the cervical collar can be removed.

An x-ray of the wrist can be used to rule out an underlying fracture. Although this patient has signs of potential wrist fracture (wrist pain, tenderness, limited range of motion), more severe injuries must be ruled out first. The patient's wrist will eventually require imaging and treatment. In trauma resuscitation, management of nonlethal injuries such as a wrist fracture is often deferred until all life threats are stabilized. Until that time, fractured limbs are often splinted for patient comfort.

question_text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of lower back pain for the past 2 weeks. The pain is stabbing and shooting in quality and radiates down the backs of his legs. It began when he was lifting a bag of cement at work. The pain has been getting worse, and he has started to notice occasional numbness and clumsiness while walking. He has hypertension and peripheral artery disease. Medications include hydrochlorothiazide and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 133/92 mm Hg. Peripheral pulses are palpable in all four extremities. Neurological examination shows 5/5 strength in the upper extremities and 3/5 strength in bilateral foot dorsiflexion. Sensation to light touch is diminished bilaterally over the lateral thigh area and the inner side of the lower legs. Passive raising of either the right or left leg causes pain radiating down the ipsilateral leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of lower back pain for the past 2 weeks. The pain is stabbing and shooting in quality and radiates down the backs of his legs. It began when he was lifting a bag of cement at work. The pain has been getting worse, and he has started to notice occasional numbness and clumsiness while walking. He has hypertension and peripheral artery disease. Medications include hydrochlorothiazide and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 133/92 mm Hg. Peripheral pulses are palpable in all four extremities. Neurological examination shows 5/5 strength in the upper extremities and 3/5 strength in bilateral foot dorsiflexion. Sensation to light touch is diminished bilaterally over the lateral thigh area and the inner side of the lower legs. Passive raising of either the right or left leg causes pain radiating down the ipsilateral leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Sudden-onset back pain and sensorimotor dysfunction in a specific spinal nerve distribution that are accompanied by radicular pain (shooting down the leg) on the straight leg raise test is highly suggestive of lumbar disk herniation (likely L4).
learning_objective: Recognize lumbar disk herniation with associated radiculopathy, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: X-ray of the lumbar spine is the first-line test for suspected vertebral compression fracture (e.g., history of osteoporosis). This patient does not have any significant risk factors for compression fractures. An x-ray of the spine has limited diagnostic value in patients with suspected lumbar disk herniation and is therefore not routinely recommended.

MRI is a first-line test for diagnosing disk herniation with associated radiculopathy. In patients with progressive or severe motor deficits, saddle anesthesia, urinary retention, or bilateral symptoms (as seen in this patient), an MRI is recommended to confirm the diagnosis. In patients with disk herniation, T2 weighted MRI images typically show a hypointense disk with disk space narrowing and evidence of impingement or compression of a spinal nerve or the spinal cord (e.g., compression of the thecal sac, hyperintense edema of the spinal cord). If the patient has progressive neurological deficits, rapid assessment of the lesion is required and emergency surgical correction may be necessary.

While disk herniation is the most likely cause of this patient’s radiculopathy, an MRI would also help to rule out a neoplastic, infectious, inflammatory, or vascular etiology of his symptoms.

images.title: Spinal disk herniation with migration (3/3)
images.description: MRI lumbar spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)The desiccated disk at L4–5 is hypointense and the disk space is narrowed. Extruded disk material (green overlay) has migrated to the level of the L5 vertebral body and is compressing the thecal sac.Hatched green overlay: normal intervertebral disks

answers.content: CT scan of the lumbar spine
answers.explanation_why: CT scan of the spine without IV contrast is the initial imaging study for patients with suspected vertebral injury following blunt trauma (e.g., fall from height). In patients with suspected lumbar disk herniation, a CT scan has limited diagnostic value as it is not the best imaging study to visualize soft tissue structures. This modality may be indicated if first-line imaging is unavailable, but it is not the most appropriate next step in management of this patient.

Therapeutic exercise (e.g., physical therapy) is part of conservative therapy for muscle strain or uncomplicated disk herniation. This patient's progressive neurological symptoms and motor weakness should raise concern for a complicated disk herniation. Exercise could worsen this condition, so a complicated disease should be ruled out first in this patient.

answers.content: Ibuprofen administration and follow-up in 2 months
answers.explanation_why: Analgesia (e.g., ibuprofen) and follow-up are part of conservative therapy for muscle strain or uncomplicated disk herniation. This patient's progressive bilateral neurological symptoms and motor weakness instead raise concern for complicated disk herniation, so further investigation is required before conservative treatment would be indicated.

question_text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained driver. After extrication, he had severe upper back pain and was unable to move his legs. On arrival, he is alert and fully oriented. His neck is immobilized in a cervical collar. His pulse is 58/min, respirations are 17/min and regular, and blood pressure is 89/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. He has flaccid paralysis and absent reflexes in the lower extremities. Sensory examination shows absent sensation below the level of the nipples including absent sensation in the perianal region. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft. Rectal examination discloses no discernable resting tone and squeezing of the glans penis does not elicit anal sphincter contraction. The remainder of the examination, including a focused assessment with sonography for trauma, shows no abnormalities. A whole-body CT scan reveals an isolated burst fracture of the T3 vertebra with no evidence of facet injury. In addition to intravenous fluid therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained driver. After extrication, he had severe upper back pain and was unable to move his legs. On arrival, he is alert and fully oriented. His neck is immobilized in a cervical collar. His pulse is 58/min, respirations are 17/min and regular, and blood pressure is 89/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. He has flaccid paralysis and absent reflexes in the lower extremities. Sensory examination shows absent sensation below the level of the nipples including absent sensation in the perianal region. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft. Rectal examination discloses no discernable resting tone and squeezing of the glans penis does not elicit anal sphincter contraction. The remainder of the examination, including a focused assessment with sonography for trauma, shows no abnormalities. A whole-body CT scan reveals an isolated burst fracture of the T3 vertebra with no evidence of facet injury. In addition to intravenous fluid therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with spinal shock (flaccid, areflexic paralysis, anesthesia below the level of the injury) and neurogenic shock (bradycardia, hypotension) due to spinal cord injury (SCI). Absent sacral sparing in the spinal shock phase correlates with a high degree of autonomic dysfunction.
learning_objective: Recognize spinal shock and neurogenic shock due to spinal cord injury, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why:
Patients with spinal shock and absent sacral sparing will have impaired micturition reflexes (often with detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia) and no bladder-filling sensation. This may result in acute urinary retention with painless bladder distension and subsequent complications (e.g., hydronephrosis, worsening bradycardia from bladder distention, bladder rupture). Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is the placement of a Foley catheter. Urinary catheterization also enables the assessment of fluid balance in patients who require careful intravenous fluid therapy for the management of neurogenic shock. When fluid therapy is no longer necessary, the indwelling catheter should be replaced by an intermittent catheter (ideally 3–4 days after the injury) to decrease the risk of urinary tract infection. Intermittent catheterization to decompress the bladder also prevents autonomic dysreflexia, a late complication of SCI above T6.

Other important management steps in the management of SCI include venous thromboembolism prophylaxis, decubitus ulcer prophylaxis, pain control, and bowel care. Patients with SCI should undergo repeated, thorough neurological examinations with documentation of the findings. The return of any neurological function in the sacral segments after spinal shock resolves indicates an incomplete SCI and predicts the return of some degree of bowel and bladder control. The persistence of complete neurological impairment in the sacral segments after spinal shock resolves indicates complete SCI and a poor prognosis.

Routine use of steroids (e.g., dexamethasone) is not recommended for patients with acute nonpenetrating spinal cord injury. Although intravenous methylprednisolone was previously indicated, recent studies have shown that it does not improve neurological recovery and increases the risk of gastrointestinal hemorrhage and respiratory infection.

There is no consensus on the timing of surgical spine stabilization for a patient with vertebral column injury and SCI. Urgent surgical stabilization of the spine is typically performed if the patient has unstable injuries (e.g., bilateral facet dislocation), especially if the injury cannot be treated with closed reduction, or if the patient has progressively worsening neurological deficits. For a patient in neurogenic shock, medical management to limit spinal cord ischemia from hypoperfusion is more important before surgery is performed.

Myelography is an imaging technique that uses fluoroscopy to examine the meninges, nerve roots, and spinal cord by injecting a radiopaque dye into the spinal canal. While myelography can be used to evaluate the spinal canal when MRI is contraindicated or unavailable, it is not routinely recommended for the management of SCI.

Patients who have SCI at T6 and above are often bradycardic, as seen here. Phenylephrine can cause reflex bradycardia and should be avoided in patients who are already bradycardic. In patients with hypotension and bradycardia, atropine or vasopressors with additional inotropic and chronotropic effects (e.g., dopamine, norepinephrine) should be used. In patients with SCI, phenylephrine can be used if the SCI level is at T6 or below because bradycardia is less likely with such an injury.

answers.content: Rapid sequence intubation with manual inline stabilization
answers.explanation_why: In patients with SCI, rapid sequence intubation (RSI) for emergency airway management can be performed with manual inline stabilization of the head and neck. Intubation is performed to treat airway obstruction, to protect the airway (e.g., if the patient has or is expected to develop an altered mental status), or to allow for invasive mechanical ventilation in patients with respiratory failure. Patients are at risk of respiratory failure due to diaphragm paralysis if the SCI is at the level of C5 or above. A different step takes precedence for this patient who has an isolated spinal cord injury at the T3 vertebral level and is alert and oriented without evidence of respiratory failure.

question_text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive loss of vision in her left eye and gradual blurring of vision in her right eye over the past 2 months. She also has occasional headaches and noticed a decrease in her sense of smell lately. She has never had these symptoms before. The patient's only medication is fexofenadine for seasonal allergies. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 61 kg (135 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and there is minimal light perception in the left eye. In the swinging flashlight test, both of her eyes dilate as the light moves from the right to left eye. Fundoscopy shows papilledema in the right optic disc and a pale left optic disc. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive loss of vision in her left eye and gradual blurring of vision in her right eye over the past 2 months. She also has occasional headaches and noticed a decrease in her sense of smell lately. She has never had these symptoms before. The patient's only medication is fexofenadine for seasonal allergies. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 61 kg (135 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and there is minimal light perception in the left eye. In the swinging flashlight test, both of her eyes dilate as the light moves from the right to left eye. Fundoscopy shows papilledema in the right optic disc and a pale left optic disc. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Ipsilateral atrophy of the optic nerve (as indicated by the pale optic disc and the afferent defect seen in the swinging flashlight test), contralateral papilledema, and anosmia suggest Foster-Kennedy syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize olfactory groove meningioma.

answers.explanation_why: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is the most common inherited optic neuropathy in young adults. Optic neuropathy causes acute visual changes, but it would not cause papilledema or anosmia. Visual field testing demonstrates a central scotoma and telangiectasias around the papilla as well as microangiopathy, none of which are seen in this patient. The lack of family history of optic neuropathy also makes hereditary neuropathy unlikely.

Pseudotumor cerebri (i.e., idiopathic intracranial hypertension) should always be considered in women of childbearing age who present with subacute-to-chronic headaches and visual changes. However, pseudotumor cerebri typically affects overweight women, causes bilateral rather than unilateral papilledema, and is rarely associated with anosmia.

Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) is the most common cause of optic neuropathy in adults > 50 years old and manifests with acute visual loss. Fundoscopic examination would show pale optic disc swelling, sometimes associated with splinter hemorrhages. Unlike in this patient, AION progresses over the course of a few days (not months) and does not cause anosmia.

Frontal lobe tumors, mainly parasellar or subfrontal meningiomas, are the most common cause of Foster-Kennedy syndrome. Anosmia is typically associated with meningiomas arising from the olfactory groove (i.e., from the cribriform plate and frontosphenoidal suture), which account for 22% of all skull base meningiomas. The most appropriate next step in diagnosis is a brain MRI, which is likely to show a round, sharply demarcated space-occupying lesion (resembling a snowball) with significant contrast enhancement. Management is based on the location and grade of the tumor, as well as patient-specific factors (e.g., age, comorbidities, accompanying symptoms). Treatment that reduces elevated intracranial pressure may improve visual function.

images.title: Dural based lesion
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane) of a 58-year-old patient with parosmia.There is a large, well-defined mass with homogeneous contrast enhancement in the olfactory groove (green overlay.This is an example of an olfactory groove meningioma.

answers.explanation_why: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a common cause of optic neuritis, especially in women of childbearing age. Optic neuritis can manifest with acute vision change and a relative afferent pupillary defect. While optic neuritis may cause papillitis, which occasionally manifests with papilledema, it does not result in optic atrophy. Also, MS typically manifests with relapsing, remitting neurologic symptoms in anatomically unrelated locations (i.e., symptoms disseminated in time and space), whereas this patient's symptoms are chronic and progressive. Less commonly, MS can cause chronic, progressive symptoms, but it does not cause elevated intracranial pressure, thus it would not explain this patient's headaches.

question_text: Three days after being admitted to the hospital because of a fall from the roof of a two-story building, a 27-year-old man is being monitored in the intensive care unit. On arrival, the patient was somnolent and not oriented to person, place, or time. A CT scan of the head showed an epidural hemorrhage that was 45 mL in size and a midline shift of 7 mm; no skull fracture was shown. Emergency surgery was performed with craniotomy and hematoma evacuation on the day of admission. Perioperatively, a bleeding vessel was identified and ligated. Postoperatively, the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit and placed on a ventilator. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 117/78 mm Hg. The ventilator is set at a FiO_2 of 55%, tidal volume of 520 mL, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 5.0 cm H_2O. In addition to intravenous administration of fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's nutrition?
content_preview: Three days after being admitted to the hospital because of a fall from the roof of a two-story building, a 27-year-old man is being monitored in the intensive care unit. On arrival, the patient was somnolent and not oriented to person, place, or time. A CT scan of the head showed an epidural hemorrhage that was 45 mL in size and a midline shift of 7 mm; no skull fracture was shown. Emergency surgery was performed with craniotomy and hematoma evacuation on the day of admission. Perioperatively, a bleeding vessel was identified and ligated. Postoperatively, the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit and placed on a ventilator. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 117/78 mm Hg. The ventilator is set at a FiO2 of 55%, tidal volume of 520 mL, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 5.0 cm H2O. In addition to intravenous administration of fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's nutrition?
hint: Nutritional support primarily depends on whether a patient is on ventilation (and, if so, for how long) and whether intestinal decompression is required.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in managing nutrition for a ventilated patient postoperatively.

answers.explanation_why: Critically ill patients with an intact gastrointestinal tract can receive short-term enteral feeding via nasogastric tube (< 2–3 weeks) if there are no contraindications (e.g., bowel obstruction, intractable vomiting, hemodynamic instability). Enteral feeding is preferred over parenteral nutrition because it stimulates intestinal motility and prevents mucosal atrophy. As long as there is no facial trauma or basilar skull fractures, a nasogastric tube can be used for enteral feeding. When feeding, patients should have their backrest elevated to prevent aspiration and reduce the incidence of nosocomial pneumonia.

Nutritional support is indicated in critically ill patients with a low Glasgow coma scale who cannot be fed. Keeping the patient nil per os would only be indicated for the first 48 hours following surgery in case repeat surgery is necessary.

answers.content: Enteral feeding using a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube
answers.explanation_why: A percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube would only be considered for long-term enteral feeding, as temporary routes such as nasogastric or nasoenteric tubes often fail with long-term use because of clogging and inadvertent dislodgement. However, for the short term, a PEG tube would be too invasive in a patient with a potentially reversible condition.

Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) via an intravenous line bypasses the gastrointestinal tract. The lack of intestinal stimulation increases the risk of intestinal atrophy, increases bowel wall permeability, and alters the gut flora, making TPN inferior to other feeding methods. TPN is only indicated in patients without a functioning gastrointestinal tract (e.g., short bowel syndrome, severe malabsorption) or when complete bowel rest is indicated (e.g., bowel obstruction).
Oral feeding would be inappropriate because the patient is on mechanical ventilation with an endotracheal tube. He cannot ingest food by mouth.

question_text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 3-day history of nonbloody vomiting and poor feeding. He transitioned to pureed vegetables 10 days ago. Over the past 2 weeks, he has become increasingly irritable and within the past day has taken more daytime naps and appears much less responsive and interactive. His mother denies any history of fever or trauma at home. He has not received any vaccinations as his parents believe he is already healthy and does not need them. He spends most of the day with a babysitter while both parents are at work. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Auscultation of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The anterior fontanelle is tense and bulging. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral retinal hemorrhage. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 10,000/mm^3. An x-ray of the chest shows healing fractures of the 2^nd and 3^rd right ribs. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 3-day history of nonbloody vomiting and poor feeding. He transitioned to pureed vegetables 10 days ago. Over the past 2 weeks, he has become increasingly irritable and within the past day has taken more daytime naps and appears much less responsive and interactive. His mother denies any history of fever or trauma at home. He has not received any vaccinations as his parents believe he is already healthy and does not need them. He spends most of the day with a babysitter while both parents are at work. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Auscultation of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The anterior fontanelle is tense and bulging. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral retinal hemorrhage. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 10,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows healing fractures of the 2nd and 3rd right ribs. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Retinal hemorrhage and associated rib fractures in a 7-month-old infant should raise concern for child abuse.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of child abuse, and recall the diagnostic finding associated with shaken baby syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Tumors of the posterior fossa (e.g., juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma) are the most common pediatric primary brain tumors. A mass in the posterior fossa could gradually lead to altered mental status and could also increase intracranial pressure in a 7-month-old child to the extent that the anterior fontanelle would be tense and bulging. However, increased intracranial pressure would more likely be associated with papilledema on fundoscopic examination than retinal hemorrhages. In addition, this child's healing rib fractures should raise suspicion of a traumatic etiology.

The skeletal manifestations of vitamin D deficiency, rickets, can also be associated with pathological fractures of the ribs and other locations. However, this child has no other signs of bony deformities or fractures, and pathological fracture at an isolated location is less common in vitamin D deficiency. In addition, vitamin D deficiency is not associated with this patient's other findings of retinal hemorrhage, bulging anterior fontanelle, and altered mental status.

images.title: Rickets secondary to vitamin D deficiency fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Bacterial meningitis could lead to altered mental status, which might manifest in the irritability and lethargy seen in this child. Before the anterior fontanelle closes (at 18–24 months of age), increased intracranial pressure (e.g., due to meningitis) can cause it to bulge. Children who are septic from meningitis may also rarely present with retinal hemorrhages. However, bacterial meningitis typically presents more acutely, in a matter of hours or days. Additionally, this child is afebrile and has a normal white blood cell count, both of which are unexpected findings in children with meningitis, particularly in meningitis due to bacterial pathogens.

An epidural hematoma could also lead to irritability, lethargy, signs of increased intracranial pressure, including a bulging anterior fontanelle, and retinal hemorrhage in rare cases. However, retinal hemorrhages are less frequently associated with epidural hemorrhage than other etiologies. Additionally, an epidural hematoma would likely present more acutely and with other physical examination findings, such as a visible hematoma or swelling in the area of head trauma, which this patient does not have. While this diagnosis cannot be excluded completely, a different option is more likely.

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is commonly seen in children with shaken baby syndrome (SBS). In such cases, DAI is most likely caused by rotational acceleration-deceleration forces inflicted by violent shaking of the infant and by secondary hypoxia (e.g., due to transient apnea). Long-term deficits resulting from SBS include sight, hearing, and speech impairment. SBS has an extremely high mortality rate, with approx. 25% of affected children dying as a result of sustained injuries. Cranial CT scan in patients with SBS often shows additional brain injuries such as chronic subdural hematoma (which would explain this patient's subacute presentation over 2 weeks), subarachnoid bleeding, and/or diffuse punctate parenchymal hemorrhages.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is caused by defective synthesis of type I collagen. Patients with this disorder are prone to pathologic fractures and may present with rib fractures. Skull fractures and associated intracranial bleeding are more common in children with OI and could cause altered mental status in the absence of a history of significant trauma. However, patients with OI often have blue sclera, hearing loss, and joint laxity, which are not present in this patient. Additionally, while OI is often hard to differentiate from child abuse, the low prevalence of OI makes child abuse more likely in the general population.

Many rodenticides contain long-acting anticoagulants, such as super warfarin. Ingestion of these rodenticides can lead to coagulopathy and pathological bleeding, usually beginning about 24 hours after ingestion. This coagulopathy could cause both retinal hemorrhages and intracranial bleeding leading to altered mental status, as seen in this patient. However, coagulopathy would likely also manifest in other locations, causing gastrointestinal bleeding, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and hematuria. This patient does not have any other signs of pathological bleeding, nor would this etiology explain this patient's associated rib fractures.

                Adult: 19–25 kg/m^2

question_text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for short stature. Neither his clothing nor his shoe size has changed over the past year. He also frequently bumps into obstacles such as furniture and has headaches at night. He is always thirsty for cold water and has been urinating more frequently. Three years ago, he had an asthma attack that was treated with albuterol and a one-week course of steroids. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and had precocious puberty. His mother's height is 147 cm (4 ft 10 in) and his father's height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in). He is at the 5^th percentile for height and 5^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/64 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The genitals and pubic hair are both Tanner stage 1. Axillary hair is absent. Patellar reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:

Na^+

145 mEq/L

K^+

4.1 mEq/L

Cl^-

102 mEq/L

HCO_3^-

25 mEq/L

Ca^2+

9.4 mg/dL

Glucose
98 mg/dL

Thyroid-stimulating hormone
0.2 μU/mL

Thyroxine
3.9 μg/dL

Insulin-like growth factor 1

24 ng/mL (N= 61–356)

Insulin-like growth factor-binding protein 3
2.1 μg/mL (N = 1.6–6.5)

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for short stature. Neither his clothing nor his shoe size has changed over the past year. He also frequently bumps into obstacles such as furniture and has headaches at night. He is always thirsty for cold water and has been urinating more frequently. Three years ago, he had an asthma attack that was treated with albuterol and a one-week course of steroids. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and had precocious puberty. His mother's height is 147 cm (4 ft 10 in) and his father's height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in). He is at the 5th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/64 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The genitals and pubic hair are both Tanner stage 1. Axillary hair is absent. Patellar reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show: Na+ 145 mEq/L K+ 4.1 mEq/L Cl- 102 mEq/L HCO3- 25 mEq/L Ca2+ 9.4 mg/dL Glucose 98 mg/dL Thyroid-stimulating hormone 0.2 μU/mL Thyroxine 3.9 μg/dL Insulin-like growth factor 1 24 ng/mL (N= 61–356) Insulin-like growth factor-binding protein 3 2.1 μg/mL (N = 1.6–6.5) Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This boy has symptoms and laboratory findings suggestive of multiple hormonal deficiencies (diabetes insipidus, secondary hypothyroidism, and growth hormone deficiency). The fact that the child frequently bumps into obstacles suggests that the child has a peripheral visual field defect.
learning_objective: Recognize craniopharyngioma.

answers.explanation_why: Long-term corticosteroid therapy (e.g., for children with nephrotic syndrome) is known to cause short stature. However, children undergoing long-term steroid therapy would have a Cushingoid appearance characterized by obesity (unlike this child with a weight at the 5^th percentile) and a moon-like facies. This child was only on a week-long course of corticosteroids, which would not result in a short stature.
An expanding Rathke cleft cyst can cause headaches, visual field defects, and multiple hormone deficiencies due to hypopituitarism. However, symptoms usually occur between the ages of 30–50 years.

Schmidt syndrome, the most common form of autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome, can manifest with decreased thyroxine levels (due to hypothyroidism) as well as polyuria and polydipsia (due to type 1 diabetes mellitus). However, Schmidt syndrome is more common among women between 20–60 years of age and is associated with elevated TSH levels (primary hypothyroidism). GH deficiency (suggested by decreased IGF-1 levels) and short stature would be unexpected. Moreover, normal serum glucose along with headache and visual field defects suggest that polyuria and polydipsia in this patient are caused by central diabetes insipidus rather than diabetes mellitus.

Constitutional growth delay is a diagnosis of exclusion that is made once other causes of short stature have been ruled out. A different cause for short stature is more likely on account of the presence of multiple hormone deficiencies, headache, and visual field defects.

Although a low mid-parental height suggests a diagnosis of familial short stature, which is one of the most common causes of short stature, the presence of multiple hormone deficiencies, headache, and visual field defects indicates a different diagnosis.

Craniopharyngiomas are the most common cause of acquired hypopituitarism among children. This child presents with features of hypopituitarism such as growth hormone deficiency (as indicated by a low insulin-like growth factor 1 and short stature), diabetes insipidus (as indicated by polyuria and polydipsia), and secondary hypothyroidism (as indicated by hyporeflexia, low thyroid-stimulating hormone, and low thyroxine levels). Headache is caused by compression of the adjacent brain parenchyma and/or stretching of the dura mater, while visual field defects are the result of compression of the optic chiasm. A craniopharyngioma can be diagnosed by an MRI of the brain, which typically reveals a suprasellar mass that extends into the sella turcica. Craniopharyngiomas are excised surgically using a transfrontal approach.

Patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) may develop pituitary adenomas, which can result in headaches, visual field defects, and multiple hormone deficiencies (due to destruction of the normal pituitary gland). However, pituitary adenomas in patients with MEN 1 usually develop during adulthood. In addition, by the time pituitary adenomas become symptomatic, patients almost always have increased serum calcium levels due to primary hyperparathyroidism, which is usually the earliest endocrine manifestation of MEN 1.

A large, nonsecretory pituitary adenoma may result in headaches, visual field defects, and multiple hormone deficiencies due to hypopituitarism. However, symptoms usually occur between the ages of 30–60 years. A different diagnosis is more likely in this 8-year-old boy.

question_text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a headache and double vision 1 hour after being hit on the head while playing with a friend. Her friend's elbow struck her head, just above her left ear. She did not lose consciousness, but her mother reports that she was confused for 20 minutes after the incident and did not recall being hit. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows the head tilted toward the right shoulder. A photograph of the eyes at primary gaze is shown. The finding in the patient's left eye worsens when she is asked to look to the right side or tilt her head toward her left shoulder. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the left temporal bone. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes when tested independently. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Muscle strength and sensation are intact bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows a flexor response. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
content_preview: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a headache and double vision 1 hour after being hit on the head while playing with a friend. Her friend's elbow struck her head, just above her left ear. She did not lose consciousness, but her mother reports that she was confused for 20 minutes after the incident and did not recall being hit. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows the head tilted toward the right shoulder. A photograph of the eyes at primary gaze is shown. The finding in the patient's left eye worsens when she is asked to look to the right side or tilt her head toward her left shoulder. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the left temporal bone. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes when tested independently. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Muscle strength and sensation are intact bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows a flexor response. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
hint: This patient has unilateral hypertropia in the primary gaze (i.e., while looking straight ahead), which can be due to ipsilateral weakness of eye depressors or contralateral weakness of eye elevators. Worsening of this patient's hypertropia in the right lateral gaze (on left eye adduction) and when the patient tilts her head to the left shoulder (on left eye intorsion) suggests ophthalmoplegia of the left superior oblique muscle (SOM).
learning_objective: Recognize trochlear nerve damage.

answers.explanation_why: The trochlear nerve innervates only the superior oblique muscle (SOM), which is a depressor and intortor of the eyeball. Trochlear nerve damage, therefore, causes hypertropia and vertical diplopia, as seen here. Hypertropia due to left SOM palsy worsens during right lateral gaze because the SOM is the only muscle that can depress an adducted eye. Hypertropia due to SOM palsy also worsens when the head is tilted toward the ipsilateral shoulder because the superior rectus muscle (an elevator) takes over the role of the paralyzed SOM as the primary intortor, resulting in elevation of the eye. To decrease vertical diplopia, patients with SOM ophthalmoplegia tilt their head away from the affected side (compensatory head tilt), like this patient who tilts her head to the right. The trochlear nerve is the cranial nerve that is most commonly damaged in cases of trauma, because its long course and thin diameter make it vulnerable to shearing injury.

images.title: Trochlear nerve palsy
images.description: Trochlear nerve palsy (here of the left eye) causes paralysis of the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle. This leads to hypertropia (upwards deviation) and excyclotorsion (outward rotation) of the affected eye (middle image). Patients typically present with vertical or oblique diplopia. Hypertropia and diplopia may increase with ipsilateral head-tilt (right image) and decrease with contralateral head-tilt (left image; patients may adopt this posture as a compensatory posture).

answers.explanation_why: Retrobulbar hemorrhage from trauma is an ophthalmologic emergency that can result in strabismus and diplopia. However, patients would have proptosis, severe eye pain, periorbital ecchymosis, subconjunctival hemorrhage, and/or visual impairment due to occlusion of the central retinal artery and/or optic neuropathy.
Abducens nerve damage causes lateral rectus palsy, which leads to an impaired abduction of the ipsilateral eye and horizontal, not vertical strabismus.

images.title: Abducens nerve palsy
images.description: Abducens nerve palsy (here of the left eye) impairs the function of the lateral rectus muscle. This causes esotropia (medial deviation) of the affected eye and limits its abduction. Patients present with horizontal diplopia that worsens when turning the gaze to the affected side or looking at distant objects.

answers.explanation_why: Damage to the oculomotor nerve (CN III) leads to strabismus due to unopposed contraction of the lateral rectus and the superior oblique muscle. This typically results in eye abduction and depression with the pupil looking “down and out” in primary gaze, as opposed to this patient's hypertropia. Complete oculomotor palsy would additionally result in ptosis (due to denervation of the levator palpebrae superioris) and mydriasis (due to loss of parasympathetic innervation to the pupillary sphincter).

images.title: Oculomotor nerve palsy
images.description: Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

answers.explanation_why: Damage to the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) leads to internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), which may manifest with diplopia and strabismus. However, these symptoms only manifest with gaze to the side contralateral to the lesion as a result of ipsilateral adduction weakness that occurs only during horizontal conjugate eye movements. Patients also have horizontal nystagmus in the contralateral eye with abduction, and a characteristic absence of ipsilateral adductor weakness during disconjugate movements (e.g., convergence). Moreover, trauma is an extremely rare cause of INO which more often occurs in multiple sclerosis or following a brainstem stroke.

Damage to the dorsal midbrain can cause Parinaud syndrome, which manifests with impaired upgaze in both eyes and dilated nonreactive pupils. This patient has hypertropia in one eye and reactive pupils in both eyes. Moreover, Parinaud syndrome is most commonly seen in patients with hydrocephalus or posterior midbrain compression (e.g., pineal tumors); trauma is an extremely rare cause of Parinaud syndrome.

images.title: Hypertropia
images.description: While the right eye fixates straight, the left eye deviates upwards (hypertropia). This may be due to congenital superior oblique palsy or trochlear nerve palsy.
