question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of hearing loss and unsteadiness while standing and walking for the past 2 months. She needs to support herself against a wall to avoid falling. She has not had any recent injuries and has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an unsteady gait. She sways when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She is unable to hear fingers rubbing next to her ears or repeat words whispered in her ears. An MRI of the brain shows a 3-cm tumor in the right cerebellopontine angle and a 4.5-cm tumor in the left cerebellopontine angle. This patient should be counseled that she is at greatest risk for which of the following?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of hearing loss and unsteadiness while standing and walking for the past 2 months. She needs to support herself against a wall to avoid falling. She has not had any recent injuries and has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an unsteady gait. She sways when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She is unable to hear fingers rubbing next to her ears or repeat words whispered in her ears. An MRI of the brain shows a 3-cm tumor in the right cerebellopontine angle and a 4.5-cm tumor in the left cerebellopontine angle. This patient should be counseled that she is at greatest risk for which of the following?
hint: Hearing loss and impaired balance in combination with tumors in the cerebellopontine angles raise concern for acoustic neuromas. Bilateral acoustic neuromas are characteristic of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).
learning_objective: Recognize neurofibromatosis type 2, and recall its associated nervous system tumors.

answers.explanation_why:
In addition to bilateral acoustic neuromas, which occur in almost all individuals with NF2 by the age of 30 years, NF2 can cause multiple tumors of the nervous system, such as intracranial and spinal meningiomas, schwannomas of other cranial nerves, and ependymomas. Most meningiomas are slow-growing and patients may therefore be asymptomatic for a prolonged period of time. If symptoms do occur, they usually include general symptoms of CNS tumors (e.g., seizures) or more specific symptoms that are determined by the location of the tumor (e.g., paraparesis and/or uncontrolled micturition if the tumor arises from the falx cerebri). Other typical clinical findings of NF2 include early-onset bilateral cataracts, seizures, skin nodules, and café au lait spots (see “Overview of neurocutaneous syndromes” table).

The clinical features of acoustic neuromas are caused by compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII) as a result of the tumor expanding into the internal acoustic meatus. Sensorineural hearing loss, which is the most common presenting symptom, and tinnitus are due to cochlear nerve involvement, whereas dizziness, unsteady gait, and disequilibrium indicate vestibular nerve involvement.

images.title: Dural based mass
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

answers.explanation_why: Optic gliomas are often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Other tumors that may occur in patients with NF1 include benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors originating from neural crest cells (neurofibromas), pheochromocytomas, and nephroblastomas. The presence of bilateral acoustic neuromas, however, is not associated with NF1. Moreover, patients with NF1 usually present with typical skin findings (due to melanocyte dysfunction) such as café au lait spots and axillary/inguinal freckling, as well as musculoskeletal findings (e.g., scoliosis, tall stature, and bone involvement) and Lisch nodules of the iris, none of which are seen in this patient.

Telangiectasias on the face and conjunctivae are typical findings in patients with ataxia telangiectasia. Other manifestations include progressive cerebellar ataxia (due to atrophy of the cerebellar vermis), athetosis, immunodeficiency (e.g., increased susceptibility to ear infections, sinusitis, and pneumonia), and increased sensitivity to radiation resulting in a higher risk of malignancies (e.g. non-Hodgkin lymphoma, leukemia). However, the finding of bilateral acoustic neuromas is not typical in patients with ataxia telangiectasia. Furthermore, symptoms typically manifest during early childhood.

Vascular malformations of the choroid and the central nervous system such as ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas are a typical feature of Sturge-Weber syndrome. These malformations may result in seizures, early-onset glaucoma (due to increased intraorbital pressure), and intellectual disability. Patients also often present with a facial nevus flammeus (port-wine stain). However, acoustic neuromas are not associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

images.title: Sturge-Weber syndrome
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with Sturge-Weber syndromeMarked, leptomeningeal contrast enhancement along the right parieto-occipital gyri and sulci can be seen (green overlay).

answers.explanation_why: The occurrence of (bilateral) renal cell carcinoma is associated with von Hippel‑Lindau disease. This neurocutaneous syndrome is characterized by the development of numerous benign and malignant tumors, including hemangioblastomas (highly vascularized in the retina, cerebellum, brain stem, and spine), pheochromocytomas, and renal and pancreatic cysts. Bilateral acoustic neuromas, however, are not a typical feature.

Giant cell astrocytomas are frequently associated with tuberous sclerosis. Other benign growths that frequently manifest in patients with tuberous sclerosis include hamartomas of the brain, cardiac rhabdomyomas, renal cysts, renal angiomyolipomas, and ungual fibromas. The brain lesions typically result in infantile spasms (head bobbing, flexor or extensor spasms in children < 3 years of age), seizures, and intellectual disability. Furthermore, skin manifestations, such as adenoma sebaceum, ash-leaf spots, and a Shagreen patch are commonly seen in patients with tuberous sclerosis. However, acoustic neuromas are not a feature of tuberous sclerosis and the condition is usually diagnosed before the age of 10.

question_text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain for the past 2 days. The pain is constant and nonradiating, and he describes it as 7 out of 10 in intensity. The pain began after he helped a friend move into a new apartment. He has a history of intravenous heroin use.  He takes no medications.  His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 128/90 mm Hg. Examination shows old track marks on the cubital fossae bilaterally. His lumbar paraspinal muscles are firm and tense on palpation. There is no midline spinal tenderness. Flexing the hip and extending the knee while raising the leg to 70° on both sides does not cause pain. Sensation is not impaired. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain for the past 2 days. The pain is constant and nonradiating, and he describes it as 7 out of 10 in intensity. The pain began after he helped a friend move into a new apartment. He has a history of intravenous heroin use. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 128/90 mm Hg. Examination shows old track marks on the cubital fossae bilaterally. His lumbar paraspinal muscles are firm and tense on palpation. There is no midline spinal tenderness. Flexing the hip and extending the knee while raising the leg to 70° on both sides does not cause pain. Sensation is not impaired. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has acute back pain  without features of radiculopathy or myelopathy (e.g., shooting or shock-like pain, weakness, numbness) following a task that likely involved lifting heavy objects, which is consistent with acute lower back strain.
learning_objective: Recognize acute lower back strain, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Epidural glucocorticoid injections may provide modest symptomatic relief in patients with lumbosacral radiculopathy that persists for > 6 months. This patient has no signs of radiculopathy, and he has only had symptoms for 2 days, so epidural glucocorticoids are not indicated.

Although refraining from strenuous activity is prudent for back strain, strict bed rest is not recommended because this may actually lead to deconditioning and worse pain. Studies have shown that bed rest is associated with a longer recovery time compared to mild to moderate activity in patients with acute musculoskeletal lower back pain.

Analgesia, preferably with NSAIDs, and continuation of normal activities (except strenuous exercise) is the treatment of choice for acute musculoskeletal lower back pain. Almost all cases of musculoskeletal lower back pain resolve on their own within ∼ 6 weeks. Analgesia reduces discomfort, and mild to moderate activity is associated with better outcomes than bed rest. Further testing (e.g., MRI) should be considered in patients with back pain if there is high suspicion for a serious or urgent underlying cause (e.g., spinal infection) and in individuals whose symptoms have not significantly improved after ∼ 6 weeks. Muscle relaxants such as cyclobenzaprine or tizanidine can be used as alternatives or in combination with NSAIDs for the treatment of acute lower back pain.

MRI of the spine may be indicated in patients with back pain if there is high suspicion of a serious or urgent underlying cause (e.g., spinal infection) and in individuals whose symptoms have not significantly improved after ∼ 6 weeks. Although a history of IV drug use is a red flag for infection (e.g., epidural abscess), this patient has none of the typical features (e.g., fever, rigors, specific tender point, neurological deficits). This patient's recent history and physical examination strongly suggest acute musculoskeletal lower back pain.

Lumbar x-ray is indicated if a vertebral compression fracture is suspected. While lumbar compression fractures manifest with lower back pain, they usually occur in patients at risk of pathological fracture (e.g., > 50 years old, osteoporosis, or malignancy) or after significant trauma (e.g., motor vehicle collision) and cause midline point tenderness on exam. This patient is young, has no clear risk factors for compression fracture, did not experience significant trauma, and has no midline tenderness.

Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy is indicated in patients if a bacterial cause of lower back pain is suspected (eg, epidural abscess, osteomyelitis). This patient is at increased risk of infection (history of IV drug use); however, he has no history of fever. Furthermore, patients with lower back pain caused by infection are typically more severely ill.

question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of early morning headaches for the past 6 months. During this period, he has had severe nausea and occasional episodes of vomiting. For the past month, he has had difficulty walking and intermittent double vision. He was born at term and has been healthy apart from an episode of sinusitis 8 months ago that resolved spontaneously. He is at the 60^th percentile for height and 50^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 105/64 mm Hg. Examination shows normal muscle strength and 2+ deep tendon reflexes bilaterally. He has a broad-based gait and impaired tandem gait. Fundoscopy shows bilateral swelling of the optic disc. There is esotropia of the left eye. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of early morning headaches for the past 6 months. During this period, he has had severe nausea and occasional episodes of vomiting. For the past month, he has had difficulty walking and intermittent double vision. He was born at term and has been healthy apart from an episode of sinusitis 8 months ago that resolved spontaneously. He is at the 60th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 105/64 mm Hg. Examination shows normal muscle strength and 2+ deep tendon reflexes bilaterally. He has a broad-based gait and impaired tandem gait. Fundoscopy shows bilateral swelling of the optic disc. There is esotropia of the left eye. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This tumor is derived from primitive neuroectodermal tissue.
learning_objective: Recognize medulloblastoma in a child.

answers.explanation_why: Optic gliomas may cause esotropia, visual impairment, and can potentially lead to increased intracranial pressure. However, these tumors are uncommon and would not cause ataxia.

images.title: Intraconal orbital mass
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)There is a large hyperintense mass (green overlay) in the left intraconal space displacing the ocular globe out of the orbital cavity (exophthalmos). The intraconal space is located posterior to the globe and contained within the cone formed by the recti muscles. The mass is well-defined and displaces rather than invades surrounding structures. The left optic nerve is not visualized on this image, and the mass either arises from it or displaces it. The normal-appearing right optic nerve (red overlay) is well visualized.The differential diagnosis for intraconal masses depends on whether or not the lesion is continuous with the optic nerve. Differential diagnoses for masses involving the optic nerve include, but are not limited to, meningioma, glioma, and lymphoma. Differential diagnoses for masses not involving the nerve include, but are not limited to, hemangioma, schwannoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma.

answers.explanation_why: Schwannomas are most commonly located in the cerebellopontine angle (acoustic/vestibular schwannomas) and typically manifest with tinnitus, hearing loss, dizziness, and/or disequilibrium from cranial nerve VIII (CN VIII) compression. Although ataxia and hydrocephalus may result from compression of posterior fossa structures in late stages of the disease, this patient has no auditory symptoms (the onset of which would be insidious) and is uncharacteristically young (the median age is 50 years).

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Pituitary adenomas may cause bitemporal hemianopsia from compression of the optic chiasm, hypopituitarism, or other syndromes from excess secretion of pituitary hormones. These tumors do not typically cause ataxia and are much more common in adults.

images.title: Pituitary mass 2/2
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactinA large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: Craniopharyngiomas may present with headaches and vomiting (due to obstructive hydrocephalus and traction on surrounding structures), as well as visual symptoms (typically bitemporal hemianopsia from compression of the optic chiasm). However, the lack of additional symptoms, such as hyperprolactinemia/delayed growth or central diabetes insipidus from compression of the anterior or posterior pituitary gland, makes this diagnosis less likely. In addition, ataxia would be an uncommon finding in craniopharyngioma.

images.title: Craniopharyngioma
images.description: MRI head (T1 weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane) of a patient with acute visual loss in the right eyeThere is an intrasellar and suprasellar mass (green overlay) with both cystic and solid portions. The solid portions show strong contrast enhancement.

answers.explanation_why: Although hemangioblastoma may manifest with ataxia and increased intracranial pressure, these tumors are rare and most commonly occur in adults.

images.title: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
images.description: MRI head (with contrast; axial view)A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: While meningiomas are the most common primary central nervous system tumors in adults (with a peak incidence in the sixth decade of life), they are rarely found in children. Due to their slow growth, meningiomas are usually asymptomatic, but they may manifest with seizures or focal neurologic deficits resulting from compression or increased intracranial pressure due to obstructive hydrocephalus. They are not usually associated with ataxia.

images.title: Dural based mass
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

answers.explanation_why:
Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children, with a peak incidence between 3–5 years of age. The mass is characteristically located in the cerebellum. Patients typically present with symptoms of hydrocephalus/increased ICP and involvement of the cerebellar vermis such as vomiting, morning headaches, ataxia, and cranial nerve dysfunction. Spinal drop metastases are found in about 40% of cases.

Ependymomas are often located in the posterior fossa and may also manifest with signs of hydrocephalus, as well as ataxia and cranial nerve dysfunction. However, these tumors are less common than medulloblastomas, accounting for ∼ 10% of pediatric brain tumors.

images.title: Medulloblastoma
images.description:
Cranial MRI (T1-weighted, with contrast)There is a mass in the posterior cranial fossa. It features solid parts (green overlay) and cystic parts (red overlay).Location and appearance are typical of a medulloblastoma.

(D: diencephalon; P: pons; C: cerebellum; yellow outline: cerebellar tentorium)

question_text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 24-hour history of severe, left-sided headache and neck pain. She says that the symptoms started after completing a half-marathon. Shortly after the headache started, she also had weakness of the right upper extremity and sudden loss of vision in her left eye, both of which subsided after a few minutes. Medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications. On arrival, she is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 77/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the left eyelid and a constricted left pupil. Visual acuity in both eyes is 20/20. There is no swelling of the optic discs. Muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal bilaterally. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Duplex ultrasonography of the neck shows an absent flow in the left internal carotid artery. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 24-hour history of severe, left-sided headache and neck pain. She says that the symptoms started after completing a half-marathon. Shortly after the headache started, she also had weakness of the right upper extremity and sudden loss of vision in her left eye, both of which subsided after a few minutes. Medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications. On arrival, she is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 77/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the left eyelid and a constricted left pupil. Visual acuity in both eyes is 20/20. There is no swelling of the optic discs. Muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal bilaterally. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Duplex ultrasonography of the neck shows an absent flow in the left internal carotid artery. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Severe ipsilateral head and neck pain and partial Horner syndrome (ptosis and miosis) in combination with duplex ultrasonography findings of absent flow in the left internal carotid artery indicate a carotid artery dissection. This patient also likely experienced the complication of a transient ischemic attack (TIA), characterized by extremity weakness and amaurosis fugax.
learning_objective: Recognize carotid artery dissection, and choose the most appropriate antithrombotic therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Oxygen is the first-line treatment for cluster headaches. Although cluster headaches can present with ptosis and headache, they classically occur as recurrent attacks (up to 8 times per day) of pain in either an orbital or temporal distribution. Additionally, pain in cluster headaches typically does not involve the neck, nor do they cause cerebrovascular accidents such as TIAs.

Sumatriptan is commonly used to treat migraines. A migraine aura may present with neurologic symptoms (e.g., extremity weakness and visual loss) that classically precede a migraine headache. However, this patient experienced headache and neck pain before the onset of neurologic symptoms. Similarly, migraine auras tend to develop gradually and symptoms typically migrate from one side of the body to the other. Lastly, they do not cause cerebrovascular accidents such as TIAs.

Intravenous mannitol is used for the management of intracranial hypertension, which may occur after ischemic stroke or subarachnoid hemorrhage, both of which are complications of carotid artery dissection. Although this patient had a carotid artery dissection with ischemic neurologic symptoms (upper extremity weakness, vision loss) she does not have any signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g., papilledema, Cushing reflex).

Treatment with antithrombotic agents (either antiplatelet drugs or anticoagulants such as heparin) is indicated for carotid artery dissection after ruling out intracranial hemorrhage. Spontaneous carotid artery dissections generally have a good prognosis, but patients should be treated with an anticoagulant agent for 3–6 months and/or an antiplatelet agent for one year to reduce the risk of associated cerebrovascular accidents (such as TIA).

Thrombolytic therapy (e.g., alteplase) is often used to treat acute ischemic stroke, which can be a complication of carotid dissection. Although this patient had unilateral extremity weakness and amaurosis fugax, these symptoms resolved within a few minutes, suggesting a transient ischemic attack. This patient presents with ptosis and miosis without anhidrosis, indicating partial Horner syndrome, likely due to internal carotid artery dissection. Brain ischemia causes full rather than partial Horner syndrome. Furthermore, there is no evidence of ischemia on CT scan 24 hours after symptom onset.

question_text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of progressive weakness of his lower extremities and urinary incontinence for the past 2 weeks. Over the past 2 months, he has had increasing back pain. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 106/60 mm Hg. Examination shows an ataxic gait. Muscle strength is decreased in bilateral lower extremities. Sensation to pain and temperature and position sense are absent in the buttocks, perineum, and lower extremities. Ankle clonus is present. Digital rectal examination is unremarkable. An x-ray of the spine shows multiple sclerotic lesions in the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of progressive weakness of his lower extremities and urinary incontinence for the past 2 weeks. Over the past 2 months, he has had increasing back pain. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 106/60 mm Hg. Examination shows an ataxic gait. Muscle strength is decreased in bilateral lower extremities. Sensation to pain and temperature and position sense are absent in the buttocks, perineum, and lower extremities. Ankle clonus is present. Digital rectal examination is unremarkable. An x-ray of the spine shows multiple sclerotic lesions in the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The presence of back pain, urinary incontinence, and progressive muscle weakness with ankle clonus as well as decreased sensation over the lower extremities are indicative of spinal cord compression. The sclerotic lesions on x-ray suggest osteoblastic metastases.
learning_objective: Recognize osteoblastic vertebral metastases, and recall the diagnostic finding of the most likely underlying primary cancer.

answers.explanation_why: A left testicular mass suggests testicular cancer. Although metastatic testicular cancer may cause spinal cord compression, it manifests with a mix of osteolytic and osteoblastic lesions rather than osteoblastic lesions alone. In this age group (> 60 years), lymphomas are the most common neoplasm of the testes, rather than primary testicular cancers. While metastatic lymphoma can manifest with sclerotic, lytic, or mixed bone lesions, another tumor entity is much more likely to be responsible for this patient's sclerotic bone lesions.

An irregular, asymmetric mole could be a malignant melanoma. Although malignant melanoma may manifest with bone metastasis, causing spinal cord compression, this disease would cause osteolytic lesions rather than osteoblastic ones.
An enlarged thyroid lobe may indicate thyroid cancer. Although thyroid cancer may cause vertebral metastases, this condition manifests with osteolytic instead of osteoblastic lesions.

Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen may suggest colon cancer. Although colon cancer can metastasize to the bones and manifest with osteoblastic metastases, this outcome is not a frequent finding (seen in only 5–10% of cases of advanced colorectal cancer). Instead, the liver and lung (in that order) are the most common sites of metastases in colorectal carcinoma. The absence of symptoms associated with colorectal cancer, such as a change in bowel habits, melena or hematochezia, signs of anemia, and/or weight loss, make colon cancer unlikely.

answers.content: Bence Jones protein in the urine
answers.explanation_why: Bence Jones protein in the urine suggests multiple myeloma (MM). This malignancy is the most common primary tumor of the spine and may manifest with spinal cord compression. However, MM causes osteolytic rather than osteoblastic lesions. Furthermore, while MM is often asymptomatic, advanced disease, which is suggested by this patient's multiple bone lesions, is likely to manifest with symptoms of anemia (e.g., pallor, fatigue), leukopenia (e.g, increased susceptibility to infections), or hypercalcemia (e.g., abdominal pain).

images.title: Lytic calvarial lesions in multiple myeloma
images.description: X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myelomaMultiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.

answers.explanation_why:
The combination of this patient's male sex, advanced age (> 50 years), and osteoblastic bone lesions strongly suggests prostate cancer, in which elevated prostate-specific antigen levels are expected. Advanced-stage prostate cancer commonly metastasizes to the spine, causing spinal cord compression and predominantly osteoblastic lesions (osteolytic lesions may occur but are rare). Prostate cancer is the most common cause of osteoblastic metastases, which manifest with increased density and sclerotic appearance on x-ray.

In most patients with metastatic prostate cancer, the digital rectal examination (DRE) reveals asymmetric areas, indurations, or frank nodules within the prostate, but the absence of findings on DRE alone does not exclude prostate cancer.

images.title: Sclerotic bone metastases in prostate cancer
images.description: X-ray abdomen and pelvis (AP view) of a patient with prostate cancerMultiple sclerotic lesions are present throughout the lumbar spine, pelvis, and proximal femurs (overlay).Sclerotic (osteoblastic) bone metastases are less common than osteolytic metastases. They are seen with prostate, breast, bladder (transitional cell), and bowel (mucinous) cancers, neuroendocrine tumors, and lymphoma.

question_text: A 66-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 4 hours after falling and hitting her head while skiing. Initially, she refused treatment, but an hour ago she began to develop a severe headache, nausea, and right leg weakness. She has osteopenia. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She has no visual changes and is oriented to person, time, and place. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min and regular, and blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a 5-cm bruise on the left side of her skull. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Muscle strength is 0/5 in her right knee and foot. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 66-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 4 hours after falling and hitting her head while skiing. Initially, she refused treatment, but an hour ago she began to develop a severe headache, nausea, and right leg weakness. She has osteopenia. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She has no visual changes and is oriented to person, time, and place. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min and regular, and blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a 5-cm bruise on the left side of her skull. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Muscle strength is 0/5 in her right knee and foot. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Focal deficits involving the lower limbs indicate involvement of the superior segment of the motor cortex.
learning_objective: Recognize subfalcine herniation.

answers.explanation_why: Tonsillar herniation can occur due to any mass effect in the superior part of the skull (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage) and manifests with symptoms of cerebellar and medullary compression (e.g., altered mental status, cardiorespiratory depression). While this patient likely has an intracranial hemorrhage, she has a normal mental and cardiorespiratory status. Moreover, her hemiplegia suggests an alternative diagnosis.

Upward brainstem herniation is rare and usually results from a brainstem mass (e.g., tumor), rather than intracranial hemorrhage, which is suspected in this patient. Typical findings include miosis, decerebrate posturing, doll's eyes, and altered mental status. This patient has pupils that appear normal, normal mental status, and no abnormal posturing, making upward brainstem herniation unlikely.

Uncal herniation leads to compression of the ipsilateral oculomotor nerve (causing a fixed and dilated pupil), the ipsilateral posterior cerebral artery (causing cortical blindness with contralateral homonymous hemianopia), and the contralateral cerebral peduncle (causing ipsilateral paralysis). While this patient is at risk of uncal herniation and has hemiplegia, she has a normal pupillary exam and has no visual symptoms.

Subfalcine herniation is the most common cerebral herniation syndrome and is usually due to cingulate gyrus herniation under the falx cerebri, causing compression of the ipsilateral pericallosal arteries (branches of the anterior cerebral artery), leading to consequent contralateral lower limb weakness. Unlike other cerebral herniation syndromes, patients with subfalcine herniation have no pupillary changes and, in the early stages, can have a normal mental status. Severe subfalcine herniation will cause obstruction of the contralateral foramen of Monro leading to noncommunicating hydrocephalus from dilation of the contralateral lateral ventricle.

This patient's subfalcine herniation is most likely due to traumatic intracranial hemorrhage (e.g., subdural hemorrhage, epidural hemorrhage), given her recent fall involving head trauma. Without emergent diagnosis and treatment, expanding intracranial hemorrhage can cause rapid progression of subfalcine herniation to brainstem herniation and death. Emergency noncontrast head CT confirms the diagnosis and neurosurgical consultation is necessary for likely craniectomy.

images.title: Brain herniation
images.description: Brain herniations occur as a result of increased intracranial pressure, such as that caused by subdural hematomas. Variations include herniation of brain tissue under the falx cerebri (1), below the tentorium cerebelli (2, 3), downwards through the foramen magnum (4), above the tentorium cerebelli (5), or outside of the skull (6).

answers.explanation_why: Central transtentorial herniation is caused by global cerebral edema and causes herniation of the diencephalon and midbrain. Typical findings include altered mental status, pupillary abnormalities, and extensor posturing. This patient presents with normal mental status and has a normal ocular exam, making central transtentorial herniation unlikely. Moreover, her unilateral motor symptoms suggest an alternative diagnosis.

Extracranial herniation occurs when brain tissue passes through a defect in the skull (e.g., fracture), with neurologic deficits due to compression of the tissue as it passes through the defect. While this patient has a focal neurologic deficit, there is no evidence of skull fracture (e.g., focal tenderness or skull depression) or brain tissue herniating through the skull (e.g., bulge near area of fracture).

question_text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent heaviness and paresthesia of the right arm for the past 2 months. She has also had multiple episodes of lightheadedness while painting a mural for the past 2 weeks. During these episodes, she was nauseated and had blurred vision. Her symptoms resolved after she drank some juice. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include metformin, glipizide, enalapril, and atorvastatin. She appears anxious. Examination shows decreased radial and brachial pulses on the right upper extremity. The skin over the right upper extremity is cooler than the left. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent heaviness and paresthesia of the right arm for the past 2 months. She has also had multiple episodes of lightheadedness while painting a mural for the past 2 weeks. During these episodes, she was nauseated and had blurred vision. Her symptoms resolved after she drank some juice. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include metformin, glipizide, enalapril, and atorvastatin. She appears anxious. Examination shows decreased radial and brachial pulses on the right upper extremity. The skin over the right upper extremity is cooler than the left. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient likely has a lower blood pressure reading in her right arm compared to the left one.
learning_objective: Recognize subclavian steal syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Sulfonylureas, such as glipizide, frequently cause hypoglycemia and any combination of antidiabetic drugs is associated with an increased risk of hypoglycemic episodes. Hypoglycemia can manifest with lightheadedness, weakness, blurred vision, and nausea, with improvement of symptoms after oral intake of glucose (e.g., drinking juice). However, the association between arm activity (e.g., painting a mural) and her symptoms makes a drug side effect less likely. Additionally, medication side effect would not explain decreased pulses in this patient's right arm.

answers.content: Reversed blood flow in the right vertebral artery
answers.explanation_why:
Reversed blood flow in the right vertebral artery into the distal subclavian artery rather than towards the brainstem occurs in subclavian steal syndrome. Given this patient's vascular risk factors (i.e., hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension), she most likely has an atherosclerotic occlusive plaque in the right subclavian artery. Reduced blood flow explains the heaviness, paresthesia, decreased pulses, and cooler skin of her right arm (i.e., upper extremity ischemia). Furthermore, exertion of the arm leads to retrograde blood flow through the vertebral artery so that the distal subclavian “steals” blood from the brain and causes her presyncopal symptoms (lightheadedness, nausea, and blurred vision) that resolve with rest.

Treatment for subclavian steal syndrome involves control of atherosclerotic disease and antiplatelet therapy. Depending on the severity and location of the occlusion, percutaneous or open revascularization may be performed.

images.title: Pathophysiology of subclavian steal syndrome
images.description: Under normal conditions, the subclavian artery distributes blood equally to the arteries in the brain and arms (A). If there is stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery, this leads to hypoperfusion of the upper extremities on the affected side (B). This is compensated by a contralateral circulation, in which there is increased blood flow from the unaffected side to the affected side via the vertebral arteries. As a result, there is hypoperfusion of the vertebrobasilar territory and corresponding central nervous system symptoms.

answers.explanation_why: Diabetic neuropathy is caused in part by an accumulation of advanced glycosylation end products, which leads to microvascular disease and subsequent nerve fiber damage. Diabetic neuropathy is a chronic, progressive disease that classically begins symmetrically in the distal lower extremities and ascends proximally. This patient's symptoms only occur in the upper extremity, are associated with exercise, and are episodic in nature.

answers.content: Compression of neurovascular structures in the neck
answers.explanation_why: Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is caused by compression of the nerves and vessels above the first rib. Neurogenic symptoms of TOS may include weakness and paresthesias of the upper extremity associated with upper extremity movement (especially overhead), similar to the symptoms described by this patient. Compression of the subclavian artery may occur in < 1% of cases (leading to lower blood pressure and decreased pulses in the affected arm), but it does not cause the central neurologic symptoms shown by this patient (i.e., lightheadedness, nausea, blurred vision).

answers.content: Infarction of the middle cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: A left middle cerebral artery stroke may manifest with several symptoms including hemiplegia of the upper extremity. However, symptoms would not be transient or episodic over a period of months. This patient has no focal neurological deficits on examination, which makes ischemic stroke unlikely. Also, asymmetric radial pulses would not be seen in a cerebral artery infarct.

question_text: A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of urinary and fecal incontinence for 6 hours. Earlier in the day, he fell off a ladder at a construction site and sustained injuries to his back and thighs but did not seek medical attention. He took ibuprofen for lower back pain. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the lumbar spine and bilateral symmetric lower extremity weakness. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the ankles and 2+ in the knees. Rectal tone is decreased. Abdominal ultrasound shows a distended bladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of urinary and fecal incontinence for 6 hours. Earlier in the day, he fell off a ladder at a construction site and sustained injuries to his back and thighs but did not seek medical attention. He took ibuprofen for lower back pain. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the lumbar spine and bilateral symmetric lower extremity weakness. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the ankles and 2+ in the knees. Rectal tone is decreased. Abdominal ultrasound shows a distended bladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The patient's history of recent trauma and current symptoms are consistent with spinal compression.
learning_objective: Recognize conus medullaris syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: This patient has conus medullaris syndrome as a result of compression of the most distal region of the spinal cord from his recent accident. Conus medullaris syndrome typically manifests with both upper and lower motor neuron signs. Bladder and bowel dysfunction within hours of the injury, hyperreflexia of the ankles, symmetric lower extremity weakness, and back pain are all consistent with this diagnosis (see “Compressive myelopathies” table).

images.title: Conus medullaris and cauda equina syndromes
images.description: 1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equinaWhile disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

answers.explanation_why: Cauda equina syndrome (CES) can be due to compression of the nerve roots below where the spinal cord terminates, which may be caused by trauma. However, CES typically manifests with asymmetric muscle weakness, decreased reflexes, and saddle anesthesia due to damage of the lower motor neurons, which is not consistent with this patient's symmetric muscle weakness and hyperreflexia. In addition, bowel and bladder dysfunction are late findings of CES and would not be expected within hours of injury. Lastly, because of nerve root compression, the pain usually radiates along the sensory distribution of the nerves affected.

Anterior spinal cord syndrome can manifest with acute motor weakness and bowel and bladder dysfunction as a result of occlusion of the anterior spinal cord artery and ischemia to the corticospinal tracts and autonomic fibers. However, in this syndrome, the spinothalamic tract is also affected, resulting in pain and temperature sensation deficits, which this patient lacks.

Brown-Sequard syndrome manifests with ipsilateral proprioception and vibration sense loss, ipsilateral flaccid paralysis, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature, which are not consistent with the neurological findings in this patient. Instead, this patient has bilateral lower extremity weakness without sensory deficits. Furthermore, a fall is unlikely to result in Brown-Sequard syndrome, which is usually caused by penetrating injuries to the back.

The cerebellum is supplied by the posterior circulation, and a stroke in this region can be due to dissection of the vertebral artery as a result of trauma. However, cerebellar stroke usually manifests with unilateral signs of ataxia, which this patient lacks. In addition, a cerebellar stroke would not explain this patient's bilateral motor weakness, hyperreflexia of the ankles, and bowel and bladder dysfunction.

A spinal epidural abscess can cause cord compression, resulting in symptoms of weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and back pain, which are seen in this patient. However, spinal epidural abscess results in systemic symptoms, such as fever and malaise, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, the absence of common risk factors for epidural abscess (e.g., IV drug use, recent spine procedure, and contiguous soft tissue infection) and the recent trauma suggest another diagnosis.

question_text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of increasing back pain for the past 2 weeks. She is unable to perform her daily chores. One month ago, she fell and hurt her back while working outside in the garden. The pain subsided with over-the-counter acetaminophen. She underwent a left mastectomy 1 year ago for breast cancer. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and a multivitamin. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows thoracic vertebral tenderness. She has mild stiffness on neck flexion. Muscle strength is decreased in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to pain, fine touch, temperature, and proprioception is intact. Her hemoglobin concentration is 13.1 g/dL, and leukocyte count is 19,300/mm^3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of increasing back pain for the past 2 weeks. She is unable to perform her daily chores. One month ago, she fell and hurt her back while working outside in the garden. The pain subsided with over-the-counter acetaminophen. She underwent a left mastectomy 1 year ago for breast cancer. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and a multivitamin. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows thoracic vertebral tenderness. She has mild stiffness on neck flexion. Muscle strength is decreased in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to pain, fine touch, temperature, and proprioception is intact. Her hemoglobin concentration is 13.1 g/dL, and leukocyte count is 19,300/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Back pain, fever, leukocytosis, and focal neurological findings (lower extremity weakness) in a patient with diabetes and a history of trauma to the back raise concern for spinal infection (e.g., spinal epidural abscess, vertebral osteomyelitis).
learning_objective: Recognize spinal epidural abscess, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Conservative management with NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) without further diagnostic workup is recommended for the treatment of benign musculoskeletal causes of back pain, such as muscle strain and mild to moderate spinal stenosis or spinal disk herniation. While bed rest can be considered in patients with severe unspecific back pain, early mobilization is indicated in most patients with back pain due to muscular or ligamentous strain. However, patients with signs of infection (e.g., fever and leukocytosis) and focal neurological findings require an urgent diagnostic workup.

X-ray of the spine can be helpful in the diagnostic workup of various causes of back pain, such as vertebral fractures, spinal stenosis, degenerative spondylolisthesis, and metastases to the bony spine. However, x-ray is not the first-line imaging study in patients with suspected spinal infection because of its low specificity and sensitivity, especially in the first few weeks of infection.

Corticosteroid therapy (e.g., with methylprednisone) is used to treat patients with suspected malignant compression of the spine. This patient has a history of breast cancer, and vertebral bodies are a common location of breast cancer metastasis. However, this patient's features strongly suggest spinal infection, which may be exacerbated by corticosteroid therapy.

Empiric antimicrobial therapy for spinal infections is indicated in patients with suspected spinal epidural abscess, new or progressive neurological symptoms, and/or signs of hemodynamic instability or sepsis. Vancomycin is part of the recommended empiric antibiotic therapy for spinal infections. Although vancomycin has excellent coverage of gram-positive pathogens including methicillin-resistant S. aureus, it does not cover gram-negative pathogens and is therefore usually administered in combination with a third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin. Nafcillin also covers only gram-positive pathogens and would not increase the coverage of vancomycin.

MRI of the spine is the first-line imaging modality for patients with suspected spinal infections. MRI provides high-resolution imaging, which helps to determine the location and extent of the infection and facilitates the planning of surgical intervention. Two sets of blood cultures should also be obtained to identify the causative pathogen. Empiric antimicrobial therapy for spinal infections is indicated in patients with suspected spinal epidural abscess, new or progressive neurological symptoms, and/or signs of hemodynamic instability or sepsis; if none of these features are present, antibiotic therapy can be delayed until the causative organism is identified. Additionally, given this patient's neurological deficits, surgical drainage and decompression should also be considered.

images.title: Spinal epidural abscess, osteomyelitis, and discitis
images.description: MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)High signal intensity collections are seen in the posterior epidural space. The largest collection (blue overlay) causes anterior displacement and high-grade compression of the spinal cord from C7-T2. The appearance is consistent with epidural abscess. The differential would also include epidural hematoma.High signal intensity consistent with osteomyelitis and discitis involves the C6 and C7 vertebral bodies (green overlay), prevertebral soft tissues (red overlay), and intervening disc space (yellow overlay).

question_text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of increasing weakness of her extremities and neck pain that is worse on coughing or sneezing. She first noticed weakness of her right upper extremity 3 years ago, which progressed to her right lower extremity 2 years ago, her left lower extremity 1 year ago, and her left upper extremity 6 months ago. She has had difficulty swallowing and speaking for the past 5 months. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an ataxic gait. Speech is dysarthritic. Muscular examination shows spasticity and muscle strength is decreased in all extremities. There is bilateral atrophy of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar response shows an extensor response bilaterally. Sensation to touch is decreased over all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of increasing weakness of her extremities and neck pain that is worse on coughing or sneezing. She first noticed weakness of her right upper extremity 3 years ago, which progressed to her right lower extremity 2 years ago, her left lower extremity 1 year ago, and her left upper extremity 6 months ago. She has had difficulty swallowing and speaking for the past 5 months. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an ataxic gait. Speech is dysarthritic. Muscular examination shows spasticity and muscle strength is decreased in all extremities. There is bilateral atrophy of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar response shows an extensor response bilaterally. Sensation to touch is decreased over all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The pattern of this patient's symptom progression suggests CNS compression in a particular location.
learning_objective: Recognize foramen magnum meningioma.

answers.explanation_why: Although the falx cerebri, the supratentorial convex surface, and the sphenoidal wings are the most common locations of meningiomas, in rare cases they also occur at the foramen magnum. Since meningiomas are slow-growing tumors, patients usually present after several months to years of slowly progressive symptoms. Early features include neck pain, which is typically worse with neck flexion and maneuvers that increase ICP (e.g., coughing, sneezing). Later, patients with meningiomas at the foramen magnum present with long tract signs and a characteristic pattern of symptom distribution: sensory and motor deficits typically start in one extremity and spread to the others. Late presentation is characterized by spastic quadriparesis (hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign), gait disturbances, and lower cranial nerve palsies (CN IX–XII), which most likely accounts for this patient's dysarthria and atrophy of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

images.title: Foramen magnum meningioma
images.description: MRI of the neck and base of the skull (left: T1-weighted, with contrast, sagittal plane; right: T2-weighted, sagittal plane)There is a well-defined mass in the anterior aspect of the foramen magnum, which enhances on the T1-weighted post-contrast image (red overlay) and appears hyperintense to gray matter on the T2-weighted image (green overlay). The mass is continuous with the adjacent thickened and enhancing dura (arrowhead). This is known as the “dural tail sign.”The dural tail sign suggests lesion originates from the dura mater. The sign is most commonly seen in meningiomas but may also be seen in other malignancies originating in the dura mater, such as lymphoma and metastasis.

answers.explanation_why: Pilocytic astrocytomas are grade I (benign) astrocytomas that are often localized in the cerebellum and most frequently occur in children and young adults. Signs of cerebellar masses include symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, and vomiting), ataxia, and possibly failure to thrive. While an ataxic gait could be caused by a cerebellar tumor, this patient's muscle weakness, sensory symptoms, and dysarthria suggest another diagnosis.

images.title: Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma
images.description: MRI head (a: T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane; b: T2-weighted; axial plane) of a childA large lesion in the right cerebellar hemisphere displaces the vermis to the left of midline. It has a large cystic component (T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense; red overlay) and a heterogeneously enhancing solid nodular component (green overlay).Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma frequently manifests as a large cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule.

answers.explanation_why: In syringomyelia, the compression from the fluid-filled cavity within the central spinal cord results in neck pain and a cape-like distribution (neck, shoulders, arms) of dissociated sensory loss, which develops over years. The sensory symptoms in syringomyelia are often exacerbated by maneuvers that increase the intramedullary pressure, such as coughing or sneezing. Muscle atrophy is another common feature of syringomyelia and most commonly affects the small muscles of the hand. Other signs of lower motor neuron lesion, such as fasciculations and areflexia (rather than this patient's hyperreflexia), may also be present. While spastic paraparesis of the limbs is a possible feature of syringomyelia due to involvement of the pyramidal tract and first motor neuron, quadriparesis is uncommon.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) manifests with signs of upper motor neuron (e.g., hyperreflexia, spastic paresis, positive Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron involvement (e.g., atrophy), both of which are present in this patient. ALS may also initially manifest with bulbar symptoms (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia) and/or asymmetrical limb weakness, which often begins unilaterally in an upper extremity and progresses with the disease. However, this patient's sensory symptoms are not consistent with ALS, which is a motor neuron disease.

images.title: Clinical features and pathophysiology of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
images.description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

answers.explanation_why: In multiple sclerosis (MS), demyelination of CNS neurons may result in upper motor neuron weakness characterized by spasticity, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign. Dysarthria is also present in almost half of all MS cases at some point during the course of the disease. However, the most common course of MS is relapsing-remitting, which progresses with alternating phases of exacerbations and remission rather than simply progressive. Also, atrophy of the muscles innervated by cranial nerve XI is not a typical feature of MS.

images.title: Multiple sclerosis
images.description: MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)At the level of the fourth cervical vertebral body, there is an area of poorly defined hyperintensity within the spinal cord (green overlay). The first cervical vertebra is not well visualized in this image due to its shape, whereas the second cervical vertebra is well recognized due to the superior projected bony element known as the dens or odontoid process.This is an example of a demyelinating plaque in a patient with multiple sclerosis. Spinal cord demyelinating plaques from multiple sclerosis are most often found in the cervical segment of the cord. They are usually shorter than two vertebral bodies in length.

answers.explanation_why: A glioblastoma multiforme is most commonly located in the white matter of the cerebral hemispheres and therefore most frequently manifests with signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, seizures). Symptoms develop over a short period of time (several weeks) due to rapid growth of the tumor. While the condition can manifest with motor weakness, the pattern of symptom progression over 3 years seen in this patient is not consistent with glioblastoma multiforme.

images.title: Bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma)
images.description: T1-weighted contrast-enhanced MRI, frontal view: bihemisphere garland-like contrast enhancement. There is peripheral contrast agent enhancement (blue overlay) with central necrosis (green overlay). The third ventricle (arrowhead) is centrally located. The tumor is displacing the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle (red overlay). Diagnosis: bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma).

question_text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in her lower back. The pain radiates to the back of her right leg and is worse at night. She reports decreased sensation around her buttocks and inner thighs. During the last several days, she has had trouble urinating. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and was treated with lumpectomy and radiation. Her only medication is anastrozole. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity and 2/5 strength in the right lower extremity. Knee and ankle reflexes are 1+ on the right. Resting anal sphincter tone is normal, but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in her lower back. The pain radiates to the back of her right leg and is worse at night. She reports decreased sensation around her buttocks and inner thighs. During the last several days, she has had trouble urinating. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and was treated with lumpectomy and radiation. Her only medication is anastrozole. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity and 2/5 strength in the right lower extremity. Knee and ankle reflexes are 1+ on the right. Resting anal sphincter tone is normal, but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Two features specific to this patient's diagnosis are severe radicular pain and asymmetric weakness.
learning_objective: Recognize cauda equina syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Conus medullaris syndrome (CMS) is caused by damage to the spinal cord segments T12–L2 and can manifest with lower back pain, radicular pain, distal paresis, perianal numbness, and urinary incontinence. The onset of symptoms is typically sudden, whereas this patient's symptoms have developed gradually over 3 weeks. In addition, distal paresis in patients with CMS is usually symmetric, in contrast to this patient's asymmetric weakness. Finally, CMS is not associated with decreased sensation of the thighs.

The gradual development of asymmetric lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, bladder dysfunction, decreased anal tone, and severe back pain that radiates to lower limbs is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome. Cauda equina syndrome is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given this patient's history of breast cancer, spinal imaging including MRI is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.

images.title: Conus medullaris and cauda equina syndromes
images.description: 1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equinaWhile disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

answers.explanation_why: Central cord syndrome can result in weakness and urinary retention. However, the weakness associated with central cord syndrome is usually symmetric and more prominent in the upper extremities. In addition, patients with this condition often experience loss of pain and temperature sensation in dermatomes near the level of the spinal cord lesion. Finally, central cord syndrome does not typically cause radiculopathy or decreased perianal and thigh sensation.

Brown-Sequard syndrome can result in unilateral lower extremity weakness and urinary retention. This condition is characteristically associated with ipsilateral diminished sensation and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the spinal lesion, whereas this patient has unilateral radicular pain.

Anterior spinal cord syndrome classically results in symmetric loss of motor function and pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion. This patient has asymmetric symptoms, including unilateral radicular pain.

question_text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after the sudden onset of dizziness, blurry vision, and a raspy voice. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, coronary artery disease, and hypertension. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks three to four beers daily. His current medications include metformin, atenolol, lisinopril, furosemide, and aspirin. His temperature is 36.6°C (98°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. The pupil on the left is pinpoint. There is ptosis of the left eye. Horizontal nystagmus is present. The gag reflex is diminished. When he stands without support, he falls towards his left side. There is loss of pain and temperature sensation over the left face and right trunk and limbs. Occlusion of which of the following arteries is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after the sudden onset of dizziness, blurry vision, and a raspy voice. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, coronary artery disease, and hypertension. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks three to four beers daily. His current medications include metformin, atenolol, lisinopril, furosemide, and aspirin. His temperature is 36.6°C (98°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. The pupil on the left is pinpoint. There is ptosis of the left eye. Horizontal nystagmus is present. The gag reflex is diminished. When he stands without support, he falls towards his left side. There is loss of pain and temperature sensation over the left face and right trunk and limbs. Occlusion of which of the following arteries is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: A crossed pattern of sensory loss (involvement of one side of the face and the limbs on the opposite side) in addition to unilateral cranial nerve deficits, vestibular disturbances, dysphonia, loss of pain and temperature sensation, and ptosis with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation of the trunks and limbs is consistent with Wallenberg syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Wallenberg syndrome, and recall its associated arterial occlusion.

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) is the most common cause of lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome). However, if the right PICA was affected, the patient would have right-sided (ipsilateral) ataxia, as well as impaired pain and temperature sensation of the right face and left (contralateral) body. Horner syndrome would also occur on the right side.

A stroke in the right MCA territory would result in sensory loss on the left (contralateral) side of the face, upper limbs, and trunk. However, in this case, all sensory modalities would be affected (not just pain and temperature) and left-sided (contralateral) motor deficits would almost always also be present. Patients with a right MCA stroke typically also have left-sided hemineglect (since the nondominant hemisphere is involved).

Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) is the most common cause of lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome). Damage to the structures in the lateral medulla manifests with the following features: dizziness (vestibular nucleus), ipsilateral ataxia (inferior cerebellar peduncle), impaired pain and temperature sensations in the ipsilateral side of the face (inferior part of the trigeminal nerve nucleus) and contralateral side of the body (spinothalamic tract), ipsilateral Horner syndrome as suggested by ptosis and miosis (descending sympathetic fibers), and dysphonia with an ipsilaterally impaired gag reflex (nucleus ambiguus). Rapid nystagmus and miosis result in blurry vision. Motor deficits are typically not seen because the pyramidal tract lies ventromedially in the medulla, outside the territory of the PICA.

images.title: Wallenberg syndrome
images.description:
Wallenberg syndrome results from occlusion of either the vertebral artery or its branch, the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). Occlusion leads to lateral medullary infarction, which can affect multiple brainstem areas in the following ways:– Lateral spinothalamic tract (purple): contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the trunk and limbs
– Trigeminal nucleus (purple): ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face
– Vestibular nucleus (red): vertigo with falling to the affected side and nystagmus to the opposite side
– Inferior cerebellar peduncle (dark blue): ataxia and dysmetria
– Nucleus ambiguus (green): dysphagia, hoarseness, and a decreased gag reflex
– Sympathetic fibers (light blue): Horner syndromeNucleus ambiguus injury and damage to sympathetic fibers can both cause persistent hiccups.

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the left internal carotid artery would classically result in a watershed infarct between the territory of the left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) and left middle cerebral artery (MCA). A left ACA-MCA watershed infarct can result in sensory deficits of the face, arm, and/or leg on the right (contralateral) side. However, all sensory modalities would be affected (not just pain and temperature) and right-sided (contralateral) motor deficits would almost always also be present. A crossed pattern of sensory loss, dysphonia, and a diminished gag reflex are not seen in patients with ACA-MCA watershed infarcts.

Occlusion of the left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) would result in weakness and sensory loss in the lower limb of the right (contralateral) side. Other features include urinary incontinence, behavioral abnormalities, primitive reflexes (e.g., grasp reflex), and/or transcortical aphasia (since the dominant hemisphere is involved). A crossed pattern of sensory loss, dysphonia, and a diminished gag reflex are not seen in patients with ACA infarcts.

Occlusion of the right internal carotid artery would classically result in a watershed infarct between the territory of the right anterior cerebral artery (ACA) and right middle cerebral artery (MCA). A right ACA-MCA watershed infarct results in sensory deficits of the face, arm, and/or leg on the left (contralateral) side. However, all sensory modalities would be affected (not just pain and temperature) and left-sided (contralateral) motor deficits would almost always also be present. A crossed pattern of sensory loss, dysphonia, and a diminished gag reflex are not seen in patients with ACA-MCA watershed infarcts.

Occlusion of the right anterior cerebral artery (ACA) would result in weakness and sensory loss in the lower limb of the left (contralateral) side. Other features include urinary incontinence, behavioral abnormalities, primitive reflexes (e.g., grasp reflex), and/or left-sided hemineglect (since the nondominant hemisphere is affected). A crossed pattern of sensory loss, dysphonia, and a diminished gag reflex are not seen in patients with ACA infarcts.

A stroke in the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory would result in sensory loss on the right (contralateral) side of the face, upper limbs, and trunk. However, in this case, all sensory modalities would be affected (not just pain and temperature) and right-sided (contralateral) motor deficits would almost always also be present. Patients with a left MCA stroke typically also have some form of aphasia (since the dominant hemisphere is involved).

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.explanation_why: A right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) infarct involving the thalamus may result in an isolated sensory loss but of the left (contralateral) side of both the face and body. Additionally, patients with an infarct in the territory of the right PCA typically present with left (contralateral) homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.explanation_why: A left posterior cerebral artery (PCA) infarct involving the thalamus may result in isolated sensory loss but of the right (contralateral) side of both the face and body. Additionally, patients with an infarct in the territory of the left PCA typically present with right (contralateral) homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. Involvement of the left PCA would also result in alexia without agraphia (since the dominant hemisphere is involved).
