question_text:
A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion and generalized fatigue over the past week. During this period, she has had muscle cramps, headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Six days ago, she underwent resection of a parasagittal meningioma. She tolerated the procedure well without complications and was discharged two days ago. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Current medications include oxycodone, acetaminophen, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. She is oriented only to person and place. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:

Serum

 Na^+

126 mEq/L

 K^+

3.6 mEq/L

 Cl^-

107 mEq/L

 Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dL

 Glucose
87 mg/dL

 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL

 Osmolality

263 mOsmol/kg H_2O

Urine

 Osmolality

523 mOsmol/kg H_2O

 Sodium

44 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion and generalized fatigue over the past week. During this period, she has had muscle cramps, headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Six days ago, she underwent resection of a parasagittal meningioma. She tolerated the procedure well without complications and was discharged two days ago. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Current medications include oxycodone, acetaminophen, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. She is oriented only to person and place. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show: Serum Na+ 126 mEq/L K+ 3.6 mEq/L Cl- 107 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 16 mg/dL Glucose 87 mg/dL Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL Osmolality 263 mOsmol/kg H2O Urine Osmolality 523 mOsmol/kg H2O Sodium 44 mEq/L Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Serum osmolality and volume status are important for differentiating the etiology of hyponatremia. This patient's serum osmolality is low (hypotonic) and she does not have edema or signs of hypovolemia, making her euvolemic. Euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia in the context of recent neurosurgery is suggestive of a specific underlying condition.
learning_objective: Recognize syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

answers.explanation_why: Cerebral salt wasting syndrome, which may occur in patients after neurosurgical procedures, is a poorly understood cause of hypovolemic, hypotonic hyponatremia. Patients with cerebral salt wasting syndrome have a low serum osmolality, as seen here, but also present with symptoms of hypovolemia (e.g., hypotension, tachycardia) and paradoxical polyuria.

answers.content: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
answers.explanation_why: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) can occur following injury to the CNS and is an important differential diagnosis to consider for any neurosurgery patient presenting with hyponatremia. SIADH causes euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia. Increased activity of antidiuretic hormone decreases free-water clearance, which results in a low serum osmolality (< 280 mOsmol/kg H_2O), and inappropriately concentrated urine (> 100 mOsmol/kg H_2O). Since patients with SIADH are typically euvolemic and therefore do not retain sodium through activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, there will be normal to high urine sodium excretion (> 20–30 mEq/L). Given the severity of this patient's hyponatremia, she should be treated with restriction of oral fluids and administration of hypertonic saline. The correction of hyponatremia should be gradual (maximum increase of 10–12 mmol/L within 24 hours, or 0.5 mmol/L/hour) and under ICU observation, as rapid correction can lead to central pontine myelinolysis. In patients with SIADH and severe hyponatremia, the use of vasopressin receptor antagonists such as tolvaptan may be considered if serum sodium either continues to drop or fails to rise by 2 mmol/L after 24 hours.

images.title: Diagnosis of hyponatremia
images.description:
FE_Na: fractional excretion of sodium
SIADH: syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
TURP: transurethral resection of the prostate
U_Na: urine sodium
U_Osm: urine osmolality

answers.explanation_why: Opioids such as oxycodone can cause sedation, confusion, nausea, and vomiting in postoperative patients, even at normally prescribed doses. However, patients with an opioid overdose present with miosis and respiratory depression. This patient has a normal respiratory rate, is not hypoxemic, and does not have pinpoint pupils on examination.

Primary polydipsia (psychogenic polydipsia) leads to euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia, as seen here. However, this patient does not complain of excessive thirst, and there is no history of the patient drinking unusual amounts of water. Moreover, patients with primary polydipsia and hyponatremia have decreased urine sodium levels (< 20–30 mEq/L) and a urine osmolality < 100 mOsmol/kg H_2O (maximally diluted urine).

Mineralocorticoid deficiency (hypoaldosteronism) would result in hyponatremia with decreased serum osmolality (hypotonic hyponatremia) and urine sodium levels > 20–30 mEq/L. However, patients present with signs of hypovolemia (e.g., hypotension, tachycardia), hyperkalemia, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. This patient has a normal K^+ level and is euvolemic.

question_text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of headache, blurred vision, and numbness of the right leg for the past 2 hours. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril and metformin. He is oriented only to person. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 158/94 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to fine touch and position is decreased over the right lower extremity. The confrontation test shows loss of the nasal field in the left eye and the temporal field in the right eye with macular sparing. He is unable to read phrases shown to him but can write them when they are dictated to him. He has short-term memory deficits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of headache, blurred vision, and numbness of the right leg for the past 2 hours. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril and metformin. He is oriented only to person. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 158/94 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to fine touch and position is decreased over the right lower extremity. The confrontation test shows loss of the nasal field in the left eye and the temporal field in the right eye with macular sparing. He is unable to read phrases shown to him but can write them when they are dictated to him. He has short-term memory deficits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient has sudden-onset neurologic symptoms, most likely caused by a stroke. He presents with vision loss in the right halves of the visual field (nasal field on the left and temporal field on the right), which is consistent with right-sided homonymous hemianopia. This finding suggests the involvement of the visual pathways behind the optical chiasma.
learning_objective: Recognize left posterior cerebral artery infarct.

answers.content: Infarct of the right middle cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral cortex, including the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the face and upper extremities. Stroke of the right MCA manifests with contralateral (i.e., left) homonymous hemianopia without macular sparing due to damage to the optic radiations. In addition, patients usually experience contralateral sensory loss and paralysis of the upper extremity, lower extremity, and lower half of the face with gaze deviation towards the side of the stroke. If the stroke occurs in the nondominant (typically the right) hemisphere, patients may also present with hemineglect. This patient has right-sided homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, sensory impairment without motor impairment, no gaze deviation, and alexia without agraphia rather than hemineglect, making this diagnosis unlikely.

answers.content: Infarct of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Patients with ischemic stroke of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) present with Wallenberg syndrome, or lateral medullary syndrome. Occlusion of the left PICA leads to ischemia and necrosis of the left lateral medulla. Patients experience ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, palatal weakness and dysphagia, vertigo, hemiataxia, and contralateral truncal sensory disturbances. This patient has decreased sensation of his right leg rather than right trunk, and the description of his verbal difficulties is more consistent with alexia than dysphagia. He exhibits none of the classic signs and symptoms for a PICA infarct.

answers.content: Infarct of the right posterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the visual cortex of the occipital lobe. Patients with right-sided PCA stroke present with homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing on the left, not right. Patients with right-sided PCA strokes also often present with prosopagnosia due to damage to the fusiform face area, a symptom not experienced by this patient.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.content: Infarct of the right anterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the anteromedial cortex, including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the lower extremities. Patients with stroke of the right ACA present with sensory and motor loss in the contralateral (i.e., left) lower limb; however, this patient has sensory findings in the right lower extremity. In addition, ACA stroke results in limb apraxia, urinary incontinence, dysarthria, and aphasia, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, ACA stroke does not typically result in homonymous hemianopia.

Patients with HSV encephalitis present with a prodrome of headache, fever, nausea, and vomiting, followed by an acute onset of altered mental status, seizures, and psychiatric symptoms or behavioral changes (e.g., hypersexuality, hypomania, agitation). Patients also present with focal neurologic deficits (e.g., dysphasia, ataxia, hemiparesis, cranial nerve signs). Although this patient does have altered mental status, visual field deficits, and memory loss, he does not present with other symptoms of HSV encephalitis.

answers.content: Infarct of the left middle cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral cortex, including the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the face and upper extremities. Stroke of the left MCA manifests with contralateral (i.e., right) homonymous hemianopia, typically without macular sparing due to damage to the optic radiations. In addition, patients usually experience contralateral sensory loss and paralysis of the upper extremity, lower extremity, and lower half of the face with gaze deviation towards the side of the stroke. If the stroke occurs in the dominant (typically the left) hemisphere, patients may also present with aphasia. This patient has right-sided homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, sensory impairment without motor impairment, no gaze deviation, and alexia without agraphia rather than aphasia, making this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.content: Infarct of the left anterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Patients with ischemic stroke of the left anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) present with lateral pontine syndrome due to ischemia of the left inferolateral pons, including cranial nerve nuclei. Symptoms include ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, facial paralysis and droop, decreased taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, vertigo, audiovestibular dysfunction, and ataxia. This patient exhibits none of these symptoms.

answers.content: Infarct of the left anterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the anteromedial cortex, including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the lower extremities. Patients with stroke of the left ACA present with sensory and motor loss in the contralateral (i.e., right) lower limb, and while this patient does have sensory findings in the right lower extremity, muscle strength is still intact. In addition, ACA stroke results in limb apraxia, urinary incontinence, dysarthria, and aphasia, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, ACA stroke does not typically result in homonymous hemianopia.

answers.content: Infarct of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Patients with ischemic stroke of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) present with Wallenberg syndrome, or lateral medullary syndrome. Occlusion of the right PICA leads to ischemia and necrosis of the right lateral medulla. Patients experience ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, palatal weakness and dysphagia, vertigo, hemiataxia, and contralateral truncal sensory disturbances. This patient has decreased sensation of his right leg rather than left trunk, and the description of his verbal difficulties is more consistent with alexia rather than dysphagia. He exhibits none of the classic signs and symptoms for a PICA infarct.

answers.content: Infarct of the left posterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the posteroinferior cortex, including the visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Stroke in this area most commonly manifests with contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, as seen in this patient, because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery. Because the PCA also supplies the lateral parts of the thalamus, patients may also report contralateral hemisensory abnormalities such as numbness or paresthesia in the limbs, trunk, and/or chest. Further manifestations include memory deficits, vertigo, and nausea. If the PCA of the dominant (usually the left) hemisphere is affected, patients may also present with alexia without agraphia, anomic aphasia, and/or visual agnosia due to ischemic damage to the splenium of the corpus callosum, which carries visual information from the visual cortex to the Broca area and Wernicke area. If the PCA of the nondominant (usually the right) hemisphere is affected, patients may present with prosopagnosia.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.content: Infarct of the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Patients with ischemic stroke of the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) present with lateral pontine syndrome due to ischemia of the right inferolateral pons, including cranial nerve nuclei. Symptoms include ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, facial paralysis and droop, decreased taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, vertigo, audiovestibular dysfunction, and ataxia. This patient exhibits none of these symptoms.

Patients with ophthalmic or retinal migraine present with headache and monocular visual impairments, such as scotomas, bright flashing lights, or complete monocular blindness. A migraine can cause paresthesias, but is usually preceded by a prodrome of yawning, difficulty writing or reading, mood changes, and, in some cases, an aura. This patient has a headache, but no history of a prodrome prior to this event. In addition, he has bilateral visual impairment rather than unilateral.

question_text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of weakness of his left leg for the past hour. He was unable to get out of bed that morning. His pants are soaked with urine. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include enalapril, carvedilol, aspirin, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are reactive to light. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the left lower extremity. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left. Sensation is decreased in the left lower extremity. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time and has a flat affect. When asked to count backwards from 20, he stops after counting to 17. When asked to name 10 words beginning with the letter “d,” he stops after naming two words. Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of weakness of his left leg for the past hour. He was unable to get out of bed that morning. His pants are soaked with urine. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include enalapril, carvedilol, aspirin, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are reactive to light. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the left lower extremity. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left. Sensation is decreased in the left lower extremity. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time and has a flat affect. When asked to count backwards from 20, he stops after counting to 17. When asked to name 10 words beginning with the letter “d,” he stops after naming two words. Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient has sudden-onset neurologic symptoms. An inability to complete goal-directed tests such as counting backward from 20 or naming words starting with the letter “d” together with a flat affect indicates abulia, which is usually the result of damage to the frontal lobe.
learning_objective: Recognize right anterior cerebral artery occlusion.

answers.explanation_why: Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) may manifest with urinary incontinence and behavioral changes including a flattened affect and abulia. However, this condition is a gradually progressive disease, unlike the acute presentation in this patient. Although patients with NPH may have a feeling of weakness and numbness, true sensory deficits or lower limb weakness severe enough to impair movement are not typically seen. Instead, gait abnormalities (typically a shuffling, wide-based gait) are usually the earliest sign.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery would result in lateral medullary syndrome, which is characterized by hoarseness, dysphagia, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral preganglionic Horner's syndrome, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensations over the face ipsilaterally and in the contralateral side of the body. Urinary incontinence, motor deficits, and clinical features of frontal lobe damage are not usually seen.

A large infarct in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) may result in abulia as well as sensory and motor deficits. However, neurologic deficits would occur in the right limb rather than the left one and are usually more prominent in the upper limb and trunk when compared to the lower limb. Patients with a left MCA stroke would also have dysphasia.

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery results in infarction of the lateral caudal pons and/or ischemia in the territory of the labyrinthine artery. Patients present with ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral preganglionic Horner's syndrome, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensations over the face ipsilaterally and in the contralateral side of the body. Urinary incontinence, motor deficits, and clinical features of frontal lobe damage (e.g., abulia, flat affect) are not usually seen.

A large infarct in the territory of the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) can cause abulia and sensory and motor neurologic deficits on the left side of the body. However, neurologic deficits are usually more prominent in the upper limb and trunk than in the lower limb. Also, a patient with a massive right MCA stroke would present with left hemineglect (if the right hemisphere is nondominant) or aphasia (if the right hemisphere is dominant).

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the anteromedial cortex, including the medial part of the frontal lobe and parietal lobe. These areas provide motor and sensory innervation of the lower extremities as well as control of micturition. Occlusion of the postcommunal segment (distal to the circle of Willis) of the right ACA typically results in upper motor neuron weakness manifesting with a contralateral positive Babinski sign, sensory deficits of the contralateral lower limb, and urinary incontinence. Signs of frontal lobe damage (e.g., abulia), as well as aphasia and limb apraxia, may also be present.

A right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion typically results in left homonymous hemianopia, not urinary incontinence and frontal lobe signs such as abulia. Larger PCA infarcts may occasionally cause hemisensory loss and/or hemiparesis. However, other features such as prosopagnosia (in individuals where the right hemisphere is the nondominant one) would also be expected.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) manifests with urinary incontinence and abulia with sensory loss and upper motor neuron weakness in the lower limb (which causes a positive Babinski sign). However, the neurologic deficits in a left ACA stroke would appear in the right lower limb, not the left one.

Encephalitis that predominantly affects the medial temporal lobe is characteristic of herpes simplex encephalitis, which may manifest with focal neurologic deficits. However, in almost all patients, the onset of neurologic deficits would be preceded by fever, headache, and/or vomiting. Other clinical features such as memory loss, emotional lability, and/or dysphasia would also be present.

Hypertensive encephalopathy is a hypertensive emergency that occurs in patients with a mean arterial pressure >180 mm Hg and can cause neurologic deficits and nonlocalizing signs of cerebral edema, such as severe headache, nausea, and/or vomiting. Furthermore, hypertensive encephalopathy typically has an insidious onset, in contrast to the acute onset in this patient. Other features such as findings of grade IV hypertensive retinopathy on fundoscopy (flame-shaped hemorrhage, papilledema, and/or cotton wool spots) would also be present.

A left posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion typically results in right homonymous hemianopia, not urinary incontinence and frontal lobe signs such as abulia. Larger PCA infarcts may occasionally cause hemisensory loss and/or hemiparesis. However, in a patient with a large left PCA infarct, the contralateral (right not left) limb would be affected, and other clinical features such as alexia without agraphia would be present.

question_text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was found screaming and clutching his head. He has had nausea and occasional episodes of vomiting for 1 week, fever and left-sided headache for 2 weeks, and increasing tooth pain over the past 3 weeks. He has no history of ear or sinus infections. He is in moderate distress. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 122/85 mm Hg. He is confused and only oriented to person. The pupils react sluggishly to light. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema bilaterally. Extraocular movements are normal. Flexion of the neck causes hip flexion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was found screaming and clutching his head. He has had nausea and occasional episodes of vomiting for 1 week, fever and left-sided headache for 2 weeks, and increasing tooth pain over the past 3 weeks. He has no history of ear or sinus infections. He is in moderate distress. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 122/85 mm Hg. He is confused and only oriented to person. The pupils react sluggishly to light. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema bilaterally. Extraocular movements are normal. Flexion of the neck causes hip flexion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: An MRI of the brain would likely show an intraparenchymal lesion with peripheral ring enhancement.
learning_objective: Recognize a pyogenic brain abscess.

answers.explanation_why: Viral meningitis can manifest with headache, fever, nausea/vomiting, and meningeal irritation. However, viral meningitis is less likely to manifest with signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., sluggish pupils, papilledema), altered mental status, and a 2-week history of focal left-sided headache, as seen in this patient.

Medulloblastoma can manifest with signs of increased intracranial pressure, including headaches, nausea, vomiting, and papilledema. Furthermore, a hemorrhage from a neoplasm could manifest with the sudden onset of a severe headache and altered mental status. However, peak incidence is during the first decade of life. In addition, since most medulloblastomas arise within the cerebellum, the lack of any cerebellar signs (e.g., gait ataxia, truncal instability, intention tremor, double vision) makes medulloblastoma less likely. Fever and a 3-week history of tooth pain suggest another etiology for this patient's symptoms.

A spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) can manifest with severe headache, meningeal irritation, nausea, vomiting, and papilledema. Some patients with SAH may also develop a neurogenic fever. However, SAH in children is quite rare, and this patient's 3-week history of tooth pain and his 1-week history of malaise and fever suggest a different etiology for his condition.

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis is the most common type of viral encephalitis and can manifest with headaches, fever, vomiting, and altered mental status. However, most patients present with focal neurological signs and seizures, which are absent in this patient. While focal inflammation of the temporal lobe (which is commonly affected in HSV encephalitis) can cause a slight elevation in intracranial pressure (ICP), this patient's sluggish pupils and bilateral papilledema suggest severely elevated ICP, which is not characteristic of HSV encephalitis. Finally, the subacute course of this patient's symptoms, with a history of toothache preceding focal left-sided headache, is not consistent with this diagnosis.

This patient has developed a pyogenic brain abscess, most likely as a result of contiguous spread of bacteria from his dental caries. Brain abscesses often initially manifest with headache and fever, and, as the abscess grows within the limited space of the cranial vault, patients develop signs of elevated intracranial pressure, such as vomiting, papilledema, and altered mental status, as seen here. Rupture of the abscess, which likely occurred in this patient, can cause acute worsening of headache and signs of meningeal irritation, as demonstrated by the Brudzinski sign.

This patient should undergo brain imaging (CT or MRI) to confirm the diagnosis. Needle aspiration or excision of the abscess should also be performed, both for treatment and culture sample collection. Streptococcus and Bacteroides spp. are some of the most common pathogens isolated from brain abscesses caused by odontogenic infection.

images.title: Ring enhancing lesion
images.description:
MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view; with contrast) of a 5-year-old girl presenting after a seizure.

An oval-shaped well-defined structure is located within the right temporal lobe. It demonstrates smooth ring enhancement with lack of enhancement centrally (red overlay). The lack of central enhancement is due to pus (green overlay). There is low signal surrounding this structure representing edema (blue overlay). Pus and edema appear hypointense, as fluid appears as low signal on T1-weigted images. 

This is an example of a brain abscess. The main other differential is a primary brain lesion or a cystic metastasis. Other MRI sequences, along with clinical information, are required to help differentiate between these differentials.

answers.explanation_why: Cavernous sinus thrombosis can develop as a result of contiguous spread of a dental infection into the cavernous sinus and manifest with headache, vomiting, fever, altered mental status, and bilateral papilledema. However, most patients present with unilateral periorbital edema and proptosis from increased pressure within the cavernous sinus, and palsies of the cranial nerves located within the cavernous sinus (III, IV, V1, V2, VI), none of which are seen here. In addition, meningeal irritation, as demonstrated by the Brudzinski sign in this patient, is not characteristic of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

question_text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty walking for the past year. He reports that his gait has become slower and that initiating steps has become more challenging. During the past 6 months, his family has noticed that he is starting to forget important family meetings and holidays. On a number of occasions, he has not been able to get to the bathroom in time in order to urinate. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His father died of Parkinson disease at the age of 63 years. The patient had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years, but quit 10 years ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is confused and has short-term memory deficits. He has a wide-based, shuffling gait. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. An MRI of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty walking for the past year. He reports that his gait has become slower and that initiating steps has become more challenging. During the past 6 months, his family has noticed that he is starting to forget important family meetings and holidays. On a number of occasions, he has not been able to get to the bathroom in time in order to urinate. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His father died of Parkinson disease at the age of 63 years. The patient had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years, but quit 10 years ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is confused and has short-term memory deficits. He has a wide-based, shuffling gait. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. An MRI of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The combination of gait abnormalities, dementia, urinary incontinence, and ventriculomegaly without sulcal enlargement in MRI highly suggests normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).
learning_objective: Recognize normal pressure hydrocephalus, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.explanation_why: Gradual-onset, mild forgetfulness, hesitant gait, and urinary incontinence may be normal consequences of aging, with risk increasing with advancing age. However, the severity and relative rapidity of this patient's symptoms are unlikely to be part of normal aging. Additionally, this patient's cranial MRI is abnormal.

Increased CSF production (due to choroid plexus neoplasia or inflammation) is a rare cause of communicating hydrocephalus. While communicating hydrocephalus also causes enlarged ventricles, it typically manifests with signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g, headache, nausea, vomiting) rather than the symptoms seen in this patient.

Degeneration of the substantia nigra is a hallmark of Parkinson disease (PD), which causes a characteristic shuffling, short-stepping gait. While this patient is at increased risk of PD given his family history, urinary incontinence and dementia are typically late findings of advanced PD. If this patient had advanced PD, he would have had other earlier signs of the disease (e.g., muscle rigidity, resting tremor, mask-like facies, etc.) for years preceding his current symptoms. Additionally, PD does not explain this patient's abnormal cranial MRI.

Frontotemporal brain atrophy is characteristic of frontotemporal dementia (FTD), which typically presents early on with aphasia and personality changes. This patient's prominent motor/urinary symptoms without substantial personality changes make FTD less likely. Moreover, his cranial MRI does not show frontotemporal atrophy and instead suggests another diagnosis.

images.title: Frontotemporal dementia
images.description: MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

answers.explanation_why:
Impaired CSF absorption (either idiopathic or due to dysfunction of the arachnoid villi) is the suspected underlying pathophysiologic mechanism of NPH. Impaired CSF absorption leads to transiently elevated intracranial pressure, which causes ventricular enlargement and compression of cerebral structures (e.g., corona radiata). Once the ventricles enlarge, homeostasis between CSF production and resorption is established and intracranial pressure normalizes.

CSF shunting is the main treatment for NPH. The next step in the management of this patient should be to perform a lumbar tap test. Improvement of symptoms after CSF removal strongly supports the diagnosis of NPH and suggests a favorable response to CSF shunting.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Obstruction of CSF flow causes non-communicating hydrocephalus. While non-communicating hydrocephalus also causes enlarged ventricles, it typically manifests with signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g, headache, nausea, vomiting) rather than the symptoms seen in this patient. In addition, evidence of an obstructive mass would likely be seen on this patient's cranial MRI.

images.title: Noncommunicating hydrocephalus
images.description:
Cranial CT (axial view) of a 13-year-old boyA large, liquor-like, hypodense lesion (red area) is located in the posterior cranial fossa in images 1–3. This lesion is most likely an arachnoid cyst compressing the cerebral aqueduct (A), which prevents the free circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the ventricles to the subarachnoid space. As a result, the third ventricle (III) and the lateral ventricles (hatched area) are dilated, and there is transependymal egress of CSF (green shaded area, images 4 and 5).

C = cistern of great cerebral vein
T = inferior horn of the lateral ventricle

answers.content: Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the temporal lobe
answers.explanation_why: Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the temporal lobe is found in Alzheimer disease (AD), which commonly causes memory difficulties and enlarged ventricles on cranial MRI. Gait changes and urinary incontinence are typically found in advanced AD years after diagnosis. However, this patient's rapid onset and progression of memory and gait changes associated with urinary incontinence is unlikely to be caused by AD. Moreover, AD usually causes cerebral atrophy (particularly of the hippocampus and temporal lobe), which is not seen on this patient's MRI.

images.title: Cerebral atrophy in Alzheimer disease 2/3
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbanceBilateral cerebral atrophy with prominent Sylvian fissures (green overlay) is seen.1: caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3: thalamus

answers.explanation_why: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare cause of rapidly progressive dementia. While CJD can also cause ataxia and a resulting wide-based gait, more than 90% of patients present with myoclonus and the condition is commonly associated with other neuropsychiatric symptoms such as hallucinations and depression. Also, this patient's MRI shows ventriculomegaly, which is more consistent with another diagnosis.

images.title: MRI in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
images.description: MRI head (left: T2-weighted image, axial plane; right: diffusion-weighted image (DWI), axial plane) of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)The DWI shows hyperintensities (examples indicated by arrows) in the putamen (red overlay), thalamus (yellow overlay), and caudate nucleus (green overlay), common locations for deep gray matter involvement with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Sporadic CJD may also demonstrate ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri (cortical ribboning; not shown). A probable diagnosis of CJD can be made when expected MR imaging patterns are seen and CJD-mimicking disorders are confidently ruled out clinically.

answers.explanation_why: Multiple brain infarctions are characteristic of vascular dementia, which is the second most common form of dementia. This patient is at increased risk of developing vascular dementia given his history of smoking and hypertension, and symptom onset in vascular dementia may be relatively rapid. However, this patient's MRI does not show the expected signs of ischemia (e.g., multiple infarcts), and a stepwise decline in function would be more typical of vascular dementia.

images.title: Subcortical atherosclerotic encephalopathy 2/2
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Abnormal low attenuation areas (green overlay) are seen in the periventricular white matter. Two frontal lacunar infarcts (arrowheads) are also present.These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial plane)There is marked dilatation of the lateral ventricles (green overlay) with mild sulcal enlargement (red overlay). The findings are suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus as opposed to age-related or neurodegenerative cerebral atrophy.Periventricular hypointensities (examples indicated by white arrowheads) are also seen and may reflect transependymal edema due to elevated cerebrospinal fluid pressure.

question_text: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of progressive enlargement of his head circumference. His parents report that he has been healthy except for an episode of tonsillitis 3 months ago treated with penicillin. The patient was born at term by a lower segment transverse cesarean delivery because of a transverse lie. He has met all developmental milestones. His immunizations are up-to-date. The patient is at the 50^th percentile for length, 50^th percentile for weight, and 95^th percentile for head circumference. He appears well-nourished. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The eyes deviate inferiorly and the eyelids are retracted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of progressive enlargement of his head circumference. His parents report that he has been healthy except for an episode of tonsillitis 3 months ago treated with penicillin. The patient was born at term by a lower segment transverse cesarean delivery because of a transverse lie. He has met all developmental milestones. His immunizations are up-to-date. The patient is at the 50th percentile for length, 50th percentile for weight, and 95th percentile for head circumference. He appears well-nourished. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The eyes deviate inferiorly and the eyelids are retracted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This patient presents with macrocephaly, tense fontanelle, and a sunset eye sign, all of which suggest hydrocephalus.
learning_objective: Recognize hydrocephalus in an infant, and choose the initial neuroimaging modality.

answers.explanation_why: Diuretics such as furosemide decrease CSF production and are sometimes used as temporary therapy in patients too unstable to undergo surgery. However, imaging is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

Although serial lumbar punctures were used in the past as a temporary measure in preterm infants with posthemorrhagic hydrocephalus as a complication of intraventricular hemorrhage, the procedure is no longer recommended. Imaging is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

Although imaging is necessary to confirm the diagnosis, CT would expose this young patient to unnecessary radiation. CT scan may be indicated in older children in an acute setting to quickly identify the cause of increased intracranial pressure and in adults with suspected hydrocephalus.
CSF shunts are a definitive treatment for hydrocephalus. However, before proceeding with a surgical intervention, neuroimaging is required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

A patient with hydrocephalus requires neuroimaging to determine the extent of the condition and the underlying cause. Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality in newborns and young infants in whom the anterior fontanelle is still open because it allows direct visualization of the brain. Moreover, ultrasound does not involve radiation and does not require sedation of the patient.

Although standard MRI is safe for infants, sedation is required, making it less appropriate than ultrasonography. Ultra-fast MRI techniques, however, do not require infant sedation and can be used as an alternative to ultrasonography. MRI is the preferred imaging modality in older children in whom the anterior fontanelle has closed (it usually closes at 12–18 months of age).

question_text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned because he is unable to walk on his own. He has been increasingly irritable over the past month, has been feeding poorly, and has had multiple episodes of vomiting. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 50^th percentile for height, 40^th percentile for weight, and 98^th percentile for head circumference. He appears lethargic. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The child is unable to stand without support and falls if he attempts to walk. Muscle tone is increased and deep tendon reflexes are 4+ in the lower extremities. Examination of the back is unremarkable. An MRI of the brain shows symmetrical enlargement of all four ventricles. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
content_preview: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned because he is unable to walk on his own. He has been increasingly irritable over the past month, has been feeding poorly, and has had multiple episodes of vomiting. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 50th percentile for height, 40th percentile for weight, and 98th percentile for head circumference. He appears lethargic. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The child is unable to stand without support and falls if he attempts to walk. Muscle tone is increased and deep tendon reflexes are 4+ in the lower extremities. Examination of the back is unremarkable. An MRI of the brain shows symmetrical enlargement of all four ventricles. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
hint: Irritability, poor feeding, vomiting, delayed gross motor milestones, upper motor neuron signs (increased muscle tone and hyperreflexia), macrocephaly, and a bulging anterior fontanelle are consistent with increased intracranial pressure (ICP). An MRI showing symmetrical enlargement of all 4 ventricles indicate a symptomatic, communicating hydrocephalus.
learning_objective: Recognize communicating hydrocephalus, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Cerebral aqueductoplasty may be used to treat obstructive hydrocephalus caused by stenosis of the aqueduct of Sylvius. Congenital stenosis of the aqueduct of Sylvius would present similarly, but the fourth ventricle would not be dilated with enlargement of all four ventricles.

A ventriculoperitoneal shunt, which diverts excess CSF from the ventricles to the peritoneal cavity, is the standard of care to decrease intracranial pressure in children with communicating hydrocephalus. Although spinal taps and the use of certain diuretics (e.g., furosemide, acetazolamide) may quickly decrease ICP, these measures are not effective in preventing the progression of hydrocephalus over the long term.

Although furosemide may decrease CSF production and intracranial pressure, it is less effective than standard therapy in decreasing ICP. Furosemide may be used temporarily in patients who are too unstable for standard therapy.

Although acetazolamide may decrease CSF production and intracranial pressure, it is less effective than standard therapy in decreasing ICP. Acetazolamide may be used temporarily in patients who are too unstable for the treatment of choice.

Studies have shown that serial lumbar punctures are not effective in preventing the progression of hydrocephalus. Frequent spinal taps also increase the risk of infection. Serial lumbar punctures may be used in preterm infants until they are large enough for the definitive treatment.

question_text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after an episode of violent jerky movements of his hands and legs that lasted for 5 minutes. After the episode, he had difficulty conversing. For the past 10 days, he has had a left-sided headache and nausea. Apart from a history of recurrent ear infections treated with antibiotics, he reports no other personal or family history of serious illness. He works as an assistant at a veterinarian clinic. He appears ill and is oriented to place and person only. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 112/78 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. There is no lymphadenopathy. Muscle strength and tone are normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows a flexor response bilaterally. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count within the reference range. An MRI of the brain is shown. Intravenous mannitol and levetiracetam are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after an episode of violent jerky movements of his hands and legs that lasted for 5 minutes. After the episode, he had difficulty conversing. For the past 10 days, he has had a left-sided headache and nausea. Apart from a history of recurrent ear infections treated with antibiotics, he reports no other personal or family history of serious illness. He works as an assistant at a veterinarian clinic. He appears ill and is oriented to place and person only. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 112/78 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. There is no lymphadenopathy. Muscle strength and tone are normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows a flexor response bilaterally. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count within the reference range. An MRI of the brain is shown. Intravenous mannitol and levetiracetam are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: In a patient with a history of recurrent ear infections, the combination of headache, seizures, clinical features of increased intracranial pressure (nausea and papilledema), and an MRI showing a well-defined rim-enhancing mass with surrounding edema in the temporal lobe strongly indicates a pyogenic brain abscess. Fever may be mild in this condition because the infection and immune response are at first limited to the location of the abscess.
learning_objective: Recognize a pyogenic brain abscess, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Although ciprofloxacin does have good CNS penetration, it decreases the seizure threshold and should therefore not be used in patients with a brain abscess. It is also not very effective against many gram-positive organisms such as Streptococci viridans group or MRSA, which are responsible for most cases of brain abscess.

A combination of metronidazole and a third-generation cephalosporin, such as cefotaxime, is one of the most commonly used antibiotic regimens for patients with a pyogenic brain abscess with an otogenic source. However, antibiotic treatment is typically initiated after a more invasive first-line procedure for diagnostic sampling has been performed. Antibiotic therapy alone may be attempted for small (< 2.5 cm) uncomplicated abscesses with a known pathogen. This patient with a large peripheral abscess and signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., papilledema) requires a more urgent management step before proceeding to antibiotic treatment, which should be initiated immediately after the first-line intervention.

Almost all patients with brain abscesses require urgent drainage or excision to decompress the cranial cavity and to obtain a sample for culture. Following drainage of the abscess, intravenous empirical antibiotic therapy should be initiated with a third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin and metronidazole. Vancomycin should be added if infection with Staphylococcus is suspected (e.g., patients who develop a brain abscess following penetrating trauma or neurosurgery, or among patients with bacterial endocarditis). In addition to surgical drainage and antibiotics, patients with evidence of cerebral edema or increased ICP should be treated with a short course of glucocorticoids.

Antibiotic therapy without aspiration and surgical drainage may only be attempted in patients with a small (< 2.5 cm) uncomplicated brain abscess with a known pathogen.

Albendazole is used to treat helminthic infections such as cysticercosis. Patients with neurocysticercosis may present with seizures, headache, nausea, signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., papilledema), and a focal ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding edema. However, neurocysticercosis typically manifests with multiple, small (< 1 cm) lesions.

Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine are used to treat patients with toxoplasmosis. This patient's occupation puts him at risk of toxoplasmosis because of his close contact with animals, especially cats. Cerebral toxoplasmosis may present with seizures, headache, nausea, and a ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding edema on cranial imaging. However, cerebral toxoplasmosis is almost exclusively seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., patients with HIV infection) and usually manifests with multiple lesions at the brainstem, corticomedullary junction, pituitary gland, and basal ganglia, instead of a single focal lesion in the temporal lobe.

images.title: Brain lesion
images.description: Cranial MRI (with contrast, axial view)An oval lesion can be seen in the left temporal lobe, with ring-like contrast enhancement (green ring) and central necrosis (green overlay). The perifocal edema (white overlay) that is visible corresponds to the lesion. Differential diagnoses include an abscess, glioblastoma, and metastasis.Diagnosis: abscess following advanced otitis media

question_text: A 73-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening bilateral lower extremity pain for the past 8 months. The pain begins after walking one to two blocks and radiates bilaterally down the buttocks with cramping and tingling. He reports that the pain is worse while walking downhill and is relieved by sitting and leaning forward. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55 years and an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair at the age of 60 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. His current medications include sitagliptin, metformin, atorvastatin, metoprolol succinate, amlodipine, and hydrochlorothiazide. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 150/87 mm Hg. Examination shows full muscle strength. Sensation is reduced bilaterally in the feet and toes. Straight leg raise test is negative. X-ray of the spine shows degenerative changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 73-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening bilateral lower extremity pain for the past 8 months. The pain begins after walking one to two blocks and radiates bilaterally down the buttocks with cramping and tingling. He reports that the pain is worse while walking downhill and is relieved by sitting and leaning forward. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55 years and an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair at the age of 60 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. His current medications include sitagliptin, metformin, atorvastatin, metoprolol succinate, amlodipine, and hydrochlorothiazide. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 150/87 mm Hg. Examination shows full muscle strength. Sensation is reduced bilaterally in the feet and toes. Straight leg raise test is negative. X-ray of the spine shows degenerative changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: Bilateral buttock pain that worsens with lumbar extension (e.g., walking) and is relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting, leaning forward) is consistent with neurogenic claudication, which is commonly seen in lumbar spinal stenosis. Symptoms of neurogenic claudication can occur in the absence of lower back pain.
learning_objective: Recognize neurogenic claudication, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Measurement of HLA-B27 antigen is performed in patients with suspected ankylosing spondylitis. The most characteristic findings include dull pain in the neck and lower back independent of positioning, limited mobility of the spine, and morning stiffness that improves with activity. In addition, onset is usually prior to age 40 and the disease follows a gradual, progressive course. Although the x-ray findings described in this case could indicate ankylosing spondylitis, the typical clinical features are absent in the patient, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

images.title: Ankylosing spondylitis
images.description: X-ray of the lumbar spine (lateral view, standing position) in a patient with suspected ankylosing spondylitisSclerosis of the facet joints, particularly L3–S1 (examples indicated by green lines), can be seen. Additionally, there are signs of degenerative changes (e.g., the formation of vertebral body bone spurs) and spinal structure defect. The typical "bamboo spine" appearance is not present here. (S = sacrum)

answers.content: Measurement of the ankle brachial index
answers.explanation_why: Measurement of the ankle brachial index is an easy way to screen for peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Although the patient has multiple cardiovascular risk factors that increase the risk for PAD, this diagnosis is unlikely because PAD would manifest with claudication that occurs after walking a certain distance and does not resolve with spinal flexion. Other typical features of PAD include erectile dysfunction, diminished lower extremity pulses, and trophic changes, none of which are present in this patient.

MRI scan of the spine is the imaging modality of choice to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of stenosis and compression of neural structures in a patient presenting with neurogenic claudication. Spondylolisthesis, degenerative disk disease, and facet joint arthropathy are the most common causes of spinal stenosis and can usually be identified with MRI imaging.

images.title: Lumbar spinal stenosis
images.description: MRI lumbar spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)Advanced degenerative changes (red overlay) involve the intervertebral disks and posterior elements at multiple levels. The spinal canal (green overlay) is narrowed at L2–3 and L3–4 (indicated by arrows).White dashed outline: spinal cord

answers.explanation_why: Polysomnography is the diagnostic test of choice for restless legs syndrome (RLS). The test quantifies so-called periodic limb movements of sleep (PLMS), which is a common finding in RLS but is not present in this patient. Although dysesthesias (e.g., pain, pins and needles, tickling sensations) may be present in RLS, it is primarily characterized by an urge to move the legs, which is relieved by movement and worsened by rest, making this diagnosis very unlikely.

Measurement of serum creatine kinase is an appropriate next step if myositis is suspected. The key clinical finding is symmetric proximal muscle weakness, which can manifest as pain while walking, but other findings such as difficulty combing hair, standing up, and climbing stairs would be present as well. Furthermore, patients with myositis commonly have muscle tenderness and cutaneous manifestations (such as Gottron papules), which this patient lacks.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of frontal throbbing headaches for 3 weeks. Yesterday, the patient had blurry vision in both eyes and a brief episode of double vision. She has been taking ibuprofen with only mild improvement of her symptoms. She has not had any trauma, weakness, or changes in sensation. Medical history is remarkable for polycystic ovarian syndrome, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and facial acne. Her current medications include metformin and vitamin A. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows decreased peripheral vision. Fundoscopic examination of both eyes is shown. An MRI of the brain with contrast shows an empty sella but no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of frontal throbbing headaches for 3 weeks. Yesterday, the patient had blurry vision in both eyes and a brief episode of double vision. She has been taking ibuprofen with only mild improvement of her symptoms. She has not had any trauma, weakness, or changes in sensation. Medical history is remarkable for polycystic ovarian syndrome, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and facial acne. Her current medications include metformin and vitamin A. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows decreased peripheral vision. Fundoscopic examination of both eyes is shown. An MRI of the brain with contrast shows an empty sella but no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Recurrent headaches and visual changes in a young woman with obesity and a history of vitamin A use raise concern for idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). Papilledema (a sign of intracranial hypertension) and an empty sella on MRI support the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize idiopathic intracranial hypertension, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Craniotomy is required for acute, severe intracranial hypertension secondary to intracranial hemorrhage (e.g., epidural hematoma). While this patient does have intracranial hypertension, epidural hematoma is usually traumatic and manifests with altered mental status and focal neurologic deficits. Additionally, the condition usually progresses more rapidly (i.e., within hours).
Acetazolamide is a first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with confirmed IIH. While this patient very likely has IIH, her diagnosis must be confirmed before pharmacotherapy would be indicated.

Cerebrospinal fluid shunting (e.g., ventriculoperitoneal shunt) is a treatment option for IIH that has not responded to maximal medical therapy. However, this patient must have her diagnosis confirmed before initiating any form of treatment.

Once neuroimaging has been performed to exclude other sources of intracranial hypertension, lumbar puncture (with opening pressure) is indicated for the diagnosis of IIH (according to the modified Dandy criteria). Because in IIH the intracranial pressure is uniformly elevated in the ventricular system and the subarachnoid space, there is no risk of cerebral herniation and, therefore, a lumbar puncture may safely be performed. An opening pressure > 20–25 cm H_2O confirms intracranial hypertension, and normal CSF studies rule out other common causes of intracranial hypertension (e.g., meningitis, intracranial hemorrhage). Once the diagnosis is confirmed, discontinuation of potential causes (e.g., vitamin A supplements), a low-sodium weight loss program, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide) would be recommended.

images.title: Optic disc edema
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeLeft image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

answers.explanation_why: Sumatriptan is a treatment for migraine headaches, which are a common cause of headache and may cause visual symptoms. The visual symptoms associated with migraine typically precede headache (i.e., aura). Additionally, migraine would not explain this patient's papilledema or empty sella.

Thrombolytics (e.g., alteplase) are indicated for certain patients with ischemic stroke, which can present with visual loss as well intracranial hypertension and a consequent headache due to cerebral edema. However, symptoms usually have a more acute onset in ischemic stroke and are typically associated with unilateral neurologic deficits (e.g., weakness, numbness, or cranial nerve palsies). Additionally, MRI in a stroke patient would show signs of cerebral ischemia (e.g., a zone of infarction/hypoattenuation) rather than this patient's empty sella.

images.title: Bilateral papilledema
images.description: Fundus photography of right (R) and left (L) optic disc of the same patientThe optic discs show severely blurred margins (dashed circle indicates supposed margin). The retinal veins are dilated and tortuous (examples marked by white lines). There are multiple peripapillary hemorrhages, which appear as flame-shaped hemorrhages (examples marked by blue overlay). Cotton wool spots are also present and appear as bright spots (examples marked by arrowheads).These features are characteristic of papilledema. If present bilaterally, possible causes include cranial hypertension or hypertensive emergency.

question_text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of headaches and nausea for 2 weeks. The headaches are worse on awakening and she describes them as 7 out of 10 in intensity. During this period, she has noticed brief episodes of visual loss in both eyes lasting several seconds, especially when she suddenly stands up or bends over. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a visual acuity of 20/20 in both eyes with mild peripheral vision loss. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. A lumbar puncture is performed; opening pressure is 310 mm H_2O. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 4/mm^3 (75% lymphocytes), a protein concentration of 35 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 45 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of headaches and nausea for 2 weeks. The headaches are worse on awakening and she describes them as 7 out of 10 in intensity. During this period, she has noticed brief episodes of visual loss in both eyes lasting several seconds, especially when she suddenly stands up or bends over. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a visual acuity of 20/20 in both eyes with mild peripheral vision loss. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. A lumbar puncture is performed; opening pressure is 310 mm H2O. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 4/mm3 (75% lymphocytes), a protein concentration of 35 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 45 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The presence of headaches, nausea, and transient vision loss in an obese woman with unremarkable MRI findings and a raised opening pressure on lumbar puncture indicates idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH).
learning_objective: Recognize idiopathic intracranial hypertension, and choose the initial pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) such as acetazolamide are the first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with IIH. Patients with newly-diagnosed IIH should discontinue any offending agents (e.g., vitamin A analogs, tetracyclines), adopt a low-sodium weight loss diet (if overweight), and begin acetazolamide. Although the mechanism is not clear, CAIs are believed to reduce the rate of CSF production, thereby decreasing intracranial hypertension.

images.title: Optic disc edema
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeLeft image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

answers.explanation_why: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) are indicated as a supplement to first-line therapy in patients with IIH or in patients who present with moderate or progressive visual field loss. This patient has only mild visual field loss, so she should be started on first-line therapy before considering corticosteroids.

Optic nerve sheath fenestration is a first-line surgical treatment option for patients with IIH who have not responded to maximal medical management or in patients presenting with rapid, severe vision loss. This patient has only mild visual symptoms, so conservative management should be attempted before surgery can be considered.

Serial lumbar puncture is typically used in IIH patients to decrease intracranial pressure before surgery or in pregnant patients who decline pharmacotherapy. Lumbar puncture only temporarily treats IIH because CSF regenerates in ∼ 6 hours. Consequently, it is rarely indicated other than as a temporary measure in patients with IIH who are awaiting a more definitive therapy.

CSF diversion procedures (e.g., ventriculoperitoneal shunting) are surgical treatment options for patients in whom all medical treatment options have been exhausted or in patients presenting with rapid, severe vision loss. This patient has only mild visual symptoms, so conservative management should be attempted before surgery can be considered.

In patients with IIH in whom first-line therapy is ineffective, poorly tolerated, or contraindicated, furosemide can be added as an adjunct therapeutic agent. This patient has no contraindications against the recommended first-line therapy, thus it should be initiated before considering furosemide.
