question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of lower back pain and tingling and numbness in his legs for the past 6 months. The pain radiates bilaterally to his buttocks and legs and gets worse while standing or walking downhill. Two weeks ago, he had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His son has ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications include enalapril and atorvastatin. The patient does not smoke. He drinks two to three beers on the weekends. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. There is no tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. The patient's gait is unsteady and wide-based. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of lower back pain and tingling and numbness in his legs for the past 6 months. The pain radiates bilaterally to his buttocks and legs and gets worse while standing or walking downhill. Two weeks ago, he had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His son has ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications include enalapril and atorvastatin. The patient does not smoke. He drinks two to three beers on the weekends. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. There is no tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. The patient's gait is unsteady and wide-based. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
hint: Lower extremity radiculopathy that worsens with standing or walking downhill is consistent with lumbar spinal stenosis.
learning_objective: Recognize lumbar spinal stenosis, and recall the postural change that relieves symptoms.

answers.explanation_why: Seronegative spondyloarthropathies have a strong genetic association with HLA-B27 and frequently manifest with lower back pain. This patient is at increased risk for seronegative spondyloarthropathies given his family history, but those diseases are usually present before age 40. Additionally, they typically manifest with reduced range of motion and enthesitis and they do not cause neurologic symptoms.

An increased HbA1c occurs in diabetes mellitus (DM) and is not commonly associated with spinal stenosis. This patient has several risk factors for type 2 diabetes mellitus (weight, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia), and long-standing DM may lead to diabetic neuropathy that manifests with sensory deficits and reduced reflexes as seen in this patient. However, diabetic neuropathy does not account for this patient's radiating back pain.

A positive straight leg raise test suggests back pain secondary to degenerative disk disease and is not a common finding in spinal stenosis. This patient's lower radiating back pain, sensory deficits, and reduced reflexes may be consistent with degenerative disk disease. However, degenerative disk disease primarily causes dermatomal sensory deficits, decreased leg strength, and reduced deep tendon reflexes only of the muscles innervated by the compressed nerve root.

An anterior disk herniation into the cauda equina could cause bilateral and multi-dermatomal/myotomal symptoms, but the association of symptoms with exertion and chronic duration makes herniation unlikely (most herniations self-resolve/improve within 6–8 weeks) and this patient has no history of trauma (e.g., heavy lifting) to explain a herniation.

Albuminocytologic dissociation on CSF analysis is seen in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which sometimes follows an upper respiratory infection like the one this patient had. GBS may account for this patient's back and limb pain and his reduced muscle reflexes. However, GBS typically also causes a rapidly progressive ascending flaccid paralysis that self-resolves within weeks to months, whereas this patient has had chronic symptoms with intact muscle strength.

Postural changes can widen or narrow the spinal canal and thereby alleviate or worsen symptoms of spinal stenosis. By leaning forward, the spinal canal is widened and spinal cord compression is reduced. Therefore, leaning forward will most likely relieve this patient's back pain. Activities that flex the lumbar spine, such as sitting, cycling, or walking uphill, also help widen the spinal canal and alleviate pain in patients with spinal stenosis.

The exacerbation of lumbar spinal stenosis symptoms by certain postures that narrow the spinal cord (walking downhill, standing, walking) is called pseudoclaudication. In contrast to vascular claudication, which is a result of arterial vessel narrowing and impaired metabolic demands of muscle tissue, pseudoclaudication is thought to result from increased metabolic demands of a compressed and ischemic spinal cord.

images.title: Posture-dependent pain in lumbar spinal stenosis (neuropathic claudication)
images.description: Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

answers.explanation_why: A decreased ankle-brachial index is seen in peripheral arterial disease (PAD), which also manifests with lower extremity pain with exertion (i.e., claudication). This patient has several risk factors for developing PAD (hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, advanced age), but his pain has a radiculopathic character and is also exacerbated by standing upright, neither of which are seen in PAD.

question_text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of the gradual onset of fatigue over the past 4 months. He also reports shortness of breath and difficulty concentrating. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 20 years. He does not drink alcohol. He appears pale. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick over the toes bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
8.2 g/dL

Mean corpuscular volume
108 μm^3

Leukocyte count
4500/mm^3

Serum

 Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2.6 μU/mL

 Iron
77 μg/dL

 Vitamin B_12 (cyanocobalamin)

51 pg/mL (170–900 pg/mL)

 Folic acid

13 ng/mL (N = 2–20)

An oral dose of radiolabeled vitamin B_12 is administered, followed by an intramuscular injection of nonradioactive vitamin B_12. A 24-hour urine sample is collected, and urine vitamin B_12 levels are unchanged. The procedure is repeated with the addition of oral intrinsic factor, and 24-hour urine vitamin B_12 levels increase. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
content_preview: A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of the gradual onset of fatigue over the past 4 months. He also reports shortness of breath and difficulty concentrating. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 20 years. He does not drink alcohol. He appears pale. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick over the toes bilaterally. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 8.2 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume 108 μm3 Leukocyte count 4500/mm3 Serum Thyroid-stimulating hormone 2.6 μU/mL Iron 77 μg/dL Vitamin B12 (cyanocobalamin) 51 pg/mL (170–900 pg/mL) Folic acid 13 ng/mL (N = 2–20) An oral dose of radiolabeled vitamin B12 is administered, followed by an intramuscular injection of nonradioactive vitamin B12. A 24-hour urine sample is collected, and urine vitamin B12 levels are unchanged. The procedure is repeated with the addition of oral intrinsic factor, and 24-hour urine vitamin B12 levels increase. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
hint: Macrocytic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and decreased vitamin B_12 levels are consistent with vitamin B_12 deficiency. The Schilling test results are consistent with intrinsic factor deficiency, which suggests pernicious anemia.
learning_objective: Recognize pernicious anemia, and recall its association with gastric carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why:
Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) have an increased risk of vitamin B_12 deficiency for multiple reasons, the most significant being metformin use (metformin affects the calcium-dependent ileal absorption of the intrinsic factor-B_12 complex). Increased gut transit time due to diabetic autonomic neuropathy may lead to bacterial overgrowth, which can also cause vitamin B_12 deficiency. However, there is no data to suggest that patients with pernicious anemia are at an increased risk of developing type 2 DM.

Type 1 DM is more commonly associated with pernicious anemia because both have underlying autoimmune etiologies.

A history of smoking is a risk factor for colorectal carcinoma and patients with colorectal cancer may present with anemia (due to chronic gastrointestinal (GI) hemorrhage). However, chronic GI hemorrhage typically results in iron-deficiency anemia (microcytic anemia), unlike this man who presents with pernicious anemia (macrocytic anemia). There is currently no clear evidence that patients with pernicious anemia have an increased risk of colorectal carcinoma.

Patients with celiac disease (CD) may present with symptoms of vitamin B_12 deficiency as a result of malabsorption. However, a Schilling test in CD would not normalize after the administration of intrinsic factor (IF) because patients typically have normal levels of IF. Moreover, while CD is associated with autoimmune conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis), there is little evidence that pernicious anemia increases the risk for CD.

There is no evidence to suggest that patients with pernicious anemia are at increased risk of developing de Quervain thyroiditis (i.e., subacute granulomatous thyroiditis), which usually occurs following a viral upper respiratory infection. Patients with pernicious anemia are, however, at increased risk of autoimmune thyroid diseases (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis, Graves disease).

Patients with pernicious anemia are at increased risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma. Approximately 90% of patients with pernicious anemia have chronic atrophic gastritis, which likely accounts for the increased incidence of gastric carcinoma. These patients are also at increased risk for gastric carcinoid tumors as a result of chronic hypergastrinemia, which induces gastric cell hyperplasia.

Patients with newly diagnosed pernicious anemia should undergo a single endoscopic examination and gastric biopsy within 6 months to confirm the presence of atrophic gastritis and rule out dysplastic changes. Endoscopy should be repeated if they develop dyspeptic symptoms. Surveillance endoscopies may also be performed every 3 years in certain high-risk patients (e.g., those with severe columnar metaplasia at the initial biopsy).
answers.explanation_but: The Schilling test can help determine the cause of vitamin B_12 deficiency, but it is no longer routinely used in clinical practice. However, the principles of the test are useful for understanding the pathogenesis of vitamin B_12 deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Although this patient's history of smoking is a risk factor for pancreatic carcinoma, the presence of pernicious anemia significantly increases his risk for another disease. Studies have shown that there is no statistically significant association between pernicious anemia and pancreatic carcinoma.

question_text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty walking for 2 months. He has been falling to his left side when he walks more than a few feet. His speech has also changed in the past few months, and he now pauses between each syllable. He has never had similar symptoms before. He has hypertension and cirrhosis as a result of alcohol-associated liver disease. He does not smoke, and he no longer drinks alcohol. His current medications include lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide daily. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows discrete scleral icterus and jaundice. Ascites and gynecomastia are present. Neurological examination shows nystagmus with fast beats toward the left. He has dysmetria and tremor when performing left-sided finger-nose testing, and dysdiadochokinesia with rapid alternating movements. He has a wide-based gait and a pronator drift of the left arm. He has full range of motion in his arms and legs without rigidity. He has full muscle strength, and sensation to light touch is intact. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty walking for 2 months. He has been falling to his left side when he walks more than a few feet. His speech has also changed in the past few months, and he now pauses between each syllable. He has never had similar symptoms before. He has hypertension and cirrhosis as a result of alcohol-associated liver disease. He does not smoke, and he no longer drinks alcohol. His current medications include lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide daily. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows discrete scleral icterus and jaundice. Ascites and gynecomastia are present. Neurological examination shows nystagmus with fast beats toward the left. He has dysmetria and tremor when performing left-sided finger-nose testing, and dysdiadochokinesia with rapid alternating movements. He has a wide-based gait and a pronator drift of the left arm. He has full range of motion in his arms and legs without rigidity. He has full muscle strength, and sensation to light touch is intact. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient would likely lose balance if he attempted to stand with his feet together, regardless of whether his eyes were open or closed (negative Romberg test).
learning_objective: Recall the clinical features of a cerebellar lesion.

answers.explanation_why: Alcohol-related cerebellar degeneration can manifest with gait ataxia, dysarthria, and nystagmus. However, individuals with this condition typically have symptoms of bilateral cerebellar dysfunction, and this patient's symptoms appear to be limited to the left side. Additionally, patients with alcohol-related cerebellar degeneration most commonly have gaze-evoked nystagmus.

Although vitamin B12 deficiency may manifest with gait ataxia, individuals with this condition typically present with spinal ataxia due to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord and subsequently impaired proprioception. This patient's abnormalities in speech and eye movement indicate a different type of ataxia. Additionally, neurological symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency are usually bilateral and include sensory disturbances.

Hyperammonemia is a diagnostic feature of hepatic encephalopathy, which is characterized by an altered mental state, impaired cognition, a flapping tremor, and slurred speech. The condition is caused by severe liver disease, such as cirrhosis. Although this patient has an increased risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy, he presents with dysdiadochokinesia, ataxia, and nystagmus, which are not features of the condition. Furthermore, his normal mental state and intention tremor suggest that another cause is more likely.

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is most often due to chronic alcohol consumption, causes Wernicke encephalopathy, which manifests with gait ataxia, oculomotor dysfunction, and confusion, and severe disease may progress to coma. Because the patient has no neuropsychiatric symptoms and no longer drinks alcohol, thiamine deficiency is not the most likely cause of his condition.

Typical symptoms caused by cerebellar tumors include gait ataxia, truncal ataxia, dysarthria, nystagmus, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia, and pronator drift. The symptoms manifest ipsilaterally to the lesion site in the cerebellum. Since the patient shows left-beating nystagmus, left-leaning ataxia, and left-sided pronator drift, the tumor must be located in the left part of the cerebellum.

Infarctions in the internal capsule manifest as lacunar strokes. Although the patient has hypertension and therefore his risk for stroke is increased, an infarction of the left posterior internal capsule would cause contralateral hemiparesis. The patient has no symptoms affecting the right side of his body and does not suffer from hemiparesis.

question_text: One day after undergoing a right hemicolectomy for colon cancer, a 55-year-old woman is evaluated for a 5-hour history of progressively worsening back pain and difficulty moving her legs. Her initial postoperative course was uncomplicated. Current medications include prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a well-positioned epidural catheter site without redness or swelling. There is weakness of the lower extremities and decreased anal tone. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in both legs. Sensation to pinprick is decreased from below the umbilicus. Her hemoglobin concentration is 11.2 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6000/mm^3, and platelet count is 215,000/mm^3. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 19 mm/h. A T2-weighted MRI of the spine is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: One day after undergoing a right hemicolectomy for colon cancer, a 55-year-old woman is evaluated for a 5-hour history of progressively worsening back pain and difficulty moving her legs. Her initial postoperative course was uncomplicated. Current medications include prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a well-positioned epidural catheter site without redness or swelling. There is weakness of the lower extremities and decreased anal tone. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in both legs. Sensation to pinprick is decreased from below the umbilicus. Her hemoglobin concentration is 11.2 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6000/mm3, and platelet count is 215,000/mm3. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 19 mm/h. A T2-weighted MRI of the spine is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with acute back pain, signs of spinal cord compression, and a hyperintense, epidural space-occupying lesion at the level of the T11-L1 vertebrae, which are consistent with a spinal epidural hematoma, most likely due to epidural catheter insertion.
learning_objective: Recognize spinal epidural hematoma, and choose the most appropriate management for spinal cord compression.

answers.explanation_why: Small asymptomatic and mildly symptomatic spinal epidural hematomas typically resolve spontaneously and can therefore be managed conservatively. This patient presents with signs of acute spinal cord compression, for which another step in management is more appropriate.

Spinal epidural hematomas can occur as a complication of neuraxial anesthesia, especially in patients with additional risk factors for bleeding (e.g., those taking anticoagulation therapy). If suspected, an MRI should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. If signs of spinal cord compression are present, treatment consists of immediate neurosurgical decompression of the spinal canal via laminectomy, followed by evacuation of the hematoma. During the procedure, the dura should be inspected and active bleeding sites (usually the venous vessels) should be controlled. Any coagulopathies should be treated (e.g., with anticoagulation reversal).

Early initiation of empiric antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and cefepime is indicated for a spinal epidural abscess (SEA), which can manifest with back pain, signs of spinal cord compression, and a hyperintense epidural lesion on T2-weighted MRI. Unlike this patient, individuals with SEA also typically have fever, leukocytosis, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and local point tenderness. Moreover, symptoms of SEA secondary to epidural catheter insertion usually occur ≥ 5 days after the procedure.

Aspiration and specimen collection for culture should be conducted in patients with suspected spinal epidural abscess (SEA), which manifests with back pain, signs of spinal cord compression, and a hyperintense epidural collection on T2-weighted MRI. Unlike this patient, individuals with SEA typically have an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, fever, and local point tenderness. Moreover, symptoms of SEA secondary to epidural catheter insertion usually occur ≥ 5 days after the procedure.

Blood cultures are obtained prior to initiating treatment in patients with suspected spinal epidural abscess (SEA), which can manifest with back pain, signs of spinal cord compression, and a hyperintense epidural lesion on T2-weighted MRI. Unlike this patient, individuals with SEA also typically have fever, leukocytosis, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and/or local point tenderness. Moreover, symptoms of SEA secondary to epidural catheter insertion usually occur ≥ 5 days after the procedure.

images.title: Spinal epidural hematoma
images.description: MRI spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)A hyperintense collection (green overlay) in the posterior spinal epidural space at level T11–L1 causes a narrowing of the spinal canal and compression of the spinal cord. There is an increased T2 signal (red overlay) within the cord, likely reflecting cord edema.These findings are consistent with spinal epidural hematoma.

question_text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has quadriparesis as a result of a burst fracture of the cervical spine that occurred after a fall from his roof 1 month ago. He has urinary and bowel incontinence. He appears malnourished. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 104/60 mm Hg. Examination shows spasticity in all extremities. Muscle strength is decreased in proximal and distal muscle groups bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows extensor response bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick and temperature is absent below the neck. Sensation to vibration, position, and fine touch is normal bilaterally. Rectal tone is decreased. There is a 1-cm area of erythema over the sacrum. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has quadriparesis as a result of a burst fracture of the cervical spine that occurred after a fall from his roof 1 month ago. He has urinary and bowel incontinence. He appears malnourished. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 104/60 mm Hg. Examination shows spasticity in all extremities. Muscle strength is decreased in proximal and distal muscle groups bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows extensor response bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick and temperature is absent below the neck. Sensation to vibration, position, and fine touch is normal bilaterally. Rectal tone is decreased. There is a 1-cm area of erythema over the sacrum. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The dorsal columns, which are located posteromedially within the spinal cord, transmit ipsilateral proprioceptive, vibratory, and fine touch sensation, while the anterolateral spinothalamic tracts transmit contralateral pain and temperature sensations. The anterior corticospinal tracts transmit ipsilateral motor impulses.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior cord syndrome, and recall its vascular supply.

answers.content: Damage to the anterior spinal artery
answers.explanation_why:
Occlusion of the anterior spinal artery leads to infarction of the ventral and lateral spinal cord distal to the level of the injury, which results in anterior cord syndrome (ACS). Clinical features of ACS include symmetric bilateral spastic paresis, hyperreflexia, and decreased pain and temperature sensation distal to the lesion. Vibration, proprioception, and fine touch are preserved because the dorsal columns are supplied by posterior spinal arteries.

Common causes of ACS include aortic surgery (e.g., aortic aneurysm repair), trauma (e.g., penetrating injury), hypotension (e.g., due to severe hemorrhage), and compression (e.g., due to tumors, cervical spondylosis, vertebral fractures).

images.title: Anterior spinal artery syndrome at T8 level
images.description: Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

answers.content: Occlusion of the posterior spinal artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the posterior spinal artery leads to infarction of the posterior spinal cord distal to the level of the injury (posterior cord syndrome). Clinical features include loss of proprioception, fine touch sensation, vibratory sensation, and two-point discrimination. Pain and temperature sensation and motor function are preserved. This patient's preserved vibration and fine touch sensation, as well as quadriparesis and absent pinprick sensation, are not consistent with posterior cord syndrome.

Hemi-transection of the spinal cord causes Brown-Séquard syndrome. Clinical features include ipsilateral spastic hemiparesis, loss of proprioception, and loss of vibratory sensation distal to the lesion. Hypotonic paralysis occurs at the level of the lesions, and contralateral pain and temperature sensation is preserved at the lesion but diminished distally starting about 2–3 dermatomes below the lesion. This patient's findings of symmetric bilateral neurological deficits and preserved vibration and fine touch sensation are not consistent with Brown-Séquard syndrome.

Cavitation within the spinal cord or syringomyelia most commonly form within the central canal of the cervical spinal cord. Clinical features include a “cape-like”, bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper limbs. Extension of the syrinx into the ventral horn causes flaccid paraparesis of the upper extremities. The lower limbs are unaffected. This patient has symmetric spastic quadriparesis and hyperreflexia, which is inconsistent with syringomyelia.

answers.content: Injury to gray matter of the spinal cord
answers.explanation_why: Injury to the spinal cord gray matter results in damage to upper motor neuron axons, as well as dendrites and cell bodies of interneurons and lower motor neurons. Clinical features depend on the level of injury and which areas of the cord are affected. Motor deficits would include hyporeflexia at the level of gray matter injury. This patient's hyperreflexia and the presence of Babinski sign are not indicative of a lower motor neuron lesion.

question_text: Four hours after undergoing an open emergency surgery under general anesthesia for a bleeding abdominal aortic aneurysm, a 55-year-old man is unable to move both his legs. During the surgery, he had prolonged hypotension, which was corrected with IV fluids and vasopressors. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Prior to admission, his medications were hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. The patient is conscious and oriented to place and person. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.0°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows muscle strength is 1/5 in the lower extremities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: Four hours after undergoing an open emergency surgery under general anesthesia for a bleeding abdominal aortic aneurysm, a 55-year-old man is unable to move both his legs. During the surgery, he had prolonged hypotension, which was corrected with IV fluids and vasopressors. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Prior to admission, his medications were hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. The patient is conscious and oriented to place and person. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.0°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows muscle strength is 1/5 in the lower extremities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Sudden onset of paraparesis and autonomic dysfunction immediately after an aortic surgery, especially in the setting of intraoperative hypotension, is highly suggestive of anterior spinal artery (ASA) syndrome, as the artery that contributes to spinal cord perfusion (artery of Adamkiewicz) can be injured during aortic surgery.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior spinal artery syndrome, and recall the preserved sensory function.

answers.content: Normal temperature sensation in the extremities
answers.explanation_why: Pain and temperature sensations are carried by the spinothalamic tracts, which are located anterolaterally within the spinal cord. In ASA syndrome, the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord is damaged, causing pain and temperature sensation to be lost.

Babinski sign, which is a feature of an upper motor neuron lesion, would eventually be present in ASA syndrome because of damage to the corticospinal tract. But Babinski reflex is usually not present initially because of spinal shock, and first appears typically 24 hours later.

The presence of a normal bulbocavernosus reflex indicates the resolution of spinal shock. Sudden-onset paraplegia and autonomic dysfunction immediately after aortic surgery are highly suggestive of spinal shock during the acute phase of ASA syndrome. The bulbocavernosus reflex is normally absent during this phase.

answers.content: Bilaterally increased knee and ankle jerk
answers.explanation_why: Bilaterally increased knee and ankle jerk reflexes are features of an upper motor neuron lesion. Since corticospinal tracts are damaged in ASA syndrome, patients eventually develop hyperreflexia in all limbs below the level of the lesion after about a week. During the acute phase of ASA syndrome, though, deep tendon reflexes are usually lost as a result of spinal shock.

In ASA syndrome, the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord is damaged. The dorsal column, which receives its blood supply from the posterior spinal arteries, usually remains intact. Therefore, proprioception, pressure, and vibration senses are preserved in patients with ASA syndrome.

images.title: Anterior spinal artery syndrome at T8 level
images.description: Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

question_text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of low back pain and weakness for the past 4 weeks. He says that the pain is sharp, radiates to his left side, and has a burning quality. He has had a cough occasionally productive of blood-streaked sputum for the past 2 months. He has had 3.2-kg (7.0-lb) weight loss in that time. He is now unable to walk without assistance and has had constipation and difficulty urinating for the past 2 weeks. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Neurologic examination shows 3/5 strength of the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperreflexive. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. Sensory examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick below the T4 dermatome. He is unable to lie recumbent due to severe pain. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple round opacities of varying sizes in both lungs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of low back pain and weakness for the past 4 weeks. He says that the pain is sharp, radiates to his left side, and has a burning quality. He has had a cough occasionally productive of blood-streaked sputum for the past 2 months. He has had 3.2-kg (7.0-lb) weight loss in that time. He is now unable to walk without assistance and has had constipation and difficulty urinating for the past 2 weeks. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Neurologic examination shows 3/5 strength of the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperreflexive. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. Sensory examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick below the T4 dermatome. He is unable to lie recumbent due to severe pain. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple round opacities of varying sizes in both lungs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This 76-year-old patient with extensive smoking history presents with hemoptysis, weight loss, back pain, and imaging concerning for pulmonary metastases. His back pain and neurologic symptoms are suggestive of compressive myelopathy due to metastases.
learning_objective: Recognize compressive myelopathy due to metastases, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical decompression of the spinal cord and resection of the tumor (if operable), is the definitive treatment option in the management of neoplastic spinal cord compression. While it is certainly indicated to improve long-term outcomes, it is not the best first step in management.

Surgical stabilization of the spine in patients with metastatic bone disease can prevent further neurologic or skeletal damage from occurring (e.g., compression fracture). While it could improve long-term outcomes (e.g., maintaining the ability to walk), it would not be the first step in management.

Radiation therapy is a treatment option for patients with spinal metastases. It can help control local tumor growth and reduce pain. However, because this patient presents with symptoms of cord compression, it is not the first step in management.

Although an MRI should be conducted ASAP, this patient is currently unable to lie recumbent for the procedure. Emergent high-dose intravenous corticosteroid therapy (e.g., with dexamethasone) is indicated for patients with neurologic deficits from spinal cord compression due to malignancy. Glucocorticoids reduce pain, inflammation, and edema, preventing further neurologic damage until definitive treatment is available (e.g., urgent decompression surgery). Patients with spinal cord compression often have such severe pain that thorough neurologic exam and imaging (particularly with MRI) becomes challenging and the use of glucocorticoids and analgesics can be helpful for this situation.

Intravenous acyclovir is the treatment for complicated or disseminated varicella-zoster virus infection, which may manifest with sharp or burning pain and rarely, neurologic deficits (direct infection of cerebral arteries that may cause ischemia or intracerebral hemorrhage). This patient's duration and progression of symptoms, along with the absence of vesicular rash, make this etiology unlikely.

Intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin is a commonly used empiric treatment regimen for patients with community-acquired pneumonia, which may manifest with productive cough and lung opacities on chest x-ray. However, pneumonia would not explain this patient's neurologic symptoms.

NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen, are common analgesic agents for the treatment of back pain and degenerative disk disease. Although NSAIDs can be used as adjunctive therapy to help control pain in this situation, they are not the best first step for this patient presenting with symptoms of cord compression.

question_text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband for the evaluation of confusion and memory deficits for the last month. During this period, she has also had mild weakness in her left leg. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her current medications include enalapril and atorvastatin. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for the last 45 years. She drinks a glass of wine every day. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. She is oriented only to person. She recalls 2 out of 3 objects immediately and none after 5 minutes. The patient is unable to lift her eyebrows or smile. Muscle strength is decreased in the left lower extremity. A T2-weighted MRI scan of the head shows several hyperintense round lesions in the frontal and temporal lobes at the border of the gray and white matter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband for the evaluation of confusion and memory deficits for the last month. During this period, she has also had mild weakness in her left leg. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her current medications include enalapril and atorvastatin. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for the last 45 years. She drinks a glass of wine every day. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. She is oriented only to person. She recalls 2 out of 3 objects immediately and none after 5 minutes. The patient is unable to lift her eyebrows or smile. Muscle strength is decreased in the left lower extremity. A T2-weighted MRI scan of the head shows several hyperintense round lesions in the frontal and temporal lobes at the border of the gray and white matter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with several round lesions at the border of the gray and white matter of the brain, suggesting brain metastases.
learning_objective: Recognize brain metastases from lung cancer.

answers.explanation_why: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) may present with decreased cognitive function, focal neurological deficits, and multifocal hyperintense lesions on T2-weighted MRI. However, PML almost exclusively develops in patients with severe immunosuppression (e.g., AIDS, patients on immunosuppressive therapy). This patient does not have any clinical feature to suggest immunosuppression (e.g., oral candidiasis), and has not received any form of immunosuppressive therapy.

images.title: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
images.description: MRI Head (A: T2 weighted, B: T1 weighted with contrast; axial plane)A T2 hyperintense lesion without mass effect (image A, green overlay) in the left cerebellar hemisphere does not enhance on the T1 weighted sequence (image B). Other enhancing foci (red overlay) are seen in B, although such enhancement is uncommon in PML.PML lesions typically involve parietooccipital subcortical and periventricular white matter, are T2 hyperintense, do not enhance, and produce little or no mass effect.

answers.explanation_why: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is one of the most common and lethal primary brain tumors in adults between 45–70 years of age. While progressive focal deficits are not uncommon, the majority of cases present with headaches. Furthermore, MRI typically shows a large unifocal lesion, unlike multifocal lesions of brain metastases.

images.title: Glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV astrocytoma)
images.description: MRI brain (T1-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a 69-year-old patient with personality changes and left-sided hemiparesis.In the white matter of the right hemisphere, there is a large, poorly circumscribed space-occupying lesion, which is hypointense centrally (green overlay) with strong peripheral contrast enhancement (red overlay). The lesion is surrounded by edema (white overlay), suggesting rapid growth and displacement of surrounding structures. The mass effect has also caused a slight midline shift to the contralateral side (white dashed line), and compression of the right lateral ventricle (white arrowheads indicate anterior horn compression).These radiographic features are typical of a glioblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Multiple sclerosis may present with cognitive impairment, focal neurological deficits, and multifocal hyperintense lesions on T2-weighted MRI. However, the symptoms of multiple sclerosis usually begin between the ages of 20–40 years, and the clinical course is typically characterized by exacerbations and remissions.

images.title: Multiple sclerosis; baseline images (1/2)
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)Extensive bilateral demyelinating lesions (plaques) appear as hyperintensities in the periventricular white matter (green overlay). Radial extensions of these lesions (Dawson fingers) are visible. Generalized cerebral atrophy, part of the disease process for multiple sclerosis, is also visible.

answers.explanation_why: Meningiomas, which are the most common primary brain tumors in adults, may present with focal neurological deficits and have a hyperintense appearance on a T2-weighted MRI. However, meningiomas usually appear as unifocal extra-axial space-occupying lesions, unlike in this patient with multiple intra-axial lesions at the junction of the gray and white matter.

images.title: Dural based mass
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

answers.explanation_why: Colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer in the US. Risk factors include smoking and alcohol consumption. While brain metastases are possible, initial metastases are usually to the liver or lungs. Tumors arising from the proximal rectum usually metastasize via the portal system to the liver, while tumors of the distal rectum metastasize via the inferior rectal vein to the inferior vena cava and thus the lungs.

Malignant melanoma is the third most common primary tumor in patients with brain metastases. However, this patient does not have any cutaneous lesions, nor risk factors associated with melanomas (e.g., chronic sun exposure, family history, immunosuppression). Moreover, intracranial metastases caused by malignant melanomas typically appear hypointense on T2-weighted imaging.

Lung cancer is the second most common cancer in the US, especially in women ≥ 60 years with a history of cigarette smoking. Lung cancer is also the single most common source of brain metastases, which cause a variety of symptoms, including progressively worsening cognitive dysfunction and focal neurological deficits.

images.title: Brain metastases in lung cancer
images.description: CT head (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of lung cancer presenting with weight loss, gradual reduction in consciousness, and deficits in swallowing, speech, coordination, and gaitCerebellar (green overlay) and brainstem (red overlay) lesions that show intense contrast enhancement are suspicious for metastases.P: petrous bone; S: sphenoid bone; T with arrows: tentorium cerebellum

question_text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the restrained driver. On arrival, she has a cervical collar in place and is unresponsive. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 131/76 mm Hg. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. She is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is begun. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Toxicology screening is negative. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial bleed and a cervical spine injury at the level of C3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing brain death?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the restrained driver. On arrival, she has a cervical collar in place and is unresponsive. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 131/76 mm Hg. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. She is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is begun. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Toxicology screening is negative. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial bleed and a cervical spine injury at the level of C3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing brain death?
hint: This patient meets the clinical criteria for brain death (here coma due to a massive intracranial bleed). Neurological examination shows an absent pupillary light reflex, indicating injury to the midbrain. The next step in diagnosis is assessment of damage to the pons.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical criteria for brain death, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: The oculocephalic reflex is a component of the neurological exam that is usually performed prior to declaring brain death. However, oculocephalic reflex testing requires quickly turning the patient's head to one side and it should not be performed in patients with C-spine injuries. This patient was recently in an automobile accident and has a confirmed cervical spine injury at C3, which is a contraindication to this test.

images.title: Testing the vestibuloocular reflex with oculocephalic maneuver
images.description: Normal: The eyes remain fixed on an object despite rapid, passive movement of the patient's head.Pathological: The eyes remain midorbit during rapid, passive movement of the patient's head; this indicates a defective brainstem reflex.

answers.explanation_why: Electroencephalography is an ancillary test that shows absent brain electrical activity (i.e., flat EEG) in brain death and that may be used to confirm the diagnosis of brain death if the clinical neurological examination is inconclusive or cannot be completed reliably. Prior to performing this test, however, it is necessary to complete a full clinical evaluation of brain death, which has not yet occurred.

Magnetic resonance angiography is an ancillary test in the assessment of brain death used to evaluate for the presence or absence of cerebral blood flow (with the latter being a sign of brain death) if the clinical examination is inconclusive. Prior to performing any ancillary tests, however, this patient requires a full clinical evaluation of brain death, which has not yet occurred.

Deep tendon reflexes are occasionally seen in brain-dead patients who have intact spinal cords, as these reflexes do not require brain activity. Though they should be tested as part of the complete neurological examination, the presence of deep tendon reflexes should not be misinterpreted as evidence of brainstem function and cannot be used to diagnose brain death.

Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography is an ancillary test in the assessment of brain death used to evaluate the cerebral circulation if the clinical examination is inconclusive or cannot be completed reliably. Prior to performing any ancillary tests, however, this patient requires a full clinical evaluation of brain death, which has not yet occurred.

Corneal reflex testing is indicated in this patient as part of a full neurologic workup for brain death. The accepted criteria for this diagnosis are presence of coma (of known cause), absence of a brain-originating motor response (including response to noxious stimuli), cranial nerve areflexia, and apnea. Currently, this patient has only met two of these requirements (coma, absent response to noxious stimuli). The corneal reflex is one of the brainstem reflexes that must be tested (along with the gag reflex, cough reflex, and pupillary light reflex) prior to declaring brain death. If all these reflexes are negative, an apnea test is performed to confirm the diagnosis.

images.title: Interconnection of brainstem reflexes
images.description:
Simplified representation of the pupillary light reflex (II → IIIa), corneal reflex (V → VII), and vestibuloocular reflex (VIII → III)

(II = pretectal area (afferent part of the optic nerve); IIIa = Edinger–Westphal nucleus: III = oculomotor nucleus; V = trigeminal nerve nucleus; VII = facial motor nucleus; VIII = vestibular nucleus)

question_text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of headaches for 1 month. She describes them as 7 out of 10 in intensity. She has no nausea. Two years ago, she was treated for invasive lobular carcinoma of the left breast. She underwent a left mastectomy and multiple cycles of chemotherapy. She has been in good health since this treatment. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. There is a well-healed scar on the left side of the chest. There is no lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An MRI of the brain shows a 4-cm temporal hyperintense mass near the surface of the brain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of headaches for 1 month. She describes them as 7 out of 10 in intensity. She has no nausea. Two years ago, she was treated for invasive lobular carcinoma of the left breast. She underwent a left mastectomy and multiple cycles of chemotherapy. She has been in good health since this treatment. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. There is a well-healed scar on the left side of the chest. There is no lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An MRI of the brain shows a 4-cm temporal hyperintense mass near the surface of the brain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The presence of headaches and a brain mass in a woman who was treated previously for breast cancer is suspicious for a brain metastasis.
learning_objective: Recognize brain metastasis, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Whole brain radiation therapy (WBRT) is the treatment of choice for patients with either multiple brain metastases or a poor prognosis. Consequences of WBRT include fatigue and alopecia in addition to neurocognitive deterioration months after therapy. Since this patient has a single metastasis with good functional status and no systemic disease, WBRT would not be indicated at this time. While WBRT was once commonly used following surgical resection to minimize local recurrence, focal radiation therapy (which has far fewer side effects) has largely replaced this treatment modality in postoperative patients.

Surgical resection has been shown to improve both survival and quality of life in patients with a single brain metastasis. This patient is a good surgical candidate as she has a good functional status with no evidence of other metastases, and her tumor is surgically accessible (near the surface of the brain). The goal of surgery is twofold: symptomatic relief (i.e. reduction of this patient's headaches) and local control (i.e. prevention of local recurrence). Postoperative focal radiation is commonly employed to reduce the local recurrence risk, although there are doubts as to whether this improves overall survival.

Chemotherapy is a useful palliative treatment modality for patients with multiple or recurrent brain metastases. However, since this patient has a single brain mass with no signs of systemic disease, chemotherapy would not be the first-line treatment in this situation.

Antibiotic therapy is an essential component in the treatment of patients with brain abscesses, which can also present with headaches and masses on MRI. However, about half of these patients also have fever or neurologic deficits. Often brain abscesses arise via hematogenous or direct spread, so many of the patients affected have a concurrent infection. Although brain abscesses can also arise without concurrent infection, this patient's recent history of breast cancer increases the likelihood that her brain lesion is a metastatic tumor (that would not respond to antibiotics).

Palliative care may be indicated in patients with a high tumor burden, poor prognosis, and/or poor functional status. Patients with a single brain metastasis tend to have a poor overall prognosis (< 3 months survival without treatment), but surgical resection can significantly reduce symptoms and increase survival to ∼ 1 year. Thus, as this patient has a metastatic tumor with good functional status and no evidence of systemic disease, palliative care is inappropriate at this time.

question_text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician because of a 4-month history of early morning headaches and worsening fatigue. The headaches are often accompanied by nausea and sometimes relieved by vomiting. She stopped going to her ballet lessons 2 weeks ago because she was embarrassed about falling frequently and having increasing difficulty performing the steps. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. She has a broad-based gait. While standing with both feet together and raising her arms, closing her eyes does not affect her balance. She is unable to perform rapid, alternating movements with her hands. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 9-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician because of a 4-month history of early morning headaches and worsening fatigue. The headaches are often accompanied by nausea and sometimes relieved by vomiting. She stopped going to her ballet lessons 2 weeks ago because she was embarrassed about falling frequently and having increasing difficulty performing the steps. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. She has a broad-based gait. While standing with both feet together and raising her arms, closing her eyes does not affect her balance. She is unable to perform rapid, alternating movements with her hands. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The MRI scan shows a large (3.5 cm), well-defined, contrast-enhancing cystic mass in the lateral posterior fossa without ventricular involvement.
learning_objective: Recognize a pilocytic astrocytoma.

answers.explanation_why: Acoustic schwannomas can present with vertigo and/or dizziness that result in falls. However, patients will more commonly present with sensorineural hearing loss, which this patient lacks. More importantly, acoustic neuromas are found within the internal acoustic canal along CN VIII or within the cerebral hemispheres. Imaging for acoustic schwannoma would also show a cystic lesion with nodular parts. Finally, acoustic schwannomas occur rarely in children.

images.title: Vestibularis schwannoma (acoustic neuroma)
images.description:
Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

answers.explanation_why:
Pilocytic astrocytoma is the most common brain tumor in children and is usually located within the posterior fossa. Cerebellar compression can cause falls and dysdiadochokinesia, while increased intracranial pressure can result in lethargy, morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Imaging typically shows a well-circumscribed, enhancing cystic mass within one of the cerebellar hemispheres, but it can also occur in the cerebral hemispheres. Since pilocytic astrocytomas are low-grade tumors (WHO grade I), patients usually have a favorable prognosis following surgical resection.

Medulloblastoma and pilocytic astrocytoma are the most common posterior cranial fossa tumors in children. Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children.

Oligodendroglioma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure. However, these tumors are usually located supratentorial rather than in the posterior fossa, which is why patients with oligodendroglioma tend to also have seizures and/or focal neurological deficits. Furthermore, oligodendrogliomas usually affect adults 40–50 years of age, not children.

images.title: Oligodendroglioma
images.description: Cranial CT scan (axial view)A large hypodense lesion (green overlay) with multiple intralesional hyperdense calcifications (yellow overlay) is visible in the temporal lobe.

answers.explanation_why: Brainstem glioma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting) and cerebellar signs (broad-based gait, dysdiadochokinesia). However, due to brainstem involvement in this condition, cranial nerve deficits are typically seen (e.g., diplopia, facial droop) and symptoms usually develop over the course of a few days, not months. Imaging usually shows minimal contrast enhancement rather than a contrast-enhancing cystic mass.

Craniopharyngiomas can present with signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting), but are located within the sellar or suprasellar region, not the posterior fossa. Additionally, this patient lacks other findings of craniopharyngioma, such as vision changes from optic chiasm compression (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia) and/or hormonal imbalances from pituitary compression (e.g., short stature, delayed puberty). Also, ataxia is not seen with this type of tumor.

Ependymoma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting) and cerebellar signs (broad-based gait, dysdiadochokinesia). However, these tumors typically arise from the floor of the fourth ventricle, adapt to the shape of the ventricle, and extend through the foramina of Luschka and Magendi into the cisterns. It would be unusual for the tumor not to invade the ventricles and have cystic components on imaging. Furthermore, patients with ependymomas tend to be younger than this patient.

images.title: Ependymoma
images.description: MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.

images.title: Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma
images.description: MRI head (a: T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane; b: T2-weighted; axial plane) of a childA large lesion in the right cerebellar hemisphere displaces the vermis to the left of midline. It has a large cystic component (T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense; red overlay) and a heterogeneously enhancing solid nodular component (green overlay).Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma frequently manifests as a large cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule.

question_text: Three days after delivery, a 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 25 seconds. She has become increasingly lethargic over the past 18 hours. She was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She appears ill. Her pulse is 123/min, respirations are 50/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Three days after delivery, a 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 25 seconds. She has become increasingly lethargic over the past 18 hours. She was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She appears ill. Her pulse is 123/min, respirations are 50/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The condition described here is a serious complication of preterm birth.
learning_objective: Recognize intraventricular hemorrhage in preterm infants.

answers.explanation_why: If left untreated, classic galactosemia may manifest with lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures, as seen here. However, the absence of cataracts (typically manifests within the first days of life), jaundice, and hepatomegaly make this diagnosis less likely.

Spinal muscular atrophy is a possible cause of muscular hypotonia in infants. The most severe type (Werdnig-Hoffmann disease) may manifest immediately after birth or up to 6 months of age. Proximal muscles, mostly of the lower extremities, are usually involved symmetrically. However, seizures, a tense anterior fontanelle, impaired pupillary response, and roving eye movements would not be consistent with this diagnosis.

While most patients are asymptomatic at birth, half of the patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) have seizures with cerebral foci, a lag of psychomotor development, and a musty body odor by 4–6 months of age. Additional features include light, pale hair and blue eyes (due to decreased melanin production). Since most patients are asymptomatic until severe and often irreversible complications have occurred, direct measurement of phenylalanine levels is an important part of newborn screening for metabolic disorders. The screening test is performed on the second day after birth using blood obtained from a heel prick.

Hydrocephalus due to congenital causes, such as the Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker malformation, and intrauterine infections, may manifest in neonates with lethargy, tense fontanelles, seizures, and changes in vital signs due to brain stem compression (e.g., irregular breathing). However, elevated intracranial pressure usually manifests with rapidly increasing circumference of the head in neonates, which is not seen in this infant. Furthermore, instead of the roving eye movements, a downward deviation of the eyes (sunset eye sign) would be expected in patients with hydrocephalus.

images.title: Manifestations of increased intracranial pressure in infants

answers.explanation_why:
Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is a common complication in preterm infants and usually occurs within the first five days after birth. This complication is typically seen in neonates of < 1500 g birth weight and born before 32 weeks' gestation due to the fragility of the germinal matrix. Additional risk factors include peripartal chorioamnionitis and hypoxia (as suggested by this patient's low Apgar scores). Most infants with IVH are asymptomatic, but saltatory (over several days) or, more rarely, catastrophic (over minutes to hours) courses are also possible. Symptoms include lethargy, hypotonia, irregular respirations, bulging anterior fontanelle, and neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures, cranial nerve abnormalities as suggested by poor pupillary light reflexes and roving eye movements), all of which this patient has.

Cranial ultrasonography is the preferred method to diagnose IVH in newborns. Since most patients are asymptomatic, screening ultrasounds are routinely performed in infants with a birth weight < 1500 g and delivery before 30 weeks' gestation.

images.title: Neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)
images.description:
Ultrasound head (top row: coronal plane; bottom row: parasagittal plane) of a newbornThe first column shows bleeding confined to the subependymal germinal matrix (red overlay), which is consistent with grade 1 IVH.
The second column shows blood occupying less than 50% of the left lateral ventricle (red overlay), with no enlargement of the lateral ventricles (yellow overlay) or the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay). In addition, the choroid plexus is clearly demarcated (blue overlay). Together, these findings are consistent with grade 2 IVH.
The third column shows blood occupying more than 50% of the lateral ventricles (red overlay) with enlargement of the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay) and both lateral ventricles (yellow overlay). This appearance is consistent with grade 3 IVH.These features suggest impaired progressive posthemorrhagic ventricular dilatation (PHVD) due to associated impairment of CSF circulation, which is a potential complication of high-grade IVH.

question_text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences, and has difficulty repeating sequences of words. He can follow simple instructions. Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left, and there is a mild right-sided pronator drift downwards. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences, and has difficulty repeating sequences of words. He can follow simple instructions. Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left, and there is a mild right-sided pronator drift downwards. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with sudden-onset focal neurologic deficits that are consistent with stroke. Telegraphic speech (as evidenced by the use of short, simple sentences), intact comprehension (as evidenced by the ability to follow commands), and impaired repetition of word sequences are consistent with Broca aphasia. The presence of this type of language deficit helps localize the damage to a specific region of the cortex.
learning_objective: Recognize occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery.

answers.content: Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which manifests with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Broca aphasia and right-sided weakness are not consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.

answers.content: Occlusion of the right penetrating arteries
answers.explanation_why: Ischemia to the right posterior limb of the internal capsule, due to occlusion of right penetrating arteries, would cause left-sided, not right-sided weakness. Furthermore, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by penetrating arteries.

answers.content: Occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery typically causes left-sided weakness and, if the right hemisphere is nondominant (most individuals), hemineglect. In some, typically left-handed individuals, the language center is located in the right hemisphere. In these patients, a right middle cerebral artery stroke could cause Broca aphasia. However, left-sided, not right-sided, weakness would be expected in this scenario.

answers.content: Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries that supply the left posterior limb of the internal capsule can result in right-sided weakness, as seen in this patient. However, Broca aphasia localizes to the inferior frontal gyrus of the left hemisphere, which is not supplied by penetrating arteries.

answers.content: Dissection of the right vertebral artery
answers.explanation_why: Dissection of the right vertebral artery can cause ischemia to brain regions supplied by the posterior circulation (e.g., cerebellum, brainstem, occipital cortex). However, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, while right-sided weakness indicates a lesion to the left precentral gyrus, both of which are supplied by the left anterior circulation.

answers.content: Occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why:
Broca aphasia is caused by damage of the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (typically left) hemisphere. This patient additionally has right facial droop, right-sided muscle weakness, and right-sided pronator drift downwards, suggesting an upper motor neuron lesion in the left motor cortex. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the inferior frontal gyrus, as well as the motor cortex. This patient has several risk factors for arteriosclerosis and, therefore, ischemic stroke (hypertension, age > 65 years, diabetes mellitus), making occlusion of the left MCA the most likely cause of his focal neurologic deficits.

Ischemic strokes do not typically cause headaches, whereas hemorrhagic strokes usually manifest with severe headaches.

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.content: Rupture of right posterior cerebral artery malformation
answers.explanation_why: Hemorrhage into the right posterior limb of the internal capsule due to rupture of a right posterior cerebral artery malformation could cause left-sided, but not right-sided weakness. Rupture of this artery would also cause left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is not present in this patient. Further, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.content: Occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome, which presents with ipsilateral face and contralateral body pain/temperature sensory deficits, dysphagia, hoarseness, and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Broca aphasia and right-sided weakness are not consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.

answers.content: Rupture of left posterior cerebral artery malformation
answers.explanation_why: Hemorrhage into the left posterior limb of the internal capsule due to rupture of a left posterior cerebral artery malformation could cause right-sided hemiparesis, as seen in this patient. However, rupture of this artery would also cause right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is not present here. Further, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, which is not supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.

answers.content: Dissection of the left vertebral artery
answers.explanation_why: Dissection of the left vertebral artery can cause ischemia to brain regions supplied by the posterior circulation (e.g., cerebellum, brainstem, occipital cortex). However, Broca aphasia indicates a lesion to the inferior frontal gyrus, while right-sided weakness indicates a lesion to the left precentral gyrus, both of which are supplied by the left anterior circulation.
