question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the hospital because of blurred vision and headache for 3 months. During this period, the father noticed that the child has been tilting his head back to look straight ahead. The patient has also had difficulty falling asleep for 2 months. He has had a 3.5 kg (7.7 lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 104/62 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are not reactive to light. The pupils constrict when an object is brought near the eye. His upward gaze is impaired; there is bilateral nystagmus and eyelid retraction while attempting to look upwards. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. The remainder of the examination shows no other abnormalities. If left untreated, which of the following is the most likely sequela of this patient's condition?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the hospital because of blurred vision and headache for 3 months. During this period, the father noticed that the child has been tilting his head back to look straight ahead. The patient has also had difficulty falling asleep for 2 months. He has had a 3.5 kg (7.7 lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 104/62 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are not reactive to light. The pupils constrict when an object is brought near the eye. His upward gaze is impaired; there is bilateral nystagmus and eyelid retraction while attempting to look upwards. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. The remainder of the examination shows no other abnormalities. If left untreated, which of the following is the most likely sequela of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient has vertical gaze palsy, nystagmus, eyelid retraction on looking upward (Collier sign), and pupils that accommodate but do not react to light, which suggests Parinaud syndrome. Additional symptoms of weight loss, headache, and insomnia raise suspicion for pinealoma.
learning_objective: Recognize Parinaud syndrome, and recall its sequelae.

answers.explanation_why: Leukocoria is a typical manifestation of retinoblastoma, which may cause nystagmus and loss of vision. However, the age of onset of retinoblastoma is typically < 4 years and this patient does not have strabismus, which is the most common initial manifestation. Parinaud syndrome and insomnia are not typical features of retinoblastoma. Moreover, leukocoria is a clinical finding and not a sequela of any medical condition.
answers.explanation_but: Rarely, individuals with retinoblastoma may have an ectopic tumor in the pineal gland (i.e., trilateral retinoblastoma), causing Parinaud syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Pretibial myxedema is a sequela of Graves disease, which may manifest with weight loss, ocular symptoms (e.g., lid retraction), and insomnia. However, in contrast to this patient's ocular findings, Graves ophthalmopathy manifests with bilateral exophthalmos and conjunctival hyperemia, not with vertical gaze palsy. Moreover, this patient does not have other characteristic symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as excessive sweating, tachycardia, and diffuse goiter.

Growth failure can result from compression of the pituitary gland due to intrasellar extension of a craniopharyngioma. Headaches, caused by compression of the adjacent brain parenchyma and/or stretching of the dura mater, and visual field defects (e.g., bilateral hemianopia), resulting from compression of the optic chiasm, are common in this condition. This patient most likely has a pinealoma, which can compress the hypothalamic inhibiting pathways and subsequently increase hCG secretion, leading to precocious puberty rather than growth failure.

Parinaud syndrome occurs in most patients with pinealomas and is caused by compression of the tectum and the medial longitudinal fasciculus, which together coordinate eye movements. If left untreated, a pinealoma may obstruct the passage of cerebrospinal fluid from the ventricles to the subarachnoid space (e.g., via aqueductal stenosis) leading to obstructive hydrocephalus, a common sequela of pinealoma. Obstructive hydrocephalus typically manifests with headaches, vision abnormalities, nausea, vomiting, and impaired ambulation (e.g, ataxia) due to increased intracranial pressure.

The most common type of pinealoma in children is a pineal germinoma that typically secretes β-hCG, eventually leading to precocious puberty.

Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (OMS) is a paraneoplastic syndrome that may develop in individuals with neuroblastoma. While weight loss and ocular anomalies (e.g., proptosis) may be present in individuals with neuroblastoma, it does not cause vertical gaze palsy, nystagmus, or Collier sign. Also, this patient has no features suggesting neuroblastoma, such as abdominal distension, bone pain, and a palpable, firm, irregular abdominal mass that crosses the midline.

question_text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressive headache and neck pain for 2 weeks. During this period, he has had multiple episodes of dizziness and tingling sensations in his arms and hands. A year ago, he underwent closed reduction of a dislocated shoulder he sustained after a fall. He underwent surgical removal of a saclike protuberance on his lower back, soon after being born. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. His neck is supple. Neurological examination shows sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally and normal gross motor function. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressive headache and neck pain for 2 weeks. During this period, he has had multiple episodes of dizziness and tingling sensations in his arms and hands. A year ago, he underwent closed reduction of a dislocated shoulder he sustained after a fall. He underwent surgical removal of a saclike protuberance on his lower back, soon after being born. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. His neck is supple. Neurological examination shows sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally and normal gross motor function. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with features of hydrocephalus (headache, dizziness, papilledema, and dilated ventricles on MRI), syringomyelia (cape-like distribution of tingling in the upper extremities), and myelomeningocele (a saclike lesion on the lower back), all of which are characteristic of this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize Chiari II malformation.

answers.explanation_why: Medulloblastoma typically first manifests with increased intracranial pressure, which causes the classic triad of headaches, vomiting, and papilledema. Although subsequent hydrocephalus is common, medulloblastoma is not associated with syringomyelia or myelomeningocele. In addition, this patient's MRI shows dilated ventricles without evidence of a midline mass arising from the vermis.

Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) manifests with headache, vomiting, and altered sensorium. Extensive bleeding from IVH can also cause hydrocephalus. However, IVH occurs acutely rather than over the course of weeks. Moreover, imaging would show blood in the ventricles, which is not seen on the MRI.

Choroid plexus carcinoma is a rare malignant neoplasm of the choroid plexus that typically occurs in children < 5 years of age and can cause hydrocephalus. However, it is not associated with syringomyelia or meningomyelocele. Additionally, there are no visible tumors in the planes shown on MRI.

Dandy-Walker malformation is often associated with hydrocephalus, typically antenatally or in early infancy. Although it is possible for syringomyelia or myelomeningocele to occur in patients with Dandy-Walker malformation, such cases are extremely rare. Much more likely associations would be orofacial and cardiac defects, as well as intellectual and motor delay (especially with crawling and walking due to lack of cerebellar neurons), none of which are present in this patient.

Chiari II malformation is characterized by the presence of myelomeningocele and caudal displacement of the vermis, tonsils, medulla, and fourth ventricle into the upper cervical canal. Caudal displacement can obstruct the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), causing it to accumulate either in the spinal cord, producing a syrinx, or in the cranium, resulting in hydrocephalus.

Patients most commonly present in childhood with evidence of hydrocephalus (e.g., headache, dizziness, papilledema) and/or syringomyelia (e.g., tingling of the arms and hands in this patient). This patient's MRI confirms hydrocephalus, and a sagittal view would show the malformation.

Vestibular schwannoma typically manifests with tinnitus, balance issues, and sensorineural hearing loss, the latter of which is the most common complaint. In very severe cases, they may grow large enough to cause headaches and brainstem compression, but they do not cause hydrocephalus or intracranial hypertension, nor would they occur over the course of two weeks. Although this patient has dizziness that could be explained by a schwannoma, it would not cause tingling in his arms or the observed optic disc swelling.

images.title: Vestibularis schwannoma (acoustic neuroma)
images.description:
Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

answers.explanation_why: Tuberculous meningitis may manifest acutely or subacutely and has several cardinal features; fever, neck pain, and headache are early signs, progressing to confusion and coma in severe cases. Systemic manifestations, such as night sweats and weight loss, may also be observed. In some cases, collections of bacteria (tubercles) can become large enough to impede the typical flow of CSF in the cranium, leading to hydrocephalus. While this patient's MRI demonstrates hydrocephalus, the absence of other clinical findings (fever, systemic symptoms, neck pain) and clear risk factors for M. tuberculosis infection (e.g., immigration from an endemic area, pulmonary manifestations of TB) make this very unlikely. Also, there is no evidence of tubercles on this patient's MRI.

Shoulder dislocation and shoulder surgery are both risk factors for brachial plexus injury, which could cause acute unilateral arm tingling following a shoulder injury. This patient's symptoms are bilateral and occur one year after a shoulder injury, ruling out brachial plexus injury. In addition, injury of the brachial plexus would not explain this patient's other abnormalities.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) classically manifests with an extraordinarily painful sudden onset headache (e.g., thunderclap headache). Vomiting and altered sensorium are also commonly observed. This patient developed symptoms over the course of two weeks and is not experiencing an intense headache, making SAH unlikely.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Regions of high attenuation (green overlay) in the interpeduncular cistern, Sylvian fissures, and left posterior fossa represent acute subarachnoid hemorrhage. The cerebellar tentorium (red overlay) should not be misinterpreted as blood.

images.title: Noncommunicating hydrocephalus
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; 2 slices in the axial plane) of a young child with known Chiari II malformationThe ventricles are markedly enlarged (green overlay) due to the obstructed passage of CSF at the craniocervical junction. The subarachnoid space appears unremarkable.

question_text: An obese 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the onset of weakness in her left arm and leg. She fell from the stairs the day prior but did not have any loss of consciousness or nausea after the fall. She travels to Asia regularly on business; her last trip was 4 days ago. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 113/min and regular, and blood pressure is 162/90 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased muscle strength on the left side. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the left. Babinski sign is present on the left. The right lower leg is swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: An obese 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the onset of weakness in her left arm and leg. She fell from the stairs the day prior but did not have any loss of consciousness or nausea after the fall. She travels to Asia regularly on business; her last trip was 4 days ago. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 113/min and regular, and blood pressure is 162/90 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased muscle strength on the left side. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the left. Babinski sign is present on the left. The right lower leg is swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This patient has swelling, erythema, and tenderness of the right lower extremity. These features, in conjunction with a history of obesity, long-distance travel, and oral contraceptive use, indicate a high risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT; Wells DVT score ≈ 3). In addition, this patient presents with clinical features of a right-sided stroke, suggesting a paradoxical embolism.
learning_objective: Recognize paradoxical embolism, and recall the diagnostic finding of the associated cardiac anomaly.

answers.explanation_why: Ventricular septal defects (VSD) are the most common congenital heart defect and may cause paradoxical embolism. However, VSDs typically self-resolve during childhood or are surgically repaired. VSDs make up ∼ 10% of adult congenital heart defects.

Carotid dissection can occur at any age and is a common cause of stroke in young patients (∼ 20% of cases). Cervical artery dissection classically manifests with headache and neck pain following exertion (e.g., exercise, sexual intercourse, or even sneezing). This patient's lack of headache or neck pain in the presence of symptoms suggesting DVT makes another etiology more likely.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a very common cause of thromboembolic stroke in elderly individuals and those with heart disease (e.g., heart failure). Although a single normal heart rhythm on physical examination does not rule out paroxysmal AF, this patient's age and absence of heart disease mean that she is at low risk for AF.

Mitral valve vegetations are seen in infective endocarditis (IE), which may embolize to the brain and cause a stroke. Although IE can manifest with low-grade fever and tachycardia, this patient does not have other typical findings, such as a new-onset heart murmur and extracardiac symptoms (e.g., splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions). Moreover, IE is unlikely in patients without risk factors, e.g., recent dental procedure, IV drug use, active untreated bacterial infection.

A right-to-left cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect) allows paradoxical emboli originating from the venous system to pass directly from the right atrium into the left atrium, from which point they may enter the cerebral arterial system. In a young patient, stroke symptoms (e.g., unilateral weakness, hyperreflexia, facial droop) and signs of DVT should raise concern for paradoxical embolism. This patient should have an immediate stroke workup (e.g., noncontrast head CT, possible thrombolysis). Furthermore, ultrasonography should be performed to confirm DVT. Because paradoxical embolism is a diagnosis of exclusion, all other causes must be excluded after the patient has been stabilized. Given the risk of pulmonary embolism and recurrent cerebral emboli, this patient should be started on anticoagulant therapy once cerebral hemorrhage is ruled out.

Suspected patent foramen ovale should be confirmed with echocardiography so that it can be surgically or percutaneously closed to prevent recurrent emboli.

images.title: Pathophysiology of paradoxical embolism
images.description: In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

answers.explanation_why: Long bone fractures (particularly of the femur) can cause fat embolism. Fat embolism typically manifests with respiratory distress and a classic (but often absent) petechial chest rash as well as neurological symptoms (e.g., focal deficits as in this patient). While this patient had a recent fall, she has no indication of a femoral fracture such as bruising, deformity, or swelling of the thigh and her tender and swollen lower leg is more likely due to deep vein thrombosis.

Primary cardiac tumors (e.g., atrial myxoma) are extremely rare (incidence < 0.1% of the population), and can sometimes embolize, causing stroke. Most patients with primary cardiac tumors experience symptoms of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, edema) due to the tumor obstructing blood flow. Additionally, patients often experience constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss). While this patient has stroke and fever, she lacks signs of heart failure. Her unilateral leg abnormalities are more suggestive of DVT.

question_text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department one hour after sustaining an injury during football practice. He collided head-on into another player while wearing a mouthguard and helmet. Immediately after the collision, he was confused but able to use appropriate words. He opened his eyes spontaneously and followed commands. There was no loss of consciousness. He also had a headache with dizziness and nausea. Upon arrival, he is no longer confused. He feels well. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is fully alert and oriented. His speech is organized and he is able to perform tasks demonstrating full attention, memory, and balance. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the crown of his head but no signs of skin break or fracture. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department one hour after sustaining an injury during football practice. He collided head-on into another player while wearing a mouthguard and helmet. Immediately after the collision, he was confused but able to use appropriate words. He opened his eyes spontaneously and followed commands. There was no loss of consciousness. He also had a headache with dizziness and nausea. Upon arrival, he is no longer confused. He feels well. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is fully alert and oriented. His speech is organized and he is able to perform tasks demonstrating full attention, memory, and balance. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the crown of his head but no signs of skin break or fracture. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
hint: Transient headache, dizziness, nausea, and confusion at the time of head injury as well as a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) ≥ 13 at least 30 minutes after the injury is consistent with mild traumatic brain injury (TBI).
learning_objective: Recognize mild traumatic brain injury, and choose the most appropriate management for observation and return to activity.

answers.content: Admit to intensive care for intracranial pressure monitoring
answers.explanation_why: Admission to the intensive care unit for intracranial pressure monitoring would be appropriate in patients with severe TBI, for which elevated intracranial pressure is a serious concern due to brain edema and/or bleeding. Severe TBI is characterized by a GCS ≤ 8. However, this patient has a GCS of 14 in the field and a GCS of 15 in the emergency department, indicating mild TBI.

Imaging is not an essential element in diagnosing concussion; it is largely a clinical diagnosis. Imaging would be important, however, in evaluating for intracranial bleeding or skull/facial fracture. This patient has a low likelihood for structural pathology, such as hematoma (epidural or subdural), hemorrhage, or fracture due to the normal physical and mental status examinations. Imaging would provide little benefit and is not the best next step.

Discharge without activity restrictions is inappropriate and against current guidelines. In this scenario, the patient may return to play that same day. Several studies exist showing that return to play without activity restrictions increases the odds of delayed symptom onset and protracted neuropsychiatric consequences.

answers.content: Administer prophylactic levetiracetam and observe for 24 hours
answers.explanation_why: Levetiracetam is a first-line agent for seizure prophylaxis after severe TBI, which manifests with a GCS ≤ 8. This patient has a GCS of 14 in the field and a GCS of 15 in the emergency department, indicating mild TBI. Seizure prophylaxis is thus not appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Administer prophylactic phenytoin and observe for 24 hours
answers.explanation_why: Phenytoin is a first-line agent for seizure prophylaxis after severe TBI, which manifests with a GCS ≤ 8. This patient has a GCS of 14 in the field and a GCS of 15 in the emergency department, indicating mild TBI. Seizure prophylaxis is thus not appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Discharge and refrain from all physical activity for one week
answers.explanation_why: Immediate discharge following mild TBI is inappropriate because patients may develop delayed-onset complications, such as intracranial bleeding. Serial clinical examinations are important for detecting such complications (as evidenced by altered mental status or focal neurological findings). Moreover, refraining from all physical activity is more strict than what is currently recommended. A gradual return to play is thought to be important in recovery from concussion.

answers.content: Observe for 6 hours in the ED and refrain from contact sports for one week
answers.explanation_why:
Observation followed by a gradual return to playing sports is the current recommendation for mild TBI. Observation in the emergency department (ED) for at least 4–6 hours should include serial neurological examination and assessment of GCS. Alterations in mental status or focal neurological signs may indicate more serious underlying pathology, such as intracranial bleeding. Following discharge, this patient should be monitored by a responsible individual for at least 24 hours after injury and return to the ED if there are any neurological changes. Patients should also progress through six stages of a gradual return to sports. As each stage requires at least 24 hours, this patient will need to refrain from contact sports for at least one week.

Neuroimaging is not routinely recommended for mild TBI. If at any point during the observation period the GCS deteriorates to < 13, patients should be reclassified as having moderate TBI or severe TBI and managed accordingly.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of repeated episodes of daydreaming over the past 2 months. The mother reports that during these episodes, the boy abruptly stops what he is doing and just stares into space. She says that he sometimes also smacks his lips. The episodes typically last 1–2 minutes and occur 2–3 times per week. Initially, the boy only experienced the symptoms at school but last week he had an episode while playing baseball with his father. When his father tried to talk to him, he did not seem to listen. After the episode, he was confused for 10 minutes and too tired to play. The patient has been healthy except for an episode of otitis media 1 year ago that was treated with amoxicillin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no other abnormalities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of repeated episodes of daydreaming over the past 2 months. The mother reports that during these episodes, the boy abruptly stops what he is doing and just stares into space. She says that he sometimes also smacks his lips. The episodes typically last 1–2 minutes and occur 2–3 times per week. Initially, the boy only experienced the symptoms at school but last week he had an episode while playing baseball with his father. When his father tried to talk to him, he did not seem to listen. After the episode, he was confused for 10 minutes and too tired to play. The patient has been healthy except for an episode of otitis media 1 year ago that was treated with amoxicillin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no other abnormalities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient presents with episodes of altered mental status that are associated with alimentary automatisms (lip smacking), occur several times a week during rest as well as during physical activity, and are followed by a postictal phase (confusion, tiredness). These episodes are most consistent with a diagnosis of focal seizures with impaired consciousness.
learning_objective: Recognize focal seizures with impaired consciousness, and recall the expected EEG findings.

answers.content: Defiant behavior towards figures of authority
answers.explanation_why: Defiant behavior towards figures of authority is a diagnostic criterion of oppositional defiant disorder. Since this boy has no history of openly defying his parents or being irritable, this diagnosis can be ruled out. His unresponsiveness towards his father can be attributed to a postictal state rather than deliberately ignoring being spoken to.

Difficulty sustaining attention is a diagnostic feature of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). A child may repeatedly interrupt an activity, appear to be daydreaming, and not pay attention to instructions or when being spoken to directly. However, since consciousness is not impaired, the child's attention can easily be regained. The absence of hyperactivity and impulsivity in this boy further rule out ADHD.

answers.content: Impairment in communication and social interaction
answers.explanation_why: Impairment in communication and social interaction is a core feature of autism spectrum disorder. While children with autism often prefer to be on their own and may ignore unwanted attempts at communication by other people, the episodes described in this case are indicative of impaired awareness. Since no other features of autism spectrum disorder are present (e.g., stereotyped behavior patterns, restricted interests), this diagnosis is unlikely. Autism spectrum disorder is associated with an increased occurrence of epilepsy and should be considered as a factor that potentially contributes to abnormal behavior in children.

answers.content: Temporal lobe spikes on ictal EEG
answers.explanation_why: This child presents with a history of focal seizures with impaired awareness, which is a primary feature of temporal lobe epilepsy. Focal seizures originate in the temporal lobe and are caused by structural changes or damage to the brain (e.g., encephalitis, developmental disorders). Seizure activity is visible as temporal lobe spikes on EEG during a seizure episode; interictal EEG may be normal. This patient should undergo an MRI to determine potential underlying causes. Treatment consists of pharmacotherapy with lamotrigine or levetiracetam; surgery may be necessary for refractory disease. The prognosis is unfavorable, as only 40% of patients remain asymptomatic on pharmacotherapy.

images.title: Anterior temporal spikes and sharp waves
images.description: EEG (10-20 system; longitudinal bipolar montage) of a patient with temporal lobe epilepsyTracings of the left cerebral hemisphere show anterior temporal spikes and sharp waves (examples in red boxes).These findings indicate a possible epileptogenic source in the left anterior temporal lobe.

answers.explanation_why: Although a child with conductive hearing loss (e.g., as a complication of otitis media) may appear to be inattentive or unresponsive when spoken to, symptoms of impaired hearing would be consistently present. While this boy has brief episodes in which he appears inattentive, he generally responds normally when spoken to and shows no abnormalities on physical exam. He also has no risk factors for developing conductive hearing loss, since his episode of otitis media 1 year ago was treated adequately with antibiotics and resolved completely.

While episodes of daydreaming may occur as part of normal development in children, daydreaming without pathological significance is often triggered by boredom, does not occur during physical activity, can be interrupted, and is not associated with retrograde amnesia or automatisms (e.g., lip-smacking). This boy's symptoms are consistent with focal seizures with impaired consciousness, which are often caused by structural or metabolic pathologies (e.g., hippocampal sclerosis, developmental and neurodegenerative disorders, CNS infections, head trauma). These conditions are also likely to manifest with impaired neurodevelopment. Furthermore, individuals with this patient's focal seizure disorder seldom remain asymptomatic despite medical treatment.

answers.content: Slow spike-wave complexes on ictal EEG
answers.explanation_why: Generalized 3 Hz spike-and-slow-wave complexes on EEG are seen in children with childhood absence epilepsy. While absence seizures manifest with brief unresponsiveness and automatisms like lip-smacking, the episodes are typically shorter (5–10 seconds). Atypical absence seizures may last > 30 seconds, have a more gradual onset, and patients may be more responsive. However, like typical absence seizures, the episodes would occur several times a day and are not followed by a postictal phase.

images.title: EEG findings in absence seizures
images.description: Characteristic 3 Hz spikes and waves. The steep rise is the spike and the flat increase the wave. This complex usually occurs with a frequency of 3 per second (hence its name). This finding most commonly occurs during a seizure in absence epilepsy; it can also be seen in a seizure-free interval (interictal).

question_text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician with her father for evaluation of her tall stature. She is concerned because she is taller than all of her friends. Her birth weight and height were within normal limits. Her father is 174 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall; her mother is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall. She is at the 98^th percentile for height and 90^th percentile for BMI. She has not had her menstrual period yet. Her mother has Graves disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tall stature with broad hands and feet. There is frontal bossing and protrusion of the mandible. Finger perimetry is normal. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 144 mg/dL. An x-ray of the left hand and wrist shows a bone age of 15 years. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician with her father for evaluation of her tall stature. She is concerned because she is taller than all of her friends. Her birth weight and height were within normal limits. Her father is 174 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall; her mother is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall. She is at the 98th percentile for height and 90th percentile for BMI. She has not had her menstrual period yet. Her mother has Graves disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tall stature with broad hands and feet. There is frontal bossing and protrusion of the mandible. Finger perimetry is normal. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 144 mg/dL. An x-ray of the left hand and wrist shows a bone age of 15 years. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
hint: Tall stature (> 97^th percentile for age and sex), broad hands and feet, prognathism (protrusion of the mandible), and frontal bossing are consistent with the diagnosis of gigantism.
learning_objective: Recognize gigantism, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why:
Growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas cause gigantism in children and adolescents, and acromegaly in adults. Growth hormone (GH) stimulates IGF-1 synthesis, which in turn promotes cell proliferation, especially of the bones and cartilage. Excess GH also has a diabetogenic effect, which explains the elevated serum glucose seen in this patient. The treatment of choice for both gigantism and acromegaly is transsphenoidal adenomectomy. Pharmacotherapy with somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide) is indicated if GH excess is not completely resolved by surgery or if surgery is not possible.

See "Etiology of tall stature" table.

Letrozole is a medication indicated to treat individuals with McCune-Albright syndrome. One of the findings associated with the condition is precocious puberty, which may lead to accelerated growth and increased height. However, since this patient shows no other features of McCune-Albright syndrome (e.g., cafe-au-lait spots, pathological fractures) and her puberty is delayed rather than precocious, this diagnosis is unlikely.

Insulin therapy is the treatment of choice for type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM). Although this patient presents with fasting hyperglycemia, which is a cardinal feature of diabetes mellitus, she has no other signs or symptoms of the disease, such as polyuria, polydipsia, or weight loss. Her obesity, broad hands and feet, prognathism, and frontal bossing are not consistent with T1DM. Moreover, T1DM is commonly associated with stunted growth rather than tall stature.

Methimazole is indicated for the treatment of Graves disease, a condition that may cause tall stature in adolescents and in which genetic predisposition (e.g., Graves disease in a parent) plays a strong role. Since broad hands and feet, prognathism, and frontal bossing are not features of Graves disease and further characteristic features are absent (e.g., tachycardia, diffuse goiter), this diagnosis is unlikely.

Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist indicated for the treatment of central precocious puberty. Common features of central precocious puberty include accelerated skeletal growth, early skeletal maturity, early development of secondary sexual features, and early onset of menarche. Because menarche has not yet occurred in this patient, she would be described as having delayed puberty rather than precocious puberty. Since this patient's skeletal maturity is age-appropriate and precocious puberty is unlikely to manifest with isolated accelerated growth, this diagnosis can be ruled out.

Caloric restriction is the primary measure used to manage overweight and obesity. While excess calorie intake in children may also result in greater height, this patient's broad hands and feet, prognathism, and frontal bossing should raise suspicion of a different pathology.

question_text:
A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressively worsening headaches, peripheral vision loss, and inability to maintain an erection. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Ophthalmic examination shows bitemporal hemianopsia. His basal FSH concentration is elevated and his prolactin concentration is mildly elevated. An MRI of the head shows a 1.5-cm, solid suprasellar mass compressing the optic chiasm. The patient is diagnosed with a gonadotroph macroadenoma. A hypophysectomy is planned. Without the appropriate postoperative treatment, which of the following sets of laboratory changes is the patient most likely to develop?

Serum dehydroepiandrosterone
Urine osmolality
Serum potassium
Serum glucose

A
Decreased
decreased
normal
decreased

B
Decreased
decreased
normal
increased

C
Increased
decreased
decreased
decreased

D
Decreased
increased
normal
increased

E
Decreased
decreased
increased
decreased
content_preview: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressively worsening headaches, peripheral vision loss, and inability to maintain an erection. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Ophthalmic examination shows bitemporal hemianopsia. His basal FSH concentration is elevated and his prolactin concentration is mildly elevated. An MRI of the head shows a 1.5-cm, solid suprasellar mass compressing the optic chiasm. The patient is diagnosed with a gonadotroph macroadenoma. A hypophysectomy is planned. Without the appropriate postoperative treatment, which of the following sets of laboratory changes is the patient most likely to develop? Serum dehydroepiandrosterone Urine osmolality Serum potassium Serum glucose A Decreased decreased normal decreased B Decreased decreased normal increased C Increased decreased decreased decreased D Decreased increased normal increased E Decreased decreased increased decreased
hint: As a result of hypophysectomy, this patient will develop panhypopituitarism, a deficiency in all hormones of the anterior pituitary (ACTH, FSH/LH, TSH, GH, prolactin) and the posterior pituitary (ADH, oxytocin).
learning_objective: Recall the laboratory findings of panhypopituitarism.

answers.explanation_why: Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) is produced in the adrenal cortex (zona reticularis) and its secretion is ACTH-dependent and thus decreased in panhypopituitarism. Urine osmolality is mostly regulated by the ADH-dependent renal collecting ducts. Absent ADH will result in diluted urine (as seen in this patient). Serum potassium levels are mainly regulated by aldosterone as part of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which, despite its upregulation due to initial volume depletion, does not significantly affect potassium concentrations. In addition, since ACTH does not directly affect potassium regulation by RAAS, the decreased ACTH levels due to hypopituitarism have no significant impact on potassium levels. Serum glucose concentration is mostly insulin/glucagon-dependent, but it is also regulated by cortisol (which itself is regulated by ACTH). Cortisol upregulates gluconeogenesis and decreases peripheral glucose utilization. Therefore, a decrease in cortisol secretion will result in hypoglycemia.

Serum glucose levels are influenced by cortisol secretion, as cortisol increases gluconeogenesis and decreases peripheral glucose utilization. Cortisol secretion is upregulated by ACTH. Therefore, an absence of ACTH in hypopituitarism would not present with elevated glucose levels but rather with hypoglycemia.

Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) production in the adrenal cortex (zona reticularis) and its secretion are ACTH-dependent and therefore decreased in panhypopituitarism. Increased levels of DHEA are seen in congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

Urine osmolality is mostly regulated by the ADH-dependent renal collecting ducts. Deficient ADH secretion would lead to diluted urine (decreased urine osmolality). A non-renal cause of increased urine osmolality would be syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

Serum potassium levels are mainly regulated by aldosterone as part of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Since ACTH does not directly affect potassium regulation by RAAS, decreased ACTH levels due to hypopituitarism would have no significant impact on potassium levels.

question_text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache over the past hour. He also reports nausea and one episode of non-bloody vomiting. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include enalapril and metformin, but he states that he does not take his medications on a regular basis. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not place or time. Physical examination shows decreased muscle strength in the right leg and arm. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the right upper and lower extremities. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows a solitary hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema in the left cerebral hemisphere. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache over the past hour. He also reports nausea and one episode of non-bloody vomiting. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include enalapril and metformin, but he states that he does not take his medications on a regular basis. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not place or time. Physical examination shows decreased muscle strength in the right leg and arm. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the right upper and lower extremities. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows a solitary hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema in the left cerebral hemisphere. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with acute onset of severe headache, vomiting, and focal neurologic deficits (unilateral muscle weakness and hyperreflexia), which strongly suggests a cerebrovascular accident (CVA). Poorly controlled hypertension is a major risk factor for the underlying cause of this CVA.
learning_objective: Recognize intracerebral hemorrhage due to hypertension.

answers.explanation_why: Intracranial neoplasms can cause seizures, focal neurological deficits, and headaches that are often worse when lying down or waking up. In individuals with a brain tumor, the onset of symptoms is usually insidious and clinical findings depend on the type and location of the tumor. This patient's CT findings and his rapid and progressive onset of symptoms suggest a different diagnosis.

images.title: Brain tumor
images.description: Cranial MRI (T1-weighted; axial view; IV contrast) in a 38-year-old patientA sharply demarcated, oval, lobulated mass (green overlay) in the posterior horn of the left lateral ventricle shows homogeneous contrast enhancement. There is mild displacement (almost no midline shift) and marked perifocal edema, indicating slow tumor growth. The differential diagnosis includes ependymoma, choroid plexus papilloma, and intraventricular meningioma. A definitive diagnosis is not possible without further sequences and layers.

answers.content: Rupture of a small penetrating artery
answers.explanation_why: This patient most likely has an intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) due to rupture of a small penetrating artery in the subcortical region of the left cerebral hemisphere. Arterial hypertension, as seen in this patient, is the single most important predisposing factor for intracerebral hemorrhage because it causes lipohyalinosis. Acute peaks in blood pressure can then lead to rupture of these weakened vessels, which was the likely mechanism of rupture in this patient. A noncontrast CT scan of the head characteristically shows a solitary hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema (most commonly within the basal ganglia or internal capsule).

images.title: Basal ganglia hemorrhage
images.description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of chronic hypertensionHyperdense hemorrhage in the left basal ganglia is surrounded by hypodense perifocal edema (red overlay).The location is typical for hemorrhage from the lenticulostriate arteries as a result of long-standing hypertension.1: head of caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3 and green overlay: internal capsule; 4: thalamus
Arrowheads: calcified pineal gland; white circles: calcified choroid plexus

answers.explanation_why: A subdural hematoma typically results from a tear in the bridging veins caused by head trauma. The clinical presentation ranges from acute loss of consciousness followed by severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and impaired memory and cognition to chronic, insidious onset of these symptoms over days or weeks following the initial trauma. Increased intracranial pressure may develop, resulting in cerebral hypoperfusion and focal neurologic deficits. However, a CT scan of the head would characteristically show a crescent-shaped, concave hemorrhage that crosses suture lines. In addition, risk factors for subdural hematoma include old age, cerebral atrophy, chronic alcohol consumption, and anticoagulation therapy, none of which are seen here.

images.title: Subdural hematoma
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)The hyperdense, crescent-shaped, extra-axial collection (green overlay) visible along the left frontal convexity is compatible with an acute subdural hematoma.Additional findings of dilated ventricles and sulci indicate generalized cerebral atrophy. The periventricular hyperlucencies are consistent with cerebral small vessel disease.

answers.explanation_why: Ruptured saccular aneurysms (berry aneurysms) located at major branches of large cerebral arteries are the most common cause of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which may manifest with sudden onset of severe headache (often described by patients as the “worst headache of my life”), nausea/vomiting, and/or confusion. However, a noncontrast CT scan of the head would characteristically show focal or diffuse hyperdensity within the subarachnoid space. Moreover, patients commonly have a positive Kernig and/or Brudzinski sign due to meningeal irritation.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Regions of high attenuation (green overlay) in the interpeduncular cistern, Sylvian fissures, and left posterior fossa represent acute subarachnoid hemorrhage. The cerebellar tentorium (red overlay) should not be misinterpreted as blood.

answers.content: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery
answers.explanation_why: An epidural hematoma results from rupture of the middle meningeal artery and is often caused by trauma. Epidural hematomas may cause headache, nausea, and focal neurological deficits. However, a noncontrast CT scan of the head would characteristically show a biconvex, hyperdense, sharply demarcated lesion located between the brain and the calvarium and limited by suture lines. Moreover, patients typically present with an initial loss of consciousness after a trauma, followed by a lucid interval (temporary regaining of consciousness), which is then followed by a renewed decline in their mental status.

images.title: Epidural hematoma
images.description: CT head (axial section; noncontrast)An epidural hematoma is visible as a solitary biconvex hyperdense lesion in the left frontotemporal region (green overlay), causing a midline shift to the contralateral side (indicated by lines and arrows). The soft tissue of the scalp overlying the lesion also appears hyperdense, indicating a scalp hematoma (red overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Rupture of an intracranial arteriovenous malformation (AVM) can result in a cerebrovascular accident and, depending on the location of the AVM, may present as an intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) or subarachnoid hemorrhage. This patient's presentation is most consistent with an ICH, but AVM is a rare cause, accounting for only 3% of cases of ICH, and most commonly occurs in children and young adults (10–40 years of age).

images.title: Arteriovenous malformation (angioma)
images.description: Angiography of the internal carotid artery and its branches. The parietal-occipital region shows a conglomerate of very small vessels (arteriovenous angioma, green overlay). Both the afferent artery (A) and the efferent vein (V), which drains the blood into the dural venous sinus, can be seen.

question_text: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache and left-sided weakness and numbness for the past 2 hours. She has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril, amlodipine, insulin, and warfarin. She is oriented to person, place, and date. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.3°F), pulse is 90/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 165/94 mm Hg. Examination shows leftward and downward deviation of the eyes. The pupils are miotic and nonreactive. Muscle strength is 2/5 on the left side and 5/5 on the right side. Deep tendon reflexes are decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased on the left side and normal on the right side and the face. Prothrombin time is 51 seconds (INR = 4.3). Hemorrhage into which of the following locations is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache and left-sided weakness and numbness for the past 2 hours. She has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril, amlodipine, insulin, and warfarin. She is oriented to person, place, and date. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.3°F), pulse is 90/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 165/94 mm Hg. Examination shows leftward and downward deviation of the eyes. The pupils are miotic and nonreactive. Muscle strength is 2/5 on the left side and 5/5 on the right side. Deep tendon reflexes are decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased on the left side and normal on the right side and the face. Prothrombin time is 51 seconds (INR = 4.3). Hemorrhage into which of the following locations is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Hemorrhage in this region may extend into the third ventricle.
learning_objective: Recognize hemorrhage in the right thalamus.

answers.explanation_why: Cerebellar hemorrhage typically manifests with ataxia, dysarthria, facial palsy, and skew deviation of the eyes. Signs of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, neck stiffness) occur early. Hemiparesis, which this patient presents with, is characteristically absent in cerebellar strokes, indicating that another area of her brain is likely affected.

Putaminal hemorrhage (from anterolateral central arteries) typically manifests with contralateral hemiplegia, contralateral hemisensory defects, and contralateral gaze palsy with an ipsilateral deviation of the eyes. Therefore, a right-sided putaminal hemorrhage can manifest with left-sided hemiplegia and hemisensory loss. However, a left-sided gaze palsy with a rightward deviation of the eyes would be expected.

Pontine hemorrhage typically manifests with quadriplegia, facial paralysis, deafness, and dysarthria. Furthermore, miotic pupils are a feature of pontine stroke. However, affected individuals have ipsilateral horizontal conjugate palsy (i.e., an inability to horizontally look toward the side of the lesion) or, in bilateral pontine hemorrhage, ocular bobbing. Vertical eye movements and blinking are preserved in ventral pontine stroke, a condition known as locked-in syndrome. This patient has almost none of the typical features of pontine hemorrhage.

Putaminal hemorrhage typically manifests with contralateral hemiplegia, contralateral hemisensory loss, and contralateral gaze palsy with ipsilateral deviation of the eyes. A left-sided putaminal hemorrhage can manifest with leftward deviation of the eyes. However, right-sided hemiplegia and hemisensory loss would also be expected.

The combination of hemiparesis, hemisensory deficits, miotic and nonreactive pupils, and gaze deviation downward and toward the affected side of the body (i.e., away from the side of the brain lesion) is a phenomenon known as “wrong way eyes” and characteristically occurs in thalamic hemorrhage. In contrast, other sites of supratentorial hemorrhage typically cause a gaze deviation toward the side of the lesion (i.e., away from the affected side of the body). This patient’s left-sided weakness and sensory loss, miotic nonreactive pupils, and leftward and downward deviation of her eyes are best explained by a stroke in the right thalamus.

Note that the thalamus is a relatively large region of the brain and thalamic stroke has a variety of manifestations (e.g., pure sensory stroke in lacunar syndromes). However, “wrong way eyes” is a classical finding of thalamic hemorrhage.

images.title: Thalamic hemorrhage
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of an older adultHyperdense hemorrhage (blue overlay) involving the right thalamus extends to the posterior limb of the right internal capsule. Intraventricular hemorrhage (yellow overlay) is also present. Mass-effect has caused a slight midline shift.Prominent sulci and ventricles are consistent with cerebral atrophy.Green overlay: internal capsule; red line: midline; T: thalamus

answers.explanation_why: A frontal lobe hemorrhage typically manifests with weakness or paralysis of the contralateral leg (sparing the arm) and deviation of the eyes toward the side of the lesion. Although a hemorrhagic stroke in the left frontal lobe can manifest with a leftward deviation of the eyes, right-sided weakness of the lower limb would also be present. In addition, sensation is typically preserved in frontal lobe lesions. Thus, another area of the brain is more likely to be affected in this patient.

A frontal lobe hemorrhage typically manifests with weakness or paralysis of the contralateral leg (sparing the arm) and deviation of the eyes toward the side of the lesion. Sensation is typically preserved in frontal lobe lesions. A right frontal lobe hemorrhage would manifest with weakness in the left leg but also with rightward deviation of the eyes, whereas this patient's eyes deviate leftward.

Thalamic hemorrhage typically manifests with contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, miotic and unreactive pupils, and upgaze palsy with gaze deviation away from the side of the lesion, a phenomenon known as “wrong way eyes”. A hemorrhagic lesion in the left thalamus would manifest with right-sided weakness and sensory loss with rightward gaze deviation, unlike what is seen in this case.

question_text:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 155/70 mm Hg. Breath sounds are shallow. Examination shows multiple head contusions and a 3 cm x 3-cm soft hematoma on his left temporal region. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and infusion of 0.9% saline is started. A CT scan of the head shows a left-sided temporal bone fracture with an associated small left subarachnoid hemorrhage. He is taken to the neurosurgical intensive care unit for further management. The decision to intubate this patient was most likely based on which of the following combination of findings?

Eye opening
Verbal response
Motor response

A
To verbal command
Oriented
Obeys commands

B
To pain
Incomprehensible sounds
Abnormal flexion

C
To verbal command
Confused speech
Localizes pain

D
To pain
Incomprehensible words
Obeys commands

E
Open spontaneously
Inappropriate words
Withdraws from pain

The decision to intubate this patient was most likely based on which of the following combination of findings? Eye opening Verbal response Motor response A To verbal command Oriented Obeys commands B To pain Incomprehensible sounds Abnormal flexion C To verbal command Confused speech Localizes pain D To pain Incomprehensible words Obeys commands E Open spontaneously Inappropriate words Withdraws from pain
hint: In cases of acute trauma, a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score ≤ 8 is an indication for urgent endotracheal intubation.
learning_objective: Recall the indications for intubation, and how the Glasgow Coma Scale score is calculated.

answers.explanation_why: A trauma patient who opens their eyes to verbal command, is oriented, and obeys commands would receive a GCS score of 14 (3 for eye opening, 5 for verbal response, and 6 for motor response). A GCS score of 14 indicates only mild head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation

A patient who opens their eyes to pain, makes incomprehensible sounds, and has decorticate posture (or abnormal flexion) would receive a total GCS score of 7 (2 for eye-opening, 2 for a verbal response, and 3 for motor response). GCS assessment is part of the primary trauma survey in any trauma patient to evaluate neurological status, consciousness, and degree of brain injury. A GCS score of ≤ 8 indicates severe brain injury with a decreasing level of consciousness, which requires emergency endotracheal intubation to protect the patient's airway and reduce the risk of aspiration of gastric contents.

See “Glasgow coma scale” table.

A trauma patient who opens their eyes to verbal command, speaks confused or disoriented words, and localizes pain would receive a GCS score of 12 (3 for eye-opening, 4 for verbal response, and 5 for motor response). A GCS score of 12 indicates only moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.

A trauma patient who opens their eyes to pain and makes incomprehensible sounds but obeys commands would receive a GCS score of 10 (2 for eye-opening, 2 for verbal response, and 6 for motor response). A GCS score of 10 indicates moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.

A trauma patient who opens their eyes spontaneously, speaks inappropriate words, and withdraws from pain would receive a GCS score of 11 (4 for eye-opening, 3 for verbal response, and 4 for motor response). A GCS score of 11 indicates moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of headaches and blurry vision for the past 6 months. He also reports frequent episodes of vomiting over the last month. His father died of renal cell carcinoma at the age of 37 years. Examination shows 20/40 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling and growth of capillary vessels in the temporal peripheral retina. An MRI of the brain shows an infratentorial mass. The patient undergoes surgical resection of the mass. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of headaches and blurry vision for the past 6 months. He also reports frequent episodes of vomiting over the last month. His father died of renal cell carcinoma at the age of 37 years. Examination shows 20/40 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling and growth of capillary vessels in the temporal peripheral retina. An MRI of the brain shows an infratentorial mass. The patient undergoes surgical resection of the mass. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with an infratentorial brain tumor and abnormal capillary growth in the retina. In combination with a family history of renal cell carcinoma, this raises suspicion for von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL).
learning_objective: Recognize hemangioblastoma associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease.

answers.explanation_why: Medulloblastomas, which are commonly located in the infratentorial region, may present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). However, they are not associated with retinal vascular changes. In addition, this type of tumor most commonly develops in the first decade of life. Histology typically shows small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, medulloblastomas are not a manifestation of VHL disease but instead are associated with Turcot's syndrome.

images.title: Medulloblastoma
images.description:
Photomicrograph of cerebellar vermis tissue (H&E stain)Numerous small, blue, round cells with scant cytoplasm can be seen throughout the specimen (examples indicated by green overlay). Their nuclei vary in size and structure (nuclear pleomorphism) and many cells feature distinctly hyperchromatic nuclei.
The majority of the cells are arranged in concentric clusters around lighter central areas consisting of neuropil (examples indicated by yellow overlay). These clusters are referred to as Homer Wright rosettes.These histopathological features, particularly the Homer Wright rosettes, are characteristic of a medulloblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Pilocytic astrocytomas, which are commonly located in the infratentorial region, may present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). However, they are not associated with retinal vascular changes. Moreover, this type of tumor most commonly develops in patients younger than 20 years of age. Histology typically shows Rosenthal fibers and positive staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, pilocytic astrocytomas are not a manifestation of VHL disease but instead are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1.

images.title: Pilocytic astrocytoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of cerebellar tissue (H&E stain)There are numerous bipolar cells, composed of a central basophilic nucleus with eosinophilic pilocytic processes (examples indicated in green) arising from either end. The pilocytic processes are arranged in bundles, which resemble matted hair. The bright red-pink bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions (examples indicated by black arrowheads) in astrocytes and indicate intense gliosis (Rosenthal fibers).These are the characteristic features of pilocytic astrocytoma.

answers.explanation_why: Craniopharyngiomas can present with headache and vomiting, as seen here. However, as opposed to this patient's tumor, this type of neoplasm is located in the supratentorial (i.e., suprasellar) region. Moreover, craniopharyngiomas are usually associated with bitemporal hemianopsia, hyperprolactinemia, and hypopituitarism, all of which are absent here. Histology typically shows metaplastic squamous cells or reticular epithelial cells, calcifications, cysts, and keratin nodules, none of which are seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, craniopharyngiomas are not a manifestation of von Hippel-Lindau disease.

images.title: Adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma
images.description:
Photomicrograph of a brain tissue sample (HPS stain; intermediate magnification)Trabeculae and nests of squamous epithelium (examples indicated by yellow overlay) with palisading cells (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay) are visible.
Additionally, there are multiple cysts (examples indicated by yellow hatched overlay), nodules of anuclear ghost cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) containing wet keratin, and calcifications (examples indicated by blue outline) .This is the typical histological appearance of an adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma.

answers.explanation_why: Glioblastomas can present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema), as seen in this patient. However, as opposed to this patient's tumor, this type of neoplasm is located in the cerebral hemispheres (i.e., supratentorial). Consequently, symptoms such as seizures, focal neurological deficits, and personality changes are common, none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, the median age of onset is between 65–75 years of age. Histology typically shows pleomorphic anaplastic cells that form pseudopalisades and positive staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, glioblastomas are not a manifestation of von Hippel-Lindau disease.

images.title: Glioblastoma multiforme
images.description: Photomicrograph of a cerebral tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)A high number and density of highly pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei are visible (examples indicated by arrowheads. These cells are aggregated around the periphery of the necrotic zone (green overlay), forming a nuclear pseudopalisading architecture.These are the characteristic features of glioblastoma multiforme.

answers.explanation_why: Oligodendrogliomas can present with headache and vomiting. However, as opposed to this patient's tumor, this type of neoplasm is most commonly located in the cerebral hemispheres (i.e., supratentorial). Consequently, symptoms such as seizures, focal neurological deficits, and personality changes are common, none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, the median age of onset is between 40–50 years of age. Histology typically shows fried egg cells and a chicken-wire pattern of capillary anastomoses, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, oligodendrogliomas are not a manifestation of von Hippel-Lindau disease.

images.title: Oligodendroglioma
images.description: Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; very high magnification)Monomorphic cells with enlarged, round/oval nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of unstained cytoplasm, which is an artifact of processing, are visible (green overlay). Thin blood vessels with an interlacing pattern are also visible (yellow overlay).These are the typical features of oligodendroglioma.

answers.explanation_why: Hemangioblastomas are rare, highly vascularized, infratentorial brain tumors, that may occur sporadically or as a manifestation of VHL disease. As in this case, patients often present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). Hemangioblastomas are further associated with polycythemia, caused by paraneoplastic erythropoietin production. Histology shows densely packed, thin-walled capillary vessels surrounded by large stromal cells with intracytoplasmic lipid inclusions. VHL-associated tumors most commonly occur in early adulthood and include hemangioblastomas of the spine, cerebellum, and retina (commonly bilateral and peripherally located, as seen here), renal cell carcinomas, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic cysts.

Intracranial ependymomas, which are commonly located in the infratentorial region, may present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). However, they are not associated with retinal vascular changes. Moreover, this type of tumor most commonly develops in early childhood. Histology typically shows perivascular pseudorosettes and rod-shaped blepharoplasts, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, ependymomas are not a manifestation of VHL disease but instead are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2.

images.title: Ependymoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of a brain tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)There is an abnormally high number of cells with round nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Some cells are arranged in a spoke-and-wheel pattern, surrounding an empty central space. Such patterns are called ependymal rosettes (example indicated by green overlay). Other cells are arranged concentrically around blood vessels, producing a similar appearance (perivascular pseudorosettes; example indicated yellow overlay).These are typical histopathological features of ependymoma.

images.title: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma (WHO grade I)
images.description: Photomicrograph of a cerebellar tissue specimen (HPS stain; high magnification)Numerous polygonal neoplastic stromal cells with lipid-laden vacuoles (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen, resulting in the typical clear-cell appearance. Additionally, there is an abundance of small, thin-walled blood vessels, many of which are densely packed together (examples indicated by blue overlay).

question_text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of fever, chills, and double vision. She also has a 2-week history of headache and foul-smelling nasal discharge. Her temperature is 39.4°C (103°F). Examination shows mild swelling around the left eye. Her left eye does not move past midline on far left gaze but moves normally when looking to the right. Corneal reflex is absent. Absence of the corneal reflex is most likely caused by compression of which of the following labeled structures?
content_preview: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of fever, chills, and double vision. She also has a 2-week history of headache and foul-smelling nasal discharge. Her temperature is 39.4°C (103°F). Examination shows mild swelling around the left eye. Her left eye does not move past midline on far left gaze but moves normally when looking to the right. Corneal reflex is absent. Absence of the corneal reflex is most likely caused by compression of which of the following labeled structures?
hint: This patient has manifestations of acute bacterial sinusitis (e.g., fever, headache, foul-smelling nasal discharge). Periorbital edema and abducens nerve palsy suggest the development of cavernous sinus thrombosis, a rare but dangerous complication of acute bacterial sinusitis.
learning_objective: Recall neuroanatomy of the trigeminal nerve and cavernous sinus.

answers.explanation_why: Compression of the abducens nerve can be caused by cavernous sinus thrombosis. Patients present with the inability to abduct the eye, medial strabismus, and diplopia, all of which are seen in this patient. However, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

Compression of the oculomotor nerve can result from cavernous sinus thrombosis and may manifest with double vision, which is seen in this patient. However, oculomotor nerve palsy also causes ptosis, mydriasis, and a down-and-out pupil. Moreover, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

images.title: Bilateral complete oculomotor palsy
images.description: Eyes and forehead of a 20-year-old female patient with tubercular meningitisImage A shows bilateral ptosis, due here to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris. To open her eyes, the patient must contract the frontalis muscle, resulting in the forehead wrinkles seen in image B. Both eyes deviate outwards (exotropia) and downwards (hypotropia) from the primary gaze position. This occurs due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, which are the only unaffected extraocular muscles. Mydriasis indicates involvement of the parasympathetic portion of the oculomotor nerve.Ptosis, mydriasis, exotropia, and hypotropia are the classic signs of complete oculomotor palsy. Complete oculomotor palsy is more commonly unilateral than bilateral.

answers.explanation_why: Compression of the trochlear nerve can occur due to cavernous sinus thrombosis and may manifest with double vision, which is seen in this patient. However, trochlear nerve palsy also causes extorsion with an inability to adduct and depress the eye simultaneously. Moreover, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

Compression of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve can be caused by cavernous sinus thrombosis. Affected patients present with an absent corneal reflex and/or impaired sensation in the upper face. Progression of the thrombus results in cavernous sinus syndrome, causing compression of the oculomotor nerve (CN III), trochlear nerve (CN IV), and abducens nerve (CN VI).

images.title: Pituitary gland and cavernous sinuses
images.description: The pituitary gland lies within the pituitary fossa and is surrounded by the left and right cavernous sinuses and the intercavernous sinuses connecting them. The internal carotid artery and the abducens nerve pass through the middle of each cavernous sinus, while the oculomotor, trochlear, ophthalmic, and maxillary nerves are located towards the lateral wall of the sinuses.

answers.explanation_why: Compression of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve can be due to cavernous sinus thrombosis, which causes loss of sensation of the midface. However, an absent corneal reflex is caused by compression of another cranial nerve.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-week history of irritability and frequent bed wetting. His mother also reports that he has been unable to look upward without tilting his head back for the past 2 months. He is at the 50^th percentile for height and weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmological examination shows dilated pupils that are not reactive to light and bilateral optic disc swelling. Pubic hair development is Tanner stage 2. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a tumor in which of the following locations?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-week history of irritability and frequent bed wetting. His mother also reports that he has been unable to look upward without tilting his head back for the past 2 months. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmological examination shows dilated pupils that are not reactive to light and bilateral optic disc swelling. Pubic hair development is Tanner stage 2. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a tumor in which of the following locations?
hint: This patient presents with vertical gaze palsy and signs of increased intracranial pressure (papilledema). These findings are suggestive of a brain tumor that is causing compression symptoms due to hydrocephalus. Signs of precocious puberty are due to the tumor cell line.
learning_objective: Recognize a dorsal midbrain tumor (pinealoma).

answers.explanation_why: Meningiomas often arise in the cerebral falx and are typically asymptomatic due to their slow growth rate. Compression of the adjacent hemisphere can cause seizures as well as spastic paraparesis and incontinence. Falcine meningiomas do not typically cause hydrocephalus or precocious puberty.

Pinealoma is a childhood tumor of the dorsal midbrain that compresses the pretectal region, resulting in vertical gaze palsy. Because of the close proximity to the cerebral aqueduct, hydrocephalus (due to obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid outflow pathway) can also develop, which would explain this patient's increased intracranial pressure. The most common type of pinealoma in children is germinoma, which often secretes β-hCG, stimulating testosterone production and causing precocious puberty in boys.

Other causes of vertical gaze palsy include stroke, multiple sclerosis, and encephalitis.

Acoustic schwannoma is the most common tumor of the cerebellopontine angle. Compression of structures adjacent to the cerebellopontine angle can cause hydrocephalus, but the absence of vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) involvement (causes unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus, unsteady gait) in this patient and the relatively short clinical course (4 weeks) make acoustic schwannoma (a slow-growing tumor) an unlikely etiology. Furthermore, the median age of patients presenting with acoustic schwannoma is ∼ 50 years.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Ependymomas are childhood tumors that are typically located in the fourth ventricle. This tumor most commonly presents with noncommunicating hydrocephalus, which can result in compression of a number of CNS structures and cause vertical gaze palsy and central precocious puberty. However, in the case of hydrocephalus due to an ependymoma, symptoms of hydrocephalus (e.g., irritability, urinary incontinence) would precede the onset of vertical gaze palsy unlike this patient who had a vertical gaze palsy before the onset of hydrocephalus symptoms.

Pituitary tumors arise within the sella turcica. These tumors can cause compression of the optic chiasm and manifest with bitemporal hemianopsia. Because the pituitary gland is not in close proximity to the ventricular system, hydrocephalus does not occur. In addition, pituitary tumors originating from gonadotropic cells (gonadotroph adenoma) are typically nonsecretory (inactive), resulting in hypogonadism due to the destruction of functioning gonadotropic cells, instead of precocious puberty.

Pilocytic astrocytoma and medulloblastoma are childhood tumors located in the cerebellar vermis. Hydrocephalus due to compression of the fourth ventricle by these tumors can cause vertical gaze palsy and central precocious puberty. However, in the case of hydrocephalus due to either of these tumors, symptoms of hydrocephalus (e.g., irritability, urinary incontinence) would precede the onset of vertical gaze palsy unlike this patient who had a vertical gaze palsy before the onset of hydrocephalus symptoms. Additionally, compression of the cerebellar vermis would cause truncal ataxia, which is not reported in this patient.
