question_text: A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressively worsening paresthesias in her upper limbs. She has accidentally burned her fingers on hot dishes several times. She was involved in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago. Neurological examination shows absent temperature sensation with normal fine touch sensation over the upper extremities and upper chest. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressively worsening paresthesias in her upper limbs. She has accidentally burned her fingers on hot dishes several times. She was involved in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago. Neurological examination shows absent temperature sensation with normal fine touch sensation over the upper extremities and upper chest. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Dissociated sensory loss (dysesthetic pain and absent temperature sensation with normal fine touch sensation) occurs as a result of the anterior white commissure compression. This finding in a cape-like distribution (upper extremities and upper chest) indicates a central cord syndrome of the cervicothoracic spinal cord (most likely at the level of the C5–T1 spinal nerves). The most likely cause of the condition in this patient is syringomyelia secondary to a whiplash injury.
learning_objective: Recognize central cord syndrome, and recall the associated clinical finding.

answers.explanation_why: In syringomyelia, damage to the anterior horn cells by an expanding syrinx would cause features of lower motor neuron injury (e.g., hyporeflexia, flaccid paresis) at the level of the syrinx. Since the syrinx is most likely located at the level of the C5–T1 spinal nerves and the anterior horn cells that form the efferent arc of the biceps reflex are located at the level of the C5 and C6 spinal nerves, the patient is at risk of developing a decreased or absent rather than exaggerated biceps reflex. Features of upper motor neuron injury (e.g., hyperreflexia) can occur below the level of the syrinx due to damage to the upper motor neurons in the medial part of the lateral corticospinal tracts.

Syringomyelia does not affect cognition, and therefore, a decreased Mini-Mental State Examination score is not expected in this patient. Conditions associated with spinal cord involvement and altered cognition include subacute combined degeneration (due to vitamin B_12 deficiency) and tabes dorsalis with paralytic dementia (due to syphilis).

The anal wink reflex is controlled by the pudendal nerve and nerve fibers arising from the sacral region, specifically at the level of S3 to S5. The absence of sacral sparing is characteristic of complete spinal cord injury. Patients with incomplete spinal cord injuries such as central cord syndrome typically have sacral sparing (i.e., an unaffected anal wink reflex or bulbocutaneous reflex) because the corticospinal fibers that innervate the anterior horn cells of the sacral segments are located in the lateral-most part of the corticospinal tract.

The trigeminal nerve provides innervation to the muscles of mastication and a unilateral lesion affecting the trigeminal nerve or its motor nucleus can manifest with a deviation of the jaw. The motor nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is located in the pons and is unlikely to be affected by the cervical syrinx. Only the spinal trigeminal nucleus (a sensory nucleus) extends into the cervical spinal cord (up to the C2 level).

Expansion of the cervical syrinx damages the first-order oculosympathetic neurons, which are located just lateral to the central canal and carry descending sympathetic innervation from the hypothalamus to the ciliospinal center of Budge in the lateral horn. Damage to these neurons results in central Horner syndrome, which manifests with ptosis, i.e., drooping of the eyelid (because the superior tarsal muscle is sympathetically innervated), miosis, and anhidrosis.

As the syrinx expands, the patient will develop features of LMN injury at the syrinx's level (due to damage to the anterior horn cells) and features of UMN injury below the level of the syrinx (due to damage to the medial parts of the lateral corticospinal tract).

images.title: Horner syndrome
images.description: Horner syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral miosis, partial ptosis, and anhidrosis. These features may be due to a central lesion affecting the hypothalamus or first neuron (e.g., brainstem stroke, cervical spine injury, anatomical malformations, demyelinating disease), a preganglionic/second neuron lesion (e.g., Pancoast tumor, trauma, lymphadenopathy, carotid artery lesion), or a postganglionic/third neuron lesion (e.g., internal carotid dissection, tumor, herpes zoster infection).

question_text: A previously healthy 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden weakness of her right arm and leg that started 3 hours ago. She returned from a business trip to Europe 3 days ago. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 115/min and regular, and blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased muscle strength on the entire right side. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the right. Babinski sign is present on the right. The left lower leg is swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A previously healthy 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden weakness of her right arm and leg that started 3 hours ago. She returned from a business trip to Europe 3 days ago. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 115/min and regular, and blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased muscle strength on the entire right side. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the right. Babinski sign is present on the right. The left lower leg is swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This patient has multiple risk factors for deep venous thrombosis (DVT), including a history of immobilization (business trip by plane), smoking, and oral contraceptive use. Now, she presents with clinical features of a left-sided stroke (e.g., right-sided weakness, hyperreflexia, positive Babinski), which in a young patient with signs of DVT (swollen, tender, erythematous left leg) should raise concern for paradoxical embolism.
learning_objective: Recognize paradoxical embolism, and recall the diagnostic finding of the most common cardiac anomaly associated with it.

answers.explanation_why: Paradoxical emboli can pass through any right-to-left shunt, but a patent foramen ovale (PFO) is the most common route. A PFO is considered an abnormal anatomical variant of the heart and is present in ∼ 25% of the general population. In addition to a stroke workup (i.e., noncontrast head CT, possible thrombolysis, etc.), this patient should also undergo compression ultrasonography to confirm DVT. Because of the risk of pulmonary embolism and recurrent cerebral emboli, this patient should be started on anticoagulant therapy once cerebral hemorrhage is ruled out and undergo echocardiography to evaluate for surgical closure of the PFO.

images.title: Pathophysiology of paradoxical embolism
images.description: In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

answers.explanation_why: Primary cardiac tumors (e.g., atrial myxoma) are extremely rare (incidence < 0.1%), and can sometimes embolize, causing stroke. Most patients with primary cardiac tumors do not initially present with stroke, but experience symptoms of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, edema) due to the tumor obstructing blood flow. Additionally, patients often experience constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss). While this patient has stroke and fever, she lacks signs of heart failure. Her unilateral leg abnormalities are more suggestive of DVT.

Embolism of septic vegetations from infective endocarditis (IE) that go to the brain can cause stroke. Patients with IE can also present with fever and tachycardia. However, IE is unlikely in patients without major risk factors for the disease (e.g., recent dental procedure, IV drug abuse, active untreated bacterial infection). This patient's warm, swollen leg could be confused with cellulitis, which would increase her risk of IE, but without a possible entry point for pathogens as in this case, a noninfectious diagnosis is more likely.

Ventricular septal defects are the most common pediatric septal defect and can cause paradoxical embolism, which has likely occurred in this patient. However, most VSDs self-resolve during childhood (and the majority of others are surgically repaired). VSDs make up ∼ 10% of congenital heart defects found in adults.

Atrial fibrillation is a very common cause of thromboembolic stroke in older adults and those with heart disease (e.g., heart failure). This patient is at low risk for atrial fibrillation because of her age and lack of heart disease. Also, her heart rhythm was normal on examination, which decreases the likelihood of atrial fibrillation (but does not rule it out).

Carotid dissection can occur at any age and is a common cause of stroke in young patients (∼ 20% of cases). Cervical artery dissection classically presents with headache and neck pain following exertion (e.g., exercise, sexual intercourse, or even sneezing). This patient's lack of headache or neck pain in the presence of symptoms suggesting DVT make another etiology more likely.

question_text: A 32-year-old primigravid woman with a history of seizures comes to the physician because she had a positive pregnancy test at home. Medications include valproic acid and a multivitamin. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Her baby is at increased risk for requiring which of the following interventions?
content_preview: A 32-year-old primigravid woman with a history of seizures comes to the physician because she had a positive pregnancy test at home. Medications include valproic acid and a multivitamin. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Her baby is at increased risk for requiring which of the following interventions?
hint: Valproic acid intake is known to inhibit folate absorption in the mother.
learning_objective: Recognize the teratogenic effects of valproic acid, and recall the interventions for neural tube defects.

answers.explanation_why: Inhibition of folate absorption in the mother due to valproic acid intake leads to an increased risk of neural tube defects such as spina bifida in the embryo, which may require lower spinal surgery after birth. Valproic acid may also cause cognitive impairment, facial, cardiovascular (e.g., ASD), and skeletal abnormalities (e.g., polydactyly), meaning that it should be avoided during pregnancy. The antiepileptic drugs phenytoin and carbamazepine should also be avoided because they may cause fetal hydantoin syndrome. Teratogenesis occurs most often during the 3^rd–8^th embryologic week when organogenesis is occurring. Since there is no antiepileptic drug that is not teratogenic, an antiepileptic drug should be chosen that controls seizures and is tolerated well by the mother at the lowest effective dose.

Kidney transplantation may become necessary in patients with end-stage renal disease (e.g., due to glomerulonephritis, toxins). Visceral malformations such as fetal renal dysplasia are rather associated with ACE inhibitors than with valproic acid use during pregnancy.

Respiratory support becomes necessary in patients with respiratory depression commonly occurring in maternal opioids use during pregnancy. This patient has no history of opioid intake and valproic acid at therapeutic doses is not known for causing respiratory distress.

Dental treatment may become necessary in children born to a mother with tetracycline (e.g., doxycycline) intake during pregnancy. Tetracyclines (“teethracyclines”) deposit in the tooth buds, causing significant and persistent discoloration of the teeth later on (i.e., varying intensities of yellow, gray, blue, or brown). The treatment of choice is placement of veneers or crowns to cover the discolored teeth. Valproic acid does not deposit in the teeth.

Cochlear implantation is required in some cases of sensorineural hearing loss that may occur if the mother takes an ototoxic aminoglycoside (e.g., gentamicin) during pregnancy, which can damage the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). As a cochlear implant relies on a functional auditory nerve, cochlear implantation is not indicated if the CN VIII or central auditory pathway is completely nonfunctional. Valproic acid intake is not associated with an increased risk of hearing loss.

Limb defects are common in thalidomide embryopathy, a condition due to maternal thalidomide use during pregnancy, which may cause phocomelia and/or micromelia (“flipper limbs”). While limb defects may occur in mothers taking valproic acid during pregnancy as well, these are usually confined to the digits. Regardless, neural tube defects are much more likely.

question_text: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. He also has had a loss of sensitivity around his buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Neurologic examination shows reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; the right side is normal. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. He also has had a loss of sensitivity around his buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Neurologic examination shows reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; the right side is normal. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Two key factors that differentiate this diagnosis are the strong unilateral radicular pain and asymmetrical weakness.
learning_objective: Recognize cauda equina syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Brown-Sequard syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would present with unilateral lower limb weakness, as seen here. However, the affected side would also present with loss of vibration and proprioception and the contralateral side would show loss of pain and temperature sensation, features which are absent in this patient.

Anterior spinal cord syndrome may lead to difficulty voiding because the descending pathways that control sphincter function are located ventrally in the spinal cord. However, it would also cause symmetrical lower limb weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensations in all areas below the level of the lesion.

Central cord syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would produce symmetrical lower limb weakness, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation, which is not reported in this patient. Sensation around the buttocks, inner thighs, and genitalia, as well as anal sphincter tone are classically spared in central cord syndrome.

Conus medullaris syndrome may cause the similar symptoms as seen in this patient, although they usually occur symmetrically with a sudden onset. This patient's symptoms developed over the course of 2 weeks and are asymmetric. Additionally, the knee-jerk reflexes are often spared and numbness is primarily limited to the perianal region, since conus medullaris syndrome typically involves sacral spinal cord segments, and not L3 and L4 (which control the knee-jerk reflex and innervate the saddle region beyond the perianal area). Radiating radicular pain also tends to be less severe in patients with conus medullaris syndrome.

The gradual development of asymmetrical lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, difficulty voiding, a decreased anal tone, and severe back pain with radiation to the lower limb is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given the history of prostate cancer in this patient, spinal imaging is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.

images.title: Conus medullaris and cauda equina syndromes
images.description: 1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equinaWhile disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

question_text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening lower back pain. The pain radiates down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot. She has had no trauma, urinary incontinence, or fever. An MRI of the lumbar spine shows disk degeneration and herniation compressing the S1 nerve root. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?
content_preview: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening lower back pain. The pain radiates down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot. She has had no trauma, urinary incontinence, or fever. An MRI of the lumbar spine shows disk degeneration and herniation compressing the S1 nerve root. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?
hint: S1 radiculopathy causes motor deficits in the gastrocnemius muscle.
learning_objective: Recognize S1 radiculopathy, and recall its effect on reflexes.

answers.explanation_why: Difficulty walking on heels (e.g., foot drop) is consistent with an injury to the L5 nerve roots (i.e., L5 radiculopathy). In addition, L5 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the dorsolateral thigh, the lateral side of the knee, lower leg, and dorsum of the foot and big toe.

An absent patellar reflex is consistent with an injury to the L3 and L4 nerve roots (i.e., L3 and L4 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause sensory deficits of the anterolateral area of the thigh. L4 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the anterolateral thigh, the area over the patella, the medial aspect of the leg, and the medial malleolus.

answers.content: Diminished sensation of the anus and genitalia
answers.explanation_why: Diminished sensation of the anus and the genitalia is seen in cauda equina syndrome. Although patients typically present with asymmetric, unilateral radicular pain in the lower limb dermatomes (due to a lesion below the level of L2), there are usually numerous spinal nerves (L3–S5) involved rather than an isolated nerve root (S1 dermatome) as seen in this patient. Furthermore, other expected findings (e.g., saddle block anesthesia, fecal incontinence, urinary incontinence or retention) are lacking in this patient.

S1 radiculopathy is caused by compression of the S1 spinal nerve root and can manifest with a weak Achilles tendon reflex. The S1 nerve root controls plantar flexion through the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, so weakness in these muscles can lead to a diminished Achilles tendon reflex and impaired toe walking. Additionally, the S1 nerve root controls sensation in the dorsolateral aspect of the thigh, the posterior calf, and the lateral side of the foot, which explains this patient's radiating pain in these regions.

answers.content: Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh
answers.explanation_why: Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh is consistent with an injury to the L3 nerve root (i.e., L3 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit of the anterolateral area of the thigh, as well as weakness of hip flexion, hip adduction, and knee extension.

question_text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of episodic headaches involving both temples for 5 months. The patient has been taking acetaminophen, but it has not provided relief. He has also had double vision. Ophthalmic examination shows impaired peripheral vision bilaterally. Contrast MRI of the head shows a 14 × 10 × 8-mm intrasellar mass. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of episodic headaches involving both temples for 5 months. The patient has been taking acetaminophen, but it has not provided relief. He has also had double vision. Ophthalmic examination shows impaired peripheral vision bilaterally. Contrast MRI of the head shows a 14 × 10 × 8-mm intrasellar mass. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: The intrasellar mass seen on this patient's MRI scan is likely a pituitary adenoma, which accounts for his headaches and bitemporal hemianopsia. The most common type of pituitary adenoma is a prolactinoma.
learning_objective: Recognize a prolactinoma, and recall its associated findings.

answers.explanation_why: Macroglossia is a manifestation of acromegaly, which can be caused by growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas. However, this tumor is uncommon. Another tumor with different findings is more likely in this patient.

Impotence is common in men with hyperprolactinemia, which causes hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Prolactin inhibits the synthesis and release of GnRH, which results in low levels of FSH and LH secretion. Low levels of LH lead to low production of testosterone in testicular Leydig cells. In men, the lack of testosterone can cause erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, reduced testicular volume, impaired fertility, and loss of axillary hair. Pituitary macroadenomas may cause headaches and bitemporal hemianopsia due to compression of the surrounding structures (e.g., optic chiasm).

Galactorrhea occurs in hyperprolactinemia because prolactin stimulates milk production in the breasts. Hyperprolactinemia can be due to a prolactinoma or any sellar tumor that disrupts the inhibitory effect of the hypothalamus on the pituitary gland. Galactorrhea is commonly seen in premenopausal women with hyperprolactinemia. This finding is very rare in postmenopausal women and male patients with hyperprolactinemia. Another finding is more likely.

Hyperpigmentation often manifests in Cushing disease, a form of secondary hypercortisolism that is caused by ACTH-producing pituitary adenomas. Other features include stretch marks (typically purple abdominal striae), hirsutism, and weight gain characterized by central obesity, moon facies, and dorsocervical fat pad, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, pituitary adenomas that produce ACTH are microadenomas, which usually do not cause mass effects (headache, bitemporal hemianopsia).

Diarrhea is a common manifestation of hyperthyroidism. Secondary hyperthyroidism is due to TSH-secreting adenomas, which are a very rare cause of sellar mass, accounting for < 5% of all functioning pituitary adenomas. While the mass effect of this kind of pituitary adenoma could explain this patient's headaches and bitemporal hemianopsia, the absence of other findings typical for excess TSH secretion (e.g., heat intolerance, weight loss, restlessness, or palpitation) makes a TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma very unlikely.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of irregular menses, milky discharge from her nipples, fatigue, and weight gain. Menses occur at irregular 25–40-day intervals and last 1–2 days with minimal flow. 5 months ago, she was started on clozapine for treatment of schizophrenia. She has hypothyroidism but has not been taking levothyroxine over the past 6 months. Visual field examination show no abnormalities. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone is 17.0 μU/mL and serum prolactin is 85 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the nipple discharge in this patient?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of irregular menses, milky discharge from her nipples, fatigue, and weight gain. Menses occur at irregular 25–40-day intervals and last 1–2 days with minimal flow. 5 months ago, she was started on clozapine for treatment of schizophrenia. She has hypothyroidism but has not been taking levothyroxine over the past 6 months. Visual field examination show no abnormalities. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone is 17.0 μU/mL and serum prolactin is 85 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the nipple discharge in this patient?
hint: Galactorrhea and irregular menstrual cycles suggest hyperprolactinemia.
learning_objective: Recognize that hypothyroidism can cause galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia.

answers.explanation_why: This patient has hypothyroidism and does not take her medications, possibly as a result of schizophrenia. Increased TSH in a hypothyroid patient suggests primary hypothyroidism. In primary hypothyroidism, decreased T3 and T4 levels stimulate the hypothalamus to release TRH (thyrotropin releasing hormone), which in turn increases TSH secretion by the anterior pituitary. In addition to increasing TSH production, excessive TRH also stimulates the lactotroph cells of the anterior pituitary to release prolactin, resulting in hyperprolactinemia.

Prolactinomas are the most common cause of hyperprolactinemia. However, prolactin levels in a patient with a prolactinoma are usually > 200 ng/mL. The fact that this patient's prolactin level is < 100 ng/mL makes a different cause for hyperprolactinemia more likely. Additionally, most secretory pituitary adenomas do not secrete multiple pituitary hormones, and prolactinomas that secrete TSH are extremely rare. This patient's increased TSH levels suggest another diagnosis.

Patients with thyrotropic pituitary adenomas have increased levels of TSH and clinical features of hyperthyroidism (secondary to increased TSH) such as weight loss, heat intolerance, diarrhea, and/or tachycardia. Since this patient is hypothyroid, thyrotropic pituitary adenoma is an unlikely diagnosis.
answers.explanation_but: Large thyrotropic adenomas (> 10 mm) can manifest with features of hyperprolactinemia because they compress the infundibular stalk and therefore interrupt the tonic inhibitory effect of hypothalamic dopamine on the secretion of prolactin (disconnection hyperprolactinemia). In addition, patients with large thyrotropic adenomas present with features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, heat intolerance, diarrhea), deficiencies of other pituitary hormones (secondary hypocortisolism, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism), and/or visual field defects.

answers.explanation_why: Ectopic prolactin production is a paraneoplastic syndrome that occurs in certain tumors, e.g., lung or renal cell carcinoma. However, this patient does not have any clinical features suggesting malignancy. Moreover, ectopic prolactin production is extremely rare in comparison to other forms of paraneoplastic hormone secretion (e.g., ectopic ACTH production).

Typical antipsychotics, e.g., haloperidol, (and to a lesser extent, atypical antipsychotics such as risperidone) frequently cause hyperprolactinemia by blocking D2 dopamine receptors of the tuberoinfundibular region in the hypothalamus. However, although clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic, it does not commonly cause hyperprolactinemia.

question_text: A 39-year-old woman with a history of migraine headaches is brought to the emergency room because of a severe, sudden-onset, throbbing headache and double vision for 1 hour. She says that she has been having frequent headaches and has not had her period in several months. Her blood pressure is 93/61 mm Hg. Visual field testing shows a bilateral visual field defect in the lateral quadrants. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 39-year-old woman with a history of migraine headaches is brought to the emergency room because of a severe, sudden-onset, throbbing headache and double vision for 1 hour. She says that she has been having frequent headaches and has not had her period in several months. Her blood pressure is 93/61 mm Hg. Visual field testing shows a bilateral visual field defect in the lateral quadrants. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's recent history of frequent headaches, amenorrhea, and bitemporal hemianopia is key to her diagnosis!
learning_objective: Recognize pituitary apoplexy.

answers.explanation_why: Although a transient ischemic attack (TIA) manifests as a sudden onset of a focal neurological deficit (e.g., double vision) that lasts for < 24 hours and may be associated with headache, it would not explain the menstrual irregularities in this patient. In addition, TIAs would be unlikely in a woman of this age with no known risk factors (e.g., hypercholesterolemia, hypertension).

Pituitary apoplexy is often caused by hemorrhage into the pituitary gland. Intracerebral bleeding increases intracranial pressure, causing sudden, severe headache. The hematoma compresses the oculomotor nerves, which lie adjacent to the pituitary, causing acute onset of double vision. The disruption of pituitary secretion and release of ACTH can cause severe hypotension. Hemorrhage into the pituitary gland usually occurs into a previously existing pituitary adenoma (e.g., prolactinoma), which explains this patient's history of amenorrhea, recurrent headaches, and bitemporal hemianopsia.

Sheehan syndrome occurs following postpartum hemorrhage but can also manifest as amenorrhea (due to decreased pituitary production of FSH and LH) several years after delivery in individuals with no prior history of postpartum hypopituitarism. However, it would not explain the sudden severe headache in this patient. Moreover, patients typically have a history of acute hypotension during pregnancy or delivery severe enough to cause pituitary ischemia and necrosis.

Migraine headaches can manifest with recurrent, severe, throbbing headaches. Visual auras of migraines typically involve flashes of light and blind spots; basilar migraines can cause double vision. However, a migraine would not explain this patient's amenorrhea or hypotension.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) manifests with sudden, severe headache (thunderclap headache) and hypotension that can be associated with visual disturbances. Spontaneous SAH occurs due to rupture of a previously asymptomatic berry aneurysm. In some cases, migraines and berry aneurysms may coexist. Additionally, the mass effect of an aneurysm in the anterior communicating artery can cause bitemporal hemianopia. However, neither SAH nor berry aneurysms would explain this patient's history of amenorrhea.

Cluster headaches typically manifest with 15-minute bouts of intense unilateral headaches that may occur several times a day with months of pain-free intervals. Although cluster headaches can present with periorbital pain and lacrimation, this condition would not explain the visual disturbances, hypotension, or menstrual abnormalities seen in this patient.

question_text: A 44-year-old woman with recurrent urinary tract infections is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after sudden onset of severe headache 30 minutes ago. She has a history of occasional, mild headaches in the morning. There is no other history of serious illness. Both her father and her paternal grandmother died of chronic kidney disease. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.1°F) and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows neck stiffness. When her hip is flexed, she is unable to fully extend her knee because of pain. Lumbar puncture performed 12 hours after headache onset yields 10 mL of yellow-colored fluid with no leukocytes. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 44-year-old woman with recurrent urinary tract infections is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after sudden onset of severe headache 30 minutes ago. She has a history of occasional, mild headaches in the morning. There is no other history of serious illness. Both her father and her paternal grandmother died of chronic kidney disease. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.1°F) and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows neck stiffness. When her hip is flexed, she is unable to fully extend her knee because of pain. Lumbar puncture performed 12 hours after headache onset yields 10 mL of yellow-colored fluid with no leukocytes. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's current condition?
hint: Signs of arterial hypertension (e.g., morning headaches), frequent UTIs, and a family history of renal failure should raise concern for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), whereas a positive Kernig sign indicates meningeal or nerve root irritation.
learning_objective: Recognize autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: While chronic kidney disease (e.g., polycystic kidney disease) increases the risk of atherosclerosis, which in turn is a risk factor for ischemic stroke, this patient does not have focal neurologic findings suggestive of a stroke. Ischemic stroke typically manifests with sudden painless neurological impairments that may be accompanied by a mild headache, unlike this patient who presented with a sudden severe headache. A sudden-onset severe headache indicates subarachnoid hemorrhage, which can cause hemorrhagic stroke instead of ischemic stroke.

While this patient has meningismus, she does not have a fever or leukocytes on CSF suggestive of meningitis. She is also not in a high-risk group for contracting meningitis (unvaccinated, college age and living in close quarters, or immunocompromised). In addition, there is no association between polycystic kidney disease and meningitis.

While a hypercoagulable state can increase the risk of a thromboembolic stroke, this patient does not have focal neurologic findings suggestive of a stroke. Ischemic stroke typically presents with sudden painless neurological impairments that may be accompanied by a mild headache, unlike this patient who presented with a sudden severe headache. A sudden-onset severe headache indicates subarachnoid hemorrhage, which can cause hemorrhagic stroke instead of ischemic stroke. In addition, polycystic kidney disease does not increase the risk of hypercoagulability.

Cerebral atrophy increases the risk of a subdural hemorrhage (SDH), which can manifest with worsening headache. This patient, however, has no risk factors for cerebral atrophy (advanced age, dementia, preceding trauma), and there is no link between polycystic kidney disease and cerebral atrophy or SDH. Moreover, SDH usually does not have a sudden onset. Instead, it tends to manifest with headache and confusion over hours to weeks that is possibly accompanied by impaired consciousness and focal neurological deficit.

Patients with ADPKD have an increased risk of developing saccular aneurysms. This patient presented with symptoms of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) resulting from the rupture of one of these aneurysms. The sudden onset of a severe headache (patients typically report having the worst headache of their life) should raise suspicion for SAH. Other signs of SAH include fever, xanthochromia (yellow-colored CSF), and meningismus (neck stiffness and Kernig sign) caused by irritation of the meninges by blood.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: A nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage is most commonly caused by the rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

question_text: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 6-hour history of severe headache, nausea, and 1 episode of vomiting. On arrival, she is lethargic and oriented only to self. Her pulse is 50/min, respirations are 8/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 150/96 mm Hg. Examination shows medial deviation of the left globe and ecchymoses of the upper eyelids. Appropriate pharmacotherapy with an intravenous drug is initiated, and the patient's urine output subsequently increases. The patient is at greatest risk of which of the following adverse effects?
content_preview: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 6-hour history of severe headache, nausea, and 1 episode of vomiting. On arrival, she is lethargic and oriented only to self. Her pulse is 50/min, respirations are 8/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 150/96 mm Hg. Examination shows medial deviation of the left globe and ecchymoses of the upper eyelids. Appropriate pharmacotherapy with an intravenous drug is initiated, and the patient's urine output subsequently increases. The patient is at greatest risk of which of the following adverse effects?
hint: The patient presents with nausea, vomiting, headache, and a decreased level of consciousness. Examination shows the Cushing triad (bradycardia, respiratory depression, and hypertension), cranial nerve VI palsy, and spontaneous bruising of the upper eyelids. These are classic features of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), which can be treated with mannitol, an osmotic diuretic.
learning_objective: Recognize elevated intracranial pressure, and recall the adverse effects of its pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Mannitol causes an increase in plasma osmolality, resulting in osmotic shifts of water into the intravascular space. This effect decreases cerebral edema but can lead to iatrogenic volume overload and pulmonary edema. Risk factors for this side effect of mannitol include very high doses and a low glomerular filtration rate.

Mannitol infusions tend to decrease intraocular pressure by reducing the volume of vitreous humor, which is why they are used for treating acute angle closure glaucoma. Since increased intraocular pressure is a potential side effect of corticosteroids, they are not recommended in cases of elevated intracranial pressure.

Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (DRESS) is associated with sulfa drugs, which includes diuretics such as furosemide, acetazolamide, and hydrochlorothiazide. Furosemide can be used as an adjunct in cases of acutely increased intracranial pressure but it is not the first-line drug. Acetazolamide is used to treat glaucoma and idiopathic intracranial hypertension but is not indicated for acutely increased intracranial pressure. Thiazide diuretics are not indicated for the treatment of elevated intracranial pressure.

Tinnitus is a potential side effect of acetazolamide or furosemide but is not a side effect of mannitol. Furosemide can be used as an adjunct in cases of acutely increased intracranial pressure but it is not the first-line drug. Acetazolamide is used to treat glaucoma and idiopathic intracranial hypertension but is not indicated for acutely increased intracranial pressure.
Hyperuricemia can arise following treatment with hydrochlorothiazide but is not associated with mannitol. Thiazide diuretics are not indicated for the treatment of elevated intracranial pressure.

question_text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for decreased vision and worsening headaches since this morning. She has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Pulse is 119/min and irregular. Current medications include ramipril and atorvastatin. Ocular and funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. The findings of visual field testing are shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for decreased vision and worsening headaches since this morning. She has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Pulse is 119/min and irregular. Current medications include ramipril and atorvastatin. Ocular and funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. The findings of visual field testing are shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Visual field testing shows the inability to see the right visual field in either eye (right homonymous hemianopia) with macular sparing, which most commonly results from decreased blood flow to the left occipital lobe.
learning_objective: Recognize occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery.

answers.explanation_why: Degeneration of the macula can be observed in age-related macular degeneration (AMD), which is subdivided into dry and wet AMD types and causes a gradual loss of central vision and metamorphopsia in the affected eyes, unlike what is seen in this patient.

Impaired perfusion of the retina has been observed in central retinal artery occlusion, which is caused by cardiac emboli in young patients and carotid atherosclerosis in old patients. It presents with an acute painless visual loss in the affected eye; it is usually unilateral and does not spare the macula, unlike in this patient.

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.content: Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery, usually due to emboli from the vertebral vessels, aorta, or heart, results in contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. The macula is spared because the macular tracts have additional blood supply from the middle cerebral arteries.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.content: Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral pontine syndrome. It manifests with vomiting, vertigo, nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia, Horner syndrome, facial muscle paralysis (lower motor neuron lesion type), and sensorineural hearing loss as well as contralateral hemisensory loss, none of which is seen in this patient.

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is the most commonly occluded artery in ischemic strokes. Embolic occlusion of the MCA can occasionally lead to the development of contralateral homonymous hemianopia. However, owing to the extensive area of the brain that the MCA supplies, the other signs of stroke, such as contralateral limb weakness and sensory loss, would also be present. Isolated visual field defects are highly unlikely to occur in MCA embolism.
answers.explanation_but: The contralateral homonymous hemianopia in MCA occlusion rarely exhibits macular sparing. This is because the MCA supplies an extensive area of the brain and, thus, occlusion of the MCA affects not only the occipital visual cortex but also the visual pathways.

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery does not affect the visual cortex but causes contralateral limb weakness and sensory loss affecting the lower limb more prominently than the upper limb. Primitive reflexes, like grasp reflexes and rooting reflexes, are also likely to re-emerge. This patient has none of these symptoms.

images.title: Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
images.description: Visual field test (perimetry)There is a bilateral loss of right lateral visual fields (black areas) with sparing of the macula (hatched overlay). Bilateral impairment of a unilateral visual field in each eye is known as homonymous hemianopia.

question_text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 2-week history of progressive disorientation and a 1-day history of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The wife reports that the patient had a minor fall 4 months ago, during which he may have hit his head. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He drinks 3–4 bottles of beer daily. He is only oriented to person. Neurological examination shows moderate spastic weakness, decreased sensation, and increased deep tendon reflexes in the left upper and lower extremities. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 2-week history of progressive disorientation and a 1-day history of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The wife reports that the patient had a minor fall 4 months ago, during which he may have hit his head. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He drinks 3–4 bottles of beer daily. He is only oriented to person. Neurological examination shows moderate spastic weakness, decreased sensation, and increased deep tendon reflexes in the left upper and lower extremities. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped, concave hemorrhage that crosses suture lines but not the midline. This finding is characteristic of a subdural hematoma (SDH).
learning_objective: Recognize chronic subdural hematoma due to tearing of bridging veins.

answers.explanation_why: Damage to the lenticulostriate arteries is most often a consequence of hypertension (Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm), cerebral amyloid angiopathy, or vasculitis. Patients typically present with severe headache, focal neurologic deficits, and loss of consciousness. The onset is acute and progresses rapidly. CT imaging would show a solitary hyperdense lesion, surrounded by hypodense edema within the cerebral parenchyma.

images.title: Basal ganglia hemorrhage
images.description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of chronic hypertensionHyperdense hemorrhage in the left basal ganglia is surrounded by hypodense perifocal edema (red overlay).The location is typical for hemorrhage from the lenticulostriate arteries as a result of long-standing hypertension.1: head of caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3 and green overlay: internal capsule; 4: thalamus
Arrowheads: calcified pineal gland; white circles: calcified choroid plexus

answers.explanation_why: Injury to the middle meningeal artery can lead to an epidural hemorrhage. The typical presentation of this injury is head trauma followed by normal sensorium (lucid interval) before onset of symptoms of increased intracranial pressure. CT scan would show a characteristic lentiform hemorrhagic collection (hemorrhage limited by suture lines).

images.title: Epidural and subdural hematomas
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (brain window: axial and coronal planes; bone window: axial plane)A biconvex epidural hematoma (green overlay) with mass effect is seen in the left frontal region, adjacent to which is a small frontotemporal subdural hematoma (red overlay). A calvarial fracture (arrowheads) involves the left temporal and parietal bones.

answers.explanation_why: Saccular aneurysm rupture leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage, which characteristically causes severe, abrupt-onset headaches (thunderclap headaches) that may be associated with vomiting, neck pain, and decreased levels of consciousness. While this patient has decreased levels of consciousness, he does not have any of the other characteristic symptoms, nor does his CT scan show blood in the subarachnoid space, as would be expected.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Regions of high attenuation (green overlay) in the interpeduncular cistern, Sylvian fissures, and left posterior fossa represent acute subarachnoid hemorrhage. The cerebellar tentorium (red overlay) should not be misinterpreted as blood.

answers.explanation_why: Embolus to the middle cerebral artery would cause an ischemic stroke. Most commonly, embolism results in acute-onset neurological defects as opposed to the subacute progression of this patient's symptoms. CT scans can present with a hyperdense MCA sign but are usually unremarkable for up to 24 hours after an ischemic stroke. MRI is the preferred modality for imaging acute ischemic stroke.

images.title: Acute ischemic stroke with hyperdense middle cerebral artery sign
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

answers.explanation_why:
SDH is caused by a rupture of the bridging veins, which cross the subdural space. This patient's history of minor head trauma followed by an insidious onset of disorientation is consistent with chronic SDH. The main risk factor for the development of this condition is diffuse cerebral atrophy associated with aging and/or chronic alcohol use. The new-onset unilateral neurological symptoms (spastic paresis, hyperreflexia, decreased sensation) are likely due to rebleeding.

See “Overview of intracranial hemorrhage” table.

images.title: Subdural hematoma: Etiology
images.description: Rupture of a bridging vein results in hemorrhage into the subdural space between the dura and arachnoid mater. Bleeding into the subdural space results in a crescent-shaped hematoma (right) that can cross suture lines but not the midline.

answers.explanation_why: Intraventricular vascular malformations are a common cause of intraventricular hemorrhage. Like other intracranial bleeding events, the characteristic presentation includes sudden onset of headache, vomiting, and altered level of consciousness. Seizures are common but focal neurological findings are not. CT imaging would show blood within the ventricular system.

images.title: Acute-on-chronic subdural hematoma
images.description: CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window)A crescent-shaped, heterogeneous lesion that crosses cranial sutures is visible on the anterolateral aspect of the right hemisphere. The anterior aspect of the lesion is hypodense (green overlay) indicating a chronic hematoma (serum extrusion and degradation of the clot decreases its radiodensity). The posterior aspect of the lesion is isodense to hyperdense (red overlay), indicating a recent hemorrhage into the existing hematoma (recent blood clots contain concentrated hemoglobin, which is hyperdense). Mass effect is visualized as a shift in the midline (white line) to the left (dashed white line), compression of the left lateral ventricle, and compression of the adjacent cerebral parenchyma, which appears edematous (hyperdense with loss of the sulci and gyri).These features are characteristic of an acute-on-chronic subdural hematoma.

question_text: A 76-year-old woman with hypertension and coronary artery disease is brought to the emergency department after the sudden onset of right-sided weakness. Her pulse is 83/min and blood pressure is 156/90 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows right-sided lower facial drooping and complete paralysis of the right upper and lower extremities. Tongue position is normal and she is able to swallow liquids without difficulty. Sensation to vibration, pain, position, and light touch is normal bilaterally. She is oriented to person, place, and time, and is able to speak normally. Occlusion of which of the following vessels is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
content_preview: A 76-year-old woman with hypertension and coronary artery disease is brought to the emergency department after the sudden onset of right-sided weakness. Her pulse is 83/min and blood pressure is 156/90 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows right-sided lower facial drooping and complete paralysis of the right upper and lower extremities. Tongue position is normal and she is able to swallow liquids without difficulty. Sensation to vibration, pain, position, and light touch is normal bilaterally. She is oriented to person, place, and time, and is able to speak normally. Occlusion of which of the following vessels is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
hint: This patient has features of a pure motor stroke without any sensory deficits or cortical signs (e.g., aphasia, agnosia, apraxia). The lesion is most likely located in the posterior limb of the internal capsule.
learning_objective: Recognize a pure motor stroke, and recall the affected cerebral artery.

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) would cause motor deficits. However, the motor deficit would predominantly affect the lower extremity and sensory deficits in the lower extremity would also be expected. The upper extremity is usually spared or only mildly affected and the face would be spared. Moreover, an ipsilateral (right) ACA infarct would produce deficits on the contralateral (left) side.

The anterior spinal artery (ASA) and vertebral artery supply the medial regions of the lower medulla. Occlusion of the ASA at the level of the brainstem can therefore damage the corticospinal tract and cause motor deficits. However, facial palsy would not be expected since this facial nerve nucleus arises in the lateral region of the upper medulla. Moreover, patients would also have impaired pain and proprioception (due to damage to the medial lemniscus) and features of hypoglossal nerve palsy (e.g., inability to protrude the tongue, tongue deviation).

Occlusion of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) causes contralateral motor deficits similar to the ones seen in this patient. However, occlusion of the entire MCA would cause additional symptoms, such as sensory changes, gaze deviation, and aphasia (dominant hemisphere) or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere). In this patient, only a branch of the MCA is affected.

Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes Wallenberg syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome), which is characterized by ipsilateral Horner syndrome, ipsilateral cerebellar signs (e.g., hemiataxia), impaired pain and temperature sensation in the contralateral body and ipsilateral face, and features of ipsilateral cranial nerve IX, X, and XI palsy (e.g., dysphagia, dysphonia). This patient with pure motor deficits in one half of the body would not have Wallenberg syndrome.

A pure motor stroke is caused by infarction in the posterior limb of the internal capsule, which contains the corticospinal and corticobulbar fibers that innervate the motor nuclei on the contralateral side. Therefore, a lesion at this site can cause contralateral hemiplegia as well as weakness in the lower half of the face because the region of the facial nerve nucleus that supplies the lower half of the face only receives unilateral corticobulbar innervation. Other cranial nerve nuclei as well as the region of the facial nerve nucleus that innervates the forehead receive bilateral corticobulbar innervation and are therefore spared. The most common cause of stroke in this region is a lacunar stroke of the lenticulostriate artery (a branch of the middle cerebral artery).

Since the internal capsule also contains somatosensory fibers, some patients with lacunar stroke in the internal capsule may present with sensory loss in addition to hemiparesis. This form of lacunar stroke is referred to as sensorimotor stroke and may be confused with middle cerebral artery stroke.

images.title: Pyramidal tract
images.description: Fibers of the pyramidal tract originate from the primary motor cortex and descend to the brain stem via the internal capsule. Bulbar corticonuclear fibers extend to each of the cranial nerve nuclei, which innervate the facial muscles. The remaining fibers descend from the brainstem as two divisions of the corticospinal tract. Approximately 80% of these fibers decussate at the level of the medulla (pyramidal decussation) to the contralateral side to form the lateral corticospinal tract. They then descend into the spinal cord to innervate the limbs and digits. The remaining approximately 20% of fibers descend from the brainstem ipsilaterally, forming the anterior corticospinal tract. These decussate at the spinal level of the trunk muscles they innervate.

question_text: A 41-year-old woman with subclinical hypothyroidism comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressively worsening headaches, loss of peripheral vision, and irregular menses. Her menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals with moderate flow, but her last menstrual period was 12 weeks ago. She also reports that her interest in sexual intercourse has recently decreased. Her serum prolactin level is elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
content_preview: A 41-year-old woman with subclinical hypothyroidism comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressively worsening headaches, loss of peripheral vision, and irregular menses. Her menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals with moderate flow, but her last menstrual period was 12 weeks ago. She also reports that her interest in sexual intercourse has recently decreased. Her serum prolactin level is elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
hint: This patient presents with decreased libido, secondary amenorrhea, loss of vision, and hyperprolactinemia. Her headaches suggest a prolactinoma as the etiology.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features of a prolactinoma, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Dopamine agonists like bromocriptine or cabergoline are the preferred pharmacotherapy for prolactinomas. These drugs act by increasing tonic dopamine signaling to inhibit lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary. This suppresses prolactin secretion and induces tumor shrinkage. Treatment for prolactinoma is indicated in cases such as this one, when the patient is symptomatic (e.g., headache, visual change, hypogonadism) or if the clinician believes that symptoms are imminent.

images.title: Pituitary mass 2/2
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactinA large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: Estrogen replacement (HRT) can reduce the symptoms associated with menopause (e.g., irregular menses, worsening headaches, decreased libido). While this patient does have these symptoms, menopause would not explain her elevated serum prolactin, and estrogen is not an appropriate treatment for a prolactinoma or hyperprolactinemia.

Methyldopa is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist and DOPA decarboxylase antagonist, which treats hypertension by decreasing sympathetic outflow to the heart, kidneys, and peripheral vasculature as well as decreasing the production of catecholamines (e.g., dopamine, epinephrine, and norepinephrine). Dopamine normally inhibits prolactin production; therefore, methyldopa-induced suppression of dopamine production would further elevate serum prolactin levels and exacerbate the symptoms seen in this patient.

Metoclopramide is both a dopamine receptor and serotonin receptor antagonist that is used as an antiemetic and to treat gastroparesis and migraines. Although migraines can be associated with hormonal changes and this patient has irregular menses, her progressively worsening headaches more likely result from increased ICP caused by her prolactinoma. Prolactinoma would not be treated by metoclopramide. Moreover, because dopamine ordinarily inhibits prolactin secretion, administering metoclopramide (a dopamine receptor antagonist) would worsen this patient's hyperprolactinemia.

This patient's subclinical hypothyroidism could progress to a manifest hypothyroidism with decreased thyroxine feedback to inhibit the hypothalamic production of TRH. TRH stimulates the secretion of TSH and prolactin. TRH-induced hyperprolactinemia can manifest as secondary amenorrhea, which is seen in this patient. However, clinical hypothyroidism would manifest with other symptoms (e.g., cold intolerance, weight gain, decreased DTR) that are not seen here.

question_text: A 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for a severe, sudden-onset headache, light-sensitivity, and neck stiffness that began 30 minutes ago. A CT scan of the head shows hyperdensity between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater. The patient undergoes an endovascular procedure. One week later, she falls as she is returning from the bathroom. Neurologic examination shows 3/5 strength in the right lower extremity and 5/5 in the left lower extremity. Treatment with which of the following drugs is most likely to have prevented the patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for a severe, sudden-onset headache, light-sensitivity, and neck stiffness that began 30 minutes ago. A CT scan of the head shows hyperdensity between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater. The patient undergoes an endovascular procedure. One week later, she falls as she is returning from the bathroom. Neurologic examination shows 3/5 strength in the right lower extremity and 5/5 in the left lower extremity. Treatment with which of the following drugs is most likely to have prevented the patient's current condition?
hint: This patient has signs of acute cerebral ischemia (new-onset unilateral lower extremity weakness) 7 days after a subarachnoid hemorrhage. Blood in the subarachnoid space leads to the release of vasoactive substances; this can bring about vasospasm in nonbleeding vessels that manifests with focal neurologic deficits.
learning_objective: Recognize complications of subarachnoid hemorrhage, and choose the appropriate prophylactic medication.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous enalapril is used in the initial management of hypertension in subarachnoid hemorrhage because of its rapid onset of action. Five days after initial presentation, this patient's hemorrhage is no longer acute. Enalapril may also be indicated in cases of rebleeding with a systolic blood pressure > 160 mm Hg, but it is not used for prophylaxis of vasospasm.

Oral nimodipine should be given after subarachnoid hemorrhage to prevent vasospasm, which can lead to ischemic stroke. This patient's sudden-onset neurologic deficit 7 days after SAH is a common presentation of vasospasm, which is a complication in ∼ 30% of SAH cases and is more common with aneurysms. Nimodipine has been shown to reduce morbidity and mortality associated with SAH, but the exact mechanism of benefit of nimodipine is unknown.

This patient should be evaluated with CT and angiography in order to distinguish a potential vasospasm from rebleeding and should receive prompt treatment to prevent ischemic stroke.

Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is used for the treatment of severe coagulopathy (e.g., caused by warfarin overdose complicated by intracranial hemorrhage). This patient has no underlying conditions that would cause coagulopathy (such as liver failure) and does not take warfarin. FFP is not used for prophylaxis of vasospasm after SAH.

Antiplatelet therapy is for secondary prevention of ischemic stroke. Given the onset of this patient's ischemic symptoms (7 days after SAH), they are more likely to be due to vasospasm than to an ischemic event caused by thrombosis. Antiplatelet therapy is not used for prophylaxis of vasospasm after SAH.

Fosphenytoin is used to treat and prevent seizures. While focal weakness may manifest after a seizure (Todd palsy), this patient has not had jerking movements or mental status changes that are characteristic of seizure activity. Seizure prophylaxis is not typically indicated for subarachnoid hemorrhage because it may be associated with worse neurologic outcomes. It may be appropriate in select cases when there is associated intracerebral bleeding, unsecured aneurysm, or concurrent intracranial pathology.

Blood pressure control is an important component of initial therapy for subarachnoid hemorrhage and rebleeding. However, nitrates such as nitroglycerin should be avoided because of their potential to raise intracranial pressure. Moreover, nitrates are not used for prophylaxis of vasospasm after SAH.

question_text: A 65-year-old woman with osteoarthritis comes to the physician because of severe lower back and left leg pain. She has chronic lower back pain that is usually well-controlled with ibuprofen, but 3 hours ago her back pain acutely worsened after she picked up her 3-year-old granddaughter. The pain radiates from her lower back over her left outer thigh and knee towards the top of her big toe. Physical examination shows a diminished posterior tibial reflex on the left side. Muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities and there are no sensory deficits. Steroid injection into which of the following anatomical locations is most likely to relieve her symptoms?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman with osteoarthritis comes to the physician because of severe lower back and left leg pain. She has chronic lower back pain that is usually well-controlled with ibuprofen, but 3 hours ago her back pain acutely worsened after she picked up her 3-year-old granddaughter. The pain radiates from her lower back over her left outer thigh and knee towards the top of her big toe. Physical examination shows a diminished posterior tibial reflex on the left side. Muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities and there are no sensory deficits. Steroid injection into which of the following anatomical locations is most likely to relieve her symptoms?
hint: Acute worsening of back pain in a 65-year-old woman after lifting something should raise suspicion for lateral disk herniation. The radiation of her pain to the lateral left leg suggests radiculopathy due to compression of the L5 nerve root.
learning_objective: Recognize lateral disk herniation, and recall the site for steroid injection to relieve radiculopathy.

answers.explanation_why: Facet joint osteoarthritis is a common cause of lower back pain in older individuals. While this patient does have chronic lower back pain that is well-controlled with NSAIDs, pain that radiates down the lower extremity suggests a disk herniation rather than facet joint osteoarthritis as the acute cause of her symptoms. Injection of steroids around the facet joints may temporarily alleviate her chronic pain, but it would not address the cause of her acute symptoms.

Disk herniation occurs when a tear in the tough outer part of the disk (annulus fibrosus) allows the gelatinous inner substance of the disk (nucleus pulposus) to protrude and compress nearby nerve roots. Surgical removal of the intervertebral disk may be considered in severe cases; however, a steroid injection into the disk would not improve her current symptoms of nerve root compression.

The subdural space is a potential cavity located between the arachnoid mater and the dura mater. This space does not exist under physiological circumstances because the arachnoid mater and dura mater of the spine are attached to each other.
answers.explanation_but: Unlike in the spine, cranial arachnoid mater does not closely adhere to the dura mater, which is why the formation of a subdural space can occur in the brain (e.g., due to hemorrhage from ruptured bridging veins).

answers.explanation_why: The subarachnoid space between lumbar vertebrae L3 and L5 is the target for analgesic medications in spinal anesthesia. It is commonly used in surgical settings in which general anesthesia is not necessary and causes complete loss of motor and sensory function below the level of injection. Steroid injection into the subarachnoid space would not be an appropriate treatment for this patient with disk herniation.

Disk herniation can cause nerve root compression, as the nerve root exits the central nervous system through the intervertebral foramen. Steroid injection at the intervertebral foramen helps reduce inflammation and edema around the nerve root and spinal cord and can relieve nerve root compression and alleviate symptoms of disk herniation.

question_text: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an excruciating headache that started 30 minutes ago. The pain is located around the right eye and it awoke him from sleep. Over the past two weeks, he has had similar headaches around the same time of the day, and he reports pacing around restlessly during these episodes. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and tearing of the right eye. In addition to supplemental oxygen therapy, administration of which of the following drugs is most likely to provide acute relief in this patient?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an excruciating headache that started 30 minutes ago. The pain is located around the right eye and it awoke him from sleep. Over the past two weeks, he has had similar headaches around the same time of the day, and he reports pacing around restlessly during these episodes. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and tearing of the right eye. In addition to supplemental oxygen therapy, administration of which of the following drugs is most likely to provide acute relief in this patient?
hint: This young man has recurrent attacks of severe unilateral headache that are associated with ipsilateral cranial autonomic symptoms (conjunctival injection, lacrimation), which is indicative of cluster headache.
learning_objective: Recognize cluster headache, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for acute relief.

answers.explanation_why: Indomethacin is highly effective in preventing attacks of paroxysmal hemicrania (PH), a rare form of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia, but not very effective as an abortive therapy in acute cases. While PH may present very similarly, the attacks are usually more frequent (≥ 5 per day) and often shorter. In cluster headache, NSAIDs like indomethacin are generally not recommended because their onset of action is too slow.

Triptans like sumatriptan are the first-line pharmacological treatment for acute attacks of cluster headache. They abort the headache and provide resolution of the conjunctival injection associated with these attacks. The exact mechanism is unclear, but it is thought to involve the vasoconstriction of cranial blood vessels in response to stimulation of 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) receptors. Inhalation of 100% oxygen is also effective in terminating acute episodes of cluster headache and has a rapid onset of action.

Triptans are also the treatment of choice for severe migraine attacks.

NSAIDs like ibuprofen can be used for pain relief in, e.g. mild to moderate migraine attacks or acute tension-type headaches (TTH). While the pain associated with TTH is usually holocephalic or bifrontal, and cranial autonomic symptoms, as seen in this patient, do not occur; migraine is characterized by episodes of typically unilateral headache lasting 4–72 hours accompanied or preceded by nausea, phono- and photophobia, and/or aura, which are absent in this patient. Furthermore, while patients with migraine tend to rest motionlessly in a quiet, dark room, this patient prefers to pace around during the episodes of pain.

Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia. While trigeminal neuralgia can present with unilateral facial pain that occurs in repetitive attacks, unlike in this patient, these attacks usually only last a few seconds and are characterized by shooting or stabbing pain (like an electric shock) from mouth to the angle of the jaw on the affected side. Frontal headache, conjunctival injection, rhinorrhea, and lacrimation are not features of trigeminal neuralgia.

images.title: Trigeminal neuralgia
images.description: Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. Classical trigeminal neuralgia is caused by neurovascular compression, most often by an aberrant loop of a neighboring artery (usually the superior cerebellar artery). The pain is typically very severe in intensity, has a sharp, stabbing quality, and lasts several seconds. Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by stimuli such as brushing teeth.

answers.explanation_why: Amitriptyline is used to prevent chronic tension-type headaches and migraine attacks. Amitriptyline is not used, however, to acutely treat any type of headache.

High-dose steroid therapy is the treatment of choice for giant cell arteritis (GCA), which can present with severe unilateral headache, as seen in this patient. However, autonomic symptoms do not occur, and symptoms such as jaw claudication and scalp tenderness, which are not seen in this patient, are usually present. More importantly, GCA usually occurs in elderly individuals (peak incidence: 70–79 years) and is rare in patients younger than 50.
answers.explanation_but: Prednisone can be used as a preventive treatment for cluster headache; however, this patient with an acute presentation needs an abortive therapy.

images.title: Pain localization in secondary headache
images.description:
Certain pain characteristics and associated symptoms can help in the diagnosis of a secondary headache:– Temporal arteritis: unilateral headache, jaw claudication, tenderness of scalp or temporal artery, constitutional symptoms, visual changes
– Hypertensive crisis: diffuse, often bifrontal, headache (Headache in the setting of hypertensive crisis can be an isolated finding but may also be a manifestation of hypertensive encephalopathy, which constitutes a hypertensive emergency)
– Sinusitis: Facial pain or pressure in the sinus cavity region, purulent rhinorrhea, flu-like symptoms
– Medication overuse headache: diffuse headache that can change in type and location within an episode and has developed or worsened with pain medication overuse

answers.explanation_why: Oxycodone is an orally administered opiate analgesic that is used to treat chronic and/or severe pain that cannot be managed with NSAIDs. Opiate analgesics should not, however, be used in the management of primary headache disorders because of the risk of opiate dependence.
