question_text: Four days after delivery, a 1400-g (3-lb 1-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 30 seconds. Over the past 24 hours, he has become increasingly lethargic. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 4 and 5 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He appears ill. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 53/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 67/35 mm Hg. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
content_preview: Four days after delivery, a 1400-g (3-lb 1-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 30 seconds. Over the past 24 hours, he has become increasingly lethargic. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 4 and 5 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He appears ill. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 53/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 67/35 mm Hg. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
hint: The condition described here is a serious complication of preterm birth.
learning_objective: Recognize germinal matrix hemorrhage in preterm infants.

answers.explanation_why: Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase deficiency is the underlying cause of galactosemia, which, if left untreated, may present with lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures, as seen here. However, the absence of cataracts (may present within the first days of life), jaundice, and hepatomegaly, make this diagnosis less likely.
answers.explanation_but: Galactosemia can cause coagulopathy and increased risk of bleeding, which may predispose children to the condition of this patient.

answers.explanation_why: Apoptosis of lower motor neurons is the underlying mechanism of spinal muscular atrophy, which is a possible cause of muscular hypotonia in infants. The most severe type (Werdnig-Hoffmann disease) may manifest immediately after birth or up to 6 months of age. Proximal muscles, mostly of the lower extremities, are usually involved symmetrically. However, this patient's seizures, bulging anterior fontanelle, impaired pupillary response, and roving eye movements would not be consistent with this diagnosis.

Hydrocephalus due to congenital causes, such as the Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker malformation, and intrauterine infections, may present in neonates with lethargy, tense fontanelles, seizures, and changes in vital signs due to brain stem compression (e.g., irregular breathing). However, elevated intracranial pressure usually manifests with rapidly increasing circumference of the head in neonates, which is not seen in this infant. Furthermore, instead of the roving eye movements, a downward deviation of the eyes (sunset eye sign) would be expected in patients with hydrocephalus.

images.title: Manifestations of increased intracranial pressure in infants

answers.explanation_why: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency is the underlying cause of phenylketonuria. While most patients are asymptomatic at birth, half of patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) have seizures with cerebral foci, a lag of psychomotor development and a musty body odor by 4–6 months of age. Additional features include light, pale hair and blue eyes (due to decreased melanin production). Since most patients are asymptomatic until severe and often irreversible complications have occurred, direct measurement of phenylalanine levels is an important part of newborn screening for metabolic disorders. The screening test is performed on the second day after birth using blood obtained from a heel prick.

Germinal matrix hemorrhage is the underlying cause of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) in preterm infants. IVH is a common complication in preterm infants that usually occurs within the first five days after birth. It is typically seen in neonates weighing < 1500 g and born before 32 weeks' gestation due to the fragility of the germinal matrix. Additional risk factors include peripartal chorioamnionitis and hypoxia (as suggested by this patient's low Apgar scores). Most infants with IVH are asymptomatic, but saltatory (over several days) or, more rarely, catastrophic (over minutes to hours) courses are also possible. Symptoms include lethargy, hypotonia, irregular respirations, seizures, bulging anterior fontanelle, cranial nerve abnormalities (e.g., pupil reacting sluggishly to light), and changes in eye movement (e.g., roving eye movements), all of which this patient has.

Cranial ultrasonography is the preferred method to diagnose IVH in the newborn. Since most patients are asymptomatic, screening ultrasounds are routinely performed in infants with a birth weight < 1500 g and delivery before 30 weeks' gestation.

images.title: Neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)
images.description:
Ultrasound head (top row: coronal plane; bottom row: parasagittal plane) of a newbornThe first column shows bleeding confined to the subependymal germinal matrix (red overlay), which is consistent with grade 1 IVH.
The second column shows blood occupying less than 50% of the left lateral ventricle (red overlay), with no enlargement of the lateral ventricles (yellow overlay) or the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay). In addition, the choroid plexus is clearly demarcated (blue overlay). Together, these findings are consistent with grade 2 IVH.
The third column shows blood occupying more than 50% of the lateral ventricles (red overlay) with enlargement of the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay) and both lateral ventricles (yellow overlay). This appearance is consistent with grade 3 IVH.These features suggest impaired progressive posthemorrhagic ventricular dilatation (PHVD) due to associated impairment of CSF circulation, which is a potential complication of high-grade IVH.

question_text: A 58-year-old woman with HIV infection is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of headaches, blurred vision, and confusion. Her current medications include antiretroviral therapy and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Neurological examination shows ataxia and memory impairment. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/mm^3. Analysis of her cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows lymphocytic predominant pleocytosis, and PCR is positive for Epstein-Barr virus DNA. An MRI of the brain with contrast shows a solitary, weakly ring-enhancing lesion with well-defined borders involving the corpus callosum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 58-year-old woman with HIV infection is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of headaches, blurred vision, and confusion. Her current medications include antiretroviral therapy and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Neurological examination shows ataxia and memory impairment. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/mm3. Analysis of her cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows lymphocytic predominant pleocytosis, and PCR is positive for Epstein-Barr virus DNA. An MRI of the brain with contrast shows a solitary, weakly ring-enhancing lesion with well-defined borders involving the corpus callosum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient with HIV and a low CD4 count presents with neurological impairment (ataxia, confusion, memory dysfunction). The likely diagnosis can be inferred from her MRI findings (a solitary ring-enhancing lesion) and CSF analysis result (EBV DNA in the CSF).
learning_objective: Recognize primary cerebral lymphoma in HIV patients.

answers.explanation_why: AIDS dementia refers to the clinical syndrome of cognitive deficits that frequently affects AIDS patients, which ranges from minor memory impairment to severe neurologic deficits. Although this patient's symptoms could potentially correspond to AIDS dementia, her MRI does not show the cerebral atrophy that would confirm such a diagnosis but rather shows a solitary ring-enhancing lesion consistent with another condition.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is often asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. Reactivation of T. gondii usually occurs in the CNS of immunocompromised patients, resulting in toxoplasmic encephalitis (which presents with fever, headache, impaired vigilance, seizures, and focal neurological deficits) and multiple ring-enhancing cerebral lesions on imaging. For this reason, HIV patients with a CD4 count < 100/mm^3 are typically started on toxoplasmosis prophylaxis with TMP-SMX to reduce the chance of reactivation, as is the case in this patient. This patient's solitary cerebral lesion, the CSF analysis result (positive for EBV DNA), and prophylaxis history make toxoplasmosis less likely.

Primary cerebral lymphoma is a non-Hodgkin lymphoma with a much higher incidence in HIV/AIDS patients than in the general population. It has a strong association with EBV infection and is derived from B cells. The condition can present with focal neurological deficits, neuropsychiatric symptoms, signs of elevated intracranial pressure, and/or seizures. It also results in solitary ring-enhancing cerebral lesions on imaging. If findings on CSF are inconclusive, pathologic examination of a brain biopsy specimen is indicated to confirm the diagnosis prior to starting treatment with chemotherapy and/or radiation.

PML is a demyelinating disease of the CNS. It is an AIDS-defining condition and is caused by reactivation of the JC virus. It does not cause ring-enhancing cerebral lesions on imaging, as seen in this patient, but rather disseminated non-enhancing lesions. Furthermore, CSF analysis in PML shows JC virus DNA on PCR, but the CSF findings in this patient only include EBV DNA.

Although bacterial abscesses can cause ring-enhancing lesions in patients with HIV/AIDS, they are not the most common cause of ring-enhancing lesions and are not associated with EBV in the CSF. Furthermore, bacterial brain abscess would present with neutrophilic pleocytosis on CSF rather than the lymphocytic pleocytosis seen here.

Glioblastoma multiforme is the most common primary malignant brain tumor in adults and often involves the corpus callosum. It presents with headaches, personality changes, seizures, and/or other neurological deficits. While glioblastomas may appear as a ring-enhancing lesion on imaging, they are poorly-defined tumors that often have a central clearing reflecting necrosis, unlike this patient's well-defined lesion. A different cause of ring-enhancing lesion in this patient with AIDS is more likely.

question_text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of left-sided body weakness and involuntary urinary leakage. He has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia treated with metformin and atorvastatin. He reports having experienced a similar episode two years ago. Neurologic examination shows left-sided hemiparesis and decreased sensation. The neurologic abnormalities are more prominent in the left lower than in the left upper extremity. He is oriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following labeled vessels in the MR angiography image of a normal brain is most likely occluded in this patient?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of left-sided body weakness and involuntary urinary leakage. He has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia treated with metformin and atorvastatin. He reports having experienced a similar episode two years ago. Neurologic examination shows left-sided hemiparesis and decreased sensation. The neurologic abnormalities are more prominent in the left lower than in the left upper extremity. He is oriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following labeled vessels in the MR angiography image of a normal brain is most likely occluded in this patient?
hint: Sudden onset of urinary incontinence in conjunction with sensory and motor loss predominantly affecting the left lower extremity should raise concern for cortical injury in the region of the anterior cerebral artery.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior cerebral artery stroke, and recall the anatomy of the circle of Willis.

answers.explanation_why: The right anterior cerebral artery (structure A) supplies the right anteromedial cortex including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes. ACA occlusion causes loss of contralateral motor and sensory function, particularly of the lower extremities. The ACA also supplies the medial frontal micturition center, the part of the brain responsible for bladder control.

The left anterior cerebral artery (structure B) supplies the left anteromedial cortex including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes. Occlusion would cause the symptoms of motor and sensory loss of the lower extremity seen in this patient, albeit on the right (i.e., contralateral) rather than the left side.

The right middle cerebral artery (structure C) supplies the right lateral cortex including the temporal lobe and the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobe. Although occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery can manifest with left-sided sensorimotor deficits, the face and upper extremities are typically affected rather than the lower extremities. Moreover, it also causes gaze deviation and aphasia (dominant hemisphere) or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere), which are absent in this patient.

The left middle cerebral artery (structure D) supplies the left lateral cortex including the temporal lobe and the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobe. Although occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery can manifest with sensorimotor deficits, symptoms would be expected on the right (i.e., contralateral) rather than the left side. Moreover, unlike this patient, the face and upper extremities are typically affected rather than the lower extremities. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of MCA occlusion such as gaze deviation and aphasia (dominant hemisphere) or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere).

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.explanation_why: The right posterior cerebral artery (structure E) supplies most parts of the right occipital cortex, the posteromedial aspects of the temporal lobe, and the thalamus. Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) typically manifests with visual field defects, contralateral hemisensory loss, and vertigo. Occlusion of the right PCA may also cause visual recognition deficits (prosopagnosia). Although this patient has left-sided sensory deficits, PCA occlusion would not explain his hemiparesis or incontinence. He also lacks the visual deficits and vertigo typically seen in PCA strokes.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.explanation_why: The left posterior cerebral artery (structure F) supplies most parts of the left occipital cortex, the posteromedial aspects of the temporal lobe, and the thalamus. Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) typically manifests with visual field defects, contralateral hemisensory loss, and vertigo. Occlusion of the PCA can also cause language deficits (alexia, anomic aphasia). Although this patient does have sensory deficits, a PCA occlusion would not explain his hemiparesis and incontinence. His symptoms are also left-sided, as opposed to the right-sided deficits expected in an occlusion of the left PCA.

The basilar artery (structure G) is formed by the confluence of the two vertebral arteries at the central groove of the pons and supplies the lower half of the cerebellum, the lower midbrain, the lower pons, the medulla, and the corticobulbar and corticospinal tracts. Basilar artery occlusion can present with vertigo, tinnitus, visual deficits, gait ataxia, and ipsilateral cranial nerve deficits with paresthesias and hemiplegia. Rarely, it can cause locked-in syndrome. Although this patient presents with sensorimotor deficits, there is no evidence of cranial nerve or cerebellar involvement. Moreover, basilar artery occlusion would not explain the urinary incontinence seen in this patient.

images.title: Circle of Willis
images.description:
Cranial MRI angiography (maximum intensity projection; dorsal view)This image shows the circle of Willis and its branches.A: right ACA
B: left ACA
C: right MCA
D: left MCA
E: right PCA
F: left PCA
G: basilar arteryNo significant pathologies are visible.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of weakness and intermittent burning pain in her neck, shoulders, and arms. She was involved in a motor vehicle collision 1 year ago. Examination of the upper extremities shows absent reflexes, muscle weakness, and fasciculations bilaterally. Sensation to temperature and pain is absent; vibration and proprioception are preserved. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of weakness and intermittent burning pain in her neck, shoulders, and arms. She was involved in a motor vehicle collision 1 year ago. Examination of the upper extremities shows absent reflexes, muscle weakness, and fasciculations bilaterally. Sensation to temperature and pain is absent; vibration and proprioception are preserved. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The presence of pain along with sensory deficits to pain and temperature in a cape-like distribution over the neck and upper extremities while sparing more distal sensory levels suggests injury to decussating fibers in the cervical and upper thoracic spinal cord. A history of motor vehicle collision and progressive symptoms point to a traumatic etiology.
learning_objective: Recognize syringomyelia.

answers.explanation_why: Tabes dorsalis, a manifestation of tertiary syphilis, refers to degeneration of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord that causes dysesthesia, as seen in this patient. It is also characterized by proprioceptive loss leading to ataxia, whereas proprioception is preserved in this patient. Pupillary irregularities, such as Argyll-Robertson pupil, are commonly associated with tabes dorsalis but are not seen here. While tabes dorsalis can sometimes cause absent lower extremity reflexes, it would not cause areflexia or other upper motor neuron signs of the upper extremities.

Post-traumatic syringomyelia can occur months to years after whiplash-type injury to the neck and presents with the classical findings of a central cord syndrome. Patients develop a symmetric cape-like distribution of pain and temperature sensory loss around the upper trunk, shoulders and upper limbs. Vibration and position sense are selectively spared because fibers of the posterior columns decussate higher up in the medulla. As syringomyelia progresses, lower motor neuron weakness develops symmetrically in the upper limbs (evident by areflexia and fasciculations in this patient) because the fluid-filled cavity begins to compress the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord at the level of the lesion. Syringomyelia is commonly associated with Chiari type I malformation.

As the lesion expands, the patient will develop an upper motor neuron palsy of the lower extremities and lower half of the trunk (due to involvement of the corticospinal tracts), as well as complete sensory loss below the level of the lesion (including loss of vibration and position sense). However, sensations around the sacral region will usually be spared.

Subacute combined degeneration (SCD) of the spinal cord affects the posterior and posterolateral columns of the spinal cord, presenting with upper motor neuron pattern weakness of the extremities and impaired fine touch and proprioception. This patient has preserved fine touch and proprioception along with lower motor neuron signs.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) may present with a combination of upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron weakness that progresses over time. However, ALS is more typically asymmetric and does not present with sensory deficits.

images.title: Clinical features and pathophysiology of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
images.description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

answers.explanation_why: Brown-Séquard syndrome , which results from a hemisection of the spinal cord, presents with dissociated sensory loss and unilateral motor deficits below the level of the injury. This patient has deficits affecting only her arms and chest without involvement of the remaining trunk and lower extremities, as would be seen in Brown-Séquard syndrome. In addition, Brown-Séquard syndrome typically occurs immediately following spinal cord injury; it is unlikely to develop 4 months later, as this patient's deficits did.

Multiple sclerosis can manifest with sensory deficits, weakness, and dysesthesia, as seen in this patient. But it would more typically manifest with upper motor neuron signs instead of lower motor neuron signs (e.g., fasciculations, loss of reflexes).

Cervical disk prolapse can lead to nerve root compression (radiculopathy), which may present with dysesthesia as well as sensory and/or motor deficits. However, neurological symptoms produced by disc prolapse are usually unilateral and localized to the distribution of the compressed nerve root. It is very unlikely that nerve root compression is the cause of this patient's symmetrical distribution of deficits; many nerve roots would have to be compressed simultaneously on both sides. In addition, all sensations are usually affected by nerve root compression, and the preservation of vibration and positional sense suggests a different diagnosis.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents several weeks after the family immigrated from Russia. The parents are worried because the child appears to have trouble seeing and has not started walking. The child was born at home and has never been evaluated by a physician. During the pregnancy, the mother had a week of fever, myalgia, diffuse rash, and bilateral nontender cervical adenopathy after the family adopted a cat. The patient is lethargic and irritable when aroused. Vital signs are within normal limits. The eyes deviate inferiorly and the eyelids are retracted. Ophthalmologic examination shows inflammation of the choroid and the retina in both eyes. An MRI of the head is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents several weeks after the family immigrated from Russia. The parents are worried because the child appears to have trouble seeing and has not started walking. The child was born at home and has never been evaluated by a physician. During the pregnancy, the mother had a week of fever, myalgia, diffuse rash, and bilateral nontender cervical adenopathy after the family adopted a cat. The patient is lethargic and irritable when aroused. Vital signs are within normal limits. The eyes deviate inferiorly and the eyelids are retracted. Ophthalmologic examination shows inflammation of the choroid and the retina in both eyes. An MRI of the head is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
hint: This patient likely developed congenital toxoplasmosis after his mother had a primary infection (fever, myalgia, and nontender cervical adenopathy following exposure to an infected cat). Cardinal manifestations of congenital toxoplasmosis include chorioretinitis and hydrocephalus.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital toxoplasmosis, and recall its neurological manifestations.

answers.explanation_why: A continuous machinery murmur arises from a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). PDA is associated with congenital rubella infection but is not seen in congenital toxoplasmosis infection. While congenital rubella can also cause vision abnormalities (e.g., due to cataracts), it is not usually associated with hydrocephalus.

images.title: Congenital rubella infection TORCH fact sheet

answers.content: Maculopapular rash on palms and soles
answers.explanation_why: A maculopapular rash on the palms and soles is characteristic of congenital syphilis, which should be considered in children born to mothers who did not receive prenatal care. Congenital syphilis can manifest with hydrocephalus, but this child does not present with other findings consistent with this condition (e.g., hepatomegaly and jaundice, Hutchinson teeth, mulberry molars, facial or skeletal alterations, generalized lymphadenopathy). In addition, this patient's mother does not have a history compatible with syphilis.

Signs of upper motor neuron damage (e.g., spasticity, hyperreflexia) are common in advanced, chronic hydrocephalus due to stretching of the motor cortices and pyramidal tracts around the dilated ventricles. The lower extremities are typically affected because the cortical regions responsible for processing the motor functions of the lower extremities are located in the medial precentral gyrus (according to the motor homunculus), which is the most stretched part of the primary motor cortex in patients with hydrocephalus. Other symptoms of hydrocephalus in children include difficulty feeding, irritability, and macrocephaly.

Another classic finding in congenital toxoplasmosis is diffuse intracranial calcifications. Pregnant women should avoid raw meats and contact with cat litter to prevent toxoplasmosis.

answers.content: Tuft of hair over the lumbosacral area
answers.explanation_why: A tuft of hair in the lumbosacral region is associated with spina bifida occulta. More severe forms of spina bifida can be associated with myelomeningocele, which itself is associated with hydrocephalus. However, patients with myelomeningoceles have a gross deformity of the lumbosacral area, not relatively minor findings such as a tuft of hair. Spina bifida occulta is not usually associated with hydrocephalus.

answers.content: Loss of pain sensation in the cervicothoracic dermatomes
answers.explanation_why: Loss of pain sensation in the cervicothoracic dermatomes (i.e., in a shawl distribution) is consistent with syringomyelia. The development of a syrinx in the center of the cervical spinal cord progressively compresses neurons of the spinothalamic tract, which explains the loss of pain (and typically temperature) sensation in the upper extremities. Later findings can include weakness or even paralysis as alpha motor neurons become compromised. Hydrocephalus is not associated with this finding.

images.title: Hydrocephalus
images.description: MRI head (FLAIR sequence; two axial planes) of a young childDilated lateral ventricles are seen in the center of both images (green overlay).

question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 4-month history of worsening dizziness, nausea, and feeling clumsy. An MRI of the brain shows a well-demarcated, 4-cm cystic mass in the posterior fossa. The patient undergoes complete surgical resection of the mass. Pathologic examination of the surgical specimen shows parallel bundles of cells with eosinophilic, corkscrew-like processes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 4-month history of worsening dizziness, nausea, and feeling clumsy. An MRI of the brain shows a well-demarcated, 4-cm cystic mass in the posterior fossa. The patient undergoes complete surgical resection of the mass. Pathologic examination of the surgical specimen shows parallel bundles of cells with eosinophilic, corkscrew-like processes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The eosinophilic, corkscrew-like processes seen in this patient's biopsy are Rosenthal fibers. The cells from this brain tumor are glial in origin and will stain positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP).
learning_objective: Recognize pilocytic astrocytoma and its association with Rosenthal fibers.

answers.explanation_why: Medulloblastoma, the most common malignant primary brain tumor of childhood, can also cause dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness (due to hydrocephalus and/or cerebellar damage) and appear as a well-defined cerebellar mass with cysts on imaging, as well. However, it is characterized histologically by the presence of small, round, undifferentiated basophilic cells (primitive neuroectoderm cells) and Homer-Wright rosettes.

images.title: Medulloblastoma
images.description:
Photomicrograph of cerebellar vermis tissue (H&E stain)Densely packed, small, blue anaplastic cells are present throughout the specimen. The cells have pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei.
On the right, a vessel (its lumen mostly obstructed by eosinophilic material) can be seen.These are typical histopathological findings of medulloblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Ependymomas typically occur in the posterior fossa (floor of the fourth ventricle) and can also present with dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness, due to obstructive hydrocephalus. However, they are characterized histologically by the presence of perivascular pseudorosettes and basal ciliary bodies (blepharoplasts) and are more common in early childhood.

images.title: Ependymoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of a brain tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)There is an abnormally high number of cells with round nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Some cells are arranged in a spoke-and-wheel pattern, surrounding an empty central space. Such patterns are called ependymal rosettes (example indicated by green overlay). Other cells are arranged concentrically around blood vessels, producing a similar appearance (perivascular pseudorosettes; example indicated yellow overlay).These are typical histopathological features of ependymoma.

answers.explanation_why:
Pilocytic astrocytoma is the most common pediatric primary brain tumor. It typically occurs in the cerebellum (posterior cranial fossa), but can also occur in supratentorial regions such as the optic nerve (optic glioma) and the cerebral hemispheres. Tumors in the posterior cranial fossa can present with dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness due to obstructive hydrocephalus and/or cerebellar damage. On imaging, a pilocytic astrocytoma typically appears as a well-demarcated cystic mass with a brightly enhancing nodule in the wall of the cyst.

Optic gliomas, a type of pilocytic astrocytoma in the optic pathway, are strongly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. A subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, another low-grade astrocytoma that occurs within ventricles, is associated with tuberous sclerosis.

images.title: Rosenthal fibers
images.description: Photomicrograph of a tissue section of a brain mass (H&E stain; high magnification)There is an abundance of eosinophilic, fusiform inclusions (Rosenthal fibers; examples indicated by blue overlay).Rosenthal fibers are intracellular inclusions within astrocyte cytoplasmic processes. They represent a nonspecific degenerative changes that are often found in CNS tumors (in this case in pilocytic astrocytoma).

answers.explanation_why: Craniopharyngiomas are the most common supratentorial tumors in pediatric patients; they are typically in the suprasellar region and cause bitemporal hemianopsia or endocrine abnormalities (e.g., hyperprolactinemia, hypopituitarism). Dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness would not be expected. The adamantinomatous variant of this tumor is characterized histologically by the presence of cholesterol crystals, calcification, and nests of “wet keratin” (desquamated cells) surrounded by stratified odontogenic epithelium, while the papillary variant is characterized by metaplastic squamous cells with very few or absent calcifications and cysts.

images.title: Adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma
images.description:
Photomicrograph of a brain tissue sample (HPS stain; intermediate magnification)Trabeculae and nests of squamous epithelium (examples indicated by yellow overlay) with palisading cells (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay) are visible.
Additionally, there are multiple cysts (examples indicated by yellow hatched overlay), nodules of anuclear ghost cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) containing wet keratin, and calcifications (examples indicated by blue outline) .This is the typical histological appearance of an adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma.

answers.explanation_why: A hemangioblastoma typically occurs in the posterior cranial fossa (cerebellum). It manifests with dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness (due to hydrocephalus and/or cerebellar damage) and appears as a well-demarcated cystic mass on imaging. However, hemangioblastomas are vascular tumors characterized histologically by closely packed, thin-walled vessels with minimal intervening brain parenchyma, and they are extremely rare among children. They typically occur among middle-aged adults.

images.title: Hemangioblastoma
images.description:
Photomicrograph of a biopsy from a cerebellar mass (H&E stain; high magnification)Numerous thin-walled small blood vessels (examples indicated by yellow overlay) containing red stained erythrocytes are visible throughout the tumor.
Surrounding the blood vessels large stromal cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with pale intracytoplasmic lipid inclusions (so-called "foamy" cytoplasm) can be seen.This appearance is indicative of hemangioblastoma. The diagnosis was confirmed by immunohistochemistry.

answers.explanation_why: A pinealoma typically occurs in the posterior fossa (dorsal midbrain) and can manifest with features of hydrocephalus (e.g., dizziness, nausea, and clumsiness) during childhood. However, most childhood pinealomas are germinomas characterized histologically by a lymphoid stroma and large vacuolated cells with enlarged oval nuclei. Moreover, other features associated with pinealomas, such as Parinaud syndrome (vertical gaze palsy, lid retraction, nystagmus, light-near dissociation) and precocious puberty, are absent in this patient.

images.title: Pineal germinoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of a pineal tumor biopsy sample (H&E stain; high magnification)Large tumor cells with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei can be seen (examples marked by green overlay). Additionally, the tumor tissue contains numerous intermixed lymphocytes (comparatively small cells with round dark nuclei).These histopathological findings are consistent with a pineal germinoma, which was confirmed by immunohistochemistry; ovarian dysgerminomas and testicular seminomas have a very similar appearance.

question_text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a seizure. His wife reports that the patient has been having recurrent headaches and has become increasingly irritable over the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a spastic paresis of the right lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the right side. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a seizure. His wife reports that the patient has been having recurrent headaches and has become increasingly irritable over the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a spastic paresis of the right lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the right side. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Brain tumors that present with seizures are most often supratentorial. The image shows a dural tail sign. The narrow rim of cerebrospinal fluid around this patient's tumor indicates that it is most likely extra-axial (external to the brain parenchyma).
learning_objective: Recognize a meningioma.

answers.explanation_why: Pituitary adenomas typically manifest between 35 and 60 years of age. Headaches and seizures may occur, depending on the size and location of the tumor. However, the motor weakness experienced by this patient would be unusual, and pituitary adenomas with a secretory function would cause endocrine disorders. Additionally, imaging would reveal an intrasellar hyperintense mass with foci of calcification and/or necrosis.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells of the cranial and/or peripheral nerves. Acoustic neuroma, the most common schwannoma, typically manifests with sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and facial nerve palsy. However, seizures are uncommon. Additionally, schwannomas appear as heterogeneously hyperintense extra-axial lesions on MRI that are most commonly localized to the cerebellopontine angle. The parasagittal location of this patient's tumor makes schwannoma an unlikely diagnosis.

images.title: Vestibularis schwannoma (acoustic neuroma)
images.description:
Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

answers.explanation_why: Metastatic brain tumors may manifest with headache, neurological deficits, and/or seizures. However, they are typically circumscribed, multifocal, intra-axial brain tumors, not extra-axial tumors, as seen in this patient.

images.title: Brain metastases in lung cancer
images.description: CT head (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of lung cancer presenting with weight loss, gradual reduction in consciousness, and deficits in swallowing, speech, coordination, and gaitCerebellar (green overlay) and brainstem (red overlay) lesions that show intense contrast enhancement are suspicious for metastases.P: petrous bone; S: sphenoid bone; T with arrows: tentorium cerebellum

answers.explanation_why: Ependymomas are intra-axial tumors that arise from ependymal cells that line the walls of the cerebral ventricles and central spinal canal. They most commonly manifest with signs of hydrocephalus due to their location near the fourth ventricle (in children) or the spinal canal (in adults). On imaging, they appear as intra-axial heterogeneous masses with areas of necrosis, calcification, cystic changes, and hemorrhage.

images.title: Ependymoma
images.description: MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.

answers.explanation_why: Oligodendrogliomas are most common among individuals 40–60 years of age and can manifest with seizures, as seen in this patient. However, on CT imaging, they usually appear as hypodense, intra-axial tumors containing focal hyperdense regions (due to calcification and/or hemorrhage). The hyperdense, extra-axial mass seen in this patient makes oligodendroglioma an unlikely diagnosis.

images.title: High signal intensity lesion on brain MRI (FLAIR)
images.description: MRI head (FLAIR sequence; axial plane)A hyperintense area (green overlay) in the right medial temporooccipital region was hypointense on a contrast-enhanced T1-weighted sequence (not shown). The lesion proved to be an oligodendroglioma. The differential diagnosis on MRI also included ischemic and inflammatory processes.C: cerebellum; M: mesencephalon (midbrain)

answers.explanation_why: Meningioma is the most common kind of primary CNS tumor with a median age of diagnosis of 65 years. Around half of all cases have a supratentorial location (e.g., near the falx cerebri, convex cerebral surface, or olfactory groove). On imaging, they appear as a round, well-circumscribed, extra-axial mass that is usually hyperdense on CT and isointense to gray matter on plain MRI. On MRI, they appear intense with homogeneous enhancement (as shown in the accompanying image). Most meningiomas show a marginal dural thickening that tapers peripherally (the "tail sign”). They cause symptoms due to extrinsic compression of brain tissue (i.e., mass effect). Parasagittal meningiomas may cause contralateral spastic paralysis due to compression of the motor cortex.

Glioblastoma multiforme almost always occurs in patients over the age of 40 and may manifest with seizures. However, on CT scan, glioblastoma multiforme appears as a poorly demarcated, hypodense, intra-axial lesion that tends to infiltrate along condensed white matter tracts such as the corticospinal tract and the corpus callosum. The presence of a hyperdense, extra-axial mass in this patient makes the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme unlikely.

images.title: Mass effect from glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV astrocytoma)
images.description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a 69-year old man with a history of personality changes and left-sided hemiparesis from glioblastomaThe right cerebral hemisphere is diffusely abnormal, with intermixed hypodense (green overlay), isodense, and hyperdense (red overlay) areas. There is mass effect with sulcal effacement and midline shift to the left (dashed line). The frontal and occipital horns (arrowheads) of the right lateral ventricle are effaced.Yellow overlay: choroid plexus calcification
Blue overlay: falx cerebri calcification

images.title: Meningioma
images.description:
Cranial MRI, axial view (T1-weighted; with contrast)Round, sharply delimited, homogeneously enhancing, hyperintense lesion (snowball appearance) in the interhemispheric region of the frontal lobe (green overlay).
The lesion displaces brain tissue. The dura is connected to the meninges of the frontal bone (dural tail sign) by a thick, hyperintense strand. A thin rim separates the lesion from surrounding brain parenchyma (CSF cleft sign).These are characteristic radiologic features of a meningioma.

question_text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had her period for 4 months. Menses had previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow. A home pregnancy test was negative. She also reports recurrent headaches and has noticed that when she goes to the movies she cannot see the outer edges of the screen without turning her head to each side. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by abnormal growth of which of the following?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had her period for 4 months. Menses had previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow. A home pregnancy test was negative. She also reports recurrent headaches and has noticed that when she goes to the movies she cannot see the outer edges of the screen without turning her head to each side. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by abnormal growth of which of the following?
hint: A cranial contrast MRI would reveal an intrasellar mass.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical presentation of a pituitary adenoma, and recall its associated cellular origin.

answers.explanation_why: Abnormal growth of astrocytes is the underlying pathology of astrocytomas. While low-grade astrocytomas commonly manifest during childhood with a benign course, high-grade astrocytomas (e.g., glioblastoma multiforme) occurs in older individuals and manifests in rapidly progressive symptoms that depend upon the location of the lesion but may include headaches. This patient's prolonged course of symptoms and secondary amenorrhea is not suggestive of glioblastoma multiforme.

Abnormal growth of the adenohypophysis is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms, which are consistent with a pituitary adenoma. Adenomas of the pituitary gland are most commonly due to aberrant proliferation of lactotroph cells in the adenohypophysis. The resulting hyperprolactinemia eventually causes suppression of gonadotropins and subsequent secondary amenorrhea. Bitemporal hemianopsia (due to compression of the optic chiasm) and headaches may develop as the adenoma grows.

Her symptoms could also be explained by a large nonsecreting pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasm (bitemporal hemianopsia) and the pituitary stalk or the gonadotropic cells (secondary amenorrhea), but the absence of other symptoms of hypopituitarism makes prolactinoma more likely.

images.title: Pituitary mass 2/2
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactinA large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: Abnormal growth of arachnoid cap cells is the underlying pathology of meningiomas. Even though this patient's recurrent headaches could be attributed to a meningioma, this tumor would not explain this patient's secondary amenorrhea or her visual disturbances.

Abnormal growth of ependymal cells is the underlying pathology of ependymomas, most of which arise close to the fourth ventricle. Ependymomas commonly cause obstructive hydrocephalus, which may manifest as recurrent headaches. However, ependymomas typically develop during childhood and are not associated with menstrual irregularities or visual disturbances.

Abnormal growth of Schwann cells leads to the development of a schwannoma, which typically arises near the cerebellopontine angle. Large tumors may lead to symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, e.g., recurrent headache. However, in the case of a schwannoma, other features would likely be present, including tinnitus, vertigo, and hearing loss. Moreover, menstrual irregularities or bitemporal hemianopia would not be expected in the case of a Schwannoma.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Abnormal growth of the pineal gland leads to the development of a pinealoma, which generally manifests during childhood. Symptoms of pinealomas include visual disturbances and dizziness or recurrent headaches (due to hydrocephalus). However, pinealomas are associated with vertical gaze palsy rather than the bitemporal hemianopsia observed in this patient. Moreover, menstrual disturbances would not be expected, as pinealomas are hormonally inactive.

question_text: An otherwise healthy 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of worsening headaches and increasing irritability. Examination shows bilateral papilledema. An MRI of the brain shows a mass in the right temporal lobe with heterogeneous peripheral rim enhancement that crosses the midline. He undergoes surgical resection of the mass. Gross examination shows a poorly-demarcated mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Microscopic examination of the mass will most likely show which of the following?
content_preview: An otherwise healthy 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of worsening headaches and increasing irritability. Examination shows bilateral papilledema. An MRI of the brain shows a mass in the right temporal lobe with heterogeneous peripheral rim enhancement that crosses the midline. He undergoes surgical resection of the mass. Gross examination shows a poorly-demarcated mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Microscopic examination of the mass will most likely show which of the following?
hint: A brain tumor in the temporal lobe that crosses the midline and displays irregular rim enhancement is suggestive of glioblastoma, the most common type of malignant brain tumor in adults. The gross pathology findings of a poorly-demarcated mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis are consistent with this diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize glioblastoma multiforme, and recall its microscopic features.

answers.content: Spindle cells with hypercellular and hypocellular regions
answers.explanation_why: Spindle cells with hypercellular and hypocellular regions are characteristic of schwannomas. Schwannomas typically occur at the cerebellopontine angle and present with lateralized symptoms, especially vestibulocochlear nerve dysfunction, whereas headache, irritability, and papilledema are unlikely findings. Moreover, hemorrhage or necrosis are uncommon, as schwannomas are slow-growing tumors.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma in a 43-year-old patient
images.description: Photomicrograph of a tumor arising from the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII (H&E stain; medium magnification)A characteristic finding of neuromas is the simultaneous occurrence of areas with densely packed nuclei (palisade pattern; A) and scattered or anuclear areas (B). There is also a large number of vacuolated cells (C).

answers.content: Closely-packed capillaries and foamy stromal cells
answers.explanation_why: Closely-packed capillaries and foamy stromal cells are characteristic of hemangioblastomas, highly vascularized benign tumors most likely to be found in the cerebellum. They may present in middle age with papilledema, but patients would likely show cerebellar symptoms or polycythemia (due to production of erythropoietin). Headache and irritability as well as findings of hemorrhage and necrosis would be unlikely in a hemangioblastoma.

images.title: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma (WHO grade I)
images.description: Photomicrograph of a cerebellar tissue specimen (HPS stain; high magnification)Numerous polygonal neoplastic stromal cells with lipid-laden vacuoles (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen, resulting in the typical clear-cell appearance. Additionally, there is an abundance of small, thin-walled blood vessels, many of which are densely packed together (examples indicated by blue overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Pleomorphic cells arranged in pseudopalisades are a hallmark of glioblastoma multiforme, a highly malignant brain tumor that arises from astrocytes. Pseudopalisades are arrays of tumor cells migrating away from an area of central necrosis. Histological findings in glioblastoma multiforme vary greatly but would most likely also show microvascular proliferation as well as necrosis and hemorrhage (as already seen on gross examination).

images.title: Glioblastoma multiforme
images.description: Photomicrograph of a cerebral tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)A high number and density of highly pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei are visible (examples indicated by arrowheads. These cells are aggregated around the periphery of the necrotic zone (green overlay), forming a nuclear pseudopalisading architecture.These are the characteristic features of glioblastoma multiforme.

answers.content: Cells with clear cytoplasm and central round nuclei
answers.explanation_why: Cells with clear cytoplasm and central round nuclei (fried egg appearance) are characteristics of oligodendrogliomas. Oligodendrogliomas would not be expected to present with bilateral papilledema but rather with seizures and sensory deficits. They are slow-growing tumors that usually occur in the frontal lobe and manifest as well-defined gray masses with areas of calcification; necrosis would not be expected.

images.title: Oligodendroglioma
images.description: Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; very high magnification)Monomorphic cells with enlarged, round/oval nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of unstained cytoplasm, which is an artifact of processing, are visible (green overlay). Thin blood vessels with an interlacing pattern are also visible (yellow overlay).These are the typical features of oligodendroglioma.

answers.content: Small blue cells arranged in rosettes
answers.explanation_why: Small blue cells arranged in rosettes (Homer-Wright rosettes) are characteristic of medulloblastomas. Medulloblastomas originate from the primitive neuroectoderm and are the most common malignant brain tumor in children (peak incidence 3–5 years). Medulloblastomas are typically found in the cerebellum, often compress the 4^th ventricle, and manifests with hydrocephalus and posterior vermis syndrome. On MRI they show a diffuse enhancement. The location, clinical presentation, and imaging findings of this adult patient's tumor are not consistent with medulloblastoma.

images.title: Medulloblastoma
images.description:
Photomicrograph of cerebellar vermis tissue (H&E stain)Densely packed, small, blue anaplastic cells are present throughout the specimen. The cells have pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei.
On the right, a vessel (its lumen mostly obstructed by eosinophilic material) can be seen.These are typical histopathological findings of medulloblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Areas of lamellated calcification are consistent with psammoma bodies, which are characteristic of meningioma and other noncerebral tumors. Meningiomas are composed of spindle cells arranged in a whorled pattern. While they might also show rim enhancement on MRI, as seen in this patient, meningiomas usually appear as a homogeneous, well-defined lesion outside the brain without areas of hemorrhage and necrosis.

images.title: Meningioma
images.description: Photomicrograph of tissue biopsied from a brain tumor (HPS stain)Several eosinophilic cells are visible, arranged in whorls (purple overlay) and sheets. A mass of disorganized cells is visible in the top right corner (yellow overlay). The nuclei of these cells show features of malignancy (i.e., large size or high N:C ratio, nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic figures). The intervening stroma contains numerous blood vessels (green overlay).Hypercellularity, whorled or sheet-like architecture, and hypervascularity are typical features of a meningioma. Psammoma bodies (not seen here) are another characteristic feature of meningioma and would appear as basophilic whorls.

question_text: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being hit by a car while crossing the street. He had a left-sided tonic-clonic seizure and one episode of vomiting while being transported to the hospital. On arrival, he is not oriented to person, place, or time. Physical examination shows flaccid paralysis of all extremities. A CT scan of the head is shown. This patient's symptoms are most likely the result of a hemorrhage in which of the following structures?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being hit by a car while crossing the street. He had a left-sided tonic-clonic seizure and one episode of vomiting while being transported to the hospital. On arrival, he is not oriented to person, place, or time. Physical examination shows flaccid paralysis of all extremities. A CT scan of the head is shown. This patient's symptoms are most likely the result of a hemorrhage in which of the following structures?
hint: This type of intracranial hemorrhage can also occur in the absence of trauma in individuals with ruptured saccular aneurysms.
learning_objective: Recognize subarachnoid hemorrhage, and recall its location within the meningeal layers.

answers.explanation_why: Intraventricular hemorrhage typically occurs secondary to intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage but can arise from rare vascular malformations. As with other intracranial bleeds, the characteristic presentation involves sudden onset of headache, vomiting, and altered level of consciousness. However, imaging of the head would show accumulation of blood within the ventricular system, which is not seen on this patient's head CT.

images.title: Basal ganglia and intraventricular hemorrhage
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)A large hematoma (red overlay) accompanied by edema (green overlay) and mild mass effect involves the right basal ganglia and cerebral parenchyma. A small left basal ganglia hemorrhage (blue overlay) is also present. Hemorrhage has extended into the ventricular system (yellow overlay). Portions of a right ventricular stent (white arrows) are visible.

answers.content: Between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater
answers.explanation_why: Shearing of bridging veins causes subdural hemorrhage, which is characterized by bleeding between the dura mater and arachnoid mater. Patients may present with headache and signs of increased ICP immediately following head trauma, as is the case here. However, head CT would show a high-density crescent-shaped collection (in acute cases) or a hypodense crescent-shaped collection (in chronic and subacute cases) across the hemispheric convexity, which crosses the suture lines.

images.title: Subdural hematoma and cerebral edema
images.description: CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window) of a patient with a history of traumaA large acute subdural hematoma is visible as a hyperdense crescent-shaped lesion along the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere (red overlay). It is accompanied by an extracranial soft tissue hematoma (hatched red overlay). There is extensive hypodense left cerebral edema (gray overlay), with sulcal effacement and shift of midline structures (green line) to the right. The anterior horns of the lateral ventricles (hatched green overlay) are compressed and the posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle (red circle) is dilated.

answers.content: Between the skull and the dura mater
answers.explanation_why: Bleeding between the dura mater and the skull is known as epidural hemorrhage and is often due to traumatic injury to the middle meningeal artery. Epidural hemorrhage should be suspected in any patient with head trauma that causes loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval, and subsequent worsening with signs of increased ICP. CT scan of the head would show a characteristic lentiform (lens-shaped) hemorrhagic collection that does not cross suture lines. While this patient does have signs of increased ICP following a trauma, his CT findings suggest a different diagnosis.

images.title: Epidural and subdural hematomas
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (brain window: axial and coronal planes; bone window: axial plane)A biconvex epidural hematoma (green overlay) with mass effect is seen in the left frontal region, adjacent to which is a small frontotemporal subdural hematoma (red overlay). A calvarial fracture (arrowheads) involves the left temporal and parietal bones.

answers.explanation_why: Bleeding directly into the cerebral parenchyma, known as intracerebral hemorrhage, is typically caused by a spontaneous rupture of vessels secondary to structural changes of the vessel walls (e.g., chronic hypertension, cerebral amyloid angiopathy). Patients often present with headache and focal neurologic deficits such as hemiparesis. However, head trauma rarely leads to intracerebral hemorrhage, and signs of increased ICP are uncommon. Moreover, this patient's head CT is not consistent with intracerebral hemorrhage.

images.title: Intracerebral hematoma
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)A large hyperdense hematoma (green overlay) in the posterior aspect of the left cerebral hemisphere is accompanied by hypodense edema (red overlay), effacement of the occipital horn of the left lateral ventricle, and midline shift (dashed line and arrowheads).ROH: right occipital horn

answers.content: Between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater
answers.explanation_why: Traumatic brain injury can cause subarachnoid hemorrhage, which is characterized by bleeding between the arachnoid mater and pia mater. Patients classically present with a sudden, severely painful headache, vomiting, loss of consciousness, and, in cases of severe hemorrhage, seizures. Head CT shows hyperdense signals in the area of the hemorrhage, which are seen in the basal cistern in this patient.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: A nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage is most commonly caused by the rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage in the basal cisterns
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Hyperdensity (green overlay) in the basal cisterns indicates the presence of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

question_text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being hit in the head with a baseball bat. Physical examination shows swelling and bruising around the left temple and eye. A CT scan of the head shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone and blood in the sphenoid sinus. Neurological examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being hit in the head with a baseball bat. Physical examination shows swelling and bruising around the left temple and eye. A CT scan of the head shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone and blood in the sphenoid sinus. Neurological examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Blood in the sphenoid sinus and a transverse fracture on imaging are indicative of an anterior fracture of the middle cranial fossa. Anterior middle cranial fossa fractures may involve the orbital apex, superior orbital fissure, and clinoid processes.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior middle cranial fossa fracture, and recall the associated cranial nerve injuries.

answers.explanation_why: Left homonymous hemianopia would be seen with damage to the visual pathways at the level of the right occipital lobe (e.g., due to right posterior cerebral artery stroke). This young patient does not have any known risk factors for CVA and given the mechanism of injury and imaging findings, a different finding is more likely.
answers.explanation_but: Severe head trauma can result in a skull base fracture extending through the floor of the sella turcica and sphenoid sinus to injure the crossing fibers at the optic chiasm, which would cause a bitemporal hemianopia.

answers.content: Inward deviation of the left eye
answers.explanation_why: Inward deviation of the eye (esotropia) can result from fractures of the sphenoid bone that extend anteriorly through the superior orbital fissure to damage the abducens nerve (CN VI). Other nerves that can be injured in skull base fractures involving the superior orbital fissure are the oculomotor nerve (ptosis with a fixed and dilated pupil), trochlear nerve (ocular extorsion and vertical diplopia), and ophthalmic nerve (absent corneal reflex). CN VI palsy is the most common cranial nerve palsy because of the long and tortuous route that CN VI takes intracranially, along which the nerve is vulnerable to injury by trauma (as in this patient), neoplasms (e.g., sphenoid ridge meningiomas), increased ICP (e.g., pseudotumor cerebri, SAH), neurovascular pathologies (e.g., cavernous sinus thrombosis, carotid-cavernous fistulas), and infection (e.g., syphilis).

images.title: Canals and foramina of base of skull
images.description: Superior view of internal surface

answers.explanation_why: Left facial paralysis would indicate facial nerve palsy. The facial nerve (CN VII) is commonly injured in fractures of the petrous part of the temporal bone (e.g., transverse temporal bone fractures) that extend from the internal acoustic meatus to the stylomastoid foramen. Although this patient has bruising around his left temple, his CT scan shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone, for which left facial paralysis is not typical.

images.title: Examination findings in facial nerve palsy
images.description: Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

answers.content: Decreased hearing in the left ear
answers.explanation_why: Decreased hearing in the left ear would suggest vestibulocochlear nerve injury, which can result from skull base fractures extending from the petrous pyramid of the temporal bone into the internal acoustic meatus. Other typical findings associated with this type of injury include signs of fluid accumulation in the middle ear, CSF otorrhea, hemotympanum, and mastoid ecchymosis. Vertigo and horizontal nystagmus may be present as well. This patient's CT scan shows a fracture through the sphenoid bone rather than the temporal bone, making this finding unlikely.

answers.content: Deviation of uvula to the right
answers.explanation_why: Deviation of the uvula to the right would be consistent with a left vagus nerve palsy. CN X can be injured in posterior cranial fossa fractures that extend into the jugular foramen., which is located between the temporal bone and occipital bone. However, this patient's CT scan shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone.

question_text: A previously healthy 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of confusion for the last 4 hours. His wife reports that 4 days ago, he had a bicycle accident in which he collided with another cyclist and was not wearing a helmet. On arrival, he is unconscious. The right pupil is dilated and fixed; the left pupil is round and reactive to light. An MRI scan of the brain shows a large right-sided subdural hematoma (SDH), right uncal transtentorial herniation, and compression of the left cerebral peduncle against the tentorial notch. Which of the following additional findings would be most likely in this patient?
content_preview: A previously healthy 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of confusion for the last 4 hours. His wife reports that 4 days ago, he had a bicycle accident in which he collided with another cyclist and was not wearing a helmet. On arrival, he is unconscious. The right pupil is dilated and fixed; the left pupil is round and reactive to light. An MRI scan of the brain shows a large right-sided subdural hematoma (SDH), right uncal transtentorial herniation, and compression of the left cerebral peduncle against the tentorial notch. Which of the following additional findings would be most likely in this patient?
hint: Compression of the cerebral peduncle contralateral to the uncal herniation may result in false localizing signs.
learning_objective: Recognize transtentorial uncal herniation, and recall the associated false localizing signs.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient's transtentorial uncal herniation is most likely caused by the mass effect exerted by the SDH. Initially, the displaced uncus exerts pressure primarily on the ipsilateral cerebral peduncle and oculomotor nerve, possibly resulting in contralateral hemiparesis (due to compression of the corticospinal tract) and ipsilateral fixed and dilated pupil (Hutchinson pupil), respectively. As herniation develops, the contralateral cerebral peduncle and oculomotor nerve are pushed against the contralateral tentorial notch, resulting in paradoxical ipsilateral hemiparesis and contralateral Hutchinson pupil. This combination of false localizing signs is called Kernohan phenomenon.

As herniation progresses, the brainstem may be compressed and caudally displaced, shearing the vessels and leading to midbrain and pontine hemorrhages, which result in coma, apnea, impaired circulation, and death.

Asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss can be caused by various conditions and can have an acute or gradual onset. Meniere disease is the most common cause of acute asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, whereas other conditions (e.g., tumors) can lead to gradual asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss. SDH with uncal herniation does not commonly result in asymmetric hearing loss.

Spasticity indicates upper motor neuron (UMN) damage. Severe advanced uncal herniation causes brainstem displacement leading to secondary hemorrhages, which subsequently cause brainstem strokes and potential concomitant damage to the bilateral corticospinal tract. Spasticity is typically a late sequela, appearing days to weeks after UMN injury, and another finding is therefore more likely at this time.

Deviation of the tongue when protruded can be caused by compression syndromes and other neurological lesions, and the tongue typically deviates to the affected side. Tongue deviation results from damage to the hypoglossal nucleus, which is located in the medulla rather than the cerebral peduncle. Compression of the hypoglossal nucleus is therefore commonly associated with skull base fractures, neoplasms, and strokes, and is rarely seen in uncal herniation with cerebral peduncle compression.

Convergence-retraction nystagmus can be seen in dorsal midbrain syndrome (Parinaud syndrome). Upon attempting to look upward, the eyes converge and retract into the orbit. Parinaud syndrome can be caused by compression of the dorsal midbrain due to an SDH, but this patient's MRI shows signs of uncal herniation and cerebral peduncle compression, not dorsal midbrain compression.

question_text: A 74-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for progressively worsening confusion and forgetfulness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a flat affect and impaired short-term memory. An MRI of the brain is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 74-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for progressively worsening confusion and forgetfulness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a flat affect and impaired short-term memory. An MRI of the brain is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: In conjunction with the MRI findings (marked dilatation of the lateral ventricles without proportional sulcal enlargement), this patient's progressively worsening confusion and memory suggest normal pressure hydrocephalus, a condition that is most commonly seen in adults over the age of 60.
learning_objective: Recognize normal pressure hydrocephalus, and recall its clinical triad.

answers.explanation_why: Startle myoclonus is seen in many neurological and psychiatric syndromes. When occurring in combination with signs of rapidly progressing dementia (rapidly worsening confusion and memory loss), Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease should be considered. However, MRI of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease would show T2 signal amplification in the caudate nucleus rather than the ventriculomegaly seen here.

images.title: MRI in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
images.description: MRI head (left: T2-weighted image, axial plane; right: diffusion-weighted image (DWI), axial plane) of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)The DWI shows hyperintensities (examples indicated by arrows) in the putamen (red overlay), thalamus (yellow overlay), and caudate nucleus (green overlay), common locations for deep gray matter involvement with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Sporadic CJD may also demonstrate ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri (cortical ribboning; not shown). A probable diagnosis of CJD can be made when expected MR imaging patterns are seen and CJD-mimicking disorders are confidently ruled out clinically.

answers.explanation_why: Papilledema can be due to either communicating hydrocephalus or noncommunicating hydrocephalus. While this patient does show signs of impaired consciousness (increasing confusion and forgetfulness), he lacks characteristic signs of elevated ICP (e.g., nausea, vomiting, headaches, Cushing triad), making papilledema unlikely. NPH, which this patient most likely has, is only characterized by a mild and intermittent elevation in ICP, and papilledema would not be expected.

A broad-based gait is a clumsy, irregular pattern of walk in which small steps are taken and the legs are spread wide. Gait dysfunction, dementia, and urinary incontinence make up the pathognomonic triad (“wet”, “wacky”, “wobbly”) of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Postural instability is one of the cardinal signs of Parkinson disease. Patients with the disease can present with cognitive dysfunctions and dementia, similar to what is seen in this patient, but only later in the course of the disease. Parkinson disease is not associated with ventriculomegaly, which is seen here.

Pill-rolling tremors are characteristic of Parkinson disease. Patients with the disease can manifest with cognitive dysfunctions and dementia, similar to what is seen in this patient, but only later in the course of the disease. Parkinson disease is not associated with the ventriculomegaly seen here.
answers.explanation_but: Imaging is not routinely required for the diagnosis of Parkinson disease. It is reserved for atypical presentations to rule out other underlying disorders.

answers.explanation_why: Choreiform movements are typically seen in Huntington disease. Huntington disease is associated with progressive cognitive deficits in advanced stages of the disease. MRI would show brain atrophy, particularly of the caudate nucleus, rather than the ventriculomegaly seen here.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial plane)There is marked dilatation of the lateral ventricles (green overlay) with mild sulcal enlargement (red overlay). The findings are suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus as opposed to age-related or neurodegenerative cerebral atrophy.Periventricular hypointensities (examples indicated by white arrowheads) are also seen and may reflect transependymal edema due to elevated cerebrospinal fluid pressure.
