question_text: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after falling while mountain biking and hitting his head. Initially, he refused treatment, but an hour ago he began to develop a severe headache, nausea, and left leg weakness. He has no visual changes and is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 17/min and regular, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Examination shows a 5-cm bruise on the right side of his skull. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Muscle strength is 0/5 in his left knee and foot. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
content_preview: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after falling while mountain biking and hitting his head. Initially, he refused treatment, but an hour ago he began to develop a severe headache, nausea, and left leg weakness. He has no visual changes and is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 17/min and regular, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Examination shows a 5-cm bruise on the right side of his skull. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Muscle strength is 0/5 in his left knee and foot. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
hint: Focal deficits involving the lower limbs indicate involvement of the superior segment of the motor cortex.
learning_objective: Recognize subfalcine herniation.

answers.explanation_why: Upward brainstem herniation is rare and usually results from a brainstem mass (e.g., tumor), rather than intracranial hemorrhage, which is suspected in this patient. Typical findings include miosis, decerebrate posturing, doll's eyes, and altered mental status. This patient has pupils that appear normal, normal mental status, and no abnormal posturing, making upward brainstem herniation unlikely.

Uncal herniation leads to compression of the ipsilateral oculomotor nerve (causing a fixed and dilated pupil), the ipsilateral posterior cerebral artery (causing cortical blindness with contralateral homonymous hemianopia), and the contralateral cerebral peduncle (causing ipsilateral paralysis). While this patient is at risk of uncal herniation and has hemiplegia, he has a normal pupillary exam and has no visual symptoms.

Tonsillar herniation can occur due to any mass effect in the superior part of the skull (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage) and presents with symptoms of cerebellar and medullary compression (e.g., altered mental status, cardiorespiratory depression). While this patient likely has intracranial hemorrhage, he has a normal mental and cardiorespiratory status. Moreover, his hemiplegia suggests an alternative diagnosis.

Subfalcine herniation is the most common cerebral herniation syndrome and is usually due to cingulate gyrus herniation under the falx cerebri, causing compression of the foramen of Monro (leading to hydrocephalus and consequent headache) and branches of the anterior cerebral artery (causing infarction in the ACA territory and consequent contralateral lower limb weakness). This patient's herniation is most likely due to traumatic intracranial hemorrhage (e.g., subdural hemorrhage), given his recent fall involving head trauma. Without emergent diagnosis and treatment, expanding intracranial hemorrhage can rapidly progress to brainstem herniation and death.

The next steps would be confirmation of the diagnosis with emergency noncontrast head CT and neurosurgical consultation for likely craniectomy.

images.title: Brain herniation
images.description: Brain herniations occur as a result of increased intracranial pressure, such as that caused by subdural hematomas. Variations include herniation of brain tissue under the falx cerebri (1), below the tentorium cerebelli (2, 3), downwards through the foramen magnum (4), above the tentorium cerebelli (5), or outside of the skull (6).

answers.explanation_why: Central transtentorial herniation is caused by global cerebral edema and causes herniation of the diencephalon and midbrain. Typical findings include altered mental status, pupillary abnormalities, and extensor posturing. This patient presents with normal mental status and has a normal ocular exam, making central transtentorial herniation unlikely. Moreover, his unilateral motor symptoms suggest an alternative diagnosis.

Extracranial herniation occurs when brain tissue passes through a defect in the skull (e.g., fracture), with neurologic deficits due to compression of the tissue as it passes through the defect. While this patient has a focal neurologic deficit, there is no evidence of skull fracture (e.g., focal tenderness or skull depression) or brain tissue herniating through the skull (e.g., bulge near area of fracture).

question_text: A previously healthy 46-year-old man comes to the physician for an 8-month history of headache that is more severe in the mornings. His blood pressure is 151/92 mm Hg. Examination shows enlargement of the nose, forehead, and jaw as well as the hands, fingers, and feet. Ophthalmologic examination shows impaired vision in the outer peripheral fields of both eyes. Laboratory studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 225 mg/dL. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A previously healthy 46-year-old man comes to the physician for an 8-month history of headache that is more severe in the mornings. His blood pressure is 151/92 mm Hg. Examination shows enlargement of the nose, forehead, and jaw as well as the hands, fingers, and feet. Ophthalmologic examination shows impaired vision in the outer peripheral fields of both eyes. Laboratory studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 225 mg/dL. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with acromegaly (hypertension, coarsened and enlarged features, hyperglycemia). His headache and bitemporal hemianopsia indicate local mass effect.
learning_objective: Recognize acromegaly, and recall its diagnostic finding.

answers.explanation_why: Low serum GH can be seen in a number of conditions, e.g., following brain surgery, severe head injury, infection, or in patients with pituitary tumors. Although this patient's clinical symptoms (headache and bitemporal hemianopsia) suggest local mass effect in the pituitary, he also presents with features of acromegaly, which is classically associated with excess serum GH.

Elevated urine cortisol levels are a typical finding in Cushing syndrome, which is most commonly caused by a pituitary adenoma. Pituitary adenoma can result in bitemporal hemianopsia and Cushing syndrome can manifest with hyperglycemia. However, other features of Cushing syndrome include proximal muscle weakness, central obesity, and abdominal striae, none of which are present in this patient.

Low insulin levels are seen in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, in which pancreatic beta cells are destroyed, resulting in persistently elevated serum glucose levels. This patient's hyperglycemia is instead due to the endocrinopathy of acromegaly, in which excess growth hormone (GH) levels stimulate gluconeogenesis, causing a state of insulin resistance. Hyperglycemia then induces compensatory hyperinsulinemia; therefore, elevated serum insulin levels would be expected in this patient.

Low urine osmolality is typical in patients with diabetes insipidus, which can occur secondary to brain tumors. Though this patient presents with features suggestive of a local mass effect from the pituitary, he does not have symptoms of diabetes insipidus, such as polyuria, nocturia, or polydipsia.

Elevated prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) can result from prolactin-secreting pituitary adenomas, which can also cause bitemporal hemianopsia and headache, both of which are seen here. In men, symptoms of prolactinoma typically include gynecomastia and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (presenting with erectile dysfunction and loss of libido). Elevated prolactin is rarely seen in individuals with acromegaly, such as this man. In addition, he lacks classic symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, making a different finding more likely.

answers.content: Elevated serum insulin-like growth factor-1 concentration
answers.explanation_why:
An elevated serum IGF-1 concentration is the most likely finding for this patient with acromegaly, a condition most commonly caused by a GH-secreting pituitary adenoma. Excess secretion of GH stimulates IGF-1 synthesis, which in turn stimulates cell growth and proliferation while inhibiting apoptosis. IGF-1 is part of the negative feedback cycle that governs normal GH production, so IGF-1 levels are high in response to the pathologically elevated GH levels.

IGF-1 is the most reliable indicator of acromegaly and measurement of IGF-1 levels is the first step in diagnosing patients with suspected acromegaly. Normal levels of IGF-1 rule out acromegaly as a diagnosis.

question_text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed with a knife during an altercation. Physical examination shows a 4-cm stab wound on the right lateral border of the T1 spinous process. An MRI of the spinal cord shows damage to the area of the right lateral corticospinal tract at the level of T1. Further evaluation will most likely show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed with a knife during an altercation. Physical examination shows a 4-cm stab wound on the right lateral border of the T1 spinous process. An MRI of the spinal cord shows damage to the area of the right lateral corticospinal tract at the level of T1. Further evaluation will most likely show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient's mechanism of injury and imaging findings are consistent with a partial Brown-Sequard syndrome. The lateral corticospinal tract originates at the precentral gyrus and decussates at the level of the medulla.
learning_objective: Recognize partial Brown-Sequard syndrome, and recall the expected motor function findings.

answers.content: Absence of right-sided motor function below T1
answers.explanation_why: A right lateral corticospinal tract injury (e.g., partial Brown-Sequard syndrome) would result in the absence of ipsilateral motor function below injury level. The lateral corticospinal tract decussates at the level of the medulla. An injury distal to the decussation (e.g., at the level of T1) would, therefore, affect ipsilateral motor function below the level of the injury. In a full Brown-Sequard syndrome (e.g., hemisection of the spinal cord), there would also be ipsilateral loss of vibration and proprioception below T1 (dorsal column), ipsilateral Babinski sign (lateral corticospinal tract), and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning two levels below the lesion (lateral spinothalamic tract).

The Babinski sign usually takes 1–2 weeks to appear after an upper motor neuron lesion occurs. This finding would be unlikely immediately following an acute injury. Furthermore, a Babinski sign would be expected ipsilateral to the injury (in this case, on the right side), as the upper motor neuron for the lateral corticospinal tract has been disrupted here and decussation of this tract occurs at a higher level.

answers.content: Absence of left-sided proprioception below T1
answers.explanation_why: An absence of left-sided (contralateral to the injury) proprioception below T1 would be consistent with injury to the left dorsal column, which is unlikely given this patient's imaging findings of lateral corticospinal tract injury on the right side. Proprioception is transmitted via ascending sensory neurons in the dorsal column ipsilaterally, until decussation at the level of the medulla.
answers.explanation_but: An absence of ipsilateral proprioception below the lesion would be expected if the right dorsal column were involved in this patient's injury.

answers.content: Absence of right-sided temperature sensation below T1
answers.explanation_why: An absence of right-sided temperature sensation below T1 would be most consistent with a left lateral spinothalamic tract injury at the level of T1. Sensory fibers from the lateral spinothalamic tract transmit input about pain and temperature and ascend two segments before decussating in the spinal cord and ascending contralaterally until they reach the sensory cortex. However, this patient's MRI shows damage to the right lateral corticospinal tract at T1, making this finding unlikely.

answers.content: Absence of left-sided fine touch sensation below T1
answers.explanation_why: An absence of left-sided fine touch below T1 would be expected with an injury to the left dorsal column, which is unlikely given this patient's imaging findings of lateral corticospinal tract injury on the right side. Fine touch is transmitted via ascending sensory neurons in the dorsal column ipsilaterally, until decussation at the level of the medulla.

question_text: A 70-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital 8 hours after the onset of impaired speech and right-sided weakness. Two days after admission, he becomes confused and is difficult to arouse. His pulse is 64/min and blood pressure is 166/96 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A CT scan of the brain shows hypoattenuation in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery with surrounding edema and a 1-cm midline shift to the right. Which of the following interventions is most likely to result in a decrease in this patient's intracranial pressure?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital 8 hours after the onset of impaired speech and right-sided weakness. Two days after admission, he becomes confused and is difficult to arouse. His pulse is 64/min and blood pressure is 166/96 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A CT scan of the brain shows hypoattenuation in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery with surrounding edema and a 1-cm midline shift to the right. Which of the following interventions is most likely to result in a decrease in this patient's intracranial pressure?
hint: Patients with large strokes are at increased risk of developing cerebral edema in the early post-stroke period. An increase in intracranial pressure (ICP) due to cerebral edema can cause impaired consciousness, papilledema, and an increase in blood pressure with a reduction in heart rate (Cushing reflex).
learning_objective: Choose the intervention to decrease intracranial pressure in a patient with cerebral edema post-stroke.

answers.explanation_why: The cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP), depends on the ICP and the mean arterial pressure (CPP = MAP – ICP). In acute strokes, vasoregulation is often lost and adequate cerebral oxygenation depends directly on the mean arterial pressure. Aggressive blood pressure reduction in this patient should be avoided as it may result in reduced perfusion and increased secondary neurologic injury.

Cerebral perfusion is regulated by pCO_2  and patients with raised intracranial pressure who are mechanically ventilated can be managed with therapeutic hyperventilation. Hyperventilation leads to a reduction in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO_2) which leads to vasoconstriction with subsequent reduction in cerebral blood flow and fall in intracranial pressure. Current guidelines recommend titrating the respiratory rate to achieve a target pCO_2 of between 28–32 mm Hg.

answers.content: Increase the fraction of inhaled oxygen
answers.explanation_why: A pO_2 < 55 mmHg would increase the cerebral perfusion pressure and subsequently aggravate the existing cerebral edema in this patient. However, the pO_2 only plays an important role in cerebral perfusion regulation in cases of severe hypoxia, which this patient does not have evidence of (normal pulse oximetry findings). Increasing the inhaled oxygen concentration (e.g., FiO_2) would be unlikely to affect his ICP.

Increasing positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is a strategy used with mechanically ventilated patients to prevent end-expiratory alveolar collapse and improve oxygenation. However, increasing PEEP reduces venous return, including the venous return from the brain, and may be detrimental to this patient with cerebral edema. Increasing PEEP is commonly used to manage acute respiratory distress syndrome but is not recommended for cerebral edema.

Decreasing the heart rate is a management strategy that may be employed in certain clinical scenarios such as acute myocardial infarction or decompensated heart failure. However, the cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) depends primarily on the ICP and the mean arterial pressure (CPP = MAP – ICP); the heart rate does not play an important role unless it is affecting the mean arterial pressure. Furthermore, this patient already has a borderline low heart rate due to the Cushing reflex.

question_text: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of right-sided body weakness. His wife reports that he does not seem to understand simple questions. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. The patient speaks fluently, but he answers questions with nonsensical phrases and cannot repeat single words. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of right-sided body weakness. His wife reports that he does not seem to understand simple questions. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. The patient speaks fluently, but he answers questions with nonsensical phrases and cannot repeat single words. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Sudden onset of right-sided body weakness in conjunction with meaningless speech and impaired comprehension should raise concern for a cerebral lesion located in the posterior part of the left superior temporal gyrus (i.e., occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery).
learning_objective: Recognize Wernicke aphasia.

answers.explanation_why: Broca aphasia is caused by lesions in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere (e.g., due to an infarct in the superior division of the middle cerebral artery). In patients with Broca aphasia, language production is greatly affected, resulting in nonfluent, telegraphic, and grammatically incorrect speech, whereas this patient speaks fluently. Patients with Broca aphasia are aware of their impaired speech and can become frustrated during the physical examination, but this patient is unaware of his language deficits. Inability to repeat single words and impaired language comprehension are not typically seen in Broca aphasia.

Conduction aphasia is usually caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus. This type of aphasia is characterized by impaired repetition with fluent speech and intact comprehension. This patient has poor repetition with fluent speech but impaired comprehension.
Transcortical motor aphasia is characterized by nonfluent aphasia with good comprehension and intact repetition. This patient speaks fluently but has impaired comprehension and poor repetition.

Global aphasia is a neurologic insult that involves nonfluent aphasia and impaired comprehension. Global aphasia is usually caused by a large lesion affecting the Broca area, the Wernicke area, and the arcuate fasciculus. This patient has impaired comprehension and repetition but speaks fluently.

Wernicke aphasia is caused by lesions in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere, usually along the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) distribution. Patients with Wernicke aphasia typically present with impaired repetition and language comprehension; although they can speak fluently, they produce nonsensical phrases. Furthermore, these patients lack awareness of their impairment, as is the case here. In addition to Wernicke aphasia, signs of an MCA stroke include gaze deviation towards the side of the infarction and contralateral homonymous hemianopia without macular sparing.

See “Types of aphasia” table.

images.title: Types of Aphasia
images.description: The different types of aphasia can be divided by the presence of good or poor comprehension (red versus blue), good or poor repetition (top three versus bottom three), as well as nonfluent or fluent (light grey versus dark grey).

answers.explanation_why: Transcortical sensory aphasia is characterized by impaired comprehension with intact repetition and fluent speech. This patient has fluent speech with impaired comprehension, but his repetition is poor.

Anomic aphasia is a type of expressive aphasia characterized by word-finding difficulties, particularly in relation to nouns and verbs. Patients with anomic aphasia usually have fluent speech and intact comprehension. This patient speaks fluently but has impaired comprehension and poor repetition.

question_text: A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for shortness of breath and chest pain. Pulmonary angiography shows a large saddle embolus in the pulmonary arteries. Emergency drug therapy is administered and she is admitted to the hospital for observation. A follow-up CT scan of the chest shortly after admission shows that the thrombus has disappeared. Five hours later, the patient is found to be lethargic with slurred speech. Physical examination shows decreased consciousness, dysarthria, and optic disc swelling bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her neurological symptoms?
content_preview: A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for shortness of breath and chest pain. Pulmonary angiography shows a large saddle embolus in the pulmonary arteries. Emergency drug therapy is administered and she is admitted to the hospital for observation. A follow-up CT scan of the chest shortly after admission shows that the thrombus has disappeared. Five hours later, the patient is found to be lethargic with slurred speech. Physical examination shows decreased consciousness, dysarthria, and optic disc swelling bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her neurological symptoms?
hint: This patient has most likely been given a thrombolytic agent for a massive pulmonary embolism.
learning_objective: Recognize intracerebral hemorrhage as a complication of thrombolytic therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Acute metabolic encephalopathy may be caused by a wide range of factors (e.g., hypoxia, toxins, ischemia, medications) and is characterized by an acute change in mental status with waxing and waning level of alertness. However, affected patients typically do not present with focal neurological deficits like dysarthria. Furthermore, metabolic encephalopathy would not explain this patient's papilledema.

Internal carotid artery dissection occurs when the tunica media separates from the tunica intima of the carotid artery, creating a false lumen that can ultimately narrow or obstruct the true lumen. Affected patients may present with symptoms of ischemic stroke (e.g., slurred speech, dysarthria), but these symptoms are typically accompanied by some combination of headache, neck pain, amaurosis fugax, or pulsatile tinnitus, none of which are seen in this patient. The timing of symptom onset after receiving thrombolytic therapy makes a different etiology more likely.

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) or pseudotumor cerebri is a neurologic condition of unknown etiology that is characterized by chronically elevated intracranial pressure without evidence of hydrocephalus or a space-occupying lesion within the cranium. IIH could explain this patient's papilledema but would not explain this patient's acute neurological change.

Drug-induced hypotension may occur in some patients following thrombolytic therapy, especially with streptokinase, which can cause an anaphylactic reaction. Hypotension due to anaphylaxis can cause depressed mental status but an anaphylactic reaction would not explain this patient's slurred speech or papilledema.

Embolic cerebrovascular accidents can manifest with dysarthria and decreased mental status. They most often occur in patients with known atherosclerosis of the carotid arteries or patients with atrial fibrillation in which an atrial thrombus has formed. An arterial embolus to the brain resulting from a pulmonary artery clot is unlikely, as the embolus must first traverse the small capillary beds of the lungs or pass through a patent foramen ovale (paradoxical embolism) before entering systemic arterial circulation.

Intracerebral hemorrhage is a severe complication of thrombolytic therapy (e.g., alteplase, streptokinase), which this patient most likely received for her acute pulmonary embolism. While the thrombolysis adequately dissolved the thrombus, it resulted in hemorrhagic stroke and increased intracranial pressure, as evidenced by her change in mental status and papilledema. In scenarios such as this where intracranial hemorrhage is suspected, thrombolytic therapy should immediately be discontinued, an emergent CT scan of the brain performed, and neurosurgery and/or neurology consulted. Thrombolysis reversal agents (e.g., antifibrinolytics, FFPs, cryoprecipitate) may also be considered.

question_text: A 73-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter for evaluation of increasing forgetfulness during the past 6 months. The daughter reports that he recently got lost while walking home from the grocery store. He has also been more irritable recently. On mental status examination, he has a normal affect. He is oriented to person and place but cannot recall which month it is. He recalls memories from more than 20 years ago in great detail but cannot state his home address or the name of his recently born grandson. His gait is normal and there is no nystagmus. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the radiologic findings?
content_preview: A 73-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter for evaluation of increasing forgetfulness during the past 6 months. The daughter reports that he recently got lost while walking home from the grocery store. He has also been more irritable recently. On mental status examination, he has a normal affect. He is oriented to person and place but cannot recall which month it is. He recalls memories from more than 20 years ago in great detail but cannot state his home address or the name of his recently born grandson. His gait is normal and there is no nystagmus. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the radiologic findings?
hint: This elderly patient has progressively worsening memory loss (especially of recently formed memories), mood alterations, and disorientation, which are all suggestive of dementia. Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia in individuals aged > 65 years.
learning_objective: Recognize cortical atrophy associated with dementia.

answers.explanation_why: Inflammation of the choroid plexus (choroid plexitis), which is most commonly caused by CNS infection (e.g., tuberculosis, cryptococcosis) can result in increased CSF production and thereby cause lateral ventricle enlargement, as seen here on the T2 weighted MRI. However, this patient does not have any clinical features of CNS infection (e.g., fever, headache, meningism) and there is no enlargement of the choroid plexus in the lateral ventricles on imaging to suggest choroid plexitis.

Atrophy of the cortex of the brain (especially the medial temporal lobe structures) with narrowing of the gyri and widening of the sulci are characteristic neuroradiological findings in patients with Alzheimer disease. The ventricular dilation seen on imaging is a consequence of cerebral loss, with the ventricles expanding to fill the volume formerly occupied by the cortex. This phenomenon is known as hydrocephalus ex vacuo but unlike true hydrocephalus, there is no primary pathology of cerebrospinal fluid production or outflow in patients with Alzheimer disease. This patient's normal gait and lack of urinary symptoms are important in differentiating this presentation of Alzheimer disease from the classic presentation of hydrocephalus, given that the neuroimaging findings in both conditions are similar.

Demyelination of periventricular areas is seen in multiple sclerosis and Wernicke encephalopathy. Patients affected by either of these conditions can develop irreversible memory loss and personality changes, as seen here. However, the onset of memory loss and personality changes would be preceded by a history of fatigue and episodic neurological deficits in the case of multiple sclerosis, and the triad of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (due to mamillary body atrophy) in the case of Wernicke encephalopathy. Furthermore, the T2 weighted MRI of this patient does not show any evidence of periventricular demyelination.

Bleeding into the ventricular system can cause obstructive hydrocephalus and thereby result in ventricular enlargement, as seen here in the T2 weighted MRI. However, intraventricular hemorrhage usually manifests acutely with a severe headache and features of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., nausea, vomiting, blurred vision), unlike this patient who presents with cognitive impairment and mood changes that have progressively worsened over the past 6 months. Furthermore, there is no radiological evidence of an intraventricular hemorrhage on this patient's MRI (e.g., mixed fluid attenuation)

answers.content: Obstruction of the foramen of Monro
answers.explanation_why: Obstruction of the foramen of Monro, which is typically caused by a tumor (e.g., colloid cyst), would result in unilateral (asymmetrical) lateral ventricle enlargement, unlike this patient who has symmetrical enlargement of both the lateral ventricles on the T2 weighted MRI.

images.title: Hydrocephalus ex vacuo
images.description: Cranial MRI (T2-weighted, axial view)The butterfly-shaped lateral ventricles are symmetrically dilated and filled with CSF (green overlay). The cerebral gyri appear atrophic (example indicated by white asterisk) and the sulci are deep and prominent (example indicated by black arrow).These features are characteristic of hydrocephalus ex vacuo, a condition in which the ventricles dilate due to brain parenchymal atrophy and CSF fills the void.

question_text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He does not open his eyes on command or respond to verbal cues. A CT scan of the head shows a hyperdense fluid collection in the right medial temporal lobe with medial displacement of the uncus and parahippocampal gyrus of the temporal lobe. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely to be injured as a result of this patient's lesion?
content_preview: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He does not open his eyes on command or respond to verbal cues. A CT scan of the head shows a hyperdense fluid collection in the right medial temporal lobe with medial displacement of the uncus and parahippocampal gyrus of the temporal lobe. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely to be injured as a result of this patient's lesion?
hint: The findings from this patient's radiological imaging indicate a transtentorial uncal herniation.
learning_objective: Recognize transtentorial uncal herniation, and recall the cranial nerve most likely to be injured.

answers.explanation_why: The facial nerve (CN VII) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VII is in close proximity to the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and it can be injured by bleeds or aneurysms of this vessel.

The vagus nerve (CN X) exits the brainstem at the medulla, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN X can be injured by direct neck trauma. Injury to this nerve can also occur because of compression by an aortic aneurysm.

The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VIII is in close proximity to the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and it can be injured by bleeds or aneurysms of this vessel.

The abducens nerve (CN VI) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VI is local to the basilar artery, and it can be injured by a basilar artery aneurysm.

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is most likely to be injured by uncal herniation, which manifests with an abducted and depressed ipsilateral eye (due to damage to motor fibers that innervate most of the extraocular eye muscles) with a fixed, dilated pupil (due to damage to parasympathetic fibers). Other features of uncal herniation include cortical blindness with contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing due to compression of the posterior cerebral artery, and Kernohan phenomenon due to compression of the contralateral cerebral peduncle. A downward shift of the brainstem causes hemorrhages and compression of the reticular formation, which can lead to impaired consciousness and, ultimately, death.

A CN III injury can also be caused by an aneurysm or bleed of the posterior communicating artery or posterior cerebral artery, both of which are in close proximity to this nerve.

images.title: Brain herniation
images.description: Brain herniations occur as a result of increased intracranial pressure, such as that caused by subdural hematomas. Variations include herniation of brain tissue under the falx cerebri (1), below the tentorium cerebelli (2, 3), downwards through the foramen magnum (4), above the tentorium cerebelli (5), or outside of the skull (6).

answers.explanation_why: The trigeminal nerve (CN V) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN V can be injured by a lateral pontine lesion. Injury to this nerve can also occur because of compression by a superior cerebellar artery aneurysm.

question_text: A previously healthy 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a progressively worsening headache for 5 days. She vomited twice after waking up this morning. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tearing of the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; right lateral gaze is limited. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An MR venography of the head shows a heterogeneous intensity in the left lateral sinus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A previously healthy 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a progressively worsening headache for 5 days. She vomited twice after waking up this morning. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tearing of the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; right lateral gaze is limited. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An MR venography of the head shows a heterogeneous intensity in the left lateral sinus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's progressive worsening headache, chemosis, cranial nerve VI palsy (impaired right-sided lateral gaze), increased intracranial pressure (evidenced by headache and bilateral papilledema), and the occlusive lesion in a cerebral sinus on imaging indicate cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT).
learning_objective: Recognize cerebral venous thrombosis, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why:
Administration of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), such as dalteparin, is the most appropriate next step in the management of a patient with acute (aseptic) CVT because LMWH prevents the formation of a new clot while allowing the body to dissolve the existing thrombus. The typical duration is two weeks, after which treatment is switched to an extended duration oral anticoagulant (e.g., warfarin). The specific agent and exact duration of treatment, however, are variable as no consensus guidelines exist to guide this therapy. In the rare event of progressive neurological compromise despite adequate anticoagulation, local thrombolysis may also be required.

Risk factors for CVT include oral contraceptive use (as seen here), pregnancy, coagulation disorders, and malignancy.

Measuring D-dimer levels is useful in the workup of any thrombosis. In patients who present with headache, vomiting, bilateral optic disc swelling on ophthalmoscopy or cranial nerve palsies, elevated D-dimer levels can support the diagnosis of CVT. However, MR imaging has already confirmed the diagnosis of CVT in this patient, and, accordingly, measurement of D-dimers would not provide any more useful information.

Endovascular thrombolysis is a procedure used to restore blood supply in emergency cases of CVT. This intervention may be necessary for patients with significant symptoms (e.g., coma, altered mental status) who do not respond to medical therapy or for whom medical therapy is contraindicated. A different step should be performed before endovascular intervention or surgery is considered.

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is an important part of the diagnostic approach to several conditions that can affect the brain and spine, including meningitis, which should be considered in a patient with headache, vomiting, and signs of neurological dysfunction. However, the absence of fever and neck stiffness in this patient makes meningitis unlikely. Therefore, CSF analysis would not be helpful diagnostically.

Treatment with intravenous antibiotics is indicated in the treatment of infectious cerebral venous thrombosis, a possible complication of a local (e.g., otogenic, rhinogenic, facial) or meningeal infection. This patient presents with neither history nor clinical signs of infection.

Surgical clipping of a cerebral aneurysm can be performed to treat acute aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). This patient presents with characteristic features of SAH, which include a headache, nausea/vomiting, and cranial nerve palsies. However, symptoms of SAH typically develop more acutely (“thunderclap headache”). In addition, MR imaging in a patient with SAH would show intracranial bleeding. Angiography would show a cerebral aneurysm. This patient's MR venography, however, shows occlusion of the left lateral sinus.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of headaches for the past 2 weeks. His headaches tend to occur in the morning and are associated with nausea and vomiting. One month ago, the patient was admitted to the hospital because of fever, irritability, and neck rigidity, and he was successfully treated with antibiotics. His temperature today is 37.5°C (98.5°F). An MRI of the brain shows bilateral ventricular enlargement and enlargement of the subarachnoid space. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient's condition?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of headaches for the past 2 weeks. His headaches tend to occur in the morning and are associated with nausea and vomiting. One month ago, the patient was admitted to the hospital because of fever, irritability, and neck rigidity, and he was successfully treated with antibiotics. His temperature today is 37.5°C (98.5°F). An MRI of the brain shows bilateral ventricular enlargement and enlargement of the subarachnoid space. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient's condition?
hint: The combination of fever, irritability, and neck rigidity is characteristic of meningitis. This patient's current symptoms and MRI findings indicate communicating hydrocephalus, which can be a complication of meningitis.
learning_objective: Recognize communicating hydrocephalus, and recall its association with meningitis complications.

answers.content: Increased CSF production by the choroid plexus
answers.explanation_why: Increased CSF production by the choroid plexus is seen in choroid plexus papilloma, a rare benign pediatric tumor that can manifest with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, vomiting) as well as enlargement of both the ventricular and subarachnoid spaces (communicating hydrocephalus). However, a history of fever and neck rigidity would not be expected with a choroid plexus papilloma, and the MRI would also show a well-defined, intraventricular, lobulated mass that enhances brilliantly because of its high vascularization.

answers.content: Impaired CSF flow through the arachnoid granulations
answers.explanation_why: CSF drains from the 4^th ventricle into the subarachnoid space and from the subarachnoid space into dural venous sinuses via arachnoid granulations. The blockage of arachnoid granulations by degenerating neutrophils and proliferating fibroblasts (i.e., arachnoid scarring) is a complication of bacterial meningitis. This blockage results in the accumulation of CSF in the subarachnoid space and the ventricular spaces, the subsequent symmetric enlargement of the entire ventricular system (communicating hydrocephalus), and features of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., early-morning headaches, nausea, vomiting). Communicating hydrocephalus can also be a complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

images.title: Cross-section of skull and meninges
images.description:
From the outside in:
1. Scalp
2. Periosteum
3. Skull
4. Dura mater
5. Arachnoid mater
6. Pia materDiploic veins lie within the inner and outer tables of the skull. Dural venous sinuses lie between the inner and outer layers of the dura mater and are connected to the extracranial veins by emissary veins. Falx cerebri (as well as the falx cerebelli and tentorium cerebelli not shown in this image) are extensions of the dura mater. Arachnoid trabeculae are strands of delicate connective tissue that extend between the arachnoid and pia mater. Arachnoid granulations (villi) are finger-like projections of the arachnoid mater that invaginate into the dural venous sinuses.

answers.content: Impaired CSF drainage into the subarachnoid space
answers.explanation_why: Drainage of CSF into the subarachnoid space would be impaired upon blockage of the median foramen of Magendie or the lateral foramina of Luschka, which connect the 4^th ventricle with the subarachnoid space. This blockage can occur as a complication of bacterial meningitis and lead to bilateral ventricular enlargement, as seen here. However, obstructive hydrocephalus only causes dilation of the ventricles upstream of the obstruction, which is why the subarachnoid space would not be enlarged in this case. Enlargement of the subarachnoid space in this patient suggests a different pathological process.

images.title: Ventricular system of the brain
images.description: Within the brain, there are several interconnected CSF-filled spaces (ventricles). The largest of these are the lateral ventricles (first and second ventricles), which are located within the cerebral hemispheres. The third ventricle lies in the diencephalon, between the two thalamic hemispheres, and has several recesses. The fourth ventricle is located in the rhomboid fossa (dorsal to the pons/medulla oblongata). The lateral ventricles are connected to the third ventricle via the interventricular foramina. The third ventricle is connected to the fourth ventricle by the cerebral aqueduct. The fourth ventricle also connects the ventricular system to the subarachnoid space (which is also filled with CSF) via several openings (e.g., the median aperture).

answers.content: Impaired CSF drainage into the fourth ventricle
answers.explanation_why: Impaired CSF drainage from the 3^rd ventricle into the 4^th ventricle is caused by obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, which can occur as a complication of bacterial meningitis and lead to bilateral ventricular enlargement, as seen here. However, obstructive hydrocephalus only causes dilation of the ventricles upstream of the obstruction, so the subarachnoid space would not be enlarged due to aqueductal stenosis. Enlargement of the subarachnoid space in this patient suggests a different pathological process.

images.title: Noncommunicating hydrocephalus
images.description:
Cranial CT (axial view) of a 13-year-old boyA large, liquor-like, hypodense lesion (red area) is located in the posterior cranial fossa in images 1–3. This lesion is most likely an arachnoid cyst compressing the cerebral aqueduct (A), which prevents the free circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the ventricles to the subarachnoid space. As a result, the third ventricle (III) and the lateral ventricles (hatched area) are dilated, and there is transependymal egress of CSF (green shaded area, images 4 and 5).

C = cistern of great cerebral vein
T = inferior horn of the lateral ventricle

answers.explanation_why: Compensatory enlargement of CSF spaces, which is seen in hydrocephalus ex vacuo, occurs secondary to loss of brain volume in neurodegenerative diseases or stroke. An MRI would show biventricular enlargement and enlargement of the subarachnoid space, as seen here. However, hydrocephalus ex vacuo does not cause any symptoms because it does not affect intracerebral pressure, and it is not typically seen in children.

question_text: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for a 4-month history of increasing difficulty recognizing her friends and family. She has had to rely on recognizing haircuts, gait, and voices because she cannot remember their faces. Neurologic examination shows that she is able to recognize objects and name facial features such as the eyes and nose. On mental status examination, she is alert and has no deficits in cognition or short-term memory. An MRI of her head shows an inhomogenous 2-cm mass with perifocal edema in her brain. Which of the following brain regions is most likely affected?
content_preview: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for a 4-month history of increasing difficulty recognizing her friends and family. She has had to rely on recognizing haircuts, gait, and voices because she cannot remember their faces. Neurologic examination shows that she is able to recognize objects and name facial features such as the eyes and nose. On mental status examination, she is alert and has no deficits in cognition or short-term memory. An MRI of her head shows an inhomogenous 2-cm mass with perifocal edema in her brain. Which of the following brain regions is most likely affected?
hint: This patient presents with prosopagnosia, which is characterized by an inability to recognize familiar faces. The brain region that is typically affected in this condition is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.
learning_objective: Recognize prosopagnosia, and recall the brain region typically affected.

answers.explanation_why: A left posterior parietal cortex lesion in a right-handed patient would manifest with features of Gerstmann syndrome (e.g., agraphia without alexia, acalculia, finger agnosia, right-left disorientation). A similar lesion in a left-handed patient would manifest with constructional apraxia and/or spatial hemineglect. This patient presents with prosopagnosia, which is not a typical feature of parietal cortex lesions.

A right posterior superior temporal cortex lesion would manifest with left upper quadrantanopia, a visual field defect caused by damage to the Meyer loop. A lesion in this location can also cause aprosodia in right-handed patients and Wernicke aphasia in left-handed patients. This patient presents with prosopagnosia, which is not a feature of posterior superior temporal cortex lesions.

images.title: Lateral view of important areas of the brain
images.description: The primary motor cortex, in the frontal lobe, is the origin of the fibers of the pyramidal tract.The primary and secondary auditory cortices, where auditory input is processed, are located in the temporal lobe. The primary visual cortex is located at the occipital pole and is surrounded by the secondary visual cortex.Different functions converge at association areas. The most well-known examples are the motor (Broca) and sensory (Wernicke) areas of speech, which are commonly located in the dominant hemisphere.

answers.explanation_why: Lesions in the hippocampus may cause anterograde amnesia, which can manifest with the inability to recognize faces of recently acquainted people. However, this patient has difficulty remembering familiar faces (friends and family), and she does not present with any other memory impairments.

The superior region of the parietal cortex contains the somatosensory association cortex and a section of the primary somatosensory cortex. A lesion in the right superior parietal cortex would manifest with left-sided astereognosis, apraxia, and possibly left-sided sensory deficits, none of which are seen here.

images.title: Lateral view of important areas of the brain
images.description: The primary motor cortex, in the frontal lobe, is the origin of the fibers of the pyramidal tract.The primary and secondary auditory cortices, where auditory input is processed, are located in the temporal lobe. The primary visual cortex is located at the occipital pole and is surrounded by the secondary visual cortex.Different functions converge at association areas. The most well-known examples are the motor (Broca) and sensory (Wernicke) areas of speech, which are commonly located in the dominant hemisphere.

answers.explanation_why: Prosopagnosia is caused by bilateral lesions or large unilateral (typically right-sided) lesions (e.g., brain tumors) in the ventral occipitotemporal cortex, which includes parts of the secondary visual cortex as well as parts of the temporal lobe. Individuals with prosopagnosia are able to visually perceive faces because the pathway to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe is still intact, but they have lost the ability to process the image properly. Affected individuals retain their ability to name parts of the face (e.g., nose, mouth) and are typically able to identify individuals by other cues (e.g., clothing, voice).

images.title: Lateral view of the cerebral lobes
images.description:
The 4 lobes of each cerebral hemisphere are separated by 3 main sulci:
–The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe.
–The lateral sulcus separates the temporal lobe from the frontal lobe and the parietal lobe.
–The parieto-occipital sulcus separates the parietal lobe from the occipital lobe.

question_text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient with a brain tumor, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of headaches and vomiting over the past week. He also has a 2-day history of blurry vision. His uncle died from colorectal cancer, and his older brother has multiple colonic polyps. The patient is alert and oriented. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weakness of the lower extremities and a broad-based gait. An MRI of the brain shows mild hydrocephalus and a contrast-enhancing intraparenchymal mass in the cerebellar vermis.
content_preview: The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set. For each patient with a brain tumor, select the most likely diagnosis. A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of headaches and vomiting over the past week. He also has a 2-day history of blurry vision. His uncle died from colorectal cancer, and his older brother has multiple colonic polyps. The patient is alert and oriented. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weakness of the lower extremities and a broad-based gait. An MRI of the brain shows mild hydrocephalus and a contrast-enhancing intraparenchymal mass in the cerebellar vermis.
hint: This patient most likely has a primitive neuroectodermal tumor.
learning_objective: Distinguish medulloblastoma from other types of brain tumors.

answers.explanation_why: Anaplastic astrocytomas are rare, malignant brain tumors that can cause headaches, nausea, and focal neurologic deficits. However, these tumors most commonly develop in adults (usually between 30–40 years of age), not in children. In addition, though they can appear on MRI as contrast-enhancing masses, they rarely cause hydrocephalus because they are typically located in the cerebral hemispheres, not the cerebellar vermis.

images.title: Low-grade glioma
images.description: MRI head (top left: T1-weighted, axial plane; top right: T2-weighted, axial plane; bottom left: T1-weighted, with contrast, axial plane; bottom right: T1-weighted, with contrast, coronal plane)There is a large, well-defined mass in the right frontal lobe (green overlay), which demonstrates hypointense signal on the T1-weighted images and hyperintense signal on T2-weighting with no significant surrounding edema. No significant enhancement is demonstrated on the post-contrast sequences.

answers.explanation_why: Oligodendrogliomas are slow-growing tumors that can cause headaches, nausea, and focal neurologic deficits. However, these tumors most commonly develop in adults (usually between 40–50 years of age), not in children. In addition, they typically appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense lesions in the cerebral hemispheres that show areas of calcification, not contrast-enhancing intraparenchymal masses in the cerebellar vermis.

images.title: Oligodendroglioma
images.description: Cranial CT scan (axial view)A large hypodense lesion (green overlay) with multiple intralesional hyperdense calcifications (yellow overlay) is visible in the temporal lobe.

answers.explanation_why: Hemangioblastomas are rare, benign, slow-growing, highly-vascularized tumors that can cause headaches and nausea. However, these tumors most commonly develop in adults (usually between 20–50 years of age), not in children. In addition, they typically appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense, nodular lesions with cystic components in the cerebellum or brainstem, not contrast-enhancing intraparenchymal masses in the cerebellar vermis.

images.title: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
images.description: MRI head (with contrast; axial view)A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Medulloblastomas are the most common malignant brain tumors in children (peak incidence at 3–5 years of age). These tumors often develop near the cerebellar midline and can, therefore, cause manifestations of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, papilledema). Treatment usually consists of resection and chemotherapy (combined with radiotherapy in children ≥ 3 years of age). This patient's family history is suggestive of a diagnosis of Turcot syndrome, a rare inherited disorder characterized by the combination of primary brain tumors and colorectal cancer or polyposis.

images.title: Pediatric fourth ventricular tumor
images.description: MRI Head (T2-weighted; axial view) of a 7-year-old boyThere is a lobulated heterogeneous posterior fossa mass (green overlay) present in the midline of the cerebellum at the level of the fourth ventricle. The fourth ventricle is obscured by the mass and is, therefore, not well seen in this image.This is a medulloblastoma, the most common malignant pediatric tumor of the central nervous system. Medulloblastomas most commonly involve the cerebellar vermis, the structure that connects the two cerebellar hemispheres. In the pediatric population, other tumors that commonly occur in similar locations include brainstem glioma, ependymoma, choroid plexus papilloma, atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor, and astrocytoma. All of these should be considered in this case, although a brainstem glioma would rather be located predominantly within the brainstem rather than the vermis and is, therefore, less likely.Arrowhead: basilar artery; C: cerebellum

answers.explanation_why: Ependymomas of the brain are benign tumors that most commonly occur in early childhood and can cause hydrocephalus. However, they typically develop in the 4^th ventricle, rather than in the cerebellar vermis. In addition, ependymomas can vary in appearance on MRI but often show necrosis, cystic changes, hemorrhage, and calcifications.

images.title: Ependymoma
images.description: MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.

answers.explanation_why: Schwannomas are slow-growing tumors that can cause headaches and nausea. However, these tumors are most commonly located near the cerebellopontine angle, not in the cerebellar vermis. In addition, these tumors often cause tinnitus, hearing loss, dizziness, and/or disequilibrium from cranial nerve VIII compression. Moreover, the median age of patients with schwannoma is 50 years; it is very uncommon in children.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Glioblastoma multiforme is a very aggressive tumor that can cause headaches and nausea. However, these tumors most commonly develop in adults (usually between 65–75 years of age), not in children. In addition, they typically appear on MRI as ring-enhancing masses in the cerebral hemispheres (potentially crossing the midline), not in the cerebellar vermis.

images.title: Bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma)
images.description: T1-weighted contrast-enhanced MRI, frontal view: bihemisphere garland-like contrast enhancement. There is peripheral contrast agent enhancement (blue overlay) with central necrosis (green overlay). The third ventricle (arrowhead) is centrally located. The tumor is displacing the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle (red overlay). Diagnosis: bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma).

answers.explanation_why: Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors that can cause headaches and nausea. Though these tumors are the most common primary central nervous system tumors in adults (with a peak incidence in the sixth decade of life), they are rarely found in children. In addition, because they derive from the dura, they cannot develop in the cerebellar vermis.

images.title: Dural based mass
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

answers.explanation_why: Craniopharyngiomas are brain tumors that have a bimodal distribution of age (children 5–14 years of age and adults 50–75 years of age). These tumors can cause headaches and nausea due to obstructive hydrocephalus and traction on surrounding structures. They can also cause visual symptoms (typically bitemporal hemianopsia from compression of the optic chiasm). However, craniopharyngiomas often cause other symptoms, including hyperprolactinemia, delayed growth, and central diabetes insipidus (from compression of the anterior or posterior pituitary gland). In addition, they often show calcifications and cysts on MRI.

images.title: Tumor at the base of the skull
images.description: MRI of the brain (T1-weighted; sagittal view; with contrast)A hyperintense, ovoid, sharply demarcated lesion (green overlay) is visible within the sella turcica and partially extends into the sphenoidal sinus.The location and appearance of the lesion suggest a craniopharyngioma or a pituitary adenoma.

answers.explanation_why: Colorectal cancer that metastasizes to the brain can cause headaches, nausea, and visual deficits. Risk factors for colorectal cancer include a family history of colorectal cancer and polyps, which are suggestive of an inherited cancer syndrome. However, colorectal cancer typically initially manifests with abdominal symptoms (e.g., gastrointestinal bleeding) and only metastasizes late in the disease course. In addition, brain metastases typically manifest on MRI as multiple, circumscribed lesions with perifocal edema, not a single intraparenchymal mass.

Optic gliomas are low-grade, astrocytic tumors that most commonly occur in early childhood (90% before 10 years of age) and can cause visual impairment and manifestations of increased intracranial pressure. However, they typically develop in the optic nerve and/or chiasm, not in the cerebellar vermis.

images.title: Intraconal orbital mass
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)There is a large hyperintense mass (green overlay) in the left intraconal space displacing the ocular globe out of the orbital cavity (exophthalmos). The intraconal space is located posterior to the globe and contained within the cone formed by the recti muscles. The mass is well-defined and displaces rather than invades surrounding structures. The left optic nerve is not visualized on this image, and the mass either arises from it or displaces it. The normal-appearing right optic nerve (red overlay) is well visualized.The differential diagnosis for intraconal masses depends on whether or not the lesion is continuous with the optic nerve. Differential diagnoses for masses involving the optic nerve include, but are not limited to, meningioma, glioma, and lymphoma. Differential diagnoses for masses not involving the nerve include, but are not limited to, hemangioma, schwannoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma.

answers.explanation_why: Pinealomas are rare brain tumors of childhood that can cause manifestations of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, papilledema) due to obstructive hydrocephalus. However, these tumors develop in the pineal region, not in the cerebellar vermis, and typically have a cystic appearance on MRI.

question_text:
For each patient with a brain tumor, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 30 minutes after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He has had recurrent headaches for the past 2 months and a 3-year history of progressive hearing difficulties in both ears. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. He takes flax seeds daily for constipation. He appears drowsy and is oriented to person and place only. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 145/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a laceration on the tongue. An MRI of the brain shows an infiltrative lesion that expands into both hemispheres with associated irregular rim enhancement, perifocal edema, and central necrosis.
content_preview: For each patient with a brain tumor, select the most likely diagnosis. A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 30 minutes after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He has had recurrent headaches for the past 2 months and a 3-year history of progressive hearing difficulties in both ears. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. He takes flax seeds daily for constipation. He appears drowsy and is oriented to person and place only. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 145/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a laceration on the tongue. An MRI of the brain shows an infiltrative lesion that expands into both hemispheres with associated irregular rim enhancement, perifocal edema, and central necrosis.
hint: A biopsy specimen of this patient's tumor will most likely stain positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein.
learning_objective: Distinguish glioblastoma multiforme from other types of brain tumors.

answers.explanation_why: Anaplastic astrocytomas are rare, malignant brain tumors that most commonly develop in adults (usually between 30–40 years of age) and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. These tumors most commonly develop in the cerebral hemispheres. However, they typically appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense lesions without central necrosis.

images.title: Low-grade glioma
images.description: MRI head (top left: T1-weighted, axial plane; top right: T2-weighted, axial plane; bottom left: T1-weighted, with contrast, axial plane; bottom right: T1-weighted, with contrast, coronal plane)There is a large, well-defined mass in the right frontal lobe (green overlay), which demonstrates hypointense signal on the T1-weighted images and hyperintense signal on T2-weighting with no significant surrounding edema. No significant enhancement is demonstrated on the post-contrast sequences.

answers.explanation_why: Oligodendrogliomas are slow-growing tumors that most commonly develop in adults (usually between 40–50 years of age) and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. These tumors most commonly develop in the cerebral hemispheres. However, they typically appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense lesions that show areas of calcification.

images.title: Oligodendroglioma
images.description: Cranial CT scan (axial view)A large hypodense lesion (green overlay) with multiple intralesional hyperdense calcifications (yellow overlay) is visible in the temporal lobe.

answers.explanation_why: Hemangioblastomas are rare, benign, slow-growing, highly-vascularized tumors that most commonly develop in adults (usually between 20–50 years of age) and can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, they typically appear on MRI as T2-hyperintense, nodular lesions with cystic components in the cerebellum or brainstem.

images.title: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
images.description: MRI head (with contrast; axial view)A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Medulloblastomas can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, these tumors are more common in children (peak incidence at 3–5 years of age) and typically develop near the cerebellar midline. In addition, they typically appear on MRI as diffusely-enhancing lesions that can show calcifications.

images.title: Pediatric fourth ventricular tumor
images.description: MRI Head (T2-weighted; axial view) of a 7-year-old boyThere is a lobulated heterogeneous posterior fossa mass (green overlay) present in the midline of the cerebellum at the level of the fourth ventricle. The fourth ventricle is obscured by the mass and is, therefore, not well seen in this image.This is a medulloblastoma, the most common malignant pediatric tumor of the central nervous system. Medulloblastomas most commonly involve the cerebellar vermis, the structure that connects the two cerebellar hemispheres. In the pediatric population, other tumors that commonly occur in similar locations include brainstem glioma, ependymoma, choroid plexus papilloma, atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor, and astrocytoma. All of these should be considered in this case, although a brainstem glioma would rather be located predominantly within the brainstem rather than the vermis and is, therefore, less likely.Arrowhead: basilar artery; C: cerebellum

answers.explanation_why: Ependymomas of the brain are benign tumors that can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. However, these tumors are more common in children and typically develop in the 4^th ventricle. In addition, though ependymomas can show necrosis on MRI, they typically also have cystic changes, hemorrhage, and calcifications.

images.title: Ependymoma
images.description: MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.

answers.explanation_why: Schwannomas are slow-growing tumors that most commonly affect adults (median age of 50 years) and can cause altered mental status, headaches, and hearing loss. However, hearing loss associated with schwannomas is typically unilateral, and these tumors do not typically cause seizures. In addition, these tumors most commonly appear on MRI as a single, contrast-enhancing lesion near the cerebellopontine angle.

images.title: Vestibularis schwannoma (acoustic neuroma)
images.description:
Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

answers.explanation_why: Glioblastoma multiforme is a very aggressive tumor of adulthood (peak incidence of 60–70 years of age) that can manifest with altered mental status, seizures, headaches, and focal neurologic deficits. On MRI, they classically appear as ring-enhancing masses (due to central necrosis) with perifocal edema. Glioblastomas are typically located in the cerebral white matter (e.g., left temporal lobe), although they can cross the midline (butterfly glioma). This condition has a poor prognosis with a median survival time of ∼ 1 year.

images.title: Bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma)
images.description: T1-weighted contrast-enhanced MRI, frontal view: bihemisphere garland-like contrast enhancement. There is peripheral contrast agent enhancement (blue overlay) with central necrosis (green overlay). The third ventricle (arrowhead) is centrally located. The tumor is displacing the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle (red overlay). Diagnosis: bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma).

answers.explanation_why: Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors that can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. Though these tumors are the most common primary central nervous system tumors in adults (with a peak incidence in the sixth decade of life), they typically appear on MRI as homogeneous, enhancing masses that arise from the dura with no associated necrosis or rim enhancement.

images.title: Dural based mass
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

answers.explanation_why: Craniopharyngiomas are brain tumors that have a bimodal distribution of age (children 5–14 years of age and adults 50–75 years of age). These tumors can cause altered mental status and headaches due to obstructive hydrocephalus and traction on surrounding structures but do not typically cause seizures. In addition, they often cause other symptoms, including hyperprolactinemia and central diabetes insipidus (from compression of the anterior or posterior pituitary gland), none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, they often show calcifications and cysts on MRI.

images.title: Tumor at the base of the skull
images.description: MRI of the brain (T1-weighted; sagittal view; with contrast)A hyperintense, ovoid, sharply demarcated lesion (green overlay) is visible within the sella turcica and partially extends into the sphenoidal sinus.The location and appearance of the lesion suggest a craniopharyngioma or a pituitary adenoma.

answers.explanation_why: Colorectal cancer that metastasizes to the brain can cause altered mental status, seizures, and headaches. Risk factors for colorectal cancer include smoking and chronic constipation. However, colorectal cancer typically initially manifests with abdominal symptoms (e.g., gastrointestinal bleeding) and only metastasizes late in the disease course. In addition, brain metastases typically manifest on MRI as multiple, circumscribed lesions with perifocal edema, not a single mass.

Optic gliomas are low-grade, astrocytic tumors that can cause headaches. However, they do not typically cause seizures. In addition, they often result in visual impairment due to involvement of the optic nerve and/or chiasm, which is not seen in this patient. Moreover, optic gliomas most commonly occur in early childhood (90% before 10 years of age).

images.title: Intraconal orbital mass
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)There is a large hyperintense mass (green overlay) in the left intraconal space displacing the ocular globe out of the orbital cavity (exophthalmos). The intraconal space is located posterior to the globe and contained within the cone formed by the recti muscles. The mass is well-defined and displaces rather than invades surrounding structures. The left optic nerve is not visualized on this image, and the mass either arises from it or displaces it. The normal-appearing right optic nerve (red overlay) is well visualized.The differential diagnosis for intraconal masses depends on whether or not the lesion is continuous with the optic nerve. Differential diagnoses for masses involving the optic nerve include, but are not limited to, meningioma, glioma, and lymphoma. Differential diagnoses for masses not involving the nerve include, but are not limited to, hemangioma, schwannoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma.

answers.explanation_why: Pinealomas are rare brain tumors that can cause headaches. However, they usually develop in children, not adults, and do not typically cause seizures. In addition, these tumors develop in the pineal region and typically have a cystic appearance on MRI.
